text: THREE DAYS TO DEAD's deck is stacked with tons of paranormal content, a funky 'work backwards' story telling style, and a tough as nails protagonist. I loved Evy; this girl has been lived through pretty much every crappy scenario you can dream up, and then some, yet she keeps her eye on the prize. Meding's DREG CITY world is vast, and exciting without being overpowering, and the urgency of Stone's situation comes through loud & clear thanks to the author writing the heroine's flashbacks in the present tense. I was iffy on the narrator for the better part of this audiobook, but I enjoyed it enough to continue listening to the series.

The ALPHA GIRL series, and I have had our ups & downs; I was worried that this magic driven installment might feel out of place amidst Aileen Erin’s werewolves, and that postponing Tessa & Dastien’s full moon ceremony (again) in favour of giving a secondary character their HEA was a mistake. BRUJA proved me wrong on both counts. Lucas single-handedly solved my first concern, and Claudia did the rest.I liked that the author waited a bit before hightailing it to Peru. She set the stage for the why of De Santos’ trip with a brief recap, and some new information which did wonders for my opinion of this book’s protagonist because she didn’t blindly accept Muraco’s wild goose chase of a quest. The story did lack Peruvian authenticity though, so the setting change was barely noticeable unfortunately.Claudia has been a useful ally in the witches vs. werewolves war, and after three volumes as a sidekick it was time for her to step outside of her comfort zone. I enjoyed witnessing her transformation from one of Luciana’s minions to future leader of the rebel coven. Her internal monologue exhibited the most growth, but by the conclusion of this tale it was apparent that Claudia was no longer a protégé.There seemed to be a bit of a love triangle emerging until Erin finished painting her ugly picture of Matt, De Santos’ betrothed, after that unpleasantness he was hastily taken off the menu. The heroine’s connection with Mr. July was impossible to miss, as were the not so subtle furry bits. The outcome was easy to predict, although admittedly the shortage of romantic drama only made the plot stronger.BRUJA was a quaint witch-y dalliance, but I’m ready for more werewolves!

I stumbled upon this novel while visiting a blog, and I have 0 willpower vis-à-vis wolves, so the LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD retelling aspect intrigued me, and honestly, who could say no to that cover!? Rosamund Hodge dazzled me with her creativity, writing, and whimsy, although I did find the story rather busy because as a stand-alone a lot needed to be packed into one volume. I could have done without the love triangle, and the Devourer’s defeat at the hands of a knitting needle set a new record for the lamest killing tool in all of Fantasy.The author’s world-building and lore were the highlights of CRIMSON BOUND. I enjoyed untangling the unknowns of Rachelle’s universe, and what it meant to be a woodwife, bloodbound and forestborn. There were flashbacks of how Zisa & Tyr held the Great Forest at bay the first time as well as several different versions of their legendary triumph which is where the riddle of Joyeuse & Durendal—the two swords capable of slaying the Big Bad Wolf—originated. It was quite exquisite how all of the fragments came together, and many of the characters had poker faces that would fool their own mothers.The Rachelle / Erec / Armand romance was completely unnecessary, and gave me the impression that it was included simply because a book can’t truly be considered Young Adult without a triangle which is so not true by the way. The heroine seemingly realized that she loved two guys overnight, and both were kooky choices. I liked d’Anjou & Vareilles as individuals, but as suitors neither really lit my fire. One was evil while as the other was a saint which made the options too radical for my tastes; I’m a boy next door kind of girl, however perhaps fans of the good/bad trope will be ok with it.The threads coalesced nicely as the story came to a close, and there were plenty of surprises that made me say “Ooh!” The barriers that Rachelle had to surmount were varied, and came from within as well as without. After the protagonist’s two part stand-off with the lindenworm; I was salivating in anticipation of the bloodshed that would surely ensue when she faced the Devourer. I’ll admit that it was clever, although after a novel-long search for a sword, I would have preferred an epic battle that ended with decapitation or evisceration as opposed to the tidy reality of Hodge’s conclusion. It was too easy.CRIMSON BOUND had big teeth, but its bite was a kinda weak; recommended with reservations. ~ 3.5 stars

This is the second time in as many years that I’ve had to bid adieu to one of Jenn Bennett’s series, and I really hate goodbyes. GRAVE PHANTOMS had a different vibe to it than the two previous installments because the final Magnusson sibling is younger, female, and the romance had a friends turned lovers spin to it. The plot wasn’t quite as strong as books 1 & 2 with somewhat choppy writing, and a discernible separation between Astrid & Bo’s relationship, and the ghost yacht story line rather than a blended narrative.To an outsider, the Roaring Twenties era appears to be a fun adventure, that is if you’re a white American, however for people like Yeung, it’s anything but. I liked how the author succeeded in capturing the prejudice of this period, and how it added a level of taboo-ness to the love story. Witnessing the general population’s treatment of Bo, and immigrants as a whole, through his eyes as well as via Astrid, someone who cares deeply for him, was humanizing, and I thought that the two characters’ reactions were very genuine.I loved how madly independent both of the protagonists were; Miss Magnusson with her refusal to live in her brothers’ shadow, and Yeung’s unwillingness to accept hand-outs. It was great seeing these two finally take steps towards achieving their happily-ever-after, and strangely it wasn’t their moving reunion that caused me to reach for a tissue, although that too was a close call. Instead, it was Bo’s heart-to-heart with Winter; his second-in-command envisioned the worst when he declared his intentions, but family by choice is no small thing.The artefact decoding facet of this tale was in a lot of ways similar to GRIM SHADOWS; however it wasn’t quite as detailed as Lowe’s novel, or as entertaining. Pirates aboard a ghost yacht sound exciting, and yet the parts didn’t fit as cleanly together as they could have which made Bennett’s last hurrah rather tame in comparison to ROARING TWENTIES # 1 & 2. I wish that the epilogue had been slightly longer, and had encompassed all of the Magnusson clan to a larger extent as opposed to being mostly about Astrid & Bo.GRAVE PHANTOMS was a fitting conclusion to this trilogy.

I was drawn to the demon summoning aspect of this series because of its uniqueness within the Paranormal genre, and I also never miss an installment of Diana Rowland's WHITE TRASH ZOMBIES, so I knew that I'd make my way to KARA GILLIAN eventually. This story was way more serious than my previous experiences with this author's writing, but it was extra sexy as well which helped to even it out. At this point in time, I'm picking Ryan over Rhyzkahl, although neither has proven themselves yet, therefore things could go either way on the romance front. I liked Liv Anderson's narration, and have already purchased the second audiobook.

IMMUNE was, well, a bit of a mess. After a respectable series debut, Shannon Mayer trades in her Urban Fantasy hat for a Paranormal Romance one which resulted in a pretty drastic u-turn that I didn’t particularly care for. Rylee/O’Shea’s relationship skipped every step in-between “hi, how are ya” and “I love you”, and you don’t get much more instant than that. But, then Liam isn’t in book 3 AT ALL if the blurb is to be believed, not to mention that the author is also going in questionable directions with a few of her characters. I just don’t know.Adamson’s snarky tough girl attitude has started to surface which was exactly what I was hoping for. It’s too bad that it didn’t carry over to her dialogue with O’Shea; whether I continue this series or not will most likely come down to if Mayer decides to focus primarily on Rylee’s angsty romance with the FBI Agent, or on her cutthroat Tracker side. I’m all for option 2 in case I haven’t made that clear yet. Adamson was also very reckless in this novel which put my ‘established heroine’ remark from my PRICELESS review into doubt.I hate Milly, I really do. Every protagonist needs a BFF / sidekick / ally, so I don’t get why the author destroyed their friendship in the first installment, and then continued to kick it while it was down in this one. It’s going to take A LOT for me to care about the witch. Why make that much work for yourself? Unless she’s disposable… I wasn’t ecstatic about what happened to O’Shea towards the end of this story either. It was yet another extreme approach to something that should have developed over multiple books, or not at all for that matter.The best parts of this novel were the interactions between O’Shea & Alex; they are fighting for dominance within Rylee’s ‘pack’—one is human, and doesn’t have two clues about the on-going power struggle, and the other is a submissive werewolf who doesn’t have an Alpha bone in his body. It made for some entertaining mix-ups! The Kindle edition came with a cool character reference feature that was useful in identifying who’s who, and the plot itself was ok too with its triple threat. It’s unfortunate that it was overshadowed by main couple drama, and unstable secondaries.IMMUNE was a far cry from book 1. It all comes down to RAISING INNOCENCE. ~3.5 Stars

COLD BURN OF MAGIC’s heroine is a younger, more reckless, less tested version of Gin Blanco, so right away I felt at home in Jennifer Estep’s BLACK BLADE series. Lila Merriweather has two Talents, one of which she keeps on the DL and she has sworn to avenge her mom’s murder—ring any bells? That mostly sums up the correlations between this world, and ELEMENTAL ASSASSIN; as a body guard the protagonist protects rather than kills, although sometimes the latter happens as a result of the former, her back story is an open book, and the antagonist is immediately apparent. This novel blended the top elements from this author’s Young Adult & Urban Fantasy titles into a smashing debut.As much as I love meeting new characters, and immersing myself in an original plot, world-building still trumps all. First installments are usually where the bulk of a series’ foundation is located, and this book was no different. Estep left me giddy with delight as I wormed my way through her symbology, magicks, and monsters. Getting a feel for the Families, especially the Draconis & the Sinclairs was a close second with the romance trailing as a distant third, but that wasn’t unexpected, and quite frankly I prefer it that way.In Urban Fantasy, whether we’re talking adult or YA, it’s pivotal that the lead be easy to connect with, and Lila filled that requirement well. A lot of info gets thrown readers’ way with regards to her past, current motivations, and future goals, but as important as all that info is, she was also incredibly likeable which ensured that she was fleshed out in all of the right places. Her POV had a degree of maturity to it that Estep’s MYTHOS ACADEMY novels lacked to a certain extent, so it only took me a split second to decide that BLACK BLADE was going on my keeper shelf.In addition to an inviting universe, and an agreeable heroine, this author’s food fetish was ever-present, as was her knack for creating standout secondary characters. Mo reminded me of Fletcher, but with his own unique personality twists, and Devon didn’t exactly cause me to insta-drool, although he’s off to a pretty good start as far as love interests go. I need more deets before I can pass judgment on Felix as BFF material, and Claudia could go either way at this point. The clear winner was Oscar: the honeybeer guzzling, redneck, cowboy, pixie. Hehe! Need I say more?Jennifer Estep knows what her readers want, and delivers it with COLD BURN OF MAGIC. Brilliant!

I've been enjoying this series thus far, but this installment really brought it! The porn star murder mystery had barrel-of-laughs written all over it, doubly so with Harry Dresden on the case. BLOOD RITES put a lot of the characters' roles into perspective; Murphy tries being a vigilante on for size, Ebenezar is not what he seems, and Thomas—I did NOT see that one coming. This book was a turning point for THE DRESDEN FILES, and... PUPPIES!

After listening to this installment, I now realize why the last few titles have made me cranky. It’s because I’ve been waiting for Garreth’s story since book 1, and the delay finally caught up with me. This series came highly recommended on account of its “sexy Scottish werewolves”, but they’ve been mostly MIA since WICKED DEEDS ON A WINTER’S NIGHT, so the younger MacRieve’s romance was long overdue. All is right with the world again.In PLEASURE OF A DARK PRINCE readers get answers to many long running questions which was perfect timing as far as I was concerned because it revived my interest in the IMMORTALS AFTER DARK series. This book covers from pre-A HUNGER LIKE NO OTHER, to Garreth’s year long pursuit of Lucia, so it was an excellent overview of where Kresley Cole has been, and her intended direction going forward, although I’m quite positive that Nix will have the last word.Valkyries and I haven’t exactly seen eye-to-eye in the past; however I’m slowly coming around to this author’s version. Lucia stood out because of her born-again-virginity—the celibate immortal queen should be discarded from IAD’s deck, just saying—and her reputation as The Archer. Garreth was awesome, and I loved the advice that his brother and Bowen kept giving him. They’ve both claimed their mates which gave them unique (amusing) perspectives.Just when I thought that I had gotten my legs back under me (Robert Petkoff’s narration will do that to you), he goes and whips out a… Texan accent! Oh, and don’t forget that his brogue was also widespread with MacRieve as the male protagonist. This installment reminded me of the earlier IAD audiobooks, the ones that I chain listened to in under a month, so I’m taking it as a sign that a second likewise spree might be around the corner.PLEASURE OF A DARK PRINCE was the werewolf that I was looking for.

'Chick with a sword on the cover. 'A werewolf sidekick. 'A $0.99 price tag. 'By a Canadian author—SOLD. One of my favourite Urban Fantasy series was discovered the same way, so I decided to go for it. PRICELESS did not disappoint with its colourful secondary characters, unique slant on the typical P.I. spiel, and a heroine with boatloads of untapped gifts. I enjoyed my first trip down Shannon Mayer’s (rabbit hole) mine shaft, and I will for sure be one-clicking IMMUNE in the near future (YAY! It’s on sale too).This novel had several paranormal elements that I’ve seen before such as the Tracker talent, and an Arcane division within the FBI angle, along with a few new-to-me spins including creative shifter limitations, and Rylee’s Immune ability. The author straight away sets to work weaving together an attractive tale of supes, magical rules, and plot threads. This was definitely a lively book, but the heavy influx of information, and extensive cast debuts were a good fit for the pacing, and added to this story’s curve appeal.Rylee was my kind of heroine, in that she already has a knack for blades, hockey player fight moves, and has been developing her powers for several years. I love a burgeoning protagonist, but sometimes it’s a relief to walk into a series with a lead that’s already got their sh*t together. No doubt, Adamson still has much to learn, however she has a sturdy foundation to build upon, so it will be interesting to see how her personality, and skill level evolves from here. I’m hoping that Mayer will rev up the humour as the installments get further along too.Every strong female protagonist needs an able-bodied man to back her up, and although O’Shea didn’t immediately fit those shoes, his character growth began shortly after his first entrance, and didn’t let-up until the cliff hanger ending. He has charm; I’ll give him that, with his excited grins over finding himself knee deep in otherworldly chaos, and his foresight to practice swordsmanship. Alex was a hit with his Golden Retriever-esque qualities, and flair for lightening up even the most deadly situation. Adversely, Milly has some atoning to do.PRICELESS was (hopefully) the start of a beautiful RYLEE ADAMSON relationship.

I was informed by many a reader that this series found its legs in book 3, and there was even an intro from Jim Butcher to that effect. It's true! I loved this one to pieces! Many of the secondary characters came out of the woodwork in a big way, and a few new ones were added to the cast as well. I enjoyed the humour a lot more this time around, the multiple plot threads kept me engaged, and the main story arc is just getting started. Harry really defined himself as a protagonist in this installment by making some tough calls, demonstrating that he can throw down in a pinch, and his relationship with Susan takes several unexpected turns. James Marster's narration has been steadily improving with each novel, and I look forward to tagging along with him, Butcher & Dresden for SUMMER KNIGHT.

As a long-standing fan of Rachel Vincent's SHIFTERS series, I was through the roof with enthusiasm when I discovered this spin-off five years later. I recommend reading the prequel / bridge novella, HUNT, prior to this one because it sets the tone for LION'S SHARE, and its events are referenced throughout this story. As fired up as I was about WILDCATS book 1, the author's switch from Urban Fantasy to New Adult Paranormal Romance did worry me, and my trepidations turned out to not be entirely false because I did in fact have issues with the heroine's foolhardiness, Jace's backsliding, the questionable set-up for subsequent installments, and... RANT TIME!The world-building and recap aspects fell a bit short in my opinion; fortunately I already had all of the essentials given my existing familiarity with the other novels, however if you opted to skip the five originals you might be left scratching your head for a bit. Same thing goes for the reappearance of a handful of the previous series' characters; without former knowledge, you may find yourself wondering who some of them are, and won't be immediately starstruck by Jace Hammond. Neither were a problem for me, yet I felt that it was worth the mention for newcomers who are considering using this title as a primer to Vincent's SHIFTERS.I gave Abby way more chances than I would have a normal heroine given her age, and everything that she's been through in her short life. Her secret and refusal to confide in anyone including readers drove me up the wall, and made following her POV a hair pulling experience. I think a little extra insight would have helped make her more likable, and by the time the big reveal rolled around I'd already reached a similar conclusion, so the twist wasn't an uber shocker anyway, and the trade-off was an obnoxious female protagonist. The author chose an extreme approach instead of a happy middle which permanently damaged Abby's character in my eyes. I mean, after all of the lengths she goes to in order to protect Robyn, only to hand her over to the very people she was hiding her from after a rushed explanation, and then hightail it to the free zone. She undermined all of her earlier actions in one fell swoop.My first thought when I saw this book's blurb was that it was about time that Jace got his HEA. He's been Alpha for 4 1/2 years now, held his territory against numerous threats, and earned the respect of his enforcers. Based on this, I expected a man, but what I got was a child. You'd think that he'd want to avoid a Faythe-type repeat at all costs, yet his resistance caved faster than a house of cards; all of his discipline and hard work went the way of the dodo because of a red-haired tabby. I was annoyed by how quickly he lost control of the situation, and quite frankly he deserved every bit of the council's harsh sentence. This novel destroyed my previously high view of Hammond and did little to convince me of WILDCATS' shelf life.I can't help but wonder how the author is going to make a romance series out of strays given the rarity of female cats. And, after this, I'm not sure that I care. To paraphrase Rachel Vincent: "nothing that felt this good could ever be wrong..." (Loc 1896) except where LION'S SHARE was concerned.

I've been procrastinating listening to this audiobook since November, but when Valentine's Day rolled around I decided that I was due for a guilty pleasure kind of title, and nothing fit the bill quite like Gideon & Ava Cross. I was also excited that this series FINALLY added a second narrator. As much as I've been enjoying Jill Redfield's performance, certain characters need that extra edge that only a male voice can bring, and I was hoping that Jeremy York would be up to the task. I wish that they'd read ALL of their respective personage's dialogues rather than just their specific chapters, but that's a common complaint of mine with dual readings. However, other than that, I had no issues with either of the narrators. My problems were with the lack of advancement on any front. Gideon & Ava are still struggling with the exact same obstacles only different versions of them, the story arc didn't really go anywhere, and the ending left me feeling like the next novel was going to be more of the same. CAPTIVATED BY YOU was like watching a dog try to catch its tail; painful and an exercise in futility.

I was psyched to be back in the SHIFTERS universe after such a prolonged break. I didn't remember much about Abby's character, but the Faythe & Jace bits were like getting a hug from an old friend. The protagonist's emotion fueled responses to a threatening situation led to some rash decisions which left me screaming at my eReader. Yes, Rachel Vincent managed to get that kind of reaction out of me in only 30-ish pages! I kept expecting Wade to be like Miss Sanders; however it took Faythe five books to become the beloved heroine that she is today, so I'm more than willing to keep an open mind with regards to her potential as the lead in the first installment of this author's WILDCATS spin-off series. This short was nearly perfect, and for a novella that's saying something! 4.5 stars

Kristen Callihan has been 5-for-5 with her DARKEST LONDON series, and I’ve been looking forward to Adam’s story most of all, so when the mailman delivered SOULBOUND the pressure was on. This installment brought with it plenty of new revelations with regards to the Fae, the King of the GIM’s curse, and we finally discover what was plaguing Archer in FIRELIGHT. The writing was as strong as ever, and the author made me weep with her romantic elements, but this book had a degree of predictability to it that the others didn’t which is why Callihan’s perfect rating streak must end here.This world is peppered with paranormal excellence from the mythology to the plethora of otherworldly characters; however only the Ghosts In The Machine have captured my interest to the point of obsession. Spooks are common enough in this genre, but this author’s approach is exceptional, bar none. Adam’s nature has been one of this series’ most closely guarded secrets, and is so intricately linked to the Fae that an examination of one will spoil the other, and both get cracked wide open in this novel, thus expect a deluge of answers, just not from me. Ha!As astounding as all of this book’s epiphanies were, they paled in comparison to the atypical conclusion. Callihan didn’t simply choose the path less traveled, she forged her own, and in doing so completely changed the definition of happily-ever-after. A common complaint of mine where ghost romances are concerned is that there aren’t any easy solutions to unite the couple, and the obvious fix is the one that no reader wants to face. I loved the direction that Adam & Eliza’s story took, although it was partially to blame for this installment’s foreseeable chain of events.Two of DARKEST LONDON’s previously featured heroines are GIM, so a coup on their King meant that this novel’s plot arc was widespread which had its benefits because the better part of this series’ characters got a word or two in. The mystery behind book 1 was solved at long last, and will in all probability carry over to the next title if Sin has anything to do with it, although I wouldn’t mind terribly if Lucien’s tale took precedence, especially after his recent admission. I guess the point I’m trying to make is that wherever this author goes from here, I will follow.SOULBOUND will make you believe in the impossible, there is love after death. 4.5 stars

The full length books are all about the vampires while as the shorts focus more on Neill's shifters which is the only reason why I read 'em cuz I'm not normally keen on novellas. Whenever Urban Fantasy protagonists take five, you know that something is going to go horribly awry—case in point. This was a cute story about family feuds à la supe with a romantic resolution that was over a century in the making. It didn't really contribute much to the series in terms of plot arc; however readers do get a dose of this author's mountain lions, and learn a bit about what life is like for vampires that live outside of the Houses (i.e. Clans). The Orangesplosion won't win any awards, but I never miss an opportunity to hang with Merit & Ethan, and neither should you if you're pro CHICAGOLAND VAMPIRES. ~ 3.5 stars

This story got off to a shaky start, and was largely reminiscent of my college years what with a guy picking a pretty girl up in a bar, luring her back to his place to discuss ‘business’, and then they bump uglies shortly thereafter. It’s a novella, so the author needed to efficiently establish a rapport between the two characters; however Cait & Owen’s connection came off as more one night stand-ish as opposed to ETERNAL MATES. That only lasted a couple of chapters though, and then the plot took over for the better.After this series’ three book long feline shifters centric sprint, I was interested in seeing how Felicity Heaton’s hellcats would distinguish themselves from the pride. That question was soon answered with two tails, a few very special breed quirks, and some hell fire in all the right places. Cait was a fascinating character who speedily won me over to her plight with good old fashioned girl power, and her sword wielding, and decapitation skills appealed to the Urban Fantasy reader in me.Owen was the first mortal hero to make an appearance in the ETERNAL MATES universe which was a nice change of pace; his infamous rep as a hunter gave him sizeable street cred, and that secret of his that’s referenced in the blurb was pretty darned bitchin’. I enjoyed witnessing him work his magic on Cait’s job from vetting sources, to his vast supernatural database, and hunch regarding Marrius’ real motives, although I was disappointed when he started using his little head more than his big one.This story didn’t set out in the direction that I had envisaged, and in turn ended up going above and beyond the ‘get this wackadoo off my tail’ schtick. I eventually bought into Owen & Cait’s relationship after the initial frat boy hook-up wore off, and the sex hit the spot just so long as I didn’t think too hard about how it came to be. The glance at Heaton’s dragons revved me up for the next novel, and I liked that the conclusion made partners out of this duo in more ways than one. Couples that kill together stay together!BITTEN BY A HELLCAT wasn’t purrfect, but sometimes a belly rub is all you need. ~3.5 Stars

We haven't gotten to see much of Alpha Elena, so it was great witnessing her knee deep in her newish role dealing with Pack politics, and the challenges that come with being not only the sole female werewolf, but also one in a leadership position. Kate frustrated me at times with her rebellious attitude, and independent streak; I had to keep reminding myself that she's only eight, and that her behaviour was age appropriate, and entirely understandable given present circumstances. All of my favourite furry Otherworld characters were out in full force, including the latest additions to the North American Pack as well as the current candidates. The twists involving the twins were totally squee-worthy, and this series' Big Bad tables a proposition that will leave me on edge until the next short is announced. Highly recommended, but not to be read as a stand-alone.

An eye-opener into what the Otherworld would have been like had the supes made their existence known to humans. Like most Dystopians, Armstrong's post-apocalyptic universe isn't a pretty one; Rayne & Braeden hatch a plan to escape the fortress only readers aren't privy to it until events are already in motion. I enjoyed how dark this short was and that for once the "devil you know" motto didn't hold true. The parallels between this novella and the WOTO series are minute, so don't expect any cameos, or new info, but I'd definitely be interested in exploring this alternate reality further if the author decides to pursue this avenue.

This wasn't your typical Ilona Andrews audiobook in that the magic system existed on a much smaller scale with it being confined to inns, but that's not to say that the world-building was by any means limited. In fact, if anything, it was larger than any of this author duo's other titles because the INNKEEPER CHRONICLES was closer to being Science Fiction than it was Urban Fantasy given that the characters originate from multiple planets. The wheel wasn't reinvented with regards to the typical paranormal beasties such as vampires & werewolves, although they did have several distinguishing traits that set them apart from other novels in this genre. Much to my dismay, a love triangle seems to be developing; however if any team is capable of making it work, it's Ilona & Gordon. The humor and writing were aces, no surprises there, and Renée Raudman's narration gave the story that extra somethin'-somethin' that keeps me choosing audio over eBook every time this trio releases something new.

Basic, simple and works for a typical small "point and shoot" camera.  The side pocket holds spare batteries.  It protects the camera so I am comfortable tossing it into my purse (something I previously didn't want to do) so I have my camera always available.  Of course, I prefer my cell camera for a quick snap (times sure have changed!).

For my purpose this is perfect, but not for all.  Note it is for items with low power requirements (no third grounding plug).  This is an economical option for those various gadgets around the house that connect to your wi-fi network. We loose power for a few minutes at a time, just enough to cause some of my gadgets to dump memory and need to be re-set.  This UPS will solve that issue for short power outages--for low power item requirements.  It has a small footprint and a replaceable battery, making it a great addition to economically protect your electronic gadgets from voltage spikes and brown outs.I have used APC UPS's for years and have been very pleased with them--the removable battery is a great improvement!

Comfortable (I'm a leftie); buttons can be easily programed after installing the associated software.  I don't use it for gaming (just as a "normal" mouse).  I love that it has higher responsiveness so with a flick of the wrist the cursor goes across both of my monitors (dual monitors)--no more picking up and shifting to do this!The only thing I noticed  was that while using my left hand my index finger would tap one of the side buttons on the left causing crazy things to happen.  I disabled the button (easily accomplished through the software) and problem solved!

I have been using this app for a few years.  I like to read stuff for relaxation and distraction.  So I go through books like water.  This app tracks them for me so I don't spend time re-reading something I've previously read.  It has the options to categorize books (file on a shelf) which I have started using to record where the books are (Kindle, audio book, etc.)  It is totally awesome to realize I read an average of 300 books/year--I had not a clue.There are two features worth mentioning:  You can scan the bar-code inside the book to find it quickly (or enter the name in the search bar).  The second, is for series--it will list all books in the series, in order.  This really helps when I've found a series I like--then I can pick up the remaining books (then read in order).

I have had this for less than a week, so if things change I will update this review at that time.Connection to my wi-fi was a challenge.  It uses "Blink" which essentially has your phone flash a light quickly to "program" the device so it taps into your home Wi-Fi--this is NOT recommended for people with epileptic issues.  My android cell phone just flat didn't work.  The directions recommend using apple products, of which I had none.  I then downloaded the app into my Kindle fire (more out of desperation than anything else) and placed my fire about 1.5" above the little light sensor (bottom left) and it took the first time.  Go figure.  BTW, the darker the environment, the better it works.  The directions say you can take the man part of the controller box off (not mounted to the wall) and inside the house to a dark room if you need to.Once "installed" I then used the app to identify and program my various sprinklers.  There were several options--type of sprinkler ("shooter" or "sprayer"); type of dirt/clay; type of vegetation (grass, bushes, etc.), type of slope.  You can name the zones something like "front left" instead of "Zone 1", which is helpful.  I found the default times double that of what I am currently using, so I cut them back to what I am currently using.  The device claims to compensate for these variables (I have clay soil), so for example it will adjust the watering cycle for more efficient watering of the clay--a burst, then rest, then a burst, etc.  Time will tell if these are the correct settings, but so far my yard is looking pretty good!The fact that it knows where I live (by zip code) and I picked up the external water sensor means no more watering in the rain!  I was able to use the website easier to plan out what days to water (we have restrictions in the summer), so now it's basically watch it and see how it does.

This is the first time I have invested (yes, it's pricey) in a hose of this quality.  It is a bit heavier than what I'm used to (especially when full of water), but there are no trips to keep un-kinking the hose.  I have used this hose several times now and am quite pleased with it.  I pull it out as far as I need then work away.  When I move and it starts getting heavy, then I stop and pull a bunch of the hose to my work area and continue.  I have used it to spray weed-killer on my yard; pressure wash my house and several other home owner chores. I lock this hose in my shed; the old hoses are now cosmetic decorations near my spigots (I can't bring myself to tossing them when they still work, sort of).  I have it mounted on a heavy duty rolling hose cart so I can easily move it around, then roll it up quickly. This hose is heavy, so I wouldn't recommend a light weight (cheap) holder--I spent around $50 for one at my local home improvement store.

For the price, this is a great deal--nothing fancy, but it does the trick.  I wanted something to swing out from the wall that I could mount a shelf holder on to hold my tablet, cell phone, etc. while I'm on the treadmill.  The part that mounts to the TV easily mounted to the block on the back of my shelf and I can swing, swivel, what-not to get it exactly where I want it.  When needed (like moving the treadmill) the whole thing (with shelf attached) neatly folds back against the wall.

Convenient, out of the way additional port to convert a wired device to a wireless device.  When I ordered this I thought it would also function as a repeater.  But, as other reviewers have pointed out it does one or the other; not both at the same time (one star).  Otherwise, it is nice to just plug it into the wall (no additional cabling, etc)--the Ethernet cable takes the same path as the power cord so it is a very neat, clean installation.  One thing that could be a disadvantage is that when working there are green lights along the top to relay the status (I've only seen green, but assume other colors will appear in an error condition)--If placed behind furniture you won't see them.  I have mine in a somewhat sheltered area, but I can still see the lights so it's fine for me.  Once set up; just forget and it does what it's supposed to.

I received 2 colors of cloths in my pack--yellow and the strange green.  This is OK as it makes them easy to identify.  These are square (after washing) and are the best I've tried so far.  They absorb water like a sponge and you can feel them get heavy (I have tried some others that are almost repellant).  Also, when you wring them out they feel damp (not wet), and they dried over night (other ones take almost a day to air-dry).  They are very soft, and I am using them as washcloths for my face.  My older ones are out in the garage where they belong.Note:  product received at a discount to provide an nu-biased review.

I have a strange foot, so finding shoes that fit is a challenge.  My foot is wide, with a high arch, and as a result I am constantly fighting pronation.  My brother wears these shoes so I thought I'd give them a try (at this price I normally buy in store only!).  Overall, they are a pretty good fit.  However, the arch is not high enough--I can't even feel it!  I ordered some glue-in arch supports to aid in this and they seem to help.  The toe box is plenty wide (my usual complaint) and the shoe is quite comfortable otherwise.  I will be keeping these but not sure if I'll buy again when it is time to replace them.

I have loved every Plugable product I have bought (I can't say that about many manufacturers).  This one is no different.  What is not obvious from the pictures, is that the green strip along the sides is really clear (when power is off).  Turn the power on, and the magic happens!  It turns a nice soft green.  It makes a nice night light, but is also visible during the day.  There are plenty of well spaced power outlets to accommodate all the stuff on my night stand (2 USB chargers, wall-wart charger, lamp, some other odds and ends).  This replaced 2 extension cords and I have room left over.  The only con is the footprint--It is on the larger side, so it sits next to my night stand (the others I tucked behind the night stand--probably a fire hazard).  But the night light feature makes this actually an advantage for those "middle of the night" runs!

These hold my lenses very nicely.  My largest lens is a 300mm, which fit nicely in the 3rd largest pouch.  I ended up not needing the largest pouch.  My hip pack has places for water bottles, or I might use it for one--shoot, I still may as it is somewhat insulated! I attached these to my hip pack for easy access while walking around (strapping through the belt loop).  The only one I had difficulties with was the smallest one.  The area to run the strap through was less than 1", due to stabilization stitching about 1" from each end of the pouch.  Fortunately, my hip pack had a narrow strap to secure the water bottles, so I was able to use that for it (otherwise it would NOT go through the waist strap as the others did).  I was somewhat panicking until I figured this out.  The 2nd largest was close, but with some wiggling, it made it.  The 3rd, not a problem--plenty of clearance.I found the easiest way to include the lens hood was to insert it in sideways.  Once past the opening, then rotate it around flat so it "cups" the lens.  Then simply drop the lens in and pull the top shut.This system works very well.  Previously I used a camera bag and was constantly juggling stuff around.  Now everything is secure on my hip pack, I can swap lenses much easier as they are very accessible.

This holds my Nikon D5000 with the 18-55 wide angle lens.  It isn't quite long enough (the lens pushes past the end of the stitching about 1/2" after snapping the back closed).  Otherwise, it is great protection for the camera.  The back is secured using two plastic snaps.  This is my first experience with this type of snap, so no idea of the durability of them.  The case is quality made otherwise, so I have high hopes that these are also a quality material.

Awesome to have on hand....just because.  I put this on a window and carefully pulled (like a chin up).  I felt no give or movement, although I didn't use my full weight as I didn't want to break my window.  I have complete confidence that this will do exactly what it says it will.  If you need a handle somewhere, this is well worth the investment.

I have a ceiling fan in my bedroom, but every time I use it I wake up with sinus issues.  I still would like some air movement, so purchased this.  It's large enough to move the air around, but not so large that I feel like I'm in a wind tunnel.  I sleep better with this (I use the oscillation feature by the way) on and no sinus issues!

Good for awkward stuff, when you just need something to help you hold on.  I tested this by pulling sideways on a window (kind of like a limited one handed chin-up).  Although it didn't move, there was a bit of a wiggle factor, so I'm not sure I would trust it 100% with anything expensive.  However it is handy for those awkward things that your arms just aren't quite big enough to get around.

Great selection of cheap DISPOSABLE brushes.  Quality isn't the best, but the variety of size is useful to just have on hand.  I hate being in the middle of a project and needing a brush for something.  With this selection (and at this price), it's worth picking up just to have on hand.  No clean up--toss when done.  What could be easier?  I have a more expensive trim brush that I am emotionally attached to and am willing to clean up because it is so awesome.  But for projects using oil based paint, I prefer to toss than clean.

Second year with one of these.  I mark my appointments on it, and it makes planning at a glance a breeze!  I enjoy marking off the day before I leave as well.  Thank you for a great product, at an affordable price (I bought it for work).  I cut off the top row of 3 months when no longer needed and move the calendar up.  The second one, I just taped to the bottom of the first and keep on rolling forward.

I purchased this with a four pack of neoprene pouches for my camera lenses.  Mainly because my shoulder bag was getting hard on my shoulder for my longer hikes when I wanted to bring my camera.  I was using something similar that didn't have water-bottle capability.  This pack has 3 compartments--the first plenty large for wallet, cell phone, keys, sun screen, etc. that I normally would have in my purse.  The middle compartment is large enough for extra batteries, a few lenses and other odds and ends I generally carry in my camera bag.  The third, outer (smallest) compartment is very flat and works well for the camera cable to computer, and a couple of other thin things (I just like to keep stuff together--really stupid to drag this junk around for longer hikes).  The two water container areas are roomy, and could double as a lens holder while switching lenses.  They also have straps so you can really secure your bottles!  This pack secures nicely to my hips, however the belt is over a foot too long (I will eventually cut this down and hem it)--but this is great for you that are a bit more generous in the hips!  It is lightly padded around the waist.  My initial wear-around-the-house test for about 15 minutes (fully loaded) was successful, I barely noticed it.  Longer hikes, with more stuff and you may want to pad it up more.  I think the weight of the lenses in front did somewhat off set the weight of the stuff over my hind end.  The biggest advantage of this system, is everything is carried on my waist, leaving my arms free to fiddle with my camera and help with my balance on steeper trails.

I got this to put in my regular purse.  I am not sure if it's a system or not, it has some snaps near the top that make it look like it might be.  I thought it would help keep things organized.  It does, but there is no structure to it.  The sides (especially the long ones) just kind of flop down.  I can find my chap stick and other small items tucked into the pockets by flipping the sides over until I locate them.  If the sides were as rigid as the picture seems to show, I'd be extremely happy with this.  But as it is, not so much.

Extra long and strong design with a cutout for the drain.  Make sure you align it with the back end of the tub before walking on it or the drain will be obscured- there is less leeway than with cheaper models, but then more protection. Good for parents of young children who want to maximize cushioning, for the elderly and for anyone else!  Translucent with large suction cups, holds fast. Machine washable and allergen free. Wash it frequently to avoid mold, as for all bath mats (even those with the chemically suspect mildew proof additives.)  Clean your tub and soak the mat before using to maximize the hold.

The cut is classic.  The size is fine- a little large across the shoulders maybe.  The color is lavender- nothing daark about it. But my main issue is the fabric,  It is a very loose muslin, a step up from cheesecloth.  The fabric quality is not high and it just feels weird.  I wouldn't purchase something with that fabric.

Maria was perhaps the most compelling character on Sesame Street, a thoughtful, loving and street smart character who played the role for 44 years. It was not easy for Sonia Manzaro who plaed Maria to grow up, become an actor and a writer who was able to audition for the role and inhabit it with her experience.  Sonia Manzaro grew up in a poor Puerto Rican family with an alcoholic father who became abusive when drunk.  Her mother told horror tales of her life in Puerto Rico so Sonia felt relief at growing up in the Bronx.  She overlooked many of the tribulations, but decided early on that she wanted to be an actor from an early age and prevailed against discouragement.The early part of the book captures the details of growing up poor and Puerto Rican in the Bronx in a loving but dysfunctional family.  It shows how a poor start in educational quality hampers her in later years as she works on obtaining the skills and contacts needed to become a good actor. She eventually prevails but you can see why she started with a rocky foundation.  Well written and insightful, but I was a bit disappointed that the book ended with her audition for Sesame Street,  . I hope a sequel is in the making because I'd like to see how her life affected the role she plaed.

Identical twins Giselle and Isabelle are hit by a car on their way to a high school concert and Isabelle was killed.  While apparently comatose Giselle can hear and think and the story revolves around her inner dialogue.  Edwidge Danticat writes lyrically and keeps the reader's attention. Isabelle and Giselle were born with hands held and their fingers had to be untwined.  It was much harder for teenaged Giselle to untwine herself from her dead sister. The book takes place in Miami with a trip to Haiti and shows the complexity of a multi ethnic, multi lingual (Creole, English, Spanish, French) family.  Well written and engaging and not just for young adults.

Turmeric is an extraordinary herb for reducing inflammation, an antioxidant, an adaptogen and a pain reliever.  Biopreine, a black pepper constituent makes it significantly more bioavailable.  What I like best about this formulation is that it uses 500 mg of actual turmeric instead of the curcumin isolate, meaning it has all of the synergistic flavonoids and buffers as well as the well-studied curcumin. I depend upon turmeric to keep my diabetes and Parkinson's in check.  Do take it with a spoonful of coconut oil which will increase the absorption (and provide benefits of its own) since turmeric needs fat.

It's water.  Elegantly packaged spray-on water.  Makes my face feel good.  But due to the Amazon Vine program I didn't have to pay $12.99 for 5.2 ounces of water.  Sure it has minerals but so does my tap water and I could even add some trace mineral concentrate to tap water and put it in a $3.00 reusable sprayer.
I love it!  Easy to use- intuitive and makes a great cappuccino.  You will need to get your own milk pitcher. Compact unit, easy to clean. Stainless beats plastic anytime!

I personally recommend 1000 mg of DHA for nearly everyone- not just pregnant mothers.  This makes it easy- two tablets twice a day.  Very important for your brain as well as your baby's. Especially good for neurological or mitochondrial diseases like MS as well. Not everyone can convert vegetarian sources to DHA.  Good formulation, comfortable size and no fishy odor.

A story of class and conflict in a coastal Oregon town that erupts into animal and human murder.  The local color rings true, with the affluent "cakes" who treat long term working class residents as prey or invisibile.  Nova the protagonist is referred to as "diner skank" because she works in her grandfather's coffee shop and kissed another boy after being dumped by a boy she trusted- lots of slut shaming in this small town,  The book is a well crafted mystery that presents several possibilities as the murderer, then with a major plot twist gobsmacks you.  I never saw it coming.  Exciting, well-written and draws ou right in.

Many of us need this product when urgency strikes.  Trouble is there isn't enough time to spray before you go.  The concept may work for the constipated but the idea of a pre-poo spray needs more work.  The vanilla is a bit strongly floral but the timing is the real issue.

If you aren't going to your Chinese herbalist for an individualized prescription, this is the next best thing in capsules. You will get a bit more effect if you bite down on the capsule so taste signals your body (taste is not just an aesthetic experience,)  The elderberry tastes pretty good. New Chapter is a very conscientious company and have done their due diligence at getting the right type and potency of elderberries. Great product.
I use it at night and it gets me more oxygen.  Great device that doesn't pop off like the breathe strips.

Great Android phone for the price, and it really has a good price.  Brighter than my Samsung and with good visibility.  Nice design, great camera and good volume so I can hear on a crowded city street. Easy to use for a novice.  Minor quibble is that it is easy to pocket phone people. Otherwise a *great* buy!

Would not support this company.  Ripoff warning. Lose the Back Pain/ Jesse Canone looked like they had some good products and I agreed to try one at a $9.95 trial price a while back but they threw on a bogus $19.95 monthly charge for their email ad and refused to retract them. No benefit and my CC co won't go back more than twice. They also enroll you in autoship at a dramatically higher price. Be forewarned.

I find that books about Israel interest me, but the writing leaves much to be desired,  The concept is great- focusing on a small cul d'sac between the Israeli and Palestinian borders where lost sheep can start an international incident and where a set of false teeth falling out of a window can lead to a temporary cease fire.I wish the writing were better,

Once you get over the idea of black toothpaste (getting a set of 4Pcs Dental Care Premium Bamboo charcoal Nano Toothbrush Set + Worldwide free shiping with soft charcoal nano bristles helps,)  the toothpaste is great.  Even used it to poultice a pimple successfully and to stop odor- charcoal and mint are an all-around useful combo. My dentist was pleased. A bit pricey but a little goes a long way.

Great for nonresponsive diarrhea.  Unlike what you have seen before;  You take 3-5 tiny soft moist pills that taste like creosote with a big gulp of water three times a day.  I am quite a bit larger than the average Japanese person so take 5. Do use a lot of water because the taste of the pills is vile.  Your urine may develop a slight scent of burnt wood, but it isn't obnoxious and no one has commented.  They contain phellodendron (huang bai) and acacia catechu which are used in Chinese medicine for diarrhea and dysentery, licorice and citrus peel.

Got this for my parents who loved it.  The sky was challenging.  They had just returned a 1000 piece Starry Night puzzle that was too big to fit on their table and overwhelmed them, much preferring this version.

I don't have a toddler so tried this as a doubler with fitted pants.  It breathes, is absorbent and was not a leakage problem.  Could be doubled outside of the pocket for  toddlers with volume issues.However one point off for the non-ecological plastic packaging.  You can't recycle it and there is no excuse for it when paper would suffice.
Beautiful design, quality thickness, comfortable sizing. No allergic reaction. A lovely ring.

The Twin Star space heater is small but powerful.  I don't think it will heat up a 400 sq ft room but it does a decent job on my 250 sq ft treatment room.  It has a fan-only function which is good for hot days in the transitional seasons.  It does NOT tilt as described, but it is small and lightweight enough to move the entire unit into the direction you want it.  There is an automatic shutoff if it turns over to prevent fires which I find useful because this last cold winter my cat sat in front of our space heater and sometimes knocked it over.It may be the automatic shut-off which is responsible for  the major problem with the unit.  When it reaches the desired heat the unit irrevocably turns off.  It may need a reset- unplugging the unit and letting it cool off works and there is a reset button on the bottom. The workaround is to set the thermostat on less than maximum heat and to set the unit on something that permits air circulation under the unit- a wire shelf for instance.  I had a similar problem with my laptop so bought press-on furniture glides to act as legs. That might not be enough for an appliance designed to provide heat but the principle is the same.  Otherwise I like the unit.One word about the color:  it is very intense green, might do best in a 60s modern decor. My room is done in lime and hunter green and it stands out. The blue is more versatile (but also more expensive,)

Most of us are deficient in magnesium, a necessary mineral used in some 350 biologlcal reactions.  Between the mid 1970s when the USDA put out its book, The Nutritional Content of Food and the separate update reports it issued in the mid 1990s, the magnesium content fell by a third and it is estimated that industrial farming which strip mines the soil has reduced it to less than 50% today.Between 68-80% of Americans are deficient in magnesium. Low magnesium is associated with low Vitamin D as magnesium is necessary for its transport molecules/  Supplementing with calcium can deplete magnesium and magnesium can be used instead of calcium (usually common in the diet) for osteoporosis.  Deficiency is associated with depression, constipation, diabetes, muscle spasms and insomnia.. I like the time release feature which eliminates loose stools from magnesium consumption. However many people need the laxative effect, so choose accordingly and don't be afraid to mix and match, especially because magnesium is poorly absorbed.  I take this, magnesium L- theronate for my brain and transdermal magnesium chloride oil for spasms from Parkinson's.The supplement is based on an Albion chelate which is bound to protein for bioavailablity and the sustained release formula is supposed to be even better absorbed.  It is said to help block aluminium.  It also contains methylated B12 and folate.  The supplement contains:  Vitamin C (as ascorbyl palmitate)  10 mg  16%  Vitamin B-6 (as Pyridoxal-5-phosphate)  5 mg  250%  Folate (as Quatrefolic 5MTHF)  200 mcg  50%  Vitamin B12 (as Methylcobalamin)  6 mcg  100%  Elemental Magnesium (as dimagnesium malate) 500 mg  125%  Malic Acid (as dimagnesium malate)  1,550 mg  * Daily Value not established

Vita Sackville West was one of the more interesting women of her generation, as much for her non-monogamous bisexual lifestyle as for her considerable writing.  Dennison has done considerable research on her sexual life but gives short shrift to her literary output.  Sackville West did not consider herself a great writer - she reserved that for her lover Virginia Wolf - but she was a good writer and influential for her time.  The book is lively and well-written but Sackville-West comes across as reduced to a rather intriguing soap opera character.  That is a shame because Dennison has the research and writing skills to have done better.

I like the idea and I liked the book, but it isn't easy'to tear out the pages and the colors are too sparkly unless you are 25 or less.  More party than everday colors. I am used to mineral makeup, so I thought this would be a convenient proxy, Not so. In trying to pull out a page to rub it on, two pages pulled out.  Way too expensive for what it is.

I am a coconut water fan, and I drink a variety.  But I found very little difference between this and CocoVia or CocoWell.  Much better than the sweetened Jamaica brand though.  I prefer organic foods, but coconuts typically have no pesticide exposure and the whole nuts may get an external fungicide dip if shipped whole- but there is a lot of husk and nut protecting it. So I don't think you need to buy organic coconut water (which is reportedly clean enough to use as field IV solution.) This is pretty expensive for what it is,The ingredients only list coconut water.  Kosher, certified Organic and verified non-GMO,  But then it wasn''t likely treyf, GMO or grown with pesticides anyway. But nicely done.

Large enough to be a people blanket for bug-free concerts in the park, this blanket is tightly bound with a proprietary permethrin formula to fabric.  The permethrin is a man-made compound identical to that found in chrysanthemums and has been used in a variety of products for human children and pets since 1977. Permethrin was tested on head lice for pregnant women in the 1970s and 4% creams which could be absorbed through the skin were found to be safe.  I believe it is safer than topical DEET, and certainly Lyme disease from the ticks it repels (not to mention mosquitoes, ants, flies, fleas, chiggers and midges and whatever they might transmit.) Permethrin oil is not safe for cats or cold blooded animals so keep your cats, snakes and lizards off of it. I tend to doubt that the embedded and bonded permethrin is actually dangerous to cats, (unless, possibly you soaked the blanket in oil and made the cat lick it,) My cat evinced not the least bit of interest in it although she is fond of small blankets,  Protection lasts through 50 washings which is the life of the fabric and has been found effective after 10 years storage. Dry cleaning would reduce the life of the protection, although that isn't the way most would treat it. This kind of fabric is also made into repellent garments for hikers.The picture looks like it is thick and padded,  It is not,  The fabric is thin microfiber and probably not water proof, but otherwise would work as a picnic blanket or something to store in your bug out bag,  There is no odor,  The color could be seen for some distance so it could double as a safety blanket for hikers

Several years ago I read The Radioactive Boy Scout,( http://www.amazon.com/The-Radioactive-Boy-Scout-Backyard/dp/037550351X) about David Hahn, a boy who was so fascinated by atomic energy that he developed a reactor in his backyard shed and contaminated his neighborhood.  Young Taylor Wilson read that book too and decided to become the responsible radioactive boy scout.  His parents and grandmother who were less informed on nuclear energy found knowledgeable adults to mentor him, school him in safety (or to confirm that he was taking proper precautions to keep himself  and his environment safe) and provided internet and a garage to work in. By age 11 he had made yellowcake. The death of his grandmother whose cancer had been treated by nuclear medicine impelled him to invent a small reactor which could provide on-site isotopes to make the treatment window of a volatile substance longer.  For school vacations his parents brought him to old uranium mines in Nevada, to used nuclear equipment stores and to Oak Ridge, Tennessee where he made appointments with high level scientists who had no idea he was only 11, and brought him to industry suppliers where he got reduced price high level vacuum pumps and other technical equipment.  With a move to Nevada where the Davidson school for gifted children hooked him up with the University of Nevada at Reno's physics department which provided him with lab space and mentorship.  He developed a working fusion reactor, a "star in a jar" by age 14.  Since then he has worked with the Department of Homeland Security to develop low cost nuclear material detection devices and he has developed prototype designs for small nuclear fission reactors that will run on spent fuel rods (a disposal problem turned into an opportunity) and will only need new fuel every 30 years.The book is as much about how to raise and educate a gifted kid as it is an extraordinary biography. Most gifted kids lose interest- they are given more things to do since they work faster but not more challenging work, Many drop out or fail to develop their gifts in a way that can benefit society.  Taylor was lucky to have parents who got out of his way when he wanted to learn obsessively about nuclear energy and provided him the support and mentoring needed at great cost to themselves.  But while he thrived in a school made up of gifted kids and knowledgeable adults, his no less gifted but shy brother needed the social stability of their Arkansas hometown to thrive.

This is another high fructose syrup, like the discredited agave syrup which is higher in fructose than high fructose corn syrup.  Guys, fructose is worse for you than than glucose but it does not measure on the glycemic index because that only measures glucose.  I don't know what the relative percent of fructose is but PubMed (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/41685) shows its identity in the articke " Preparation of high-fructose syrup from the tubers of the Jerusalem artichoke (Helianthus tuberosus L."Go with monkfruit or stevia or even xylitol.

I'm pretty picky about chocolate and while this isn't Vosges, it is pretty good.  Way above Hershey's Premium.  This is an assortment of two-bar sticks,  The dark chocolate flavors and coffee and cream were my favorite.The marzipan was a little sweet.  However, gluten alert, and allergens include milk, wheat, soybean, peanut, sheanut, hazelnut, almond, egg and tree nuts.

Ramineh Andalibian's memoir tells of the loss of what appeared an idyllic existence in pre-Revolutionary Iran, the disillusionment of revolutionary change, the costs of secrecy and the high costs of immigration on family life.  Vivid and compellingly written, Ramirah comes from a conservative family who ran a successful hotel near a pilgrimage hotel, with no music, no alcohol and no dancing.  During the conflict two thugs who rape  an older woman are stashed in the largely empty hotel until functioning courts of law can be re-established.  They feign repentance which appeals to her religious Baba, but  instead implicate her 16 year old brother in a murder for which he is clandestinely executed by the new revolutionary justice system.  This is not conveyed to his brothers and sisters who are told he is studying abroad but has a corrosive effect on family well-being.  Immigration comes with significant separation, suffering and financial loss.  It upsets the self-image of every child where turbulent adolescence and apparent assaults on traditional Persian Muslim values threaten to break the strong family ties.  Well-written and compelling.
These cables are junk. One does not work at all. Another one charges devices very slowly which is indicative of a short or other problem. Also took nearly two months to arrive. Waste of money.
Product was missing the ink pad. Pricey for what it is. too much of a hassle to return it so we will get some kid friendly ink at a local store.

My wife and I had already purchased both the Dreambaby Gate and the Lascal KiddyGuard Accent gate and needed a 3rd gate for the top of the stairs.My experience with the Accent model (it's a lower end version of the Lascal gate) was that it was not substantially better than the Dreambaby gate to justify the much higher price, but my wife preferred its operation so we got the wider Lascal Avant and I installed it at the top of the stairs.Installation wise, the Avant gate is just as much of a headache to install as the smaller Accent gate.  The locking strip is a continuous piece of plastic that needs to be anchored firmly to a wall or other object.  Lascal offers bannister installation kits but they are truly horrible (will need to review those separately) so most customers are probably going to have to figure out their own workaround.For me, my wife did not want to tear moulding off of the bannister and screw the locking strip in so I needed another solution.  I bought a 1" square dowel rod from a hardware store and cut it down to the same height as the locking strip and then screwed the locking strip onto the dowel rod.  Next I used a dremel to cut away material so that the dowel rod could go directly onto the bannister around the moulding trim.  Final step was to drill holes in the dowel rod and use heavy gauge wire ties to wrap the whole thing around the bannister.  It's not super attractive but it does work.For the gate side I mounted the bottom clip to the base board moulding as low as I could towards the floor (pushing down on carpet while doing it).  I then cut a section from a 1x2 plank, anchored that into the wall and then screwed the gate with top bracket into it.All in all installing these is more of a pain than it should be.  Apparently the Lascal is a European product and they don't have problems with decorative moulding, base boards, skirting on bannisters, etc.  If they want to sell the product in the U.S. market they should modify their product to make installation easier for the typical homeowner here.As to the gate itself, it operates like the shorter Accent gate with a key difference.  The Avant gate makes use of a "timer" for the gate unlock/retract knob that allows much easier one hand operation.  You twist the knob and have a corresponding amount of time to move the gate around... when the timer expires the gate is locked.I do think that the visual indication they have (a tiny red circle that pops up slightly when the gate is unlocked) is not clear enough and could be improved so it was even more obvious if the gate is locked or not.Because of the timer function it is much easier to operate the gate one handed, and that is what bumps it up for me from 3 to 4 stars.  It is still worth pointing out that the gate doesn't pose much of a barrier to anything (or any little people) trying to get UNDER the gate as, even when installed as low as possible a small child or pet can slip underneath it.The rule of thumb for making sure barriers are sized properly for crawling infants is whether or not a softball can fit through and that's not a problem for the underside of this gate... which is probably why all of the advertisements for it show older children being contained by this gate.

My wife and I recently purchased the Dreambaby retractable gate as well as the Lascal Accent gate and I will attempt to compare the two.Dreambaby gate is easier to install than the Lascal gate since the locking strip on the Lascal gate is a continuous piece of plastic where-as the Dreambaby gate comes with templates and just uses a couple of hooks to retain the gate when you put it into use.Dreambaby gate also is easier for me personally to operate than the Lascal Accent since it has a cutaway for your hand which makes operating it from either side of the barrier pretty simple.Now as to the negatives on the Dreambaby Gate, there are several.  The most serious one to me is that it is easy to deploy the gate and not have it fully engaged.  I always have to check after putting the gate out that it has really started retracting and that the gate is going to do its job.Another drawback is that the knob that you rotate to engage or disengage the gate is kind of flimsy and there's no positive feedback that lets you know you've engaged the gate release.  Sometimes I will twist the knob and realize it's not engaged and have to do it one or two more times.  This is annoying.Another disadvantage is that it is a very basic looking gate.  There is no cartridge that retains the gate reel so it's just out in the open ready for something to bump into it and damage it when the gate is not being used.The biggest problem though that affects all of the retractable gates (Lascal included) is that even if you mount this flush with the floor/carpet there's a good 3-4 inches of room underneath the gate for an object to move through.  Absolutely an intrepid youngster (especially small baby or toddler) could figure out how to crawl under the gate, defeating it.I would strongly recommend that if someone uses one of these in an area such as at the top of the stairs (we put this gate at the top of our basement steps) don't leave the child completely unattended with just this gate in place.... especially not if you haven't seen what they will try to do while exploring what is possible with the gate.I view this gate as simply a barrier in case my son is playing around and gets into the area with the stairs to avoid any instantaneous mishaps.  I would not leave him at the top of the stairs with this gate unattended especially since I know he could fit under the "gate" if he really wanted to.

I have seen some mixed reviews of this set, but wanted to comment as I have now built two sets of shelves with two different kits.  One kit came as part of a workbench set and sat neglected for almost a year before I finally put it together.When I looked at the kit the biggest thing that I didn't like was the cheap screws it came with.  I spent about $8 at the local hardware big-box store on a box of 100 torx construction screws that included a couple of bits.I was then able to assemble this shelf set, including cutting in about one hour.  I did not follow the directions.  In a nutshell what I did was assemble the top level of the shelves (and using the better quality fasteners I was able to use my Makita driver to just drive the screws directly with no pre-drilling), then flip it over, place the four support beams, then slide the other shelves on, flip the whole thing around, get everything leveled and then do the final fastening.Final tip is that when cutting the final pieces for the middle shelves you want to try to cut them so that they are tight.  You should need to gently tap them in with a mallet.  I also recommend for maximum stability to anchor this to a wall.  It is pretty easy to do with about $5 of corner braces from your local big box store.In my case I liked the results I got with the first one enough to buy a 2nd one for another shelving need in my basement.  The mistake I made with shelf number 2 is that I assembled it using the included fasteners, which are junk. I ended up splitting some wood by not pre-drilling the holes and the time it takes to pre-drill everything is a huge waste of time vs just shelling out a few bucks for quality construction screws that require no pre-drillling.  If they included decent self-tapping screws and some corner braces at the same or slightly higher price this would get 5 stars from me.

I use this with a Lee turret press.  As with other Lee die sets I have used the dies are of excellent quality.  I have not used the crimping die but have gotten great results with the sizing die and the loading die.  I have loaded up about 500 rounds of 300 BLK in a variety of cartridge configurations with this die with no surprises.  It is also handy for removing the primers from spent cartridge cases using the resizing die, just make sure to give the cartridges a bit of lube first so they don't stick and possibly damage the resizing die.This really offers a good value, good enough that I bought a spare to throw in my "just in case" box of reloading equipment in case a part from this set eventually got damaged and I needed a replacement.  I normally don't do things like that but with the current political climate leveled at gun owners, well, you get the picture.

I was pretty excited to try this out after having read a lot of reviews on grill cleaning products.  When the product arrived I was a bit alarmed to see that they very boldly say on the box that this is only recommended for "newer" grill grates that are less than one year old.  This is pretty disappointing.  How many people feel they need to go and purchase an expensive grill cleaning kit for their grates after just a year of use?  The typical person will be buying this to keep grates that are a few years old and now need some extra attention.In any event I followed the directions and loaded the kit up with the grates (stainless steel) from my huge Weber Summit grill as well as some of the dirtier flavorizer bars (the bars that go over the burners).I rotated everything around so all of it got washed throughout the day in the solution.While the bag is pretty tough, the grates still managed to poke holes in a couple of spots which left me with a bit of a mess to clean up when it was time to remove the grates.  The cleaning material is not toxic so there is no reason you can't do this part over your lawn, etc.When I removed the grates some areas were pretty clean and I was a bit wowed.  Other areas were still quite dirty and even after heavy scrubbing with a wire brush I could not get them completely clean.The flavorizer bars were pretty much wasted with this kit as it did nearly nothing for them.All in all I don't feel that this did a much better job than I could have gotten by putting the grates in a trash bag and throwing a gallon or two of a citrus based degreaser in for several hours.  The biggest beef I have is that there is not nearly enough solution provided in this very expensive kit to clean the grates on a larger sized grill like my Summit.

This is a solid no frills tape measure.  I purchased a few of these in different sizes after a 15 year old Stanley finally croaked (the tape finally broke).  This one has a better coating on the blade and a more solid fit between the tape ledge and the tape itself so I expect this one will actually outlast the previous one.Hard to recommend spending more unless you plan on dropping it on concrete on a weekly basis.

I bought this ball for my son who was 5 months old at the time.  My wife had given the baby a balloon to play with and he absolutely loved it, but I was nervous about the scare he would get when the balloon inevitably popped, so I ordered this ball.The ball arrived in perfect condition.  I saw some comments about the ball being deflated but mine arrived with proper inflation and is still fully inflated aver nearly three months of use.  There is also a traditional port on the ball for adding air, so I don't really see that as being an issue.The ball itself is very colorful and will attract the attention of babies and toddlers.  It is just big enough for a small child to manipulate without being so small that it will get lost under furniture or so big that it is unwieldy.  In short the size is about perfect.My son loves playing with it.  We are teaching him to try to roll it back and forth to us in a floor game version of catch.  He also really laughs when we play "soccer" with the ball by rolling it to him and have him kick the ball by supporting him and having his legs swing out to hit it.This is a solid purchase, at least it should be for most families.

I actually picked this pack up at an Arc'teryx outlet store in Castle Rock Colorado.  I had been looking for the very well reviewed Arc'teryx Altra 65 which they did not carry, but they did have the Altra 50 pack and for an incredible price (about $140 plus tax).I did a quick test fit of the pack in the store and then purchased it with the intention of giving it a full rundown at home.... I'm glad I did the home rundown before removing the tags from the pack as I ultimately returned it.First off, construction quality of this pack appears to be quite good.  The stitching and material construction, as well as materials selected appears to be every bit as good as one would expect from an Arcteryx product.The pack has a pretty innovative feature in which the pack is a top loader but the contents of the main compartment can be accessed from one of two side zippers which means that if you load your pack smartly you can access smaller individual items without having to root through the contents of your pack.  This feature as well as the construction quality is what kept this bag from being a one star product.The shoulder straps and hip belt of this pack are the biggest disappointments.  The shoulder straps are very narrow and lack adjustability... they also have minimal padding.  Totally unacceptable in a pack that should be able to comfortably tote 25-40 lb loads.  Similarly the hip belt is narrow and not adjustable and also quite thin.  I was disappointed (and had not noticed in the store) to discover at home that the hip belt has no pockets.  Instead the pack has a couple of wingman pockets on the sides that are extremely difficult to access while wearing the pack.I loaded the pack with the roughly 20 lbs of gear I would take for a 2-3 night trip and found that I could not get the pack as comfortable as even a 3 year old REI brand pack (which ironically had better shoulder straps and hip belt than this brand new high end Arcteryx pack).  It also doesn't help that the pack lacks a dedicated storage system for a sleeping bag.  You can either wedge your sleeping bag in between the adjustable straps between the pack brain and the pack body or else just stuff it into the main compartment.  Disappointing for a nearly $300 MSRP pack.
