My advice when it comes to electric toothbrushes is to avoid the low-end and the high-end.  somewhere in the middle is the sweet spot.  Get a model that uses the same brush heads as the higher-end models and you will get the same cleaning performance.

Refill it instead.This refill system is very easy to use.  It extends the useful life of your Textsurfer classic highlighter.  This product should be more widely available.  It is a hard to find item.I have refilled three of my highlighters.  All three are working as well as when they were new.

World History 101 for "A Song of Ice and Fire".Yes, if such a college course exists, this would be the required textbook.  This book is the written history of the known lands that are the settings for George R R Martin's epic "A Song of Ice and Fire" (ASOIAF).  This is another must-have reference item for the ASOIAF scholar.  While not a necessity, its contents can only serve to enrich the reading experience for you when "The Winds of Winter" comes out.  The more back story you know, the more realistic and the more immersive the reading experience will become.  Say you have read all of the books up to this point, including this one.  And then the next novel comes out and you read it in the quiet comfort of your favorite room.  All that back story can only help you immerse yourself in the story.  In short, what I am saying is that these supplemental materials are not necessary to enjoy the main novels, however, spending time (and money) reading the back stories will definitely make the journey more engaging for you.  Highly recommended.The history lesson starts at a time period of what is known as the Dawn Age.  Primitive humans lived on the large continent of Essos.  Westeros, at this time, did not have human populations.  Rather, its inhabitants were human-like beings, the giants and the forest-dwelling Children.  A very barbaric, primitive people called the First Men migrated to Westeros from Essos, crossing a narrow land bridge in what is now known as the Step Stones.  Conflict with the Children followed, and lasted for thousands of years.  At some point, the two sides worked out a deal for peace and they coexisted for many centuries.  A more advanced people, the Andals followed, bringing weapons of iron with them.  Meanwhile, in the East, the empire of Valyria slowly rises from the foot of fourteen active volcanoes.  These people would later take technology, magic, science, and warfare to levels of sophistication that were previously unknown.  One powerful Valyrian noble family, the Targaryens, survived the cataclysm that destroyed the great city and made their way to Westeros.  Using the power of their mighty dragons, the Targaryens conquered Westeros and ended the perpetual wars between the kingdoms which comprised the continent.  The Targaryens built great cities, and brought sophisticated knowledge with them from Valyria.The history then details the reign of some of the more notable Targaryen monarchs, ending with King Aerys II.  Aerys is the father of Princess Daenerys, one of the main characters in the current story.  Although, he was actually already dead by the time of her birth, Aerys is  mentioned frequently in the novels.  We also learn more about some of the other major characters in the story, particularly Ser Barristan, Lord Tywin, and Ned Stark.The lesson also takes us to lands that have not been discussed in the novels.  We go East, to the Free Cities, all the way to Asshai. Yi Ti is given a reasonable amount of space.  Volantis and Braavos are discussed in detail.Very interesting, and yet, the scholar needs to bear in mind that some of the material need to be treated with a healthy dose of doubt.  In typical George Martin fashion, bias and other factors affect the history that was recorded.

Is this the best filter carbon available in the aquarium hobby?This could very well be the best filter carbon available to the hobbyist.  The other contender is the Hydrocarbon (Two Little Fishies) brand.  Both are excellent and will do a great job of keeping your aquarium water clear.  The water will always smell fresh and the water will remain clear with regular use of carbon.The key to the effective use of carbon in your filter is to replace it frequently.  You will also want to make sure that you are passing the water through a fine mechanical filter before it goes through the carbon layer.  That way, your carbon will last longer instead of clogging prematurely.  Use only a moderate quantity, but replace frequently.The quantity of carbon that you can use will depend on your filtration system.  Small, box filters will not hold very much carbon.  And the carbon in those systems tend to exhaust (clog) very quickly because the mechanical filter is not every thorough.  Particulates exhaust the carbon prematurely.  Canister filters are your best choice for chemical filtration.  But you can get good results using a HOB box filter if you pay attention to the mechanical filter ahead of the carbon media.I keep mopani wood in the tank for decoration.  This wood releases tannins in the water.  Within a short period of time, this will turn your water yellow.  If you have enough mopani wood in the tank, the water may even turn brown.  The more dense the wood, the longer it will continue to release tannins.  A good quality carbon, like Matrix, can keep your water from turning yellow.  How often the carbon will be exhausted will depend on the factors already mentioned above.  Seachem Matrix and Hydrocarbon are the brands that have been the most effective for me.  The Black Diamond (Marineland) brand also works fine, and it is quite a bit cheaper than the Seachem brand.  The pre-packaged carbon for the Aquaclear filters and the Fluval C series filters work fine, but they exhaust very rapidly.  Even when compared to the same quantity as Seachem Matrix.  In a 20-gallon planted tank, with one medium-sized mopani wood, 1/3 cup of either Seachem Matrix or Two Littles Fishies' Hydrocarbon will keep the water fresh, and clear.  Combined with weekly water changes of 30% to 50%, the water never has a chance to turn yellow.  I replace the carbon in this tank every third or fourth water change.  Basically, that means once every 3 weeks.  Sometimes the interval stretches to 4 weeks.  This tank has a lot of floating plants.  Without the carbon, the water would turn noticeably yellow in a short amount of time.Seachem Matrix or Two Little Fishies' Hydrocarbon?Either one will do an excellent job of keeping your water smelling fresh and crystal clear.  The Hydrocarbon is granular, and the sizes are naturally irregular.  The uniform size and shape of the Matrix is said to aid water flow, but I have not noticed any difference in flow.  Neither one has affected the ph in my tanks.  Neither one has caused an algae bloom.  So far, all they have contributed are positives.  The Seachem Matrix is easier to find in retail stores compared to Hydrocarbon.  As it comes out of the container, Matrix has less dust than Hydrocarbon.  If you are going to use a filter bag, keep in mind that the holes might allow the Matrix to pass through.  To use Matrix, you need a filter media bag that have small holes.  The Matrix has a diameter of approximately 1 mm. You will need a fine media bag to hold this carbon.  The Hydrocarbon will work with any filter media bag.Highly recommended.

Effectively rids your tank of ich.  But you do have to follow directions and not stop the treatment too soon.  Patience is a virtue when it comes to getting rid of ich.There are stronger medications out there that will get rid of ectoparasites.  Copper is stronger than Rid-Ich and will kill even the most resistant of ectoparasites commonly found in the hobby.  However, copper is not for the novice and its use require you to measure copper concentrations in the tank.  So, to use copper, you really need to own a copper test kit.  Long story short, for something like ich, copper is not necessary.  Kordon's Rid-Ich will be more than sufficient for ich.Based on my experience, this product is safe for plants.  Mind you, I can only make this claim based on the plant species in my tank.  Rid-Ich seems to be a fairly gentle treatment that has not had noticeable side-effects in my tanks.  I do not have any scale-less fishes in the tank.  These are said to be sensitive to the active ingredients.Should you raise the water temperature to speed up the lifecycle of the parasite?  That would depend on your fish.  Some species do not like high water temperatures.  Most tropicals should be fine with 77-80 degrees.  At this temperature range, the parasite should complete its life cycle within 7-10 days.  This is important because the parasite is only vulnerable to the medication during certain stages in its life.  You can dose the tank every 24 hours, for 8 days.  Feed sparingly during this time.  You do not want to decrease the water quality during the treatment period by overfeeding.  You can do water changes during the treatment period if necessary, but please keep in mind that doing so will cause temperature fluctuations.  Dose for the actual quantity of water in the tank, as close as you can.  Do not use carbon filtration during the treatment period, as it can remove the medication from the water.  Observe your fish carefully during the treatment period.  The instructions say that you can decrease the time intervals down to 12 hours if the fish show no signs of improvement.  Ich is present in the tank, so even if only one fish is showing the symptops, you still need to dose the entire tank.  Be consistent and be patient during the treatment.At the end of the treatment period, perform your normal water change.  Clean out the filter, replace the filter media, and add fresh carbon.  Slowly decrease the water temperature, if your fish require it.  Observe the fish carefully for the first few days.  If you see signs of the disease again, it means that you have not eradicated the parasite.  You will need to start over.Rid-Ich will not work for leeches, tapeworms, and internal parasites.  For worms and leeches, you can use praziquantel or copper.  I would rate Kordon's Rid-Ich as equally effective as Seachem's Paraguard for ich.  Both are gentle medications for the treatment of ich.  This is not a complicated medication to use.  Raising the water temperature is not even required, although it can accelerate the life cycle of the parasite, thereby shortening treatment duration.  However, should you not wish to raise the temperature, you can still treat ich, it will just take longer.  Do an internet search for ich and its lifecycle.  You should not have any trouble finding a chart that shows how long the lifecycle takes for a given temperature.  Use that to help determine your treatment duration.  You can add an extra day or two, just to be safe.Highly recommended.

Makes the impossible, possible!  Ok, that was a huge exaggeration.  How about this instead:  Seachem Neutral Regulator makes it convenient for those who live in hard-water areas to keep soft-water tropicals.Yes, you can soften the water using reverse osmosis filtration and ion exchange resins.  However, you will still need to adjust the water and make sure that it has enough buffering capacity to maintain a stable ph.  Seachem's Neutral Regulator can soften hard water, if you add enough of it.  However, the best approach for those who live in areas where the water is very, very hard 300+ ppm) is to use a combination of methods.  First, soften the tap water by mixing with R/O water, deionized water, or clean rain water.  Get it soft enough so that you will not have to add a lot of Neutral Regulator.  The advantages to this combination method is that you will not have to add as much of the product, which may help avoid getting cloudy water.  You will also limit the amount of phosphate that you are adding to the tank.  As has been mentioned, this product is a phosphate-based buffer.If you visit online forums dedicated to the hobby, some wise sage will always chime in and say, "don't fight your water, keep fishes that will thrive in your tap water".  I agree.  Very sound advice.  If you live in an area where the water is hard and alkaline, you are setting yourself up for a lot of expense and a lot of work if you decide to keep soft-water fishes like Discus, Rams, and Cardinal Tetras.  However, if you accept  your hard, alkaline tap water and instead decide to keep African Rift Lake Cichlids and Livebearers, you will have a much easier time, as far as water chemistry is concerned.  The problem is, I am not interested in keeping African Rift Lake cichlids.  The fishes that I wish to keep originated from soft, somewhat acidic environments.  Therefore, I have accepted the fact that I will have to fight my hard, alkaline tap water every week in order to maintain the types of fishes that I prefer to keep.  You see, if your tap water is very hard and very alkaline, it will resist adjustment.  In other words, you will just have to be as stubborn as your tap water if you decide that you want to keep soft-water fishes.The method you should use will naturally depend on just how hard your tap water is.  You will also need to know how much buffering capacity it has, the KH.  Usually, the higher the general hardness (GH), the higher the carbonate hardness (KH).  So, let us say that you have decided to fight your tap water.  The first task then is to do some measuring.  Get yourself a test kit and measure the GH, KH, and PH of your tap water.  Knowing these measurements will tell you not only how much work you will have to do, but also the best way to go about it.If your tap water is very hard, over 250ppm, then you will have to add a lot of this product just to get it down to neutral.  Before the water's ph will budge, the buffering capacity will have to be overwhelmed by the phospate.  So, the harder the water is, the more phosphate you will have to add to overcome the resistance.  You might be thinking of going natural and adding peat granules to your filter, to help remove some of the KH.  That will work if the water is only slightly hard, or moderately hard.  But when the water is very hard, you will have to resort to non-natural means to lower hardness and ph.  That means mixing your tap water with softened water, by one of the following ways:  reverse osmosis filtration, ion exchange, and collecting rain water.My suggestion, if this is possible for you, is to collect rain water.  Much cheaper than reverse osmosis and ion exchange.  You can always filter the rain water through carbon if you are afraid of contaminants.  In this way, you will avoid the water waste that is the side effect of using a reverse osmosis filtration system.  And, you will avoid adding sodium to your tank, a side effect of using a typical home water softening system.  Some fish would not mind a little sodium, some do not like it.  If you do not mind the added expense, you can use potassium instead of sodium (salt) to recharge your water softening system.  That would be a better way, for the fish.  After you have gotten the GH down to about 150ppm, then you can use the Seachem Neutral Regulator.  By this time, KH would also have been lowered, so you will only need to use a little bit of the product.While we are on this topic, let us talk about phosphate.  Will phosphate lead to an increase in algae?  Possibly, but let us look at this situation another way.  Do you have algae now?  If the answer is no, then perhaps you will not want to add any phosphate to your tank.  But the likely answer is yes, you do have algae now.  Your water is hard and alkaline.  If you keep plants and have strong lighting, you will most likely have algae.  But phosphate levels are not the only reasons why a fish tank will get algae.  Algae needs very little, in the way of nutrients, to thrive.  Adding more phosphates will not necessarily increase your algae.  By softening the water and decreasing the ph, your plants are likely to thrive.  Most plants prefer slightly soft, neutral water.  By helping your plants grow faster, you might make it harder for algae to compete for nutrients.I have a 20 gallon long, with ram cichlids.  This is a planted tank, with strong lighting.  I use a combination of deionized water and Seachem Neutral Regulator to bring the water down to a reasonable hardness (approx. 100).  This is still somewhat hard, but much better than the 400+ppm that comes out of the tap.  The neutral regulator can maintain ph at 7.0.  Were I interested in breeding the rams, I will have to add more deionized water to the mixture and add a product to lower the ph.  In other words, instead of using the current ratio of DI water to tap water, I will have to increase the portion of DI water.  The use of the neutral regulator has not increased the growth of algae.  I had algae before, and I still get algae now.  It was never out of control before, and it is not out of control now.  The use of floating plants, weekly water changes, frequent replacement of the filter media, and modest feedings keep algae under control.  The plants are able to thrive.  Algae only grows on the glass and the one ceramic ornament in the tank.  Regular use of Flourish Excel helps the plants thrive, but also helps keeps the algae under control.  What I am saying is that the worry that Seachem Neutral Regulator will cause an algae explosion in a tank that was in balance to begin with may not be warranted.

This grill cooks food nicely.  Even though it is an electric grill, the results will be far superior to what you can get out of an electric hot plate.  And while it may not deliver the same taste as a charcoal grill, I do not think you will be dissapointed with the results.Let me admit right now that your steaks will taste better on a charcoal grill.  However, for those who cannot grill with an open fire, this is your best option.  Depending on where you live, you may not be allowed to use a charcoal grill or a gas grill.  Electric will be your only choice.  If you have to go electric, then I highly recommend this.  I have tried grilling with the hot plate types, like the Foreman grills.  While they do cook food faster, they also do not taste as good as the meats cooked on the Char-Broil.I have grilled a lot of steaks and pork chops on this grill, as well as vegetables like zucchini, bell peppers, mushrooms, onions, and squash.  If you grill a lot of high fat foods, you can still get a little bit of flare up, but they only lasts for a short time.  You can compensate for the slight less taste, due to it being an electric, by being creative with your marinade and by basting the meat right before you remove it from the grill.  You can also add wood chips, but I have not tried that.Electrics have a lot of advantages.  You will never have to go out and buy charcoal and starter fluid.  Nor will you have to go out and buy gas.  This makes it convenient for those spontaneous moments when you get the urge to grill something for dinner.  However, please keep in mind this grill is only for outdoor use.  It is not like a hot plate that you can use indoors.  This one will produce a lot of smoke.  And, like I said, you still get the occasional flare up.  And because it is an electric, it should last for many years with very little maintenance.  Unlike a gas grill, this one only needs to be cleaned.  No parts to replace.  Clean out the drip tray from the bottom and clean the grate.  That is all the maintenance it will need.  If you are lazy on maintenance, a gas grill is not for you.  An electric version, like this one, would make better sense for you.The grill grate is hard to clean.  But then again, have you ever had a grill grate that is easy to clean?  Yes, if you clean it immediately after cooking, it will be much easier.  But really, who actually does that?  I mean, most people would want to dive into their steak before it gets cold, right?If you cannot grill with an open flame, this is your best choice.  Highly recommended.

This pair of scissors were designed for use by elementary school age children.  For use in the classroom to cut paper, arts, crafts, and similar items.  The end of the scissors have been rounded off, rather than pointed, for safety.  Even so, you should caution your child to make sure that they handle the device carefully.  To always be mindful of the steel blades.  They can still do some damage to flesh.This is a higher quality product than the scissors that you may typically find in an elementary school classroom.  Most of the scissors for the target consumers will be primarily made of plastic, with just enough steel at the cutting edges.  This one is different in that the blades are completely made of steel.  This cuts better than your average school scissors.I have used this pair on paper goods.  However, most of my use is "off-label" and not what it was originally intended to do.  I use mine to prune aquarium plants.  The stainless steel blades do not rust.Highly recommended.

Sexual gratification, without the commitment, appears to be the lead character's mission.  As the plot unfolds, you realize that there is more to Hemel than something as simple as that.Let's talk about the censored version first.  The censored version is what you get if you bought the streaming media from Amazon.  However, if you buy the DVD, as I did, you will not have to worry about censored content.  This review is about the DVD, the uncensored movie.The movie follows the life of a young lady who pursues sexual gratification for its own sake.  She is not interested in forming relationships with her bed partners.  There is nothing inherently wrong with this, as quite a lot of men do the same thing and are viewed differently under traditional values.  What is fascinating about her is the relationship that she has with her father.  The movie is Dutch, with English subtitles.  However, you do get enough understanding of the story to know that she is in love with her father.  Not necessarily in a sexual way, but definitely is possessive.The reason for the casual sexual encounters is simply to fulfill her needs.  But clearly her heart is not in it, only her genitalia.  In other words, the encounters are simply for sex.  At some point in the story, it becomes clear that the father will be committing to a relationship with his girlfriend.  At that point, Hemel is emotionally upset.  Even to the point of contemplating jumping off the roof of a building.The star of the movie is the beautiful Dutch actress, Hannah Hoekstra.  I reviewed another one of her movies, "App", earlier this year.  While I enjoyed "App" more than I did this one, "Hemel" is still a fascinating movie to watch.Recommended.

Unplug that mouse from your computer, replace it with this Logitech joystick, download the software from IMG, and you are good to go.Yes, you can replace your computer mouse with a joystick.  But you need to get the software to make it work.  There are free software that you can download, but I chose to purchase mine from a company called IMG (Innovation Management Group).  This Logitech Extreme 3D Pro Joystick and the "Joystick-to-Mouse" software from IMG work perfectly together.I got the idea to do this because an acquaintance of mine suffers from arthritis.  The nature of her work include a lot of data entry,as well as document processing.  She has tried "ergonomic" mice, but have not gotten relief.  We bought this Logitech joystick, bought the software, and installed on her workstation.  It has worked wonders for her, but the adjustment is taking a lot of time.  Moving that cursor with a joystick is not as precise for her as with her mice.  It is taking time, but she is slowly adjusting.  I am giving her a break because she is not a video game player.  The idea fascinated me and prompted me to buy the same model of Joystick from Amazon for my own use.  I also purchased the same software, from IMG.  And, I am enjoying the change.What do I like about using a joystick, in place of a mouse?  Well, it is cool.  Very cool to have a joystick on your desk.  I have also programmed a lot of functions on the buttons and controls of the "stick".  All those buttons, 12 in all, can be put to good use.If you have arthritis, this might be worth a try for you.  If you suffer from some kind of physical disability that make the use of a mouse difficult, this could be the ticket.  If you want to be cool, so cool that you use a joystick instead of a mouse, this is it.  The secret here is that excellent software from IMG.  You can call them at 1-800-889-0987, or visit their website at www.joystick-to-mouse.com.My advice to you is to pick a good quality joystick, like this Logitech.  You do not have to spend a lot of money.  You're not buying this to battle an enemy MIG fighter on your monitor!  But you do want good quality.  You will be using this constantly, so precision, quality, and durability are important.And, if you do play games on your comptuter that uses a joystick, this is a good way to learn precision.  As you use the joystick daily, your precision and control will develop nicely.

Mouthwash, for dogs and cats.This is not as effective as brushing your pet's teeth, but it may be a sensible alternative if your dog will not tolerate brushing.  This water additive works like mouthwash.  Basically, you add a measured amount to your pet's bowl each time you add water.  When the pet drinks, Dental Fresh acts like a mouthwash.Dental Fresh does a very good job of keeping tartar under control.  Yes, tartar will still form, but not as fast.  You should use this product all of the time.  A side benefit is that it will keep the water in the bowl fresh.  If you have a messy dog that drops food particles in his water, then you will still need to change the water out daily.  Dental Fresh can extend the water's freshness if your dog is not too messy in his dining habits.Cats tend to be picky about their water.  I have known cat owners who say that their cats do not like anything added to their water.  Dental Fresh smells faintly like chlorine.  Perhaps some cats will be turned off by that.  In this case, use a product that is added to the food, instead of the water.  Food can hide the smell of the chemical.  There is a brand called "Petsafe Indigo Dental Sauce" that works really well.  I reviewed one earlier this week, for Amazon.  That should be your choice, if your dog or cat refuses to drink water that was treated with "Dental Fresh".  My dog will readily lick "Petsafe Indigo Dental Sauce" from the bottom of his food dish, without the need to tempt him with food.

It works fine.  This product works fine, but it is not as useful as the water additive types like Dental Fresh.This is an effective product that is easy to use.  Your dog will accept this without any resistance due to the fact that it is added to the food.  Naturally, how appealing the dog food is to begin with, will determine how easily your dog will accept this product.  You can, if you wish, put this on a slab of beef and you are guaranteed not to get any resistance from your dog.  Pour it on dry kibble and your dog might ignore it completely.This "dental sauce" works to help prevent tartar build up on your dog's teeth.  Most dogs are very resistant to having their teeth brushed.  If your dog resists regular teeth brushing, then this is the next best thing, along with regular dental checkups from the Vet.  To use this, please follow the directions on the container.  Using too much may cause a stomach upset.While this product is effective and easy to use,  my preference is to use a water additive.  A water additive not only will help keep your pet's teeth clean, but it will also keep his water bowl clean.  A product like Dental Fresh, added to the water bowl, keeps the water clean while keeping your dog's breath fresh.  However, some dogs are very sensitive to the taste and the smell of their drinking water.  They may not drink, or rather drink sparingly, if they can taste "doggie mouthwash" in their water bowl.  Yes, they may avoid the water bowl and drink from the toilet bowl instead!  Which is the last thing you want.  In that case, use a product like PetSafe Indigo Dental Sauce instead.  In other words, your pet is more likely to accept this Petsafe Indigo Dental Sauce when compared to water additives like "Dental Fresh".

It is hard to review a book that is designed to help the reader "self-improve", become more effective, and happier.  Ultimately, the true test of the material is to evaluate its effects on the reader's life.  That's not really practical, since influences outside the book, reader compliance with the advice, and time make such an evaluation almost impossible.  As far as book reviews, it would not be a long enough period, the review period, to evaluate at how effective the material is at changing the reader's life.  However, we can take a look at some of the core principles in the book.Here, to manifest, means to make happen.  To have an idea, to have a goal, a desired outcome, and turn that into reality.  The book takes a spiritual approach to helping the audience achieve, or manifest, their desired outcomes.  However, if you can see beyond the spiritual, which is probably not the intention of the authors, there are some very practical ideas here.  I will cover one of those ideas.  The idea that the way we react, the way we respond to situations can either help us "manifest" or prevent us.  Our past experiences have created in us an automatic response, knee-jerk if you will, that sometimes can sabotage our efforts to manifest our goals and desires.  One of the first things that the authors do is to help you relieve yourself of that burden, and instead learn to reflect and respond in ways that will help you, rather than hinder you, in manifesting your desires.  In other words, to get that weight off your back, so that you can find a better response, a more appropriate response to the situations that you may face.Another principle discussed here is to find what it is that you truly want.  To peel away expectations and practical concerns to discover what it is that you really want.  Your life mission, your soul's mission, that is.  Knowing that will then help you take steps to try to achieve that.

Historical fantasy?  Is that the best way to describe what this tv movie is about?  In any case, this is an adaption of Kate Mosse's book of the same name.  It is a medieval fantasy, with a twist.  It is a story of two women, separated by time.  Alais, living in southern France over 800 years ago, becomes the guardian of the Grail.  Meanwhile, in the present day, Alice Turner is a teacher on holiday in the same location.  Alice is a volunteer at an archaeological site near the walled city of Carcassone.  The story centers on the Grail, all wrapped up within the bigger story of what happened to the Cathars as they were purged from the city.  In the present day, two powerful factions are on a race to find the Grail.The movie seamlessly switch from one time period to another, giving the impression that the events are all occurring simultaneously, rather than separated by 800 years.  The production quality is very high.  And the acting from the major characters are all great, coming from a terrific young cast.Jessica Brown-Findlay plays Alais, while Vanessa Kirby plays Alice.  John Hurt, Tom Felton, Katie McGrath, and Sebastian Stan play major roles.  John Lynch, Emun Elliott, and Tony Curran round out the excellent cast.The plot unfolds slowly at first.  This may bore some viewers.  However, your patience will be rewarded with some good action scenes.  The fight choreography in the movie was of good quality.  Both Ms. Brown-Findlay and Ms. McGrath have nude scenes.  And the castle town of Carcassone is quite a sight to behold, even on film.Will Alice Turner discover the secrets of the Grail, as well as its current location, before it falls in the wrong hands?  One faction wants to harness its power for wealth and profits.  While another would like to destroy it and its secrets forever.Highly recommended.

This is more of a solid 3.5 but I am giving it a four because I do think Rothschild attempts and mostly succeeds at telling a story that is original and engaging.However it does have flaws.First I felt it dragged a bit.  The author really does a great job to get the book going.  The narrative parts by the painting at first seemed to try a bit too hard.  But after a few chapters it ends up working as it weaves in with all the various points of view we are given.  And those various points of view present another problem.  One they don't help in tightening the story.  Two, some are mere glimpses and I think the author could have winnowed a few out and simply used a longer point of view of lesser characters.  Three, this may sound odd, but the lesser characters turn out to be more engaging and interesting and move the story better than the main character.  And since the main character gets more and longer sections, the compare works against the book as a whole for me.While Annie comes alive when she is devoted to her food, the book ultimately is about art.  And here, she seems petulant, too nebulous and too often uninteresting.  In fact there are times the author has her act in ways that seem almost completely disjointed by what is happening.  She is abrupt and even irrational.  She never seems to be fully fleshed as a person and instead becomes an odd reaction (odd in that she moves the plot but does not do so in a reason that seemed plausible to me -- she reacts to one person as odd or comes off as strangely judgemental and works off that when there seems to be no reason for her to do so).In fact by the end, the main character was the most annoying thing about the book.  The rest works wonderfully.  But it is hard to overlook the flawed presentation of Annie.  And taking a stab at why.  For me it felt that Annie is simply there to set things up.  And because she is so flat for me, this drags the book out.  Makes it seem over long.  To try and explain with a bit of clarity, I will give an example -- not a quote, but the sense of how I felt this played out.  Annie would engage with an art expert.  Annie is not an art expert.  She is adrift and rather meandering.  But this picture has brought her into this world.  Aimless the character still gives me the sense of impatience.  Of being put upon.  And reacts in terse and almost scornful ways to people that are simply trying to help her.  And despite being a novice to the art world, again and again, the author shows this character engaged through her cooking with art.  So it made no sense.  But her attitude helps drag things out.  Keep her from taking the next step.Last, I felt that there were interesting elements that came together, but in the end the various threads were just a bit too thick on their own.  The provenance of the painting got in the way of finding out the provenance of the painting.  Rebecca on her own would have been an interesting story.  Annie, written with a bit more nuance and complexity, discovering the history of the painting on her own would have been interesting.  As it was though they were written as too large on their own to share the stage successfully as it were.  Instead of  weaving together they tangled.Still, this was a book I read start to finish and had nothing else distract me or lure me away.  I really liked some of the characters and their disparate stories that slowly came together.  In the end the main character should have been given the same level of charm for good or ill as the rest of supporting cast and this could have been a true 4+ star review.

As a compendium of beekeeping as recorded in Ancient Egypt this gets four stars.  But as a read?  It is just too dry.  And that is sad since the author's interest and expertise come through here and there.  Amid what is nothing more, too often, of list after list of tomb inscriptions and records, there is some wonderful writing by Kritsky that underscores the enthusiasm that prompted such a book.  But for me it was mere sentences.  Maybe a paragraph at most.  And then the return to rote citation.  And that is a disappointment.  Particularly at a time when the importance of bees and their place in the environment still gets ignored at our peril.  Getting a glimpse of how long and how important bees have been in one of the oldest and most enduring civilizations that impacted the rest of the world and its growth was fantastic.  Unfortunately I just feel we barely get even a  glimpse through an expert's eyes. Maybe a hint instead; it almost felt more like I was reading a great book's bibliography and notes.

I feel a bit too 'meh' on this one.  Do we really need another book to plumb the fictional depths of how WWI changed so much for so many?  Maybe.  This wasn't the one for me though.  It seemed way too been there and done that.  And what made this worse instead of mitigating it, was that Clark has a nice way with words.  To put it simply.  Her descriptions and sense of setting in the time are wonderful.  But instead of making this a better read, it underscores, for me, how flat everything else is.There is almost a paint by the numbers approach.  Great house, female characters who struggle with the limitations of the time and culture, change, looming war, change, looming doom, change.The one factor that might have saved this was a set of compelling and engaging characters.  They didn't have to be likable, just interesting.  And here I found another letdown.  Flat and unappealing in part and simply trite in the other.This isn't a horrible book.  And if I wanted to simply settle down into yet another book for the sake of familiar I might have been inclined to give it a higher rating.  However this is not a period that I think deserves workable and yet pedestrian approaches.  It needs something brilliant to set it apart and make it worthwhile.  And sadly I did not find that here.

I wanted to like this.  As anyone who has gone through terminal illness in the family, there is one part identification warring perhaps with the personal "ownership" each of us has.  Making us irrationally possessive of the experiences and insights.  Basically it is coping and grief.  Don't believe me?  Bring up whatever terminal illness experience you have to someone and I guarantee you will get one or more back.  Unasked.  Which I just did in a kind of round about way.So I do think in some cases if identification isn't immediate or overwhelming, it is easy to get a little irate at times. It is easy to let little things bother you.  The same could be said when the tone and style is such/And that is the case here.  I truly appreciate the candor the author explores.  I just wish he and his editor have worked a bit on the sincerity.  In no way am I saying he never felt the things he is describing.  Sometimes funny sometimes profound and mostly poignant.  But he just tries too hard in his writing for me.  Way too hard.  It is overly glib in a manner when he clearly is trying to illustrate the whole "before" aspect.  And how shocking and funny and edgy and outrageous and irreverent he and his family were.  It comes off to me a bit of a, dare I say, humblebrag?  It is like "look at how awful this series of events we were handed and yet isn't it outrageous how we were still able to be such outrageous people who didn't do the "normal" thing and just be outrageous?!?!?Again I get it,  I have giggled in funeral homes and while absently rubbing the fine but startling copious amounts of hair off my arms post-chemo told a telemarketer over the phone that unless she had a cure for my illness that had me bent over a toilet for hours, I wasn't interested.  And if she didn't believe me I would put the phone on speaker next time I was in the same situation in a few minutes.  Thing is i do understand I am looking into his situation.  His grief.  His coping.  And there were plenty of moments  when I did smile and relate and be incredibly overwhelmed at my safe remove that whatever tragedy I have experienced, even if I felt it equal, was not the same.But I felt all the good was too over shadowed by what I felt was the deliberate attempt to tell the story in a certain way.  A way I felt deprived the story of the authenticity that could have come through the whole book.  Instead the arc felt scripted.  The arc from over privileged and obtuse self-involved family who relies on the underlying truth of loving family being conveniently camouflaged by wry and witty and slightly bitter facade.  To get pulled back and the true depths explored.  Yes it was real.  But it still felt like a bad holiday movie coming to a theater near you.Again though.  I am not discounting the experiences given here.  Simply the style in which they were presented to me as a reader.

I was a bit disappointed in this.  I did not want a thoroughly modernized take on the story of David, but I was hoping for something a bit richer.  Something that made him the main character of a novel rather than an almost detached recounting of his story as I remember it from the Bible.David seems too removed with another as a narrator.  He ends up lacking the complexity that is arguably one of the most interesting in the Bible.  David was the epitome of the warrior king who basically saves his own culture and expands it.  War was such a defining point of his life; playing the role of shaping his character and shaping his relationships.  The flip side being how a man of culture he turns out to be win war is no longer the main role he pursues.And yet that all falls a bit flat with the remove that the author employs.  Lots of tell and not much show is almost criminal in such a book.  Delving into the nature of a man who perseveres over many chances of betrayal only to commit his own later on in the name of love is a fascinating dichotomy that should encourage an author to peel back the layers and even indulge a bit in fictional exercise.  But I felt that not only did that not happen, but Brooks is deliberate in that regard.  Making for a dull main subject and a slow story in what is actually a rather short novel

What makes for hilarity is to tap into the most absurd of the everyday.  And this is captured so well in this collection of Reza Faramand's book here.  I laughed out loud plenty of times in a short read.  It is pictures after all...but not all pictures.  There is a great section with the author that is just as funny and sharp.But this is the type of book that if it does not make you laugh, even silently, there is something wrong.  With it.  You are fine.  I'm sure....really I am.With an almost bitter insight that can be scathing, the everyday is turned on its head and given a good shaking.  Just in case I was not clear enough bitter and scathing are definitely in my wheelhouse.This is a book you will read more than once.  Plus if you own it you can leave it out for others to see and check out.  And either share in its wit or provide you with plenty of superior feeling scorn at the other person's lack.  Either because you hated it and can feel smug seeing them enjoy it.  Or vice versa.  In either case there are plenty of ways to enjoy this book.

This is not some brilliant book that will redefine its genre.  And I find that the prose can sometimes be a little too affected.  The dialogue trying a bit too hard to be wry and witty.That said, this is a fun book.  It is also a book that I felt needed the first one under the belt to enjoy.  Steinmetz takes his creation and characters and expands immensely.  With a pace that is driving and absorbing at the same time.  Detail does not get in the way of the story itself and the plot is nicely padded out by the author's imaginative elements.I do find that overall the storytelling is rather linear and singular.  One event piles on top of the other in a sequence that can seem, well, too much of a sequence.  Except that I do not mean this to be a criticism.  This is simply that type of book for me.  And it seemed deliberate and written in a way that brings out the positive aspects of that type of story.  It provides a wonderfully realized setting and world and yet also keeps a pace that is nicely compelling.  Motivations are kept simplistic and well defined in a way.  Somehow this manages to be a nicely complex tale and yet doesn't get in its own way by being too convoluted.  I guess Steinmetz is more of an author that builds on his previous elements more than say, another author who tries to weave elements together in the moment but leaves much of the thread yet unresolved.  Either done well, work to produce good solid greatly entertaining fiction. And that is definitely the case here.

I was severely underwhelmed.  And then disappointed.  I so wanted this to be my fall book.  The one I huddle down for a weekend, eat food right out the container while devouring this and then wondering how long I have been sitting in that position.Instead?  Instead after a hundred pages or so the book becomes plodding.  And I know some of that is on me.  I'm not rooting for Strike and robin to get together.  Sad to say I'm not a teenager anymore.  I can see a male and a female related to one another get to know one another and not immediately start writing their names together in my Trapper Keeper.  I was hoping Rowling was now smart and experienced enough to realize how dull and trite and simply boring having the whole "will they won't they' aspect take such center stage. Then again I remember how cloying and incredibly bad her writing was in the Harry Potter books as she wallowed in wish fulfillment school girl romantic fantasies.  And I realized it could get worse.  in fact with her twist on the matter I suspect it will.  Get very very worse.Another thing that stood out and basically hit me over the head as to how plodding and bloated and directionless this was, was when she dragged out yet another character drenched in Rowling's gleeful self-absorbed accent beleaguered dialogue.  I suspect many love this.  I find it silly and over affected.  Telling a story should be first and foremost.  This silly amount of gee gaw on her part goes to an extreme in this entry.  I know she has done it in the past two books and Harry Potter had its hare.  But anything that is deliberately obstructionist seems to go against simple story telling rules.  It adds nothing for me.  And if she dropped it and spent some time on an actual compelling plot in this one, I would have been thrilled.Because that was a huge problem for me here.  The book's plot was incredibly thin.  In good part because it centered more on Strike and Robin.  In the crime way.  It was too involving at this point and combined with their personal humdrum but overly detailed personal lives stole the heart and soul out of it for me.  Why she also thought it was cute to drag out the suspects as she did is beyond me.  Past page 400 and I just wanted it over.  I did not care who did it.  I did not care if Robin or Strike was in danger.  I did not care.  To find myself thinking that in a Rowling/Galbraith book only third entry in the series and I find that almost heartbreaking when I think how much I loved the first two.And then the harebrained idea of writing the criminal's pov?  In such a trite way?  Trying to imbue tension suspense with such heavy handed brutality that is almost inhumanely rote in her telling?  For me it did not make me want him to be caught.  To get his comeuppance.  All I could think was psst.  hey Jennifer?  Or is it Jenny?  Put down the flat gratuitous violence and just write some great story why don't you?  Shock doesn't work in this kind of book.Did anyone who likes to get a little sloshed (safely of course) think about taking a shot every time the villain is almost seen but something catches Robin or Strike's eye?  Are dead or in an alcohol induced coma yet?And this is not a spoiler.  Not even for the events in this book let alone any next.  But all I can say is Matthew might as well start wearing red shirts.  Nothing but red shirts.  I hope I am wrong.  Not because i like the character of Matthew.  I don't.  In fact I find Robin's relationship with him completely implausible at this point.  And Rowling shows how little she has not grown in the fact that she cannot for the life of her add any nuance or facet that would suggest he is nothing but a flat trope to the series and will add nothing but being the main obstacle to yet 'well they won't they'  more silliness.  Because a main male character and a main female character have to get together.  Or at least have that be one of the main constant themes.  Because that has always worked so well for any series in pop culture.

On first read I thought this was a bit like the Russian nesting dolls.  A thought that as soon as I had it was trite and a bit too easy (and not just considering the title and the intertwined stories).So rewind (slight nod to the cover image).  Instead it is like a set of Legos.  not kidding.  And not trying to be glib or clever.  But rather there is a wonderful sense of these stories interlocking.  And building something.  Laying a foundation for the next story to expand and enrich and touch on in some way.  Sometimes predictable (and yet rewarding) and sometimes surprising.  And even surprising in that what weaves through I found surprising.  Making me ask and wonder why such was a surprise.Marra has a wonderful stlye but I do think it is somewhat unique.  I will say that anyone who sets this aside after only one story/segment is cheating himself.  That is not to say that every reader should love this or even like it.  But the effort (and for me it was a clear execution) of Marra in crafting this whole book would be missed and the reading experience wasted.  There is a small quiet precision to each story that makes the whole a wonderful read.

Three stars may seem like I don't like this.  Or I don't like it enough.That would be wrong.  But also might be my fault if I don't succeed in explaining myself.  Or even if I do!Hurley has always been a tough read for me.  Both her science fiction trilogy (and the short works associated with that) and this ongoing series) bear a style that simply is more work for me than I care to take on most days.  Some days I do.  Which is why I want to say that I don't dislike this series.  Or rather this book.  But simply that try as I might I find the style is a detraction not a plus.And yet here, even more than her previous works, the aspect of Hurley I like is front and center.  She has created a world (more than one but here I mean the plane of setting if you will) that is frightening.  Rich.  Surprising.  Exotically intriguing. Complex.  All things I love.  Yet in her hands it is not only a set of compelling elements, it also seems to get in the way sometimes.  To the point I have to struggle to stay engaged.  There is just something here that does not grab hold of me without something else a few pages later losing me.In the end I finished and was glad I did.  Hurley's plots and ideas are unique and intriguing.  Her prose though is dense and while it does not meander, I do think it twists on itself in ways I just do not care for.  Kay Kenyon's series The Entire and the Rose (I hope I got that right) started the same way and I ended up loving it.  I just think this is one of those works that I keep trying to connect with and keep missing by a small and frustrating margin.  Great enough to want the next work in hopes it does.  Selfish enough to dread pushing myself to reading another big novel and feeling the same level of slight disappointment I felt finishing this.It is definitely one of those books where I strongly feel the number of stars is solely a matter of my taste and less some other reviews where I felt my taste was a broader and more general regard.  Not (or not as much for me) for me does not mean it isn't for a different and quite well be broader audience.

I'm bumping this up a star (or a half star I guess) because I am a David Wong fan.  Not out of charity but because as a fan I think the book delivers most of what I want from David Wong.  His wit and funny slant on things.  His pop culture references that are sometimes almost lovingly awkward.  And often as not darkly funny.  His love of action scenes that translates into wacky and yet thrilling moments I found myself emerging almost dazed pages later.So David Wong gave me many elements of what I want from a David Wong book.However I will say that this is not the tight and gripping read his other two books were for me.  In between those great moments are not almost just as great moments.  I felt that it did not have the smooth background richness the other two books did.  The simple patter between characters never comes alive either.  So it felt more like a great fan fiction of a David Wong feeling book almost.  Or maybe the early rawer work that gets dusted off and published after an author becomes established.Overall i liked the book.  Overall though I felt there was something missing.  More than just the flow of the other two novels, more than just the smaller but just as important connective elements Wong has shown in the past.  But perhaps the deeper and more complete sense of what and where the author wants to take the reader.  John Dies At the End was such a departure for me and it never let up.  Instead the intensity of the read grew right to the end.  In This Book is Full of Spiders... I had a book that was building off the first.  And it had a smoother storytelling effort than John...This seems more like going back to the drawing board.  Yet it lacks the explosive verve of John... and it never gains the height of storytelling the two books achieve in terms of setting.I'm glad a I read it. Wong does things I see others try and just not quite pull off.  He still manages that here if in a more tepid fashion.  I just want the third book to John Dies... Not just because I feel slightly let down by this, but because it also strongly reminds me of what Wong CAN do.

This is an extreme case of an imagination running full throttle.  And in some regards it produces some wonderfully realized aspects of storytelling.  In others it produces some over affected and slightly over indulgent exercises in style over substance.I am not keen on works that I feel let the style get in the way of telling a story.  So some of the oblique aspects in telling the story here simply did not work for me.  I hate to use the words gimmicks, but they did seem to be that.  As in look at what I can do/am doing that never really, when completely pared down, added to the story itself or felt intrinsic in any way.  While the story itself ended up being quite engaging.  And despite a slight feeling that some of the characters' eccentricities were a bit heavy handed, overall I was entertained and drawn in by them.But in the end I felt that the determination by the author to produce something different got in the way of delivering something as good as it could be.  I felt there was too much sacrifice on the part of simply fleshing out a good strong narrative that flowed and communicated clearly to me, the reader.There are those that will go into more detail about what the book is about.  I won't because I feel the blurb sums it up pretty much and too much more exposition gets into some spoiler-ish territory.  This is a book that if the style of it is something you immediately find appealing, you will want to explore the story on your own with the slight but telling twists and the author's verve in crafting and delivering his characters and their plot.It took a little too much effort in the end to finish a book I was really hoping would be better.  I was kind of hoping this would be the next step in story telling that Nick Bantock's Griffin and Sabine books were.  Using some clever and witty visual elements mixed with straight old old fashioned prose.  It almost was.  But one got in the way of the other.  I'm just not quite sure which I would have preferred in the end.  Which isn't the slam it might seem.  But it also isn't the verdict an author who wants to take up permanent space on my book shelves wants to hear.

Interesting and yet a bit dry.  Not too long ago I read a book about the go-between's for Hitler.  A look at the various members of royalty and nobility who used their familial ties to the royal house of Great Britain to try and sway politics and make inroads into British involvement in mainland Europe's affairs.  So it was with some interest I delved into this.For those who know at most how WWI was the war between cousins (prosaically speaking), this is a nice overview of just how German the British royal family is.  Well was.  Well still is if you are looking at the DNA that makes up Britain's greatest tourist attraction (among other things less glib of course).  Palmer breaks down generation after generation of marriages with the various German houses that span petty princedoms and sweeping empires.It does get a bit too dry and the prose falters slightly.  I think part of the flaw for me was that it was treading too familiar ground in a way that was not fresh or engaging simply because it was telling me what I already knew.  For those less knowledgeable I think it might be more engaging.The other problem I had was that it seemed a large part of the book unnecessarily dwells on the relationships that precede the Hanoverians.  Yes, I do think some background is needed.  But there are some odd skips even as I felt it dwelt too long on the period of the Stuarts.  While it may outrage many, the thing is is that during the time the lines between the houses of Nassau and Oldenburg from their German counterparts was not as defined.  In some ways they were almost as "German" in regard to how they were intermarried into the Stuart dynasty.  By this I mean the overall theme of the Anglo-German royal connection.  Of course in many regards they weren't.  But I felt the author overlooked a small but key point in the introducing chapters dealing with the Stuarts that carried over into the Hanoverians.  and how the Dutch and Danish ties reflected the overall dynastic knot that became 17th, 18th and 19th century Western Europe then going into the 20th century and two world wars.But overall a decent read and a nice overlook of royal marriages and a ruling house's familial culture.

Strong solid look at Hannibal which I found engaging and well written.Bradford is not unbiased in how he looks at Hannibal.  There is both a strong current of looking at Hannibal through the Romans' eyes.  I.e. the winners. but he also goes in the opposite direction at times which feels slightly forced and yet at the same time provides a nice balance.As a devotee of Republican Rome, this is not a huge leap from classical sources many such as myself will find already familiar.  However it provides a wonderfully tight readable narrative for those looking to expand their general knowledge beyond elephants over the Alps.  Giving a broader sense of what the world looked like at the time, how this man fit in that world and how he changed it.  All nicely written in a way that takes you past the drier classical sources with a polished flow to the narrative I found engaging through out my read,

The dues of fashion are presented here by Alison Matthews David in a fun and detailed look at how much people are willing to sacrifice for looking good.  Most often without ever realizing the hazards they were incurring.This is a fun read even if you are not a fashion buff.  I'm not really and had a great time reading this.  Short and yet fully detailed, the narrative is fun and engrossing to provide a rather quick read.  Yet one that is never slight.If you never fail to tune into a season of Project Runway or look forward to the red carpet season.  If you find historical fashion or even just historical trends and behaviors fun?  This is your book.  And chances are, this is fun even for those who scoff at such matters.

To borrow slightly from others, I found this both an event and a read.  An event in that it is almost mind boggling all the disparate story lines and approaches there are to the DC overall myth/legend/universe.  To be frank I'm not sure I know enough of it to actually appreciate how much this collection spans.Story wise I was even confused at certain points.  So I can't give it all the analysis perhaps it deserves.What I did like, and I think in such a vast work, there is something for every DC universe fan, was the background and reference work.  Not just as an expository element but simply as a look into the creative process of the whole thing.  Revealing a wonderful gamut of style and story building process.  And, for me, a nice touch of humor as it worked in the ideas of comics into a comic.I also really liked the different approaches to story that also paid homage to different eras and different takes on stories that have remained the same and yet always tried to deliver a fresh slant in so many ways.My favorite art was definitely Jim Lee's segment.  His use of lines is always so nicely real and yet wonderfully accentuated to convey the wonder of it all for me.  And he did not disappoint.  But there are many other pieces of art that either bring the overall story to vivid life or carefully explore a trope tied to past eras or certain explorations of the DC universe.  For fans deeply immersed in the DC culture, I'm not sure where this fits.  But for me, and I think fans in general of DC, this is a treasure trove that I think might surprise on some point but will deliver in the end.

I was introduced to David Rakoff via his appearances on the Daily Show.  His dry morbid wit and look at life was hilarious engaging and sometimes a bit disturbing.  Disturbing in the way he find the surface humor immediately but it might take a second to capture the underlying bitterness.  What made his wit and humor work so well, is that underneath much of the apparent bitterness was a sense of humor that was often surprisingly warm.Here is a wonderful collection of his work that is a must for fans.  It is also a nicely disparate array of his talent that readers new to Rakoff will likely find something to enjoy and appreciate and savor.  I had read his last work which is odd and brilliant.  Short succinct it begs re-reading.  Much of the other work here is the same.  But wonderfully different.  Rakoff always has a distinct biting voice that somehow tricks me with a seemingly lazy facade.  It sneaks up on you, I think and lingers.For a life cut too short, this is a wonderful gift to fans and a gem waiting to be discovered by a new audience for something that can deliver both a bite and a stroke along the cheek.  Often at the same time.  Life is richer with Rakoff even if he often seems to tear it apart.

I vary on Mitchell.  Black Swan Green is still my favorite of his works.  And Cloud Atlas my least.  So that gives everyone else a starting point I guess for where to file this.Slade House is not Mitchell at his best.  But it is still a fine work that in many ways is very much a David Mitchell novel. There is plenty of weirdness.  Both of the slightly off kilter kind that fits in with a wonderfully creepy ghost story/haunted house novel and of the outright weird but completely rational approach Mitchell employs to define and explain other worldly nature of his tale.Short, gripping, the tale spreads out over a span of years with varying points of view that connect through the titular eerie abode.Mitchell delivers each segment of the story in a way that even as certain elements are predictable they are no less affecting.  This is a perfectly timed release for the season that almost demands grim chill weather if not after dark reading.  Mix in the atmospheric clatter of leaves in a strong sudden wind and you have just the right mix of reading experience to creep yourself out and deliver something layered and complex beyond just scaring yourself silly.

I loved this book in small bites.  I found if I read more than one segment/chapter back to back, I found it too preachy and lost momentum.I should say that Theroux has always been slightly too weighty in prose.  Many (or even most) readers find his descriptive powers to be amazing and his works must reads.  I have to say up front that is not the case for me.  My tastes, good or ill, run otherwise.  Here, as in hin other works, I just find his prose lacks a crisp clarity.  Yes it can be powerfully descriptive.  But at the heart perhaps it taps into insecurities and issues that I should be paying hundreds an hour to unlock.  Or in simpler terms I just feel that I am reading the words of someone who thinks and wants everyone else realize, is the smartest person in the room.  I am too strong a believer, right or wrong, that books should be a form of communication.  And here I feel that Theroux often seeks to write to a singular audience.  Instead of trying to convey his ideas to a wide one, there is almost a style that speaks towards a clique if you will.  Those conversations you hear that exclude anyone but a subset of people in that group.  In some ways the oblique style of structure and use of certain words is the literary equivalent of sitting on the edge of a conversation that taps into nothing but common ties for a few.Not sure if that makes sense to anyone but myself, but I prefer books that might challenge me but not in a way I feel wants me to fail.  Or feel like I just can't quite keep up.I also did not care for some of the heavy handed too singular views on the whole idea of fixing problems closer to home.  There seemed too much emphasis on giving money to "there" instead of "here" that didn't address the fact that if you look close enough you realize amid the waste and greed and corruption, there is more than plenty in a capitalistic world economy for both 'here' and 'there'.  Many of Theroux' observations I found myself agreeing with and then following with a "but....".  Which was frustrating as it went along since some of it was so strongly a black and white issue in his regard but not be me.So why four stars?  Because it does capture a moment that lingers despite the irrationality of the matter.  Because it captures again and again a segment of life and society that is either romanticized or simply ignored.  And it all has ties and binds to the rest of us that I think we simply do not get in a way.  It takes someone to explore it and do so as both an outsider and someone who gets his foot in the door so speak.  It takes time and consideration.  And while I don't always care for the manner of delivery, I do greatly appreciate here, Theroux' consideration on the matter.  It is thoughtful and deliberate and I never feel like it is not explored with the care and a certain respectful elegance that never loses sight of what it means socially and culturally for the subject matter and the subtle but complete way it speaks to all of us.

This is one of those probing looks at a current matter (or recent matter) that leave me almost stunned that I live in the 21st century.  At the heart of the matters of politics, faith and culture (and gender too) is that such inhumanity still arises and does so in a fast and wide spread affecting manner.  Warrick captures what should terrify (without panicking or lashing out thoughtlessly) us about ISIS even as in Black Flags, we get an already Gordian Knot of misinformation and knee jerk grandstanding on the organization and the overall matter.  Which is probably why I use the word terrify.  Warrick doesn't just delve into the whys and wherefores of who and how and what ISIS is.  But does so in a way that shows some of the clear factors in their rise.Warrick balances well most of the factors within the geographical culture as well as the outside impositions.  Whatever agenda is behind the book, it does not interfere with ( rather dense at the start) the concise and quickly gripping account of how and what this organization came to be.  It also captures the nebulous "lightning in a jar" sequence of events and moves that make ISIS so successful now and yet underscore how nebulous in turn their power might be.  And as Warrick seems to perfectly understand, as bad as ISIS is, in five or ten years what will fill a void ISIS creates if they are removed?  Or simply become mitigated by their own extremities?  Warrick hits the target here for me because the area itself is not something we can flip a switch and make better.  Because better is hampered in so many ways by our own mindsets and culturally formed ideas.  With an upcoming election that will likely hit on this in some way as a trigger point, Warrick's study becomes all the more compelling since it makes an effort, and mostly succeeds, at pulling back the rhetorical rock and seeing what scurries out of the light.  Something I think politicians either won't or simply can't do.  Even as they try to use the matter for their own self-interest.What makes this such an engaging read, for me, was that even when I did not agree with a few points that Warrick makes, the assertions are not a black and white matter.  And that is captured perfectly here.

Higgins delivers a solid read that has a few flaws but much to otherwise recommend it.What it has working for it is a seamless match of science fiction and mystery.  The plot is engaging and the science I found plausible and did not drag the plot down at all.  I say this with a bumper sticker on my car that reads "All the Science I know, I learned from the Big Bang Theory'.  Okay that is a lie.  But it gives anyone who cares a sense of where I am on science in science fiction.  An author would have to go really far to disrupt what I believe could be possible in a fictional framework if he or she abides by the parameters set in the book.  So for those with a much stronger scientific background and a need for plausibility, I am afraid I can't help you.  For me it works.  The rules are made, make sense as presented and don't vary in some sort of attempt to save a plot hole.The mystery is less strong, but I found that did not matter much.  It still kept up its end so to speak if it let is end dip a little.What I found could be off-putting is that the style of writing seems to be a bit flat and even bland at times.  For a short novel, I found the pace to lack a stronger level of engagement.  There lacks the driving suspense that would have made this a top notch thriller.  Still I am definitely going to check out the next book to see where the author goes.

I'm not a huge Atwood fan.  That probably makes me a bit of an odd reviewer of this in some ways.  As always with any Atwood I have read, it immediately grabs just a few pages in at most and then putters.  Emotionally.  Grim, bleak and threatening (this is not ALL Atwood novels I have read, just most), it seems almost too deliberate and flattens any suspense.  It is like going into a teen horror movie and trying to pick which character to be emotionally invested in.  Turning out, none being your best bet.Atwood is a stellar writer.  And this is how and why she is able to draw me in and cause such an affect right away.  And she does that here.  What is even more interesting is somehow I don't like Stan or Charmaine.  I don't dislike them.  But I just find them disquieting and Atwood somehow takes this bleeding heart and in a chapter makes Stan and Charmaine those "other people".  People you immediately see as being much less fortunate.  People in need but not needing.  The people who might drop money in a hat or jar for but want to move on immediately.Because what Atwood captures so vividly and yet in a quiet nuanced manner, is the deeply affecting sense that so many of us have.  That misfortune is contagious.  That it sucks in people who try to alleviate it.  This is a myth.  But it is so compelling and Atwood simply gets it here.And in typical Atwood fashion there are moments that, while not laugh out loud funny, are still worth a silent chuckle and plenty of appreciation of the plausibly absurd.  Her deft ability runs through the whole novel, if in a more than Atwood usual manner for the most part.I did not enjoy this book.  But I was entertained and it made me think a bit further past my usual boundaries.  It was a book, so it didn't change my life or give me heavy deep thoughts to last me the rest of my days, mind you.  But it engaged on many levels during my reading.  Atwood is quite good at that.  It also was a depressing and slightly laboring read plot wise.  The characters do become ones I could empathize with and care for.  But overall it was a very interesting take on a theme that has and probably will get a considerable fictional look.

Collaborations can be tricky.  I just read a wonderful one in fantasy and it was seamless and smooth.  Here it is a little rougher.  I feel, rightly or wrongly, where the two different authors are.  It is two authors I felt that wrote this as opposed to the better and more enjoyable read of two authors coming together and somehow making a book seem like it was written by a single writer.  Or a third writer  if you will -- the two styles and voices combining into a seamless single, third, writer.That does not make this a bad book in any way.  The singular strengths of the two do work well together.  But I did feel a slight pull in one direction that did not merge completely into one voice.  On the one hand you have some really engaging intrigue that compels and delivers some wonderful tension and suspense.  I found myself wanting to know all the whos/whats/whys of the main plot and I felt that the story does a great job of keeping it not just interesting but also highly plausible.  And it is the plausibility that is both a strength and a weakness.  Shoring up that suspension bridge of disbelief rather nicely is some science that simply becomes a bit too miring and even pedantic.  It is nice in some ways that the detail is there because it avoids the fault of many books that simply serves up the plot and expect the reader to swallow whole everything.  Its' "Just So".  This type of writing only works for me if everything else is simply perfect.  A rare thing.  So I am glad we get so many of the things that serve to underpin the structure of the setting and much of the plot.  But here is where the separation makes itself known the most.  We get some serious info dumping.  And it broke the pace just a bit.  In one author's hands I might have had a more enjoyable transition and melding.  But in a single author's hands I might have also not gotten the expertise and style the other brings.Overall I enjoyed this book.  I thought the characters were nicely crafted and the plot itself was sharp and tense and for the most part compelling.  I thought the detail and what it added to the plot and the ideas it provided to convey a setting both familiar and just slightly different from our own to provide an engaging contrast extremely well done.  It just had a few rough spots here and there as it all tried to come together.  On the highway of reading, no construction issues that force a delay but some less than perfect spots of construction that might prompt a reduction in speed once or twice.

Some very interesting ideas get mashed in with some incredibly trite and overly predictable elements. Then get divided into two.  Each becomes a story --- a culture in trees, with way too many of the predictable elements; the other being an advanced spacefaring story.  And then the author brings them together in a rough meld that then plays on even more overly predictable elements.Sadly this just never engaged as fully as I wanted or even expected.  Again some interesting ideas get buried among some plot elements I just think have been done to death already and Moffitt does not put enough effort into making them his own or even integral to the two plots that eventually become one.  Decent prose just never brings it up to a level that would make this a book I would brag about reading (as in 'I just read this great book).  I think if anyone is a fan of the author or simply looking for a workable if not inspiring science fiction read that doesn't demand much of the reader in basically the same way it doesn't deliver as much.

I like Sarah Monette's writing.  I like Elizabeth Bear's writing.  Both have produced books I've greatly appreciated and both have produced books I've had to work at and ended being a bit underwhelmed by.  But as a team, I have loved all three of the Iskryne books.  I cringed a bit at the graphic nature of the male-wolf bond and how it translated over into the human aspect of sexuality.  But it was also as realistic as it was graphic and, while I could see how it rubbed some people the wrong way, it never fell into some kind of exploitative exercise.  Something I cannot say the same for in even much tamer depictions.The second book took the strong characterization and plotting and expanded it a bit into larger and more complex world building and allowing the plot to expand as well.Here we get the fruition of that in an even broader, but no less complex and detailed story.  Complete with wonderfully varied new characters that play off the expansion as we are given even greater views of the world and its events.Bear and Monette play off each and greatly enhance the aspects of their writing that I enjoy in each.  Bear does great immersions of characters in their world.  Her worlds ring with a nice exoticism as well as a great sense of permanence -- she does what great world builders do, they not only bring it alive in the moment but add the sense of deep history and culture that never bog down in info dumping but simply are there as part of the characters and the plot.  Monette's strength seems more character oriented.  Both are also good at what the other seems to excel at.  But here it is a nice process of polishing only the finest of facets as they meld and merge effortlessly, the collaboration is a smooth and engrossing read that feels exactly as it should.  Two extremely great authors on their own managed to combine and create a third writer in a sense.This is a book that definitely depends on the previous two volumes in my eyes.  Maybe because I am drawing so much from them as I read this.  But maybe with new narrators and characters a novice could jump right in and enjoy this.  I suggest you read the first two prior to delving into this. But I do strongly suggest you get to this as soon as you can!

Ostlund delivers a strong thoughtful debut novel that provides many personal glimpses amid a large general notion of what it feels like to be one of the disconnected.  It is hardly a new idea to explore in fiction.  Feeling out of sync with the rest of the society around us is an idea most of us can identify with even if it is something we can't even admit to ourselves.But what makes Ostlund'a approach so worthwhile is that she takes some extreme specifics in her cast of the socially disenfranchised, takes them almost to the point of being absurd.  And instead keeps them perfect as "small moment' characters.  Individuals who deliver some of the tropes that feed a stereotype -- gay, overweight, etc -- and yet stay wonderfully unique and yet still delivering their ideas and personalities in a way that I think will speak to many readers.What Ostlund captures so well, is mostly in her main character Aaron.  She makes him sympathetic without being pathetic.  She makes him flawed without being scorn worthy.
