And even as she explores his past and his present, the author makes sure to provide insight into Aaron that is incredibly realistic; his decisions are perfect explored as not just means for Aaron to take what he believes to be the best for himself, but as the means to move past moments, long and short, that seem a trap for Aaron.  No matter how foolish the decisions seem, Ostlund does a masterful job of making the character incredibly believable as he makes them.  Never falling into the trap of moving Aaron around a board of events the author feels is the main element of the story.  Aaron is the story.  And he and his supporting cast make for a rich and fulfilling read.

I remember Mary McGrory getting mentioned in a few college journalism courses.  But she was sadly overlooked in my opinion after reading this great biography.  It also underscores how much she and others have been overlooked for some of their more attention grabbing associates who used television as their career path.  It also hammers home a bias against many of those same people.  In many ways, Mary's story is the story of modern journalism.  One that I feel no longer exists.  But time to slide the soapbox away and simply mention what I liked about this great book.First is the style.  Norris does a great job of not just delivering a rousing and compelling read, a biography that juggles telling Mary's story as well as delving into the fascinating events and people around her.Second is the detail.  Spanning so much could be an overwhelming read.  Yet Norris keeps things in the right perspective, paying the right amount of attention to events that are pretty widely known, and pulling back the curtains on the finer points I never expected.  And keeping Mary right in the center.  Not only where she was professionally, but where a book that rightly illustrates how pivotal a position Mary not only enjoyed but also by her own efforts and skill, achieved.Whether you want insight in Mary, her role as a female journalism in a male world, or just want a good read that captures so many historical moments with a fresh insight that also feels informative.

Megan Chance mixes and melds a few of the popular trends in the new YA market of a certain type.  A young woman discovers herself and explores conflicts and confusions along the way.  This is of course a broad trend that covers everything from The Hunger Games to, well, this.  It is broad and seems to contain a multitude.What makes this stand on its own is Chance's eye to description, and appreciation, for her setting.  Venice is captured extremely well, likely appealing to both the reader who has a familiarity as well as the arm chair traveler.  Chance makes sure to balance her setting with actual action.  While her ability to set the scene is her strongest, she does do a more than adequate job of making sure the story itself moves.What I did not care for was the lead character.  I found her too credible.  To deliberate in not asking some of the most obvious "right' questions in the moment.  Yes, in some cases that would mean a much shorter book.  But in some ways, the weakness of the narrator dragged the book out and made it too frustrating in terms of plausibility instead of heightened suspense.In the end, I did not think the negatives outweighed the positives, but put in pretty much in the middle of the pack.  For those looking for a something of a slightly different approach to the usual YA fare, this might punch that ticket.  If anything you will get a nice glimpse of the author's view of Venice.  Which is pretty darn nice.

I've had a spotty history with Groff.  I loved Monsters of Templeton.  Didn't care for Arcadia.  And of course, felt about half of her story collection was good and the rest mediocre or just disliked them.  So it was interesting to take on her new work and see how it fell.Like Monsters... this starts off with an almost disparate set of set ups despite them revolving around the married couple of Mathilde and Lotto.  Disparate because I felt there are a series of feints, if you will about where the book and its characters are going.  And disparate because certain narrative conventions are ever so slightly twisted.  And yet Groff manages to do with slight series of shifts in where the book is going without it feeling like a manipulative set up for some kind of stunning twist.This is both a plus and a negative.  A plus because it calls back to the style I ended up loving in Monsters.  Nuance was the key there as Groff explored ways to pay homage and still twist certain tropes and subvert certain subgenres; and yet for me ended re-inventing them both.Here is the same idea at the heart, but for the negative, I think she takes too long to get to where she finally wants to go with the story.  Also there is a different set of ideas she goes after and I don't think the notion of marriage and her main characters fit in that type of approach.However what saves this is her characters.  Lotto and Mathilde are wonderfully crafted.  They bring the glamour and Groff uses them to bring the book alive in the second half in a way that brings together certain ideas that seem to have stalled in the first half.  Groff manages to create a book that's first half works as a hindsight as the second picks up, shifts direction slightly and picks up the pace.  But by the end, I appreciated that the almost odd pacing in the first half set up so much that then took off in the second.  While about fifty pages in I thought I was going to tap out on the book, I was not just glad to keep going but I actually liked the little bit of work I had to put into it.  In fact if I had to gamble I think Groff almost challenges her readers to commit.  A nice conceit on my part in a book about a marriage and the individuals that struggle to define it even as they each try to define themselves and each other.  Their efforts, in Groff's hands, is a fascinating novel that raises plenty of questions in ways unexpected.  The answers depend on the reader I suspect.

While somewhat predictable and treading some rather familiar ground, Of Sorrow and Such is a wonderfully written complex short tale that has an almost perfect mix of plot and character.  In Slatter's hand, there is just the right amount of world building that uses a somewhat (to this reader) fictional society that lets her provide the right amount of atmosphere without sacrificing other elements of the story.  It is a bit simplistic but it works so well since it has a nice rich take on the vague but identifiable aspects of where the story takes place.  We have the village that embodies aspects that could take place in a period of a couple of hundred years in our own western society.  But it does not really matter since Slattery uses it in just the right amount.In her hands we also get some rather typical tropes.  Witchcraft and persecution.  Villagers superstitious and hypocritical and yet dependent on the main characters skills and talents.  But the story telling is tight and has a nice amount of suspense.  Both complete in and of itsself, but also providing enough glimpses into the setting overall that made me hope for more set in this world if not exploring the further adventures of some of the characters.Tor.com has managed to provide some rather stellar short works that manage to give plenty of story in a short form and introduce some rather talented authors that in terms of time and money has proven to greatly appreciated by this reader.  Adding to K.J. Parker's The Last Witness and  Alter S. Reiss' The Sunset Mantle, Slattery's work here shows great things can come in small packages.

Though not without some flaws, Snyder presents a strong and compelling look at how the Holocaust was enabled.  With a different approach, Snyder explores what statehood meant going into Nazi expansion and occupation.I do think some of the analysis followed Snyder's premise a bit too closely at times; some of the compares did not look at Hitler and the Nazis ethnic views as much as needed.  He does a good job of exploring the issue, but I think he ends up leaning towards the matters that support his thesis.But as a study of some of the issues that focus on the reaction of the states themselves which either enabled or staggered or simply halted the Holocaust's agenda, this stands quite strongly by itself.  An important work on an issue that not only defined a generation but also permeates how we as a world wide society move through conflict and still perceive matters of ethnicity and even faith.  History, no matter how horrific, is something we simply refuse not to repeat, in both small and large ways.

Boyd pursues a particular storytelling style here that just never comes together for me as a compelling read.  The memoir approach is a bit too removed and Amory's voice is a bit too detached and ends up being flat.  She lacks nuance and everything ends up being too predictable.  Not that this type of book needs a shock or twist, but she never seems to be an individual but rather a generic everywoman in how she deals with life and what it throws at her.  Added to that, her life seems a bit of a checklist of events that seem a bit trite at times; likely due to Amory being rather trite in how she acts and reacts in the context of those events.Readable, and even pleasant, it is still a book I don't find memorable and hardly Boyd at his best.

A fun and interesting continuation in this shared world series.  I think I preferred Gladstone's first episode over this.  But I still enjoyed this for what it is; a nice tight little story that I think will appeal to fans of urban fantasy.A reader plunging in might find it a bit sparse as it builds on Episode 1.  I do think it could stand alone as it provides all the details that the story is built on.  But episode I provides a bit more depth and it also provides an interesting compare to how two authors approach a similar theme.  I found Gladstone a bit more up front  And tighter.  Slattery seems more intent on providing a style and atmosphere that definitely is his own(I base this on having read Slattery's other works).  I thought there was a slight vagueness that was deliberate and rather different than Gladstone's Episode 1.  This is not a negative so much as a shift in style I found less to my taste than Episode 1.

Nice strong entry to a serial type shared world.Up front I should say that I have not had much luck with Max Gladstone.  I was not impressed with his opening novel in his ongoing series.  Not enough to continue with it.  And I have read at least one of his stand alone shorter works (I believe on Tor.com) and found it similar in quality in terms of his style to my taste.  Just not a right fit.  So I was surprised at how much I enjoyed his set up here.This is very much both a work that establishes the premise and character of a cop drawn into a secret society that protects the unknowing world (for the most part) of magic books that can unleash devastating horrors.  This has been done before, but it is a clean tight and nice story that provides plenty of punch even as it paves the way for the shared entries that follow.It not only removed any doubts to the series started here, but also gives me the impetus to make sure to give Gladstone a second chance elsewhere.

I greatly enjoyed this.  Curry provides a time and setting that feels authentic and is always engaging.  She captures the atmosphere in a way that I found rich and nicely detailed.  She sets a state that doesn't get cluttered with overly pedantic bits of information and yet it is evocative to the point that I was completely immersed.Curry also delivers a solid cast of characters that not only reflect China of this period in a brutal but intriguing manner, but also are written in a way that capture the sense of looking in on the Western World.  Curry writes with a thoughtful quietness that can seem a little slow at times but for me it carries the story style-wise.  The plot twists and turns slightly but in ways that were engrossing and in the end her characters never seemed to waver in in terms of motivation or how they become defined.  For historical fiction, this is a nice strong entry that covers a time and place that usually explored and with a quality that raises it above most novels.

I found this somewhat engaging at the start.  However it also was burdened by relying a bit heavily on too many tropes within the theme of  good guy stuck in a bad position of his own making.  When the action started to drag, all this smaller flaws became larger and played off one another.  Highlighting each and raising the focus of what made this a bit too mediocre.I think had Holm committed to making his main character a bit more gray in morality and a bit more ruthless that provided a bit of motivation as to why a 'good guy' has no problem killing other people no matter how bad.  It seemed glib and a bit too thin that pulling a trigger can be so 'good'  for one man.  The level of mitigation employed just did not work and made the story a bit too flat in what could have been a more interesting, but probably less commercial read that ends up feeling like the tossed aside script for an actioner starring Jason Stratham or Karl Urban.  Going straight to On-Demand.

I was wavering on whether this really deserved four stars or should fall back to three.  I was feeling generous I guess.  but I did find this a wonderfully approachable book and a fast engrossing read.  Quick but not slight or thin in story or character.The reason I was thinking three, is that I felt on some level the author abandons the premise that grabs hold.  The high school angle does get full resolution in some ways, but I felt there was a bit of a cheat at the end.  Slight spoiler-ish comment on that at the end that doesn't give away actual details but a general feel so be warned.Another thing I was kind of disappointed in was that the author felt the need to have a secondary, but deeper dysfunction that I actually found too trite and too labored.  The whole secret guilt reveal lacked the punch I strongly felt the author wanted.  Maybe that makes me cold hearted, but I felt that the relationship with her daughter and her daughter's issues as a parallel to the main character's story was much more interesting.  Also I felt an almost odd disconnect when the author introduces an array of new characters that seem trite at first as the oddball cast and yet ever so briefly captured my interest and then seemed suddenly abandoned.  Yes they exit in a logical way, but it just seemed an odd focus to provide and then do so little with them.  'I am Spartacus' (this is to avoid spoilers but to provide reference once read) seemed a rich vein to explore that gets shoved aside quicker than needed.Overall Dicks writes a great set of characters and a decent story.  Some things could have come together better for me.  Some things needn't have occurred at all and others broadened.  Still it was a smooth and compelling read for the most part and had the right amount of humor that wasn't forced or heavy handed to balance the other emotions out.******SPOILER-ISH REACTION******Do go further unless you want to have a general idea greater than you already doNote to author, there are villains in high school that never get past that.  It is essentially why Facebook is a business and not dwindled away like the oughts pet rocks.  I was underwhelmed by the pull back from certain aspects of the bullying and mean girl behavior that the author employs to give an ending that is almost too pat.

I thought this was a cute book to some extent.  But it was too affected in that regard to be as enjoyable as I thought it should.  I found the narration a bit too slight and any character complexity was sacrificed for the quirky tone that author seemed to find fascinating.  Robbing the book of any significant substance.  Instead I felt like I was being told how to react to certain moments in a way that I just never felt.  The joke where you can see the punchline well ahead of its delivery, robbing the moment of its needed surprise for fun and entertainment.  It just tried way too hard and never seemed to even try to develop the slightest nuance which would have balanced the over-affected quirky style.

First a slight confession.  I love dumplings.  I adore them.  I could fall asleep in a bed of them after taking an ambien so I would wake up to a full stomach and clean set of sheets.Second a slighter larger confession.  I have not made my own wrappers from this book yet.  I've gone the easy route of the nice solid stack from my local Asian market.  But I will.  I do plan on it.  Some day.Lao provides a wonderful primer on the matter that goes well beyond dumplings.  I love the set up in the book that provides wonderful visuals in how to go about setting up a dumpling friendly kitchen.  The listing of tools and ingredient as well as pictures to make sure there is no mistake (I actually greatly appreciate that the author makes no bones about communicating what he knows -- as opposed to any assumptions of what he thinks I should already know -- here it works wonderfully) in what I need to have ready should I want to make any of the delights he provides recipes and careful detailed instructions for.I love the combination of familiar flavors placed in a dumpling.  the Chicken and Thai basil was a huge hit.  As was the Lamb and Cumin, the spicy Beef and Shiso and the chicken saag.Fun sauces that mean you can break out a bag of your favorite already made frozen dumplings and still feel like you did your own bit.  There is even a great chart that explores combining dumplings with sauces that just typing about it makes my stomach growl.Lao goes the full soup to nuts approach with this, so not just the familiar dumplings and their immediate cousin, the bun.  He also tackles noodles and salads and of course the aforementioned soups.  There are drinks and desserts that were also a nice twist on some familiar concepts that I still haven't tried (I'm still working up to my own dough here and haven't even considered moving up to making my own noodles).This is a great book for those wanting to expand their love of the dumpling to more than ordering them from the take out menu.  Whether you want to simply trigger your appetite, expand your frozen dumpling repertoire to including some fresh and interesting new dipping sauces, take the leap to filling, folding and cooking your own, all the way to doing everything yourself, this is the book for you.

I wanted to like this.  I do like fantasy and I actually can enjoy some of the more old fashioned approaches.  I'm hardly averse to adherence to tried and true tropes if combined with strong world building and good characterization.  And above all, a deft turn of telling a story.Sadly I found none of that here.  I did find some general story telling that I felt was been there done that.  Which again is not horrible in and of itself when told through a new and fresh imagination.But this imagination is cluttered to say the least.  The world building seems a mish mash of large ideas that never come together or are defined in a way that established the setting my mind was supposed to move through and absorbed.  Just too many concepts that never seem to be as clear or as evocative as I feel the authors were going for.The worst aspect of this though was the prose.  It was purple.  It was five adjectives in a sentence when one would do.  Many sentences seemed like the authors had lifted a bunch of the most esoteric words from a thesaurus listing  and slapped them together one after another.  Some of the usages seemed downright silly at times.  Simple sometimes is best when trying to tell a story.  Which is a basic form of communicating.  Why anyone would go out of their way to do so with as little clarity as they could was baffling to me.Last, I found that everything was too much of an extreme to find any form of investment.  The characters are too over the top in in what we are told but rarely shown.  And the showing, sadly, didn't help either.  Evil characters embody almost every single bad trait to the point of becoming caricatures.Just not a very good effort and as a first in a series, a bad bad sign of things to come.

Rushdie is one of those authors who has a rather particular style.  And it is definitely present in this latest offering (I'm not typing the title out it is simply too long, almost as long as what I just typed.....).I suspect that if you have read every single Rushdie novel and loved it, this will put you on the floor.  Or left smoking a cigarette in sated happiness.  But don't smoke.  it is nasty and disgusting and have you ever smelled what a smoker smells like?For new readers to Rushdie I'm guessing it will be a bit of a shock.  Either a joyous one of discovery or a kind of 'what is going on here' in terms of style.Anyway, I have had great luck with Rushdie and mediocre luck.  All with the same signature style.  So go figure.  Here I think my problem was that the scattered back and forth and all over approach to writing detracted instead of enhanced the ideas i found interesting and the significantly larger story of Geronimo.  While Dunia the ancestress figures across the novel just as large or maybe even larger, for me the story of her descendant seems to be the novel's heart.  And it gets shoved aside again and again in ways I found frustrating and even worse, boring.Granted, I knew rather quickly this was going to take a little more effort on my part as a read.  Rushdie is usually like that.  But sometimes a baby can find those dangling set of keys hours worth of fun.  And sometimes they are just a jangling annoyance.Not too much of the latter but still enough to make this a less than brilliant and enjoyable read for me.

Not a favorite of mine.  I found the artwork is incredibly busy for the story being told.  Some of the panels were simply cluttered to the point of being incoherent if you will.  And not much really happens.  The set up is quick but then it just sort of churns without going anywhere.

Great artwork is nicely coupled with a strong story that embodies a simple message wrapped in some rather complex ideas on that matter.  Oppression is at the root of this tale of the future distant enough to be set on colonial interplanetary societies.  Yet close enough in time to be immediately recognizable.  It is a nice mix of what is familiar in a sort of dystopian kind of way and what is identifiable as future-wish.The story is delivered nicely with the artwork, minimal and yet rich in detail.  Both serve the other nicely here and make for a smooth read that still is rich and complex enough to go back and visually take more in on a second serving.

Are you looking for that book to sit out on your coffee table that will impress your guests?  Or just leave them briefly engrossed?  Are you looking for that book to sit on the shelf in the guest bathroom to leave similar guests intrigued?  Confounded?  Left wondering at the hidden depths you might enjoy?Yeah that is a weird combo for some I have no doubt.  But this is one of those books.  Show how clever you are or pretend to be by putting this out for others to see.  But first read it yourself.  At least twice.  Maybe thrice.  Don't worry, you will go back more than that as long as you have it I am sure.  If you get the physical copy though be prepared for your less ethical and more rude guests to maybe accidentally let it fall into purse or messenger bag?What I am trying to say is that this is funny, witty, thoughtful and even slightly provoking all in a short but deftly written set of ideas in simple epigram form.

Follow up to Hearth's first Miss Dreamsville book, this is pretty much more of the same.  The story is different, but the tone and approach is in lock step with the previous book.  I do think this could be read without the first.  Hearth does a good job of centering her characters and establishing those that have returned in a way that defines them nicely and yet doesn't for the returning reader it doesn't get in the way.Do I like this type of book?  It is relatively harmless fun.  Slightly glib and just plain slight, it is still fun and Hearth captures her time and place in way that is probably her chief strength.  Sure there is heavy handed social commentary (pretty much what I agree with but it is a sort of revisionist approach -- her good characters are socially progressive beyond much of their own generation and self aware to the point that they could open a psychic hotline they are so ahead of their times in some regards).  And the bad characters embody pretty much all of the traits we can look back on and shudder.Hearth also likes to find redemption.  Which can be a little cloying, but it also speaks to the over nature of these books eking out the happiness that existed even in some rather horrible moments in time.  Which makes them a quick fun read.  It is all the sassy movies that combine the progressive alliances of oddball characters who triumph over brutish ignorance of some sort boiled down to a frothy feel good read.

I will say that this is not my favorite Holland historical fiction.  Here is a sort of detached approach that I sometimes find in her work.  In such cases, as here, I find the story is more about the characters as opposed to a more immersive style (that Holland can certainly employ) that makes you the reader with the characters as the story unfolds.  I hope that makes sense.However even in this removed style or approach, I find Holland is masterful at capturing a period and crafting a plot that seems incredibly authentic and accurate.  She captures the brutality of the times in way that proves compelling as action as well as providing a strong foundation for character motivation.Any Holland, I find worth the read.  Even one such as this that suffers in compare to, say Great Maria or Firedrake, is still pretty darn good historical fiction.

Bill Clegg employs a style that I found a little off putting at first.  As already noted, this is very much a tell and and not show type of story.  Which is not my favored form of narrative.  As this is a novel driven by the various characters' introspection, this is not as bad as it might seem.  However it still made for a slow read for me.What strength lies in this is Clegg's ability to delve into grief and how it can define someone and how that same someone can try and resist any such definition.  Here the slow almost meandering approach works well.  And it is the heart of the story itself.  So it is the style itself I guess I had problems with.  Completely subjective of course.  But it was enough to make me wonder, and wish, to read Clegg's ability to capture grief in this way but with a different narrative approach.  There were so many small moments that I, on one hand, was completely moved by and yet at the same time felt was deflated a bit emotionally by the manner in which it was delivered.I do think Clegg is a new voice that is almost startling in some of his skills in the area of completely tapping into the moment he sees and feels and conveys through his lead character.

I will point out that I found this slightly dry.However it works as the focus and detail the author employs in examining these almost elemental stories at the foundation of the three faiths, in my opinion, demands it.  Gregg is simply masterful in examining not just the similarities and differences but the reasons why such exist.  And the the possible reasons.  Which in such a work I find just as, if not more important.  Gregg's writing here was nicely balanced and made sure to avoid seeming any type of agenda as its cause.  This is a wonderful study that I think anyone looking at culture, not just faith, will find fascinating and illuminating.Thank you to the publisher and netgalley for the opportunity to read this book in exchange for a fair review.

Once finished, I have to say that I found the title to be the funniest thing about the book.  By the blurb I was expecting (or at least hoping) for something hilarious.  And I really did not get that.  But I did get a story that was fun if not funny.  Amusing and oddly detailed in terms of a cast of characters that should not have worked and yet did.This is my first book by Dobyns so I had no idea what to expect.  But I was pleased with the end result.  There is a level of absurdity at play here that might frustrate or annoy other readers, but I found it added a nice level to the book and plot itself.  On a certain level the author is giving a wink and letting you in on the joke itself.  I think the form of narrative actually works in the story's favor in that regard.  The silliness is something shown off the bat as being a bit over the top and yet the whole paradigm of the story is that it is over the top.  Accept that and you are in for a ride that might not leave you with tears of laughter streaming down your face or a gut sore from guffaws, but it might leave a bemused and pleased smile on your face and an appreciation for a odd but tightly written fast paced novel that enjoys itself, it you will.

Fran Wilde delivers a nice rich story that opens a new fantasy world that begs for greater exploration.  World building can be the making or breaking of a novel for me.  Something like the one here is richly rewarding.  Wilde creates something here I found fresh and inventive  as well as extremely well described and employed.Wilde almost seems to go out of her way to incorporate her world in the story itself.  Managing to avoid infodumping and showing much of the world and motivations through the eyes of her main character, Kirit.  Kirit manages to strike the right balance.  She is an insider to her world in most ways and yet she still is able to serve as the narrative voice of discovery.  This lets Wilde deliver a stronger story that is not weighed down by forcing the reader to wade through the details of world building outside of a smooth narrative.And while I always appreciate an author that strongly follows the 'show; don't tell' rule of narration, I do think this pulls the book down a little bit at the start.  I had a rather small struggle to find the point I was completely engaged in the story.  And I think some of that was due to the immediacy of the author placing the reader into the action of the world as well as a few oddities in the world building itself.  There slight problems disappeared quickly or were addressed as the story went along.All in all I was really happy with this and immediately went to Beneath Ceaseless Skies to read the ancillary story set in the same world.

I pop 3 or 4 of these if I get dispatched to structure fire or any other scene in which I know will be a prolonged one. I am career firefighter in South Florida. Electrolyte replacement and good rehab are critical elements on any fire ground scene here in hot, humid South Florida.

Right off I can honestly say this is not a "CRICKET" hairbrush. I have been using a "CRICKET" for about twenty five years. I still had the same original brush until I misplaced it somewhere in my own house (old age?) I have two spares but thought after twenty five years maybe there might be a better brush out there. This isn't a better brush for me.Yes it would a easy 5 star if I had really thick hair or just thick hair in general, I don't. The bristles though thin are not very flexible. They do move if you push them back & forth with your hand or that thick hair. The handle I have to say is great. Thick with grooves in it for your hands to really hold it. A good shower brush if using one to brush your conditioners though. It's vented as well for faster hair drying if using a blow dryer.I tried using this one for almost two weeks and found it just to hard on my scalp. I do have very fine thin hair. I gave the two I purchased to my daughter in law. Her & my 8 year old granddaughter has crazy thick, long hair. They love them. They want to pick up a couple more ( stocking stuffers). As for me I went and ordered two more crickets. The bristles are much more flexible for my scalp & hair.👱THANKS FOR READING, BYE🙇

I reviewed this already, but I purchased this from another supplier.I have been using Therapy-G products for about 6 months or so. They fit my samsung note 4 very snuggly but not to tight where it 's difficult to change them out.I purchased three of these cases.The backs of them came with a clear film on them during their shipment probably. *NOTE* I wasn't able to see this clear film,  I actually thought the cases themself were defective. I have been using these nail brushes for a few months now. They work well. The three longer ones are made of a hollow plastic, so they are very light. I prefer a heavier brush so I simply added alittle molding clay just above the brush at the metal part.The red ended (NO.1) brush is 6 3/4" long w/ the bristles, The bristles are 1/2" long. The green ended (NO.2) brush is 7" long w/the bristles, the bristles are 3/4" long. And the blue ended (NO.3) brush is 7" long w/bristles, the bristles are 1" in length.These 1, 2 & 3 brushes are strip brushes. For making lines, feathers  whatever comes to mind with these brushes.The other three have wooden handles. Two measuring 5 1/2" long, w/bristles, the bristles are 1/2" long & 1/4" long. The third brush w/bristles is 5 1/4" long , the bristlesare 1/16" long.These three brushes I use for flowers, clouds, grass , these short bristles could paint many things on your nails. I paint birds, trees , leaves. These brushes are small yet big in punch. They hold nail polishes & acrylic paints very well, and are really easy to clean. I haven't lost any bristles from them either.They came with clear plastic open ended covers , but they don't stay on very well, unless firmly pushing them down onto the handles. I just don't use them, I store my nail brushes in a vinyl baggie, open end so they get air. Bristles face up.These brushes haven't disappointed me so far.'THANKS FOR READING, '

These pens write well & the stylus end works even better. These are a thicker barrel pen as shown, but they are a little on the "could be better made side". These nail art decals are lovely. No they are not stickers. They are water decals. There are 23 flowers on each sheet. I have been doing my own fiberglass nails for a long time now. I usually use acrylic paints for my designs unless I come across gems like these.I have used water decals many times, they are rather easy to use. I take an old pill bottle cap, remove the cardboard from the inside of it (if any) cut the decal out , lay it in the cap with very warm water, or use something that will not be affected by the warm water, waxed Dixie cups are not ideal. The decal will separate from the paper on it's own after a minute or two. If it doesn't, using blunt tweezers lift it off & with those tweezers place the decal on your " damp" nail, position the decal where you want it, then carefully blot your nail & decal with moving the decal. This will become easier & easier every time you do your nails.Before you know it , piece of cake. Make sure there is no curling at the edges. Water decals generally do not curl, if that happens dampen the decal with a little water using the tip of your finger. Gently without moving the decal. It probably won't move, just take care. Waiting a few seconds apply two coats of your favorite top coat. Try from side to side, then cuticle area to tip of nail assuring it is covered around the entire edges.For a little twinkle, sparkle on your nails check out the OUT THE DOOR'S  NORTHERN LIGHTS. I use it alot.💅THANKS FOR READING, BYE💅

I love ladybugs. This is why I had to have this flag. The measurements are as stated, 28"×40". Made of polyester which means easy to clean, I simply hose mine off before changing them out. They dry crazy fast.I change mine out every two weeks, I have two decorative flag poles on my front porch, which is in direct sunlight all day long. They do fade after awhile.This flag is super cute. Daisies are also my favorite flower. The "welcome" on this flag is only on one side. (Mine is ).Also it is a banner sewn on the ladybug flag at the top & bottom. The welcome is 5 3/4" wide & is double stitched up, both sides. The entire flag is also double stitched as well.The colors on this flag are not as bright as pictured but are eye popping non the less. In the sleeve of the flag(for the pole) are the two nylon loops to hook the flag pole to. I have found too many times it can be somewhat hard to hook it. I always use a ziptie, run it through the loop, making hanging it so much easier. Bring the tie just past the outside of the sleeve put a strong crease in it after zipping the tie, cut off the excess, done. Well I find this is easier for me 😄.THANKS FOR READING, BYE.

I ordered this ballerina barbie for a baby shower gift. First christmas stocking , first ornament , first teddy & of course her first barbie.Her knees don't bend , but she will be put on the shelf in the baby's room. True only her tutu  is removable.  Her permanently attached outfit some reviews say it's odd looking, strange. That is because the outfits are interchangeable with other barbies.This doll can wear the mermaid outfit, the swimsuit, there are just so many different outfits.The photo shows a blonde barbie, the one I received has like a dark blonde, almost brown, pretty non the less.It is just a good first barbie for any little girl.👌THANKS FOR READING, BYE👍

This nail stickers are beautiful. You get 24 sheets truly, I had a couple of doubles so my daughter in law now has some. The silver outline of these flowers are raised, you will feel it when applying them. The flower is just a very soft pretty pink, dainty & delicate looking.Don't let that fool you , these stickers, yeah they are stickers, not water decals. These are pliable, not really stiff,  but thicker then most nail stickers I have used in the past. My advise, apply them to a completely dry painted nail, if applying them to even the slightest tacky nail they probably will absorb the moisture from the polish , then curl at the edges. Also once on your painted nail , gently hold it down for several seconds just to make sure it doesn't curl.The curling sometimes does happen due to the thickness of the nail sticker or decals. After you waited that short time apply at least two coats of your favorite topcoat. My first coat goes from side to side, second coat from finger to tip. I have been doing my own fiberglass nails for a very long time. Buying nail stickers for myself & my granddaughter's, these are by far the nicest, prettiest stickers I have seen & purchased. Also just to let you know , there are between 22 & 30 flowers & petals on each sheet , depending on the flower design.There are lillies, roses mums, & others. They will keep you busy. I will be looking for some different colors & designs.👌THANKS FOR READING, BYE💅

This works wonders on bug bites, we have a pond in our yard, at night we do get the occasional mosquito bites, this really takes away the itch. Also I am always washing my hands , I use jergens oatmeal cream , but I rub this on my cuticles and no more dryness. I use cuticle oil regularly,  after using bleach or strong chemicals when cleaning bird cages, kennels and toilets, I find this lasts much longer then applying cuticle oil over & over.I also had a pretty bad paper cut , it helped with that sharp stinging irritation that comes with paper cuts.This is thicker being an ointment and the lavender oil in it makes it pleasant smelling.This is in a thick glass jar, not many products do, so a hard fall onto ceramic tile or concrete would break the jar. Though I did drop mine and it didn't break , but who can control gravity?I have this coming to my house on a regular basis through amazon.Yes I would recommend this to anyone with a problem where this has helped my family.👌THANKS FOR READING, BYE👍

This is my second set of these cooling racks. I make cupcakes for my grandkids, dozens & dozens of cookies during the holidays.But this time I plan to use them for other purposes. I am already using one in my livingroom, I know, the livingroom? Our cable box is on quite often and gets warm , not enough air circulation around it. Also our ROKU BOX tends to get warm, I simply put both boxes on this cooling rack, keeping the flip out risers ( legs?) folded in , it really helps . Two of these new ones will be used for that purpose in my son's room & family room.The first set I bought have been washed & washed, by hand & in the dishwasher, they still look great.No rust , no flaking or peeling, the folding risers still move very freely, no rusting there either.I also love how they stack on top of each other, saving counter space, especially during those holiday baking marathons. They can be just a little awkward to store because they don't lay flat, those damn risers again. You can store them, each one with risers folded only measure about 1" high. Laying the folded rack in between the wires of the others it won't take up much space , about  3 1/2" wide. If you really could use these racks , space won't be a concern. I just wish they made these even larger for my holiday cookies. 🍰THANKS FOR READING, BYE🍞

I purchased "OLE ONE EYE" ( that's what my 3 year old grandson calls him, from a dinosaur movie). He loves him. His measurements are as stated, he's big. His colors are done well. Other reviews said he is hollow , but about 1" up the back of his tail there is a very small hole, probably for air to escape during the moulding process. There was some coarse angel hair like fiber coming out the hole , long continuous fiber. I cut it off as close to the hole as I could, and put a very small dot of clear silicone over the hole . It dried in no time .Now maybe it is hollow except for the tail, to keep it stiff so the dinosaur is able to stand with the help of the tail. Maybe the entire dinosaur is slightly filled, I'm not sure, just keep an eye on that hole if your little one's Dino has a hole somewhere. He is weighty but not to heavy, so even the youngest of toddlers can carry him & toss him around.We have a HOWARD MILLER presidential collection grandfather clock in our livingroom, Ole one eye gets tossed around without any worry for our clock.All grandparents would appreciate these toys. The photo looks as if maybe there are some sharp points or edges to him, that is not the case. Also with his rubbery feel to him, he is very easy to just wipe clesn. And I found when he arrived there was no odor on him like some plastic toys do.This T-REX is one of many of these very soft dinsaurs. I already ordered more.THANKS FOR READING, BYE🐊

I purchased this frame as a baby shower gift. It's so cute. The patchwork border with hearts , star & bow, perfect for any little girl. It is made of resin, but has a little weight to it. It has a piece of glass to protect the photo., Some frames have been using plastic or acrylic.The colors in this frame are more vivid then the photo shows, well the frame I received has brighter colors.This frame does measure 5"7" , but only holds a  3"×5" photo.This would also be a great gift for a new "gramma" & "grampa", or anyone who holds a little girl close to their 💕.It came well packed in the formiliar amazon box, with plenty bubble wrap. Inside a "preciuos moments box wrap in a plastic bag surrounded by Styrofoam. It also has the thick cardboard arm in the back to stand it on a dresser, table or shelf.It's just adorable , I love it.THANKS FOR READING, BYE🎁

'She is adorable ! So soft & fluffy.Truly 14" in length .The bottom of her feet & inner ears are pink & white plaid shown . She has a lovely soft pink ribbon around her neck. ** With all this being said, her eyes are not embroidered as stated **, they are little shiny black eyes you see on many stuffed animals, about 1/2" round. I purposely pulled them really really hard , twisting them as well ,just to see how easy it would be for a baby or toddler to pull or even bite them off, I have to say, they are put on her pretty darn good.Her nose & her smily face (you can't see in the photo) is also embroidered on. I believe they are for sitting her up on a shelf on display her in a baby's or little girl's room.She does sit up nice and straight.This bear I purchased is for a baby shower gift. I would recommend this cutie for anyone, letting them about the eyes and beads in her little tooshy.'THANKS FOR READING, BYE'

I purchased this "GLCON" bluetooth along with a "allreli" brand bluetooth, which I have already posted a review.I purchased them both at the same time.I have always used the "BLUEANT" voice command bluetooth, one lasted better then 5 years, the second one about a year.  I have dropped both of them and they broke in the exact same spot, prompting me to look at other brands.I looked at this one , as well as the $ and thought I would give it a try.My one and only complaint is , the silicone earpiece that comes with it , though I found it to be very comfortable,  the little loop that is at the end of the earpiece is thinner and not as stiff as I am used to having in my ear, giving me the feeling that it is going to fall out. This did come with two earpieces and two over the ear hooks , which I have never used. This one has not yet fallen out of my ear. Maybe it's just in my head that it feels thinner, even after shaking my head back & forth all around it didn't fall out.Yes the side of this bluetooth does have a large button, you are not able to see it in the photo and when it's in your hand . Holding the bluetooth in your hand, sideways you are barely able to see a very small gap at the end the the bluetooth where thev"Glcon" logo is, that also lights up indicates the charging & charging complete. The lights are bright enough to see from across the room. Red means charging , green means completely charged.This is where you actually push the button , Like a diving board motion. The volume up & down buttons are on the side of this bluetooth on top or bottom depending on which ear you use it in.I received 4 ear hooks with this along with everything else stated in the product description.  It all came in a very nice hard case for traveling, I use it for my lip glosses & lipsticks.The power ON /OFF switch is on the inner part of the bluetooth ,  yes it is close to the earpiece.I find no trouble switching it on or off. I do have fiberglass nails, so I had my 7 year old granddaughter and my 3 year old grandson turning it on & off, they had no problem either.The voice is clear , easy to operate & I had no problem connecting it or the other one I purchsed to my samsung galaxy note 4.I don't use these for alot of music, but when I have it was just fine for me. Others may need something with more oomph.  The finish on it is a bright white with a very glossy shine to it .The underside has a shiny chrome finish to it. This bluetooth I find to suit my needs well, and anyone who needs just a simple easy to use attractive bluetooth, I recommend this "GLCON".THANKS FOR READING, BYE.😄

I purchsed this when I gave my other safe edge can openers to family members. I really reseached the Zyliss brands and thought I'd give them a try. My other  "safe" can openers were the "kuhn rikon" & they worked well. This one is every bit as good , actually better.This can opener has a silicone handle to help with keeping control of the opening of thd can. After closing the handle together you simply twist the large silicone handle to open your cans.*NOTE* The twist handle is on top of the opener, if looking at your can , the twist handle is on top of the can , not on the side of the can opener like the traditional ones we all remember.Once opened the lid & the can are safe, not sharp at all. You are actually able to use the lid to snuggly re-cover the can. ( LEAVE THE LABEL ON, WASH THE LID & CAN STORE VALUBLES IN THEM😉. WHO STEALS CAN GOODS)!When first using this type of can opener it may be awkward, but only once or twice. After that you've mastered it.  👫kids are always wanting to help in the kitchen, they will not cut their little fingers & hands using this Zyliss can opener.👍THANKS FOR READING, BYE.😄

I have been using the safe edge can openers for some time now. After giving the two, away to a family member, I checked into the "Zyliss brand".I purchased this one in red.when I open can goods that need to be this type of can opener is what I grab. Sour kraut in the can, there is so much juice in those cans. I try to drain it in a strainer but the kraut gets into the holes so bad it makes clearing those holes of the kraut gets to be tedious.I wipe the top of the can off, then simply open the can, leave the lid on the can , turn the can with the lid on and place the can unto the bottom of a large plastic drinking tumbler standing in the kitchen sink. Then just slowly start pushing down on the bottom of the can, draining the kraut juice out . ( this works for me).This can opener is easy to use , and not hard on my carpal tunnel hands. Thd red you see on the handles are silicone , so, your handd aren't slipping while using it, yet the silicone doesn't have that tacky feeling like some silicone does.On the top of the opener there is a little red slide locking latch. You slide it towards the handles to release them, when finished using it rinse it off if needed then squeeze the handles together , the latch will catch & stay, locking the handles together again.The twist handle on the opener is also silicone and large enough for anyone to use this . The elderly shouldn't any difficulty with this opener. If this helps st all while using using squeeze the handles together , the lock will catch so anyone using it doesn't have to strain by squeezing these handles, focusing more on the twist movement. When finished opening the can , simply place your thumb on the latch & slide it toward your hands.It truly is a simple , yet very practical design. ☺THANKS FOR READING, BYE.😄

I have been wearing propet sneakers for many years now, I always purchase the ped walker 8.  While shopping for a men's propet for my husband, I ran across these. The carpal tunnel in my left hand was becoming unbearable, my son said I should try a brace or something support my wrist. This wrist wrap saved me. I wear a 8 - 8 1/2 inch wrist. This wrap fits me beautifully, with room to spare. From the palm of my hand to about  2 inches above my wrist in the wrap is a metal support in the natural shape of ones wrist & palm . It isn't adjustable or removeable. I did order the large/ extra large wrap. The opening for your thumb has plenty of room for the biggest of hands. The hole measures 2 1/2 inches long by 2 inches at the widest opening of the thumb hole. This hole is egg shaped if that helps. Once the wrap is on your wrist, on the back of your hand there is another metal support bar, so the movement of your wrist is very limited, really controlling your wrist at all times.This metal support measures 5 1/2 inches long by 1 3/4 inches wide, also not adjustable or  removable either. This wrap is spot clean or hand wash only. There are three straps to easily adjust the wrap, to the tightness move ability you choose.I am oredering another left hand wrap , as well as a right hand wrap. My right so far has not been nearly as painful. I don't wear it while cleaning, but driving , relaxing , watching tv and even sleeping I am wearing it. I also purchased a three pack of hand strengthening exercise balls. They have also helped alot. The brand is called FITBALL. These two products have really helped with my carpal tunnel.THANKS FOR READING, BYE.😄

I didn't take a second to read the dimensions of these candles when I ordered them, I ended up ordering two sets. When they arrived, needless to say I couldn't believe the size, they were going back. After three days went by, I was cleaning my kitchen where I have 2 sets of sconces on my walls. I never wanted to burn tealight candles or the bit larger votives. The two smaller of these three fit perfectly in my glass votive cups on my sconces.The two tallest ones are in my livingroom on a shelf I have mounted on the wall. The battery life seems to last FOREVER. Plus both sets came with 6 extra batteries . They only use one in each candle, so each candle comes with two extra batteries because each candle already has a battery in it. They take the large quarter size button cell batteries. LITHIUM CELL CR2450 3V. The candles are a cream color, but when lit they do look a deeper yellow as shown in the photo. The dimensions of these candles are as stated in the discrimination.  They are not wax, but a plastic. The timers on these work beautifully and are accurate coming on everyday at the same time, simply flip the power button from off to on, there is no timer switch . Turning the candle on is turning on the timer . 6 hours on, 18 hours off, easy. These are small, but could be used in bookcases, curio cabinets, childrens' bedrooms as nightlights, even a guest bathroom. You are now able to purchase a carvable foam resin pumpkin for halloween. These candles would be great in those jack-o-lanterns. Your imagination could go crazy.4 out of five stars from me only because there are so many creative uses for these little candles, I would love to see them in many more colors. Red for christmas & valentines day. Pink, lavender for spring & summer. But the lack of colors won't keep me from ordering more. I am going to try to paint one or two with some stained glass paint. These candles are not expensive, and stained glass paint is easy to use.THANKS FOR READING, BYE✌

This plays a big part in the Therapy-G system. This gets used after shampooing, but before conditioning your hair. Also my eyebrows are thicker.I am committed to using this for a longer amount of time just to see where my hair ends up, As long as it doesn't end up in my shower drain or hairbrush.THANKS FOR READING, BYE 🙇

I have been using Therapy-G products for three months now, I can honestly say I really see & feel a big difference with my hair. I just got my haircut and the lady who has cut my hair for many years also noticed a big improvement with the look & feel of my hair.I use the shampoo, leaving it in my hair for 2 minutes then rinsing out well. Then the follicle stimulator 8 pumps , then massaging into my scalp, leaving it in for another 2 minutes , rinsing out. Then the conditioner, also leaving it on my hair for 2 minutes, rinsing out well. The products have a soft minty scent & you will feel the tingling on your scalp as well.Also available is a volumizer spray. I spray it into my hands then distribute it evenly through my hair. The Therapy-G products are pricey, but I have seen much much less hair in my shower drain & in the bristles of my hairbrush. This is truly the first time in at least 10 years there is no hair in the bristles of my hairbrush. 🙇I have been using the Therapy-G treatment in my hair for three months now. I first saw it & ordered the treatment kit from a catalog I receive "AS WE CHANGE" .What do I have to lose, hair ? I felt a strong tingling through my scalp. The treatment has a soft minty scent. The first time after using it, my hair instantly had more body then I thought I would ever see again.The catalog price was WOW EXPENSIVE, but I did see results about a month after starting with much less hair in my shower drain & on my hairbrush. So I thought amazon sold Therapy-G, they sell everything else. They did and it was much more affordable.You first wash your hair with the shampoo, leave it on for 15 seconds according you the directions. I leave it on for about 2 minutes. Rinse it out well. Then you spray on the follicle stimulator, about 12/15 pumps as directed. I only spray on 8. Massaging it into my scalp. Leaving it on for another 2 minutes. Rinse out well. Then applying the conditioner , I leave it in for 2 minutes again. The bottle says only 30 seconds, rinse out well.Your scalp & hair will feel different, well mine did. There is also a hair volumer, I only use this if I am going out for the day. It comes in a spray pump bottle , I spray it into my hands then stroke it through my hair with my fingers.I am going to use these products for a year, really giving them and my hair time to do their thing.I went and got my haircut 3 days ago. She has been cutting my hair for about 7 or 8 years, she noticed a huge difference as well.You can only try it, maybe it will work for you, maybe not, but you'll never know unless you simply wash your hair.One small plus , I also noticed my eyebrows much thicker as well.THANKS FOR READING, BYE🙇

The price for these full well nail tips is truly a great value. I say full well because looking at the photo and the tips I received, they are full well tips. Half well tips are when the well of the tip that actually is sitting on & glued to your natural nail only covers the tip of your natural nail. Look at the photo, these tips cover much more of your natural nail plate, giving the name full well. Which I only use full well.My ring finger is a size 9 . When placing tips on, i would glue a size 5 or 4 tip on depending on the brand. I have used kiss long curved tips with a full well for more than 10 years now, and I will continue to. These tips I received are for the lovely ladies out there with much smaller fingers than mine. These tips are natural looking in color, they are strong, yet not thick at all. But my ring finger took a size 2 of these tips. My thumb is a 2 from the kiss brand, these , my thumb took (barely) the 0. I gave these tips to my daughter in law. She has very small hands.I believe the quality of these as well as the value is a 5 star easy, but as far as my ability to use these tips is 3 or below. I hope this helps the readers out there. If these tips fit me I would be making my switch from kiss to these. Now mind the readers I do not buy the extra wide tips, just the kiss brand tips that are hanging in the Walmart stores in the nail polish section. All the do it yourself gals with hands where your ring finger is at a 5, 6, even 7 could probably use these with no issues.  My daughter in law's wedding ring is a size 5 1/2.There are most definitely for the smaller hand gals. Again I feel these are a good artificial nail tip. They simply don't fit me.THANKS FOR READING, BYE.😄

I do my own fiberglass nails, have for 15 years, give or take. My way of using this is simple. For repairing a cracked , split , or broken nail , lightly buff the area , remove any polish, oil , anything on your nail to be repaired. Take a small, amount of nail resin or nail glue , brush on works best. While the glue is barely tacky, take a strip of this fiberglass & completely cover the section of nail, needing repaired.Tap the fiberglass down gently using an orange stick, cuticle pusher, whatever is handy.Remember whatever you choose to use will have to be wiped clean from the glue. Brush a thin layer of glue over the entire strip, over lapping onto your own nail. Avoid your skin & cuticle area. Now using resin activator spray the repaired area. Hold spray bottle about 6" from your hand. Do this three times, really sealing in the fiberglass.This is what you would do if putting a full set of tips on as well, just covering your entire nails, putting a stress strip across the area where your natural nail meets the tip you applied.  Gently buff your entire nail, apply one more coat glue , spray, buff out the shine .Wipe nail, with alcohol or polish remover. Paint your nails , or not. The activator cures , hardens, and seals the fiberglass you put on your nail.Before my husband retired we laid brick for a living.I mixed the mortar , unloaded the brick, laid pavers .When used the correct way , this will stand the test of time .Yeah you still can break a nail , but this will really add durability & strength to them.Not many of us ladies lay brick and still have long nails . I did while using fiberglass nail wraps.I couldn't find  A.S.P.'s instruction videos for their products, if you really want to use fiberglass for your repairs or for applying tips, go to:BACKSCRATCHERS NAIL SYSTEM, they have videos for everything nail related. Their products as good as they are , I've used them, are very $$$. You can find fiberglass wraps in pre-cut strips as well, as silk wraps in pre-cut strips . The difference between fiberglass & silk is only the thickness & tightness the the fibers. The silk has a  tighter weave , yet thinner then the fiberglass, both equally strong, and both tacky on the back for keeping it in place while working with it. Please just keep in mind you have natural oils on your hands even when clean, so touch the side of the strips as little as possible , or it won't  work as well as it should.Sorry this review left you with so much to read, there are only my personal experiences with a product I have used & trusted for a long time now. 💅THANKS FOR READING, BYE💅

I have had these brushes for quite some time now. I can honestly say how much I love them. Always my first concern with makeup brushes is how well they stand up to regular cleaning. Some alright, some not, bristles coming out before , during and after cleaning them. These hold up well. I have already cleaned them three times. The bristles held up well , kept their shape, and none came out . The way I clean them is I soak them in a clear glass, about 1 or 2 minutes, about  1/4" past the bristles with the cleanser I use on my face. Swishing them around only a couple times,  removing them, running them under very warm water, rolling them back & forth in a clean towel then squeezing the bristles, fanning them out of excess water & letting them air dry, laying flat.These brushes are all full, size makeup brushes.The measurements on these brushes are (FOLLOW THE MEASUREMENTS WITH PHOTO PROVIDED);FOUNDATION BRUSH - 6 3/4" LONGCREAM/LIQUID FOUND ATI ON BRUSH - 6 3/4" LONGMINI KABUKI BRUSH - 2 1/2" LONGBRONZER BRUSH - (FLAT TOP BRISTLES) - 4 1/4" LONGBRUSH BRUSH - (ROUND TOP BRISTLES) - 4 1/4" LONGEREYESHADOW BRUSH - 5" LONGCONCEALER BRUSH - 6" LONGANGLED EYESHADOW BRUSH- 6 1/4" LONGMULTI-TASK BRUSH - 7 1/2"LONGEREYESHADOW SMUDGE BRUSH - 6 1/4"LONGEYELINER BRUSH - 5 3/4" LONGThe handles on these great brushes are a bamboo wood. Very nicely finished, no worries about splintering.The bristles are very, very soft, yet durable enough to handle all your makeup needs.The $$$ is what first got my attention, now I'm purchasing 2 more sets for my two daughter - inlaws.👌THANKS FOR READING, BYE👍

I have been having very bad sharp pains in my left wrist and thumb. My son said I probably have carpal tunnel like my mother had. She was a sseemstress, making wedding gowns , leather jackets, serious sewing. Thirteen sewing machines in her sewing room, all ready to go. She was in her later years wearing a wrist brace for carpal tunnel on both hands everyday.I don't sew, I cut out ornate snowflakes, i do my own fiberglass nails, and am a huge card sender, 100 + christmas cards every year, plus the other holidays. My hands are always busy. I have been using these balls for just 5 days now, and I can honestly say I can feel alittle difference in my left hand. There are 18 exercises for your hands that are on a chart you'll get with the balls. The chart measures 8"   20" , very clear simple drawings. Glossy, thicker paper , but not poster board thick. While having my morning coffee, I do 5 sets of each illustrated exercises. I can't believe how much pain I had in my hand.At night in bed I repeat them again. After the 3rd night, I still felt the pain, just not as bad.These balls are  2" in diameter,  green is soft, yellow is medium, red, which to me looks more like orange is firm. They all felt the same to me, until I started using them.I haven'-t worked my way up to the "red" ball yet. Green in the morning, yellow in the evening. The balls are not sticky or gummy to the touch. They had a slight odor when I first opened them, but it went away shortly after. My grandson misplaced my "red" ball today, my 4 out of 5 stars is maybe these balls could have came with a little pouch to store them in. But no biggie. I am going to order a set of these for a dear friend of mine, she has arthritis in both her hands.My son says if & when I no longer need them, we can always learn to juggle.👍THANKS FOR READING, BYE👌

I have two of these cleavers. I love them. The blade is a stainless steel blade, which is also a product of germany, holding it at an angle you will read solingen germany-ice hardened steel.The cutting blade itself is approximately  4 1/2" in length. The cuttingboard part of this cleaver is not removable,  and measures 4 1/2" long × 1 1/4" long. The entire length of this is 9 1/4" long, the upper part of the handle is 3/4" wide × 3 1/2" long, this measurement is where your thumb rests on the handle. The area for your four fingers is just under 4" in length. Both sides as you are able to see in the photo have a grey rubbing yet smooth finish so your hands won't slip while using this cleaver.At the very end of this cleaver there is a small red locking mechanism for unlocking the cleaver for use & locking it back up for safety & storage.It is very easy to clean. My favorite use for this knife is cutting carrots. With a knife you really feel the knife blade cutting through the carrot, this goes through it like butter. It also can very easily slice through the root end of an entire celery bunch.Then cutting off the tips. I mainly use mine for veggies & fruits , apples pears even grapes for salads. Lunch meats are another no problem food this cleaver goes through. Antipasti salads are made much quicker.This is just simply a handy kitchen gadget to have in your cooking space.🔪THANKS FOR READING, BYE🔪

I have four of these LED under cabinets lights. Two that are black & two white. The measurements stated are accurate. I use the black ones in my very large entertainment center/curio cabinets. They are well lit from the top , with glass shelves where I keep my seraphim angel collection and my Llano angels. So the two black lights sit in the bottom shelves in front (easy to, turn off & on) facing in different directions casting light throughout my cabinets. Because the lights swivel  360  and the round part of the light moves back & forth, with three LED lights in each head (12 total) I am able to direct the light just about anywhere.The other two I keep handy for wherever we may need extra light. Because the bottom is completely flat it can be useful anywhere. We changed our garbage disposal , it was really helpful under the sink. When our power went out , I placed one on our kitchen table . Being able to direct the lights where I needed them was great because our kitchen is odd shaped, but it did light our kitchen up. Yes they can suck the life out of the batteries so  just remember they're on . My grandson left one on when he stayed over. The batteries finally drained completely by day eleven , that was on normal . There is also a dim setting. When my son ordered these for me they were only $15.00 each . I would really like to see these in a woodgrain look (everything else is).💡THANKS FOR READING, 💡

💅 I have been doing my own fiberglass nails now for more then 10 years. I usually use the a.s.p. resin , but I haven't ever been able to find it in brush on bottles. I have been using this for about 5 years , followed by the a.s.p. resin activator. Now this states GEL, but it isn't very thick like the gel for gel nail applications.  To use a resin it is always best to follow up with an activator. Holding the actitvator spray bottle about 6 "  from your nail , or this resin along with any resin or nail glue will take some time to dry. Using the activator speeds up the dry time & hardens the resin you applied to your nails.🌟if you really prefer to use a thicker gel resin or glue try wonder bond , it to is a great product🌟.When taking the brush out of the bottle , it will have plenty of resin on the brush. So to remove some of  the resin from the bristles do not run the brush across the top of the bottle ( unless you keep pliers in your nail kit , resin will dry up inside the brush/cap). Instead, run the brush pull up on the inner side wall of this bottle . If you do get resin on the rim take a piece of paper towel not cotton ball or pad with acetone free polish remover and wipe a rim off while the resin is still wet. I also place this little shot glass so it doesn't tip over and because the shot glass has slanted inner walls , the resin bottle rests inside the glass at an angle.My best results with this product is to use 3 or 4 thin coats , rather then thicker layers.This way the layers will be more even, with less filing in the long run. After applying to your nail , very lightly tap the tip of your nail on a double folded piece of paper towel once or twice .This will prevent your nail tip from becoming thicker at the side ends of your nail. And the folded paper towel protects whatever table finish your working on. I use a yempered glass cutting board on my workspace. I only wish it came in a larger bottle.I hope this helps anyone reading , take your time , relax and just have fun , that's what acetone was made for .💅THANKS FOR READING, BYE💅I

These children's cough & cold relief tablets work Really well. In Michigan where we live , we had another cold cold winter.  With cold weather comes COLDS. MY 3 year old grandson and 7 year old granddaughter both had colds . These very very small 💛 shaped little tablets desolved on their tongues. The packing is unual due to the very very small size. First they come in the soft yellow box as shown , but opening it takes care . It's designed to dispense them. I just opened the box and put them all into a clean pill  bottle.These little 💛's have no flavor but because they are so very very small I can't see anyone having difficulty their small patients taking them. They really helped with my grandkids cough & cold .I gave 2 each to both my grandkids , then 1 every 4 to 6 hours. Their colds really seemed to go away faster. With my grandson it did take a few days longer. This 💛 is about the actually size of these children's cought & cold medicine.💊THANKS FOR READING, BYE💊

I love Halloween masks and this one (in all my many years) has to be my favorite.I live on a ranch with 8 formerly homeless dogs, a mess of goats and chickens and ducks and cats and a formerly homeless burro I adopted whom I named Pablo.My devil mask arrives and I am eager to test it out on the nearest creatures available. And all the "test creatures" just moments earlier saw me walk into my house as I was wearing my blue-jeans and a blue shirt.5 minutes later I come outside wearing the mask and the same shirt and blue jeans. I swear I saw Pablo mutter "WTF" and then he looked at the goats and said "Run for your lives!"The chickens were so afraid they didn't lay eggs for a week!The ducks though must have seen me through the window putting this devil's mask on (so they knew in advance what was going on) and my mask "quacked them up."The dogs howled and ran under the barn, the cats clawed their way up into the mighty oak tree here. And my donkey Pablo made an ass out of himself as he galloped out the pasture and stepped in his own pile of "organic matter."And Halloween night, the fun will just begin!

The "Good News"... 'This is a very well-built and small device actually having a personality like a cross between a pet-rock and a toy Chihuahua.God, is the Go Karma cute. I loved mine.It came in a small package with minimum packing and the smallest manual of any tech-product I've ever purchased.And now the "Bad News"...'Go Karma relies on service coming from the Sprint cell phone company and if you do a Google search for "Sprint Coverage Reviews" you'll come across an article "Sprint coverage is getting 'LESS HORRIBLE" which pretty much means Sprint takes a back-seat to coverage by the big-two careers, and I'm fact Spint rides in the last train car of a very long train and on that last train car, Sprint is stuck in the toilet.Even though a coverage map showed I could get my Go Karma to work in a rural area here in Texas, it couldn't. I had a little better luck driving 50 miles to "the big city" where the Sprint Map suggested it had very strong coverage, my Karma had hit and miss luck at working there (might have been the sparrows flying overhead or some kid flying his paper kite causing problems, but even taking my Go Karma outside (clear of trees) it still had problems with Sprint.Bottom line... Go Karma is s very exciting product especially since your unused data can be cycled-forward to your next month.I have a data plan in my 2015 Chevrolet Volt, costing $50 per month (works EVERYWHERE) but if I don't use all the data, it goes away and won't by passed into the following month. I had hoped the Go Karma would replace my OnStar data plan, but Sprint failed miserably.If Sprint could ever become much more "less than miserable" and create a better and more saturated coverage area, I'd purchase the GoKarma again in a heartbeat.

And then some.My hands hurt every morning when I have been getting up for the past year and I decided to try these gloves.After one month of using them, I'm totally delighted because I have a lot less pain in my hands and the bonus, my wife must be an ESKIMO because she cranks down the AC at night and my hands were freezing.
