So impressed!I received these for testing purposes in exchange for my honest review.

This beard balm wax is 100% organic and smells like vanilla.Made of Beeswax, Shea Butter, Argan Oil, Jojoba Oil, Vitamin E Oil, and Grapeseed Oil.Good sized 2 oz container, the product is a white color.I ordered this for my Dad who likes to tame his handlebar mustache.BIG beard balm has a 60 day guarantee.I bought this at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I ordered this Fingertip Pulse Oximeter Blood Oxygen Saturation Monitor for my father.He has lung issues and was going in for surgery and I really wanted him to have something at home so he could monitor his oxygen levels.This fingertip oxygen sensor was very easy to use.Simply pull the plastic piece to activate the batteries. turn the unit on by pressing the small button on top of the unit. Open the clamp and insert index finger. Within seconds you will have you blood oxygen levels and pulse.The digital display was very easy to read.This also comes with a silicone case to cushion the unit and protect it when traveling.I would have liked to have some sort of information as to what the oxygen levels should read, the normal ranges. As well as the pulse. This information is very important for those monitoring these numbers. And the person caring for them(family/friend) may not be awaare of what the range should be.I received this for testing purposes in exchange for my honest review.I cannot wait to take this to him this weekend.

I have been wanting a different cheese grater, especially when grating my fresh Parmesan cheese.This drum roller type cheese grater has 3 different drums, with a small shredder, medium shredder and a sliced drum.Very easy to use, and you can be right or left handed. It will work either way, which is a huge plus for the lefties of this world.So first you open up the handle and unclip the top and insert your desired drum attachment. Lock into place and insert the cheese into the top compartment above the drum. Then press down firmly on the handle. This will keep the cheese in place and you crank the handle to start the shredding process.I started with my Parmesan cheese and the small shredder. This was easy to use. Cranking became hard at times. Keep in mind Parmesan is a hard dry cheese.Next I inserted the medium shredder roller. And put a chunk of Mozzarella in the top compartment, and proceeded to shred that. It was easy to turn. Next I tried the sliced drum roller. I got small slices of cheese.I posted photos of each cheese and the shredding options in my photos.This grater seems  to be made very well, but I'm a little uncertain about the top of the handle where you grip. I feel like this could be a weak point. I will not let my husband try this. I feel one big squeeze might crack it. I had no problems and loved how easy this was to use. And I did not injure myself as I normally do when shredding Parmesan on my handheld grater.This item will be well used in my household.This is dishwasher safe. I used my top rack.Stainless steel graters.This also comes with lifetime warranty.I received this complimentary for testing purposes in exchange for my honest review.

I love these metal type jaw clips for chips and coffee.You never have to worry about them breaking and the plastic chipping off like the one I compare these to in my photos.I love the strength of these Stainless Steel Jaw clips.There are serrated edges on both of the jaws which means that the clamp is able to hold more items together securely.These clips are 4 inches long.They can be used for more than just chips clips. They can be used to seal coffee packages, keep paperwork clipped together, etc..They come 6 to a pack. They are packaged on a cardboard board with plastic overlay.I received these complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion.

I love the "mace" products from Nature's mace!I have tried other mace products from this company and have been very pleased.This Dog mace is all natural ingredients.We have 3 male dogs and they all mark their territory, and then one by one, the next dog comes right behind the last one, and repeat! There are places in the yard that just reek of urine. There are places like the corner of the garage, shed and certain places in the yard that the have designated to be their own personal urinal!I wanted to use something that would deter them, and that was natural.This product is a granular form, looks alot like coffeegrounds but is actually peanut hulls and smells heavily of natural essential oils like peppermint oil, citronella and lemongrass.I hope they get the hint and find a new place to potty and stay off the sides of the garage and other places that are wooden.I received this complimentary in exchange for my honest review.

I was very excited to order this assorted pack of 100 premium stickers.I say premium as they are very well made. I will be using these for my nieces, nephews and my Grandson! They will love these high quality stickers!These stickers are sun proof and waterproof. Stick them to windows, kids bikes, and they will last!I bought these at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

I love the design of these additional lenses for our cell phone.This is advertised as a 3 n 1 lens system.The clip allows the lens to screw into it and then it clamps onto the cell phone and turns your phone into a neat little camera.I used this on my Iphone 6.The lens are a 180' Fisheye, and a Wide angle/Macro lens. Each lens comes with a lens cover.The clamp is made of a softer material and I used it right over my phone case with no issues.I did read where some people stated this might scratch the phone. They will love these new lens options!

Very excited to be able to use these on my husbands mountain bike.You will get a set of 2 very high quality bike pedals with grooves that catch on the bottom of your shoes as you pedal, so your feet will not slip under the demand of your pedaling power.These have a screw in peg. My husband is quickly becoming a fan of these UPF 50 Dri Fit type material shirts.They are a silky type material, lightweight and easy to breathe material. I'm very excited to have these in our truck and for using with our grandson.We have a quad cab truck which means we have 4 doors, but not 4 full sized doors so the room behind our seats is tight. With my grandson strapped in his carseat in the back, he is constantly kicking and putting his feet on the back of my seat!These car seat protectors are a heavy nylon material that strap around the seat headrest, and near the bottom of the back and base of the seat(where the seat reclines back). The power behind this portable inverter is excellent!This 1300W inverter has both a cigarette/power adapter end as well as the alligator clip to hook directly to a car battery.This will be really useful on our trips in the vehicle. This can power my father's breathing machine using the cigarette charging adapter. Which will be a huge help when traveling or during power outages.This is great for use in vehicle to charge cellphones, tablets or even to run a portable dvd player with the screens for movies in vehicle with the kids.You can hook direct to the battery for items that might need a higher power demand. Like a small compressor for filling up air mattresses, a bigger sized tv or even some smaller power tools.The unit is nice and compact and lightweight. It weights about 2 lbs and is 6 3/4"x3 3/4"x2 1/4".The plugs look a little confusing, but this will accept a standard ac power plug. There's a port for the usb.  There are red and green lights to show when the unit is powered on (green) or if there has been a fault (red), along with the on/off switch.Keep in mind if you are using this in car the car battery will be fine as you are driving and your cars battery is staying charged. But if you are stopped and using a device for a long period of time, you will want to start your vehicle up to recharge your main car battery.Very impressed with the high wattage of this inverter and the price point.I received this for testing purposed in exchange for my honest review.

I love the quality of these stay put suction bowls.This is a set of 3 multi color bowls, and lids. The lime green suction cups works very well! These 2 pack universal fit stroller hooks from Attmu were just what I was looking for.The velcro wraps around the stroller handle and the plastic hooks swivel and can hold your other personal items like your purse, diaper bag, coats or plastic shopping type bags.Each velcro piece is a little over 7 inches long, and can easily wrap around a 2 inch bar.Each hook can handle up to 6 lbs each.These hooks fit securely and will be an awesome improvement to the stroller when taking my grandson on walks, shopping and to the zoo.These would make a great gift for new parents.I received these for testing purposes in exchange for my honest review.

I was very impressed with the presentation of DMC Innovation's 2 handles leash.This leash came rolled up in it's own little pouch and was housed in a cute little box with a pull out drawer.I was not expecting a leash to be inside this cute little gift box.This 4 foot padded leash is very nice quality. The reason they call this a 2 handle leash is there is also a built in strap 1 foot above where the collar would attach on the dog, so you can easily grab there and keep the dog close to you in case he gets a little too curious and tries to pull toward whatever is catching it's interest.The latch is also high quality and easy to clip onto the dog's collar.Cute little red logo (hand in hand) nicely stitched onto leash.This high quality nylon leash is machine washable but states it's better to hand wash the item.Lifetime guarantee.I would highly recommend this 4 foot double handle leash.I received this for testing purposes in exchange for my honest review.

This lime green trash can with lid is just the perfect size for a small bathroom, travel trailer or anyplace where a compact garbage can is needed.I actually plan on putting this in my bathroom in my RV due to the compact size.The rectangular shaped can measurements are- Length 9.52 inches Width 7.28 inches  Height 14 inches including the swing top lidThe green swing top lid is a great feature. The white can top does have 2 clamps on each side to keep the lid in place.Cand also has the 3 gallon can liners that work just perfect for this can.On the green part of the trash can under the lid there a 2 pull up handles to take the whole can out to the garbage if necessary.Very well made. I would love to see a Kitchen can in this same style.This little garbage can worked just great for my needs, and will keep my nosey dog from getting into the garbage can.I received this for testing purposes in exchange for my honest opinion.

This 8 slice apple corer by Westmark is a high quality Stainless Steel frame with cushioned green colored handles.This Apple slicer also cores as it slices.This is dishwasher safe and very easy to use.This will come in handy when making apple pies, applesauce and just for the cutting of an apple to snack on.This Apple Slicer/corer was pretty easy for me to use. There are so many great things about this antimicrobial toothbrush from Pro-sys.The bristles have a unique feature, they are a StaCleanTM technology with silver and zinc to inhibit the growth of microorganisms.The bristles of this toothbrush are very soft and gentle on your teeth and gums.I was surprised by the unique design of the handle. This CardioTech Pro Digital blood pressure cuff was very easy to get set up and easy to use.The cuff came with the 2 batteries needed, and a storage case, and instruction booklet.Easy to install batteries. Easy to program.The blood pressure cuff fits on your left wrist and is very quiet during operation.I found the reading to be right on, with what my reading normally runs.Good easy to read digital display. I ordered this for my Mother in law to try since she has been teetering on the border of high sugars and being a diabetic.I read through parts of the book, and it seems like there is alot of information from various Doctors that I have heard of before.I'm not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing. But I think you can take parts of what they are saying and apply it to your lifestyle, meat eater or vegetarian.I think proper diet and exercise can play an important part of dealing with your health, and hopefully keeping you diabetes free.If nothing else it's an easy read and you do come away with some good recipes and knowledge from these Authors and doctors.I received this complimentary in exchange for my honest review.

Very easy read.This book's recipes are geared toward the Nutribullet in terms of measurement to fill line. My husband was very surprised when he opened the package and saw a pocket Chainsaw blade with handles!He smiled and said this is going to be great on our ATV/UTV riding excursions!The 24 inch chainsaw blade is very sharp, and is connected to a fabric handle on easy side, to easily grasp and start sawing.This would be great in any emergency situation where there are tree limbs or small trees preventing you from accessing an area.Would be great when camping and you need to cut branches for a fire or marshmallow sticks or hotdog sticks.I would venture to guess probably a 2 inch round would be an average size to use this on.Maybe bigger branches, but it might take you a little more effort.This blade comes with a nice carrying pouch with clasp, that has the loops to attach to the side of a belt.Well designed and thought out. Very sturdy piece of equipment and would work perfectly during those challenging times when you need something to cut with and have nothing available.I would recommend this to have in any camping type kit, or in an RV. In a UTV/ATV underseat kit. Even put in a car or truck glovebox for that emergency situation.I received this at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

I ordered this Portable Boombox for my husband to take to work with himThis radio is very unique.This is the first radio I have seen with a USB hookup, an SD card slot and an AUX input! You may be asking what all that is for... You can load music to your SD card, use the USB to hook into some Cell phones to listen to your playlist, or use the AUX post to hook up a bluetooth receiver to pull music off you cellphone, or plug in an aux cable to a MP3 player for your playlist. The possibilities are amazing!This also has the AM/FM radio as well as a CD player built in. The sound is quite good, considering the compact size of this boombox.This plugs into the AC power with the cord or uses 6 C batteries( not included) . The cord has a hideaway compartment if you are using just the batteries, for ultimate portability.All button are easy to access on the front of the unit. Dial for the radio is located on the right size. The AUX port is located on the back of the unit.Hubby has chosen to use this at work, and loves it!I could not figure out how to listen to my music using the USB and my Iphone 6. Hubby has a Windows phone and was listening to his music just fine. It did sound different when listening through his phone and the USB connection. He said there was probably a setting he needed to switch on his phone, as it was kinda muffled when playing.The price point seems a bit high, but considering all the features, makes this product alot different than other like products, and totally worth it.I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

I ordered this scar cream for a friend who's daughter has some terrible scarring from an accident.She wanted to find a natural product to try and get the scars to fade.I like that the ingredients are made with natural ingredients and that this product is made in the USA.The scar gel is a brown colored gel. "Lee's Colonels: A Biographical Register of the Field Officers of the Army of Northern Virginia" by Robert K. Krick (Morningside Publications, 1991, 520 pages).  "Lee's Colonels: A Biographical Register of the Field Officers of the Army of Northern Virginia," is an invaluable reference to the Lieutenant Colonels and Colonels that were assigned to the Army of Northern Virginia.  Mr. Krick to the best of his ability alphabetically listed these officers on all the regiments (Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas,  and Virginia) and their brief biographical history.  In this reference book, there is no "frills" of narration of the officers.  The information of the officers are straight forward as where they were born, married, career before the war, battles fought in, if they were prisoners, killed in action or survived the war, and date of death, and where buried.  There are a few facts in the biographies if it is of special importance.Pictures of various colonels are throughout this book.  Lists of Regiments and Battalions in the Army of Northern Virginia are appendixes. in the back of the book.  The chapters are as follows:- Acknowledgments- Introduction to Third Edition- Introduction to Second Edition- Introduction- Ages of Lee's Colonels- Miscellaneous- Heights of Lee's Colonels- Education, Pre-War Occupations, Post-War Occupations, Post-War Mortality, Notes and Abbreviations, Biographical Sketches, Confederate Field Officers other than ANV, Introduction to Appendix, Regiments and Battalions in the ANV.Mr. Krick is to be commended for his thorough research for this fascinating and important reference book.  This is an extremely important work for any serious Civil War scholar, researcher, historian, genealogist and author.  It provides information that can be used to document a families forefather that fought for the Confederacy in the Army of Northern Virginia.  It is also a handy read for the "arm-chair" historian who wants to learn the history of the individual Colonels that fought in the Army of Northern Virginia.  This is an important and fascinating reference book that is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

"History of Travis County and Austin 1839-1899" by Mary Starr Barkley (The Steck Company, 1963, 388 pages).  "History of Travis County and Austin 1839-1899" by Mary Starr Barkley is the history of the capital of the Republic, then the state of Texas and it's formation of being a small frontier town to the important capital of Texas over a 60 year time span.  Ms. Barkley relates the growth of a community from a small spot in the center of Texas wilderness to its important place in Texas' political and economic world.  First called "Waterloo" the town was selected as the capital of the Republic of Texas in 1839, and the name was soon changed to honor the pioneer and one of the first founders of Texas, Stephen F. Austin.The six decades of history presented in this book gives an excellent insight into the persons who laid the foundation for Travis County and Austin as the capital and capital county of Austin.  Government officials, both state and local merchants, educators, clergymen, farmers, adventureers, average citizens, (and a few outlaws and banditos) are presneted and explained with great clarity and fascinating prose.  All facets of Austin are included as the county first surged to life with rugged optimism, went through the split of brother versus brother, and family versus family during the Civil War.  Many regiments that fought for the Confederacy gathered in Austin and were sent off to fight in the Army of Northern Virginia, Army of Tennessee, Trans-Mississippi theater regiments.  The men from Texas would enlist and then hear great speeches from the officials of the state and the Confederate government to bolster spirits of the men who fought for the south.  However, at the same time there was a sizeable citizenry in Austin that were against secession including Texas great and an important founder Sam Houston, who tried in vain to keep Texas neutral and out of the Civil War.  During the early days of secession, 6th street in Austin would host huge bonfires with effigy's of Abraham Lincoln lit afire and sing great patriotic Confederate songs.  As the war progressed however, many would gather in Austin to hear the news of far off battles such as Gaines Mill, Second Manassas (Bull Run), Sharpsburg (Antietam), Gettysburg, Vicksburg, Chickamauga, Franklin and other terrible battles and see the casualty lists that claimed the lives of many men from Austin.  Economic hardship was also prevalent in the capital of Texas.After the Civil War Austin, as the rest of Texas, was set back due to Reconstruction and it would be over 20 years until Austin and Texas would rebound and have great growth in the 1880's and 1890's.The author has presented in an interesting way the threads of history of this local history.  Ms. Barkley used documents, books, newspapers, and narratives as source materials and used personal interviews with the "old timers" of Austin to give this complete 60 year history of the capital of the Great State of Texas.The chapters are: 1. Path of the Pinoeers 2. Geography-Topography-Indians 3. Austin in 1839 4. Austin, 1839-1846 5. Austin, 1846-1860 6. Austin, 1861-1870 7. Austin, 1870-1899 8. Austin in 1899 9. Education-Schools 10. The University of Texas 11. Capitol and Newspapers 12. Civic Development (Fire and Police Protection, Utilities) 13. Economic Development 14. Religious Development 15. Recreation, Historic Homes, Arts, Folklore. Appendix, References, Index.This is a very IMPORTANT book because Austin reflected the hardship, growth, war, and opportunity that was also Texas.  Ms. Barkley has woven together a vital history of the capital of the Lone Star State and it should be in every serious student, scholar, and historian of Texas and Texas History library.  It is a book that is VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED and is a MUST HAVE to any devotee to Texas history.

"Reminiscences of Company H First Arkansas Mounted Rifles" by Dr. Robert H. Dacus (Post-Dispatch Print, 1897, 48 pages).  "Reminiscences of Company H First Arkansas Mounted Rifles" by Dr. Robert H. Dacus is the battle history of this regiment of the famed "First Arkansas Mounted Rifles" written by a soldier some 32 years after the end of the Civil War.  Dr. Dacus during the war was a private in the First Arkansas Rifles and tells the battle history of the regiment as they fought primarily in the Western then Trans-Mississippi theater.He begins his memories saying "What I have written has been almost entirely from memory; having nothing but the company roll to guide me; and as more than thirty years has elapsed the incidents recorded occurred.  I feel that someone ought to give to posterity a condensed but true history of every company of Arkansas troops that served in the war.  Were this done, and the whole taken and compiled into historical form, it would show the heroic part by Arkansas in the great struggle for state supremacy, one of the grandest of all the grand principles of Democracy."Throughout this short but fascinating read Dr. Dacus gives the history of the various battles of company H and they were intense. The company was formed at Fort Smith, Arkansas and drilled and then were in their first battles at Oak Hill, MO and then at Elkhorn Tavern (Pea Ridge) Arkansas.  It was then transferred east of the Mississippi and under the command of Generals P. T. Beauregard,  Braxton Bragg, Joseph E. Johnston, John Bell Hood, and then at the time of surrender again under General Joseph E. Johnston.This hard fighting regiment was in the major engagements of battles in the Trans-Mississippi/Western Theater from Pea Ridge to Bentonville.  Between these battles they were in the Chickamauga Campaign, Meridian and Atlanta Campaign, Franklin-Nashville Campaign, and finally the Carolina Campaigns. Dr. Dacus gives brief descriptions of the battles and what Company H did in the battles.  It is an intense read full of heroism by the soldiers of Company H.  This is one of the few reminiscences where a soldier does not describe mainly the camp life of the soldiers.  However, it is not needed in this short read.  The battles are descriptive enough of the hardships the company and regiment went through.  Even though the official name of the company was Mounted Rifles, they fought mostly dismounted.This is a fascinating read that is a valuable source of information about an Arkansas Regiment.  There are not nearly enough published history about the brave regiments from Arkansas that fought in the War Between the States and especially the Western/Trans-Mississippi theater of the war.  This history provides an invaluable source to fill in the lesser known history of western regiments of the Confederacy.Dr. Dacus did a tremendous service to the history of the Confederate regiments from Arkansas, Confederate military history, and Arkansas History in this excellent history.  Highly Recommended!

"The Army of Tennessee" by Stanley F. Horn (University of Oklahoma Press, 3rd Printing, 1941, 503 pages). "The Army of Tennessee" by Stanley F. Horn is the monumental book about the major Confederate army in the western theater of the Civil War.  This monumental work is in-depth and the narrative is excellent by the author Stanley F. Horn.  The author tells the history of this tragic yet valorous army that fought in many states against the Union army. The Army of Tennessee had ever-changing commanders, jealousy and bickering among the major generals in the army, many hard fought battles and many "what ifs" and "could have been".  While the Army of Northern Virginia was the main attention in the history of the Civil War, the Army of Tennessee was just as important and fought in just as many hard fought battles as their brothers in the eastern theater of the war.The Army of Tennessee was the major army of the Confederacy that operated between the Appalachians and the Mississippi River.  It carried the fortunes of the south and on its bayonets went into major battles numerous times often being ill-equipped and without major supplies.  This excellent army went against the Union's best generals such as U.S. Grant, George "The Rock of Chickamauga" Thomas, William T. Sherman and it matched these generals blow-by-blow.  From the fighting at Shiloh where the first general of the Army of Tennessee  the Texan Albert Sidney Johnston was killed, to the hard and bloody fought battle at Chickamauga where the army suffered heavy casualties, the Army of Tennessee's soldiers were noted for their brave and tenastic fighting.  Yet the Army of Tennessee would be denied victory many times due to the unwise decisions of its commanders such as Braxton Bragg who would suffer defeat from the almost victory after the Battle of Chickamauga in 1863 where the Army would suffer defeat at Chattanooga and Lookout Mountain.The Army of Tennessee would be commanded by Joseph E. Johnston an excellent general but an "enemy" of Confederate President Jefferson Davis.  The animosity between these two leaders would hinder the Army of Tennessee as did the in-fighting between the generals in the army.  The Army of Tennessee would suffer heavily in the battle of Franklin under yet another commander John Bell Hood, who before Franklin would lead the Texas Brigade in the Army of Northern Virginia and would win the famous early battles of the Civil War against the Army of the Potomac.  However, as a corps commander General Hood would suffer defeat as he was not able to lead the Army of Tennessee and would make a grievous error at Franklin.The Army of Tennessee tried to stop General William T. Sherman as his army marched through Georgia and would make Sherman pay for his mistake at Kennesaw Mountain outside of Atlanta.  However, this would be a fruitless victory for the Army of Tennessee and the Confederacy as Sherman would continue his destructive march through the Georgia countryside.  The Army of Tennessee would ultimately surrender to the Union as its General Joseph E. Johnston surrendered to General William T. Sherman in North Carolina a few weeks after General Robert E. Lee surrendered the Army of Northern Virginia at Appomattox Courthouse in April 1865.Mr. Horn rightfully makes the case that it wasn't due to the soldiers and officers fighting spirit that would make the Army of Tennessee lose major battles, but it was the constant in-fighting between its commanders and ever replacing the major commanders that would lead to nearly won victory's but not clear victory's the Confederacy dearly needed.  This in-depth and fascinating history clearly states that case.Mr. Horn is to be recommended for this monumental book that is the definitive history of the Army of Tennessee.  It was first published in 1941, and is the referenced history for many other author's and historians books about the Civil War in the Western Theater.The prose is outstanding, the references are clearly accurate, and the maps inside this classic work enhance the reader to understand the actions of the Army of Tennessee.This is a very important book on the Civil War and must be considered a vital part of anyone's Civil War library.  Simply said, if a reader doesn't have this book in their own Civil War personal library, then their library is missing a vital history and will have a noticeable incomplete Civil War library.This is a MUST have to any serious student, author, historian or Civil War Scholar.  It is a must have for anyone interested in the Western Theater of the Civil War, Confederate Military History, Union Military History of the Western Theater and Civil War History overall.  It is not merely a recommended history but should be a REQUIRED history to any serious Civil War scholar, historian, or student!  A MUST HAVE!

"The Highly Irregular Irregulars: Texas Rangers In the Mexican War" by Frederick Wilkins (Eakin Press, 226 Pages).  "The Highly Irregular Regulars" Texas Rangers in the Mexican War" is the history of the famous Texas Rangers during the Mexican War of the 1840's.  When the United States declared war with Mexico it called on for men to fight and conquer Mexico and their "upstart".  Thousands of Texans would volunteer to join in the fight against Mexico.  The Texas Rangers was one of the fiercest units in this war.  In the beginning chapters of this excellent book, Mr. Wilkins gives the history of the Texas Revolution and the men who fought for Texas against General Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna.  Many of the men of the Texas Revolution were still angry towards Mexico and the Mexican Army so they enthusiastically would join in the fight against Mexico for the second time.The governor of Texas and the U.S. Government called for the men and they were formed under such leaders as Jack Hays and Ben McCulloch who would in less than 20 years later become a Confederate General.  The Texas Rangers during the Mexican War would endure hardships and lack of efficient supplies, however, these hardships would not affect their ferocity against the enemy or the "wildness" of the Texans.Many of the Texas Rangers had years of fighting before the war against hostile Comanches, Kiowas, and Apaches in Texas.  Many of the Rangers also had "checkered backgrounds" and were on the wrong side of the frontier law of Texas.  Combining these men into regiments definitely led to some "fierce and wild regiments" and many times would show no mercy towards overrunning the enemy.The Texas Rangers would also fall under the commander of U.S. Forces in Mexico Zachary Taylor who would assign the Rangers in some of the toughest fighting of the war in places such as Monterrey, Buena Vista, and other locations in Northern and Central Mexico.Under excellent leadership from Samuel H. Walker, Jack Hays and Ben McCulloch, the Rangers became well known for their fierce fighting but also as unpredictable and wild men who would often take the valuables off of the Mexican prisoners and the dead and keep the "fortunes of war" for themselves.  The Rangers would also display "lawlessness" that was often overlooked by their officers in the regiment, as they knew that in combat the Texas Rangers were always ready to fight".  Supplies not only for the Rangers but also for the U.S. Army in Mexico was piecemeal at best so they would often have to forage for their own food and supplies and would raid towns in Mexico to get their supplies.After the U.S. defeated Mexico, many of the Rangers found it hard to adapt to "peacetime" and would become bounty hunters, others would go back to Mexico, where the law was few and far between the frontier.  Others would go back to Texas and resume their frontier and city lives.Mr. Wilkin's fascinating read of the "Irregular Regulars" is a valuable history of the Texas Rangers in the War with Mexico.  His descriptions of the weapons the Rangers would use is also a valuable history of the weapons used during the Mexican War.  His description of daily camp life among the rangers is accurate and provides excellent photos, illusrations and stories of the men not only in camp life but also in describing the action against the Mexican Army. The chapters are: 1. The Legend Begins 2. First Service 3. The Regiments Form 4. June 1846 5. Toward Monterrey 6. Armistice 8 The Walker Colt 9. Buena Vista 10. Chevallie's Battalion 11. Central MexicoI highly recommend this book for anyone interested in Texas History, The Mexican War History, Texas Ranger History and U.S. History of the 1840's.  A GREAT READ!

"The Civil War Reminiscences of Major Silas T. Grisamore C.S.A. edited with an introduction by Arthur W. Bergeron Jr. (Louisiana State University Press, 1993, 227 pages).  "The Civil War Reminiscences of Major Silas T. Grisamore C.S.A." is the diary of this officer/quartermaster of the 18th Louisiana Infantry Regiment that fought mainly in the Trans-Mississippi Theater of the War Between the States and in Louisiana.  Silas T. Grisamore, originally born in Indiana in 1825 and moved to Louisiana when he was 21 in 1846 was a merchant before the war.  When the war began, Grisamore enlisted with the Lafourche Creoles, soon to become Company G of the 18th Louisiana Infantry Regiment and was commissioned as the quartermaster officer of the regiment due to his experience as a merchant.  Much of his service during the war was as the quartermaster (supply and acquisitions) of the regiment and later the infantry division.Major Grisamore's personal diary details the daily life, the battles, the hardships that the regiment went through.  Many of the Major's tales are humoerous such as one account where a Colonel of the regiment was actually relieved that his brand new uniform was left behind and "captured" by the Union.  He hated new clothes and a "burden was lifted" when the Yankees captured the house he was  in after he escaped the night before.  Major Grisamore also details the hardships of obtaining supplies for the regiment during the war, as the war dragged on, supplies were harder to get and severe shortages was common to a Confederate Regiment and the 18th Louisiana Infantry Regiment was no exception.  Major Grisamore was also in close proximity to many of the battles the regiment fought in.  From Shiloh to Pleasant Hill, Mansfield and other battles in and around Louisiana, the major is a keen observer of the terrible reality of battle and gives an excellent and accurate account of the regiment in battle.Major Grisamore provides detailed information about the status of General Alfred Mounton during the battle of Labadieville and the actions of General Henry H. Silby at the battle of Bisland that are not found in any other sources thus far.  Major Grisamore was an excellent writer and observer.After the war, Major Grisamore beginning in 1867 under the pseudonym of "Uncle Silas," wrote his memories to a a local newspaper "The Weekly Thibodaux Sentinel" as a weekly entry of his reminiscences of the war.  He would write these articles up into 1871.  Arthur W. Burgeron would take the reminiscences of Major Grisamore and presented them in chronological order with excellent footnotes and author's notes that greatly help the reader follow the actions of the 18th Louisiana Infantry Regiment and the actions of Major Grisamore.  At the end of the book, Major Grisamore provides the history of the officers of the 18th Louisiana and what they did after the war.This is an excellent book that is a valuable resource to anyone interested in a Confederate regiment from Louisiana and the supplies they procured in order to survive.  This excellent book also provides a valuable service in describing the lesser known battles and skirmishes in Louisiana and the Trans-Mississippi Theater that are not well known.I highly recommend this to anyone interested in the Civil War in the Trans-Mississippi Theater, Confederate Louisiana history, and history of the 18th Louisiana Infantry Regiment.  Highly recommended!

"The Fighting Fifth Pat Cleburne's Cutting Edge: The Fifth Arkansas Infantry Regiment. (Floyd R. Barnhill Sr, 1990, 245 pages.)  "The Fighting Fifth Pat Cleburne's Cutting Edge: The Fifth Arkansas Infantry Regiment" by Flolyd R. Barnhill Sr. and Major Calvin L. Collier is the fascinating history of one of the hardest fighting Confederate regiments in the western theater of the Civil War.  The author's grandfather fought in the Fifth Arkansas and this book honors his service in the Civil War.  The Fifth Arkansas was part of the Arkansas Brigade organized in 1861 by General William J. Hardee at Pittman's Ferry on the Current River.  The brigade was commanded at various times by Generals S. A. M. Wood, T. C. Hindman, St. John Richardson Liddell, Daniel Govan, and the by one of the finest and fiercest Generals in the Confederate Army Patrick Cleburne.Very little information exists relating to the Arkansas regiments that marched off to the war and even less is known about the regiments raised in Northeast Arkansas, however because of the author's excellent research he has been able to write a fascinating and accurate history of one of the regiments, The Fifth Arkansas Infantry Regiment.  The author has graphically recounted the exploits of this regiment as it fought in many battles such as Perryville, Murfreesboro, Chickamauga, Atlanta and Franklin.  These fierce battles are shown how hard and fierce the Fifth Arkansas Regiment fought and suffered many casualties in the battles against fearful odds.The men of the Fifth saw the enemy in plain sight and close up for the first time at the Battle of Perryville, Kentucky and it was a small introduction to the many bloody battles the Fifth fought in.  The regiment marched from Arkansas at the beginning of the war and then would march over Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia and North Carolina and while doing so their casualty list in killed and dead of wounds would surmount.  At the end of December 1862, they were again in the battle at Murfreesboro against the Union Army and the men of the Fifth Arkansas would go into battle with many having no shoes and had to wear feed sacks or rags tied to their feet with twine.  Many were without coats or serviceable trousers.  Those who did had liberated them from dead and wounded Union soldiers and brought them from the field at Murfreesboro. The Fifth would also fight in the battles of Liberty Gap, Ringgold, Resaca, New Hope Church-Pickett's Mill, Marietta, Kennesaw Mountain, Atlanta, Jonesboro, Decatur, Nashville and at the end of the war the few that survived fought at Bentonville and surrendered in April of 1865 as part of the army of General Joseph E. Johnston.Throughout this excellent book the authors describe the attitudes of the men as fiercely loyal to Arkansas and the Confederacy, the harshness of disease and sickness that swept through the army, the endless marches with little rest, and between battles the everyday life of living in camp.Major Calvin L. Collier (USAF, Ret) the author of many fine books about Arkansas regiments contributed and edited to this excellent book and both authors have written an outstanding "biography" of one of General Cleburne's fine Arkansas Regiments over the four years of the War Between the States.  The appendixes have the muster rolls of the Fifth Arkansas Infantry Regiment, the casualty lists of the various battles."The Fighting Fifth" was self-published and is EXTREMELY RARE with only 500 copies being published, and is VERY expensive (several hundred dollars), however, this being said it is a very important history to anyone interested the regiments under General Patrick Cleburne, the history of the battles in the Western and Trans-Mississippi Theater of the war, Confederate Arkansas history, Confederate Military history, and Civil War history in general.  A HIGHLY RECOMMENDED read!

"The Thirty-seventh North Carolina Troops: Tar Heels in the Army of Northern Virginia" by Michael C. Hardy (McFarland & Company, Inc, 2003, 346 pages).  "The Thirty-seventh North Carolina Troops: Tar Heels in the Army of Northern Virginia" by Michael C. Hardy is the fascinating and thorough history of the soldiers of North Carolina who made up this Tar Heel Regiment that fought in the Army of Northern Virginia.  The author from numerous sources wrote the history of the officers and men who fought four years under the leadership of General Robert E. Lee and other excellent and not-so-excellent generals and leaders in the Army of Northern Virginia.  As the back cover states, "This account of the unit's four years of service, told largely in the soldiers' own words.  Drawn from letters, diaries, and postwar articles and interviews, this history follows the unit from its organization in November 1861 until its surrender at Appomattox."  The author has done OUTSTANDING research in compiling all the sources to write this history of a hard fighting regiment.  This is NOT a casual read of a Civil War Regiment, it is an in-depth "biography" of a regiment.  Mr. Hardy gives great honor to the soldiers of the 37th NC Regiment in writing the history of the regiment mostly in their own words, however, there is numerous maps, photographs of the officers and men of the regiment that were taken during and after the war, an outstanding bibliography, appendixes, author's notes, and other excellent references that help the reader understand the complete history of the 37th NC.  After reading this, it is easy to understand why Michael C. Hardy is considered to be one of the top historians of North Carolina history.  His books are well documented, have excellent prose, thoroughly researched and an invaluable resource into North Carolina Civil War and post Civil War history.There is so much fascinating history that it would take several pages to account for each important historical account of the regiment.  Suffice to say this is an OUTSTANDING history of the hard fighting North Carolina regiment that is invaluable to anyone interested in the history of Confederate North Carolina, the Army of Northern Virginia, battles of the eastern theater of the Civil War, and Civil War history in general.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

"Fight and Survive! A History Of Jackson County, Arkansas In the Civil War." by Lady Elizabeth Watkins (River Road Press, 1974, 203 Pages).  "Fight and Survive! A History Of Jackson County Arkansas In the Civil War", is the history of this county in northern Arkansas that was a key point of mustering Confederate soldiers, and a key transportation portal that was fought over by both Union and Confederate forces during the Civil War.  Ms. Watson, the author provides a fascinating story of the men who overwhelmingly joined Confederate Regiments from Jackson County and fought primarily in the Trans-Mississippi Theater in the First Arkansas Infantry Regiment as well as many other regiments provided from the state of Arkansas when the state seceded from the Union and joined the Confederacy in 1861.Jacksonport, Arkansas (the county seat) was one of the main mustering points for the Confederate army in Arkansas.  Throughout the war, both armies contended for possession of this strategic port that shipped cotton, corn and other agricultural supplies.  Located at the center of the White and Black river trade.  The Confederate attack on Helena was planned here in 1863 by Generals Sterling Price and Theophilus H. Holmes.  At various times Jacksonport was headquarters for such military leaders as Earl Van Dorn, John S. Marmaduke, Dandridge McRae and Jo Shelby.  Thus the importance of having a protection of the county from enemy forces was quite evident.Jackson County provided many young men to the Confederacy and Ms. Watson describes the tremendous burden of supplying these men the adequate food, clothing, weaponry and other essentials for the men in the Arkansas Regiments.  From the first "rush" of excitement of the men who wrote home with "war fever" to the harsh reality of sickness that killed many men in the first years of the war, to the skirmishes and battles these soldiers from Jackson County fought and were wounded and killed.  Jackson county faced the harsh realities of hostile Union forces who were looking to seize food-stores, supplies and capture Confederate soldiers.  Many families would suffer sever hardships, yet remained resolved to the Confederate cause throughout the war. Ms. Watson has the newspaper articles, letters from the soldiers, official reports from the Confederate officers and great photos of the leaders who were in and fought in Jackson County during the war.  Many skirmishes were fought in Jackson County and the author describes the short but fierce action.  Jackson County suffered from bushwhackers, roving bandits, renegades and other fierce men who would prey on the civilian population due to a lack of legal deputies and other officials.  General Jo Shelby and other leaders demanded more soldiers from the county and state to join the Confederacy and many families did provide all their fathers and sons,but some would hide their sons and fathers as the war wore on.  However, Jackson County provided a key and proud service for Arkansas and the Confederacy as did most counties throughout the Confederate States.Men from Jackson county wold join the 1st, 2nd, 7th, 8th, 30th, 31st, 32nd, 37th, Arkansas Infantry Regiments, Jackson Artillery, 1st, 2nd, 45th, 46th, 47th,  Arkansas Cavalry Regiments, Ford's Arkansas Cavalry Battalion, Hooker's Company of Arkansas Mounted Volunteers, McGehee's Arkansas Cavalry Regiment, and the 1st Regiment of Arkansas Mounted Rifles,  She also provides a roll of each of these regiments and battalions so it is very useful to trace genealogy for those interested in their Civil War ancestors.  Maps are included that show the key river locations and troop positions in Jackson County, both Union and Confederate.This is an outstanding book and resource of history that gives the background of a county that supported the Confederacy for four years.  Jackson County did a tremendous service and Ms. Watson's fascinating account of the history of Jackson County, Arkansas is a valuable resource of information about the Confederate history of Northern Arkansas, the Trans-Mississippi Theater, Arkansas Confederate History and regiments, and civilian life during the Civil War.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

"With The 11th New York Fire Zouaves In Camp, Battle, and Prison: The Narrative of Private Arthur O'Neil Alcock in The New York Atlas and Leader." by Brian C. Pohanka and Patrick A. Schroeder. (Schroeder Publications, 2011, 232 pages).  "With The 11th New York Fire Zouaves" is the fascinating read of a series of letters that a Union Soldier Private Arthur O'Neil Alcock wrote to his hometown Newspaper of the New York Atlas and Leader.  His letters provide a view into the life of a Union Zoave Soldier in camp, marches, and battles.  The late Civil War Historian Brian Pohanka author of "Vortex of Hell" about the 5th New York Zouaves, and Appomattox Court House National Historic Park Historian Patrick Schroeder did an outstanding job editing these letters and also providing an excellent introduction about the zouaves and the regiment that was made famous by Colonel Elmer Ellsworth who was the leader of the famous drill unit before he was killed by a tavern owner while removing a Confederate Flag in 1861.Private Alcock's letters provide a view into the life of these firemen turned soldiers during the Civil War.  This regiment would fight in battle after battle, they put out a hotel fire or two, they would drill most proficiently and would lose many men to battle and sickness.  Private Alcock himself would be mortally wounded during the battle of the Wilderness when a minie bullet struck him above the left knee and cause his leg to be amputated and he would never recover from the surgery and died at the age of 44 in 1864.The editors as always provide outstanding photographs of the officers and men of the 11th New York, as well as many illustrations to enhance the readers appreciation of the regiment.  Both editors are known for their dedication of the history of the New York Zouaves and have done a great honor of the history of the New York Zouaves with the addition of this fine book as well as their other books.I highly recommend this excellent book to anyone interested in the history of the famous New York Zouave Regiments that fought in the Civil War, the history of the Army of the Potomac, the battles of the eastern theater of the Civil War, and New York Civil War History!

"General Lee and Hood's Texas Brigade at the Battle of the Wilderness" by Dayton Kelley (Hill Junior College Press, 1969, 75 pages) is about the famous incident during the Battle of the Wilderness on May 6, 1864 where General Robert E. Lee, (Commanding General of the Army of Northern Virginia) was at the front lines during the Battle and as the men of Hood's Texas Brigade were being formed into line of battle in preparation to stem the Federal Advance they became aware that General Lee intended to lead the brigade.  Realizing the danger that General Lee put himself in, they shouted and implored him to go to the rear out of danger.  From all sides arose the shout, "Lee to the rear!  Lee to the rear!"A Texan stepped out of the ranks and caught Traveller's (General Lee's horse) bridle, turning the horse and rider around and away from the fire to the front.  The Texas Brigade then moved forward behind its commander, General John Gregg and went into battle at the right time to stem the Federal Advance.Mr. Kelley in this account examines and tells the history of the account from many of the men who witnessed it.  From the reports of General James Longstreet down the ranks to Sergeant J. B. Polley of the Fourth Texas Infantry Regiment there are many who remember this and give their views of General Lee's desire to lead the charge.  There is always different views of what happened and who actually took Traveller's bridle and led General Lee to the back of the lines, however the overall account remains true and accurate. In the book there are paintings and illustrations of the incident done by various artists over the years.Mr. Kelley also tells that this was not the first time that General Lee wanted to be at the front of a charge.  During the Battle of Spotsylvania, General Lee wanted to lead the charge against the Federals with regiments of either Georgia or Mississippi (various accounts differ), and they too told General Lee to get behind the lines so he could be safe from harm.This interesting book only describes the incident and not the entire battle.  Mr. Kelley used letters, correspondence, and other accounts from the veterans in the book.This is a rare book that is a bit expensive, however it is a must have for those who want to learn about the famous history of General Lee offering to lead the charge.This is an the only dissent is that Mr. Kelley should have written the history of the Texas Brigade during the entire battle and not just the one incident with General Lee.  However, that being said, this is a book that I recommend to those who want to know about the famous "General Lee to the rear!" account.  General Robert E. Lee was a brave and courageous leader who was willing to lead the charge against the Army of the Potomac, and it was only the love and devotion of his troops that prevented him to lead the charge that would have certainly got him killed or seriously wounded.Highly recommended to those Civil War students, authors/historians who want to know more about the Battle of the Wilderness, Hood's Texas Brigade, Confederate Military History, and Civil War History.

The Olympia Tools 85-188 Collapsible Service Cart is very handy to have around!  If you need it to put your kitchen utensils and have no room in your kitchen drawers then you can have this to store them in.  If you need it for your bathrooms supplies you can use it there.  If you need it in the garage, den, or any kind of room you can store them in any room in the house inside or outside.  It is collapsible so you can put it in your closet or against the wall.  It is VERY handy indeed!

Dove Men+ Care Dry Spray Antiperpirant is a refreshing deoderant that isn't heavily perfumed, isn't wet and sticky and still keeps the underarms dry.  For many years spray deoderants were wet and sticky and the smell would fade just after a few hours.  This isn't so with Dove Men+Care Spray Antiperspirant.  It has a pleasant smell, it goes on cool, and it leaves underarms dry for at least 12 hours.  I have tried many antiperspirant and even though I still use a typical mans stick deodorant, whenever I want to switch to a spray, it will definitely be Dove Men+ Care Dry Spray Antiperspirant!  Highly Recommended!

My dog "Pistol" is a male Dachshund and has HORRIBLE breath, I mean really, really BAD!  In the past I have tried various ways to get him to have decent breath.  He doesn't care for rawhides, any other type of "breath mint" chewables for dogs he just looks at me to say "NO! Try again!".  About 6 months ago I picked up Milk-Bone Brushing Chews Daily Dental Treats and gave him one.  He LOVED it!  He ate it, and then jumped into my lap and then gave me the "approval" look!  And...his bad breath is greatly reduced!  I mean he has dog breath that is always unpleasant, but after he eats the Milk-Bones his breath is decent and it doesn't smell like he just ate something rotten!  The Milk-Bone's also do a great job of removing plaque from his teeth which is critical in a dog's health (especially now that he is an older dog).I HIGHLY RECOMMEND Milk-Bone Brushing Chews for dogs!

"Gettysburg Glimpses: True Stories from the Battlefield" by Scott L. Mingus Sr. is the short but fascinating histories of individual soldiers (both North and South) during the Battle of Gettysburg from July 1 to July 3, 1863.  The stories contain instances of heroic and brave actions, tragic circumstances of death, hardships before the battle, the aftermath, the bodies left, and other details that the soldiers went through.  From civilians who witnessed the battle from rooftops and other observatories, to the soldiers in the thick of the battle at the Bliss Farm, Little Round Top, the Peach Orchard, the Railroad Cut, Pickett's Charge and other areas of the battle, reading these gives you an understanding of the chaos, the deadly encounters, the heroism, and the carnage that was fought over three days in the hot and muggy Pennsylvania summer.  Men from as far away as Texas and Arkansas and as close by as Chambersburg, Harrisburg, and Gettysburg fought violently against each other, and they all had encounters.  Most of the soldiers who survived never told their history of the battle, but some did, and that is what Scott Mingus did excellently, he researched from many sources, books written in the years right after the battle or at the turn of the century, or from personal diaries, letters to loved ones and newspaper articles.  These soldiers who fought for the USA and CSA wrote their memories for people to know what happened during the battle.Each story is fascinating be it a paragraph or pages long.  Each story told adds to the tremendous history of the battle, and the men who fought in it.This is an excellent book that helps those who are interested in the battle the intense short stories of the soldiers that fought at Gettysburg.  It is highly recommended for those who want to know more about the Battle of Gettysburg, the Army of the Potomac and the Army of Northern Virginia, Civil War History, and the Civil War in the Eastern Theater of the War.This is another excellent book by Gettysburg/Civil War Historian and author Scott L. Mingus Sr. and it is a valued book in my personal library of the Battle of Gettysburg and the Civil War!

"A History Of The Third South Carolina Infantry 1861-1865" by Mac Wyckoff (Sergeant Kirland's Museum and Historical Society Publishing, 1995, 330 Pages), is the history of the hard fighting regiment from South Carolina that fought in the Army of Northern Virginia under the leadership of Robert E. Lee during the Civil War.  This regiment from the first state of the secession was quickly formed right after South Carolina seceded from the Union in December of 1860.  The regiment was formed from the men of Charleston and other towns throughout South Carolina.  From the cities to the country young men would enlist in the Confederate Army at first due to their passion of becoming independent from what they considered a hostile Federal Government, others would join because their brothers, fathers, cousins, and close friends would enlist, and others for the "romanticism and adventure" of going off to war.The men were organized into companies that formed the Third South Carolina Regiments and were enthusiastically supported by the people they encountered as they first formed on the South Carolina Coastline then marching up to Virginia to be a part of the Army of Northern Virginia.  At first the regiment encountered the Union Army in small skirmishes, then afterwards would be involved in the major battles of the ANV.  The regiment would fight in Manassas (Bull Run), the Seven Days Campaign, Sharpsburg (Antietam), Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, Gettysburg, while as a part of the famous Kershaw Brigade where they would fight at the Peach Orchard the Wheatfield, they would encounter the Army of the Potomac's Second Corps and engage in intense close combat many soldiers would fall.After Gettysburg, the regiment would transfer to the western theater of the war under General James Longstreet's Corps and fight a Chickamauga, the Tennessee Campaign, Overland Campaign, Petersburg, Cedar Creek and finally surrender at Greensboro on April 28, 1865 a few weeks after General Robert E. Lee surrendered the ANV at Appomattox Courthouse.Mac Wyckoff wrote an excellent history of the Third South Carolina Infantry, his narrative puts the reader right in the action of the battles the Third SC fought in, the daily camp life the soldiers endured, and of course the unfortunate phases of the diseases that swept thru the regiment and cause much sickness and death of the men of South Carolina.Of the 1343 soldiers in the regiment 298 were killed in battle from 1861-1865, 298 died of disease, 697  survived combat wounds, 110 men transferred to other units during the war.The author also provides many photos of the officers and men of the regiment, maps, illustrations of the battles the Third SC fought in, and the end chapters provide an excellent muster of the regiment, great footnotes and author's notes.This is a great book about this hard fighting regiment from South Carolina, it is an interesting read that is not bogged down in mundane details, and keeps the reader interested from the first pages to the end of the book.  Highly recommended to anyone interested in the history of South Carolina during the Civil War, South Carolina Infantry Regiments during the war, the Army of Northern Virginia, and Confederate History.  A great read!

"Duty Bound: The Hyatt Brothers and Confederates of the Third Arkansas Infantry Regiment, Army of Northern Virginia, C.S.A." by Van Hawkins (Arkansas University Press, 2011, 158 pages) is the letters from three brothers of Company C of the Third Arkansas Infantry Regiment to their parents.  The three brothers, Benjamin, Elijah, and Robert enlisted in the Third Arkansas in 1861 and described their life as a Confederate Infantry Soldier in the regiment.  The brothers wrote a total of 70 letters home addressed to their parents and gave a valuable view of day-to-day existence in the regiment in addition to the chaotic and gruesome battles they participated in.Benjamin's (Ben) letters display an intense passion for the cause he believed in, he also has great detail and insight into the various important leaders he fought under in the Army of Northern Virginia.  These are important letters in Civil War history because the Third Arkansas Infantry Regiment is the only regiment from Arkansas who fought in the Army of Northern Virginia under the leadership of General Robert E. Lee.  Also included in this great read are letters from other soldiers in the regiment.  The letters date from 1860 to 1865 and begin while Ben was attending law school at what would become the University of Mississippi.  Ben would describe the camp life and the battles he fought in until his death at the Battle of Chickamauga in September 1863.  Elijah's letters started on August 9, 1861 to September 14, 1862, just three days before he died in the Battle of Sharpsburg (Antietam) where he received mortal wounds.  Thomas would be wounded at the Battle of Mufressboro in 1862, and after his recovery, he would be captured at the Battle of Jonesboro and would remain a POW until his parole in June of 1865.Throughout the book, the author gives the history of the regiment as they fought in the ANV.  He gives a brief but excellent history of the various battles the Third Arkansas Infantry fought in under the great command of Colonel Van Manning.  Mr. Hawkins also gives excerpts of the letters the Hyatt brothers wrote, great photographs of the various documents from the Ordinance of Secession that Arkansas delivered, photographs of the officers of the regiment, after battle photos, illustrations of the time, and also good endnotes.  At the end of the book is a muster of Company C of the Third Arkansas and a brief history of the soldiers of Company C.This is a valuable book due to the scarcity of published material of the Third Arkansas Infantry.  There is only one other book that I know of that is solely about the Third Arkansas and that is Calvin L.Collier's classic book "They Do To Tie To!: The Story of The Third Arkansas Infantry C.S.A.", which was published in 1959.The Third Arkansas Infantry as a part of the famous Hood's Texas Brigade was known for their bravery and tenacity in battle.  During the Battle of Gettysburg, the Third Arkansas with their "brother regiment", the First Texas Infantry helped take Devil's Den in the late afternoon of July 2nd, 1863 with many casualties.  At Gettysburg and other battles, the Third Arkansas fought fiercely and with the other Texas Regiments were part of General Robert E. Lee's "shock troops" which he would send in charging first into the Union lines to break up their infantry lines.There is not nearly as much published history about the Third Arkansas Infantry as compared to other Confederate Regiments in the Army of Northern Virginia, and this great read helps add to the history of the brave regiment from Arkansas that fought in the Army of Northern Virginia.  It is a great all around read and history, from the letters of the Hyatt Brothers, the letters of other soldiers of Company C.  The book has excellent photos that help enhance the history of the regiment, and as stated good footnotes and the muster of the men of Company C of The Third Arkansas Infantry.The author of Duty Bound, Van Hawkins did excellent research, editing, and overall fascinating history of the Third Arkansas and it is highly recommended to any Civil War scholar, student, and enthusiast who is interested in Arkansas Civil War History, Army of Northern Virginia History, Confederate Military History, and history of Hood's Texas Brigade during the Civil War.  Again, this is a great read that I highly recommend!

"Ships of The Civil War 1861-1865: An Illustrated Guide To The Fighting Vessels Of The Union And The Confederacy" by Kevin J. Dougherty is an excellent resource for anyone interested in the fighting ships of both the Union and Confederate Navies during the Civil War.  At 224 pages, the brief history of the vessels and outstanding illustrations of the ships tell the amazing stories of many of the famous and not so famous vessels that patroled the coastlines, rivers, and open seas during the Civil War.  Many of the ships in this book were overhauled and adapted to become fighting vessels.  Included in the book are the Ironclads, Gunboats, Raiders, Cruisers, Blockade Runners, and Submarines.  It was both the Union and Confederate Navies that helped "modernize" vessels and the world had to take notice.  Such famous vessles and the CSS Merrimack and the USS Monitor are highlighted, including their famous battle, the Confederate Dreadnaught the CSS Abelmarle which became the victim of what some consider the "first Navy Commando/SEAL" Lt. William Cushing who with a 12 man crew sunk her.Other brief histories are about the Blockade Runners (invaluable assistance in bringing supplies to the Confederacy), gunboats (which helped secure the Mississippi River for the Union), sailing "man of wars" including the CSS Alabama, and other great vessels of the time.The illustrations of the vessels are truly excellent and enhance the reading of the history of the vessels.  A brief but fascinating read in the beginning give the historical overview of the naval war between the Union and the Confederacy and the stratigies used by the navies is provided.Only a few vessels survive today as museum displays, but after reading this fascinating book and with the outstanding illustrations it is easy for the reader to understand how important both the Union and Confederate Navies were during the four years of hte Civil War.  Highly recommended for anyone intersted in Civil War Naval History, American Naval History, and Union and Confederate Naval Strategy from 1861 to 1865.

"The Marshall Guards: Harrison (Texas) County's Contribution to Hood's Texas Brigade by Colonel Harold B. Simpson (USAF Ret),  (Port Caddo Press, 1967, 26 pages) is the history of Marshall County Texas soldiers who fought in the First Texas Infantry (Company E) as part of the famed Hood's Texas Brigade fighting primarily in the Eastern Theater of the Civil War as a part of the Army of Northern Virginia.This limited release book (only 50 copies), is based on a lecture that Colonel Simpson presented in 1965 to the Harrison County Historical Society and the Colonels lecture was later expanded and published in a very limited release of 50 copies.  The men of Marshall  County Texas would hear the call of Texas and the Confederacy in 1861 and join the Confederate Army.  The men of Texas in Hood's Brigade were raised in 26 counties located in East Central and Southeast Texas.  The men from Harrison county would be known as the "Marshall Guards" and later would be designated as Company E in the First Texas Infantry.  The soldiers of Company E were originally trained under the experience eye of Frederick S. Bass, a former instructor in military tactics at Marshall University.  A short while later, the company was sent to Virginia and organized as a regiment in later what would be known as "Hood's Texas Brigade".The original strength of the company was four officers, eight non-commissioned officers, one ensign or flag bearer, and 55 enlisted men for an overall strength of 68 men. The company as with the rest of Hood's Texas Brigade fought in 38 battles and skirmishes including the battles of Gaines' Mill, Second Manassas (Bull Run), Sharpsburg (Antietam), Gettysburg, Chickamauga, and the Wilderness.The company lost the most men in battle at Manassas where the First Texas would suffer 82.3% casualites.  At Gettysburg the company would lose 8 men.  During the war the Bass Company (in Company E) had an overall rate of 53% casualties which included 15 killed, 40 wounded and nine either missing or POW.These men endured the hardships of severe winters, disease, battle casualties, starvation and other terrible things endured by the Civil War soldier.  However, the men of Hood's Texas Brigade were always known as fierce in battle, shock troops that General Robert E. Lee always depended on in "tight situations" as he called them.  At the Battle of The Wilderness it was the men of Hood's Brigade who led General Lee back to safety of his lines as he wanted to lead the Texans and other regiments in the ANV into charging the Union lines.  General Lee would say "Texans always move them!".  A great tribute to the men of Company E, and the rest of Hood's Texas Brigade.This is a brief read about this great company from Marshall, Texas who fought valiantly in the War Between the States.  Colonel Simpson who was the modern historian of Hood's Texas Brigade did a great tribute to Harrison County, Texas by publishing this great read.  It is a Very Rare book that is expensive, however it is a valuable history to anyone who is interested in Hood's Texas Brigade, the Army of Northern Virginia, Confederate Military History, Texas History, and Civil War History.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

"Reminiscences of the Boys in Gray 1861-1865" and originally published in 1912 is the outstanding compilation of the Texas Confederate Civil War veterans who were interviewed, wrote letters to the editor Mamie Yeary who took 3 years to conduct interviews, receive letters from hundreds of veterans who fought and survived the Civil War. These men had various and fascinating experiences of their service in the Confederate Army and Navy and wrote either a few lines or up to 3 or 4 pages describing what camp life was like, battles that were harrowing, and their views of the officers and men that they served with.  From the eastern theater of the Civil War fighting in the Army of Northern Virginia under General Robert E. Lee to serving in the far flung western posts in Texas, the Trans-Mississippi, the Army of  Tennessee and other places, all these veterans described their actions.  In each of the histories the men told where they were born, the regiment, company and brigades they were under, and where they currently lived.These soldiers accounts of the battles they were in is fascinating and a harrowing read, seeing their friends, fellow soldiers, and the leaders of their regiments being wounded and killed in battle is sobering.  Some of the soldiers were captured and sent to Union POW camps and their survival was also a sobering read.  Their views of why they fought for Texas and the Confederacy provides a valuable insight to their beliefs of the Confederacy and Texas.The book is a LARGE volume of work.  Originally printed in 1912, and reprinted in 2003 by Morningside Publications it is 902 fascinating pages long.From Generals to the Privates all these men in this outstanding and historical publication provide a VALUABLE insight to the experience not only of the men from Texas but the Confederate Soldier who fought in the War Between the States.What makes this even a more amazing read is that these interviews and letters took place almost 50 years after the war.  Yet almost every soldiers memories is detailed clearly.  It is true that being in a battle and the emotions and memories are always there and these men never forgot.  Skirmishes to the large battles such as Gettysburg, Chickamauga, Shiloh, Manassas, Pea Ridge, Mansfield, Iuka, Glorietta Pass, Galveston, Vicksburg, Perryville, and many, many more battles the Texans fought in and their memories of these battles are in this great book by Mamie Yeary.This is one of the most valuable books not only of Texas Confederate History and Confederate History but of Civil War History in existence.  I highly recommend that any true Civil War scholar, author, student, "arm chair general" should have this in their library.  This is an important work of American history and Texas History.  It is a somewhat rare volume that is usually over $100.00 and is mainly sold by secondary booksellers, yet if you want to add a treasured and important Civil War book to use as a reference than this is the book.One of the most important volumes of Civil War History in my opinion ever published and HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

"Ten More Texans In Gray" by Dr. W. C. Nunn (Hill Junior College Press, 1980) presents an outstanding and vivid brief biographical accounts of ten Texas Generals who fought for the Confederacy.  It is a companion volume to the earlier book "Ten Other Texans In Gray" that was also edited by Dr. Nunn.  The ten Generals brief biographies and wartime service are:- John S. "RIP" Ford- Thomas Green- Albert Sidney Johnston- Samuel Bell Maxey- Ben McCulloch- Oran Milo (O. M.) Roberts- Lawrence Sullivan "Sul" Ross- Henry Hopkins Silbey- Benjamin Franklin Terry- James Webb ThrockmortonA few of the generals in the book are well known to Civil War students and scholars such as Albert Sidney Johnston, Ben McCulloch, and Benjamin F. Terry.  However, the book contains the brief biographies of lesser known Texas Confederate General such as O. M. Roberts, Sul Ross, and James W. Throckmorton.Each of these generals played an important part in the Confederate Army.  General A. S. Johnston was killed at the Battle of Shiloh in 1862, B. F. Terry was killed in action in 1862 and leadership of "Terry's Texas Rangers" was transferred to another officer.Dr. Nunn who taught U.S., Texas, and Civil War history designated individual members of his class to write the brief biographies of the generals and the brief biographies are outstanding, accurate, and have excellent end notes.  Published in 1980, this great volume is a must have for anyone interested in Texas Confederate history and leadership, pre-Civil War and post-Civil war history of Texas.  The generals played an important part in Texas and Confederate history and this outstanding book is a great tribute to the leaders of the Texas Regiments and Brigades and is a HIGHLY RECOMMENDED read!

"Life of Robert Hall" is an outstanding book about the life of this true Texas pioneer, soldier, and observer of Texas in its early years.  Edited by "Brazos", Hall penned his autobiography in later years and his life was definitely a fascinating and valuable one for the Republic and later the great Lone Star State.Born in South Carolina, in 1814, as a boy Hall and his family moved to Tennessee where he grew up and became close friends with legendary Davy Crockett..  He led an exciting young life and traveled up and down the Mississippi River delivering cargo and goods to famous ports along the river.  After hearing about the brave Texans and their independence from Mexico Hall and some of his friends traveled to Texas but arrived to late to help with the Alamo and arrived in Texas shortly after the Battle of San Jacinto.  He became a close friend to General Sam Houston and married into the prominent King family of Gonzales County.  He became noted for his bravery, chivalry, and tenacity against friends and foe alike and wrote a fascinating account of his actions in the Mexican War.  Hall's account of such battles as Monterrey, and Buena Vista are a valuable history to those who want to know more about the battles of the Mexican War.  He also participated as a Texas Ranger against the fierce Comanche Raids to were a common occurrence in Young Texas. His first hand accounts of expeditions such as the one that fought at Plum Creek are "gritty and intense".He considered such men as good friends, Sam Houston, Ed Burleson, Paint Caldwell, Ben and Henry McCulloch, "Big Foot" Wallace and Jack Hays.  Talk about knowing some interesting and famous men of Texas and U.S. History!Hall's was against slavery and secession, and thought that Texas should of remained in the Union, though he came to fight and defend Texas in the 36th Texas Cavalry CSA.  After the Civil War, Hall became a famous man throughout Texas and many came to hear his great stories and history of the early Republic and later U.S. state of Texas.  He died in 1899 in Cotulla, Texas and is buried in Belmont, Texas.The original publication of this book published in 1898 is an extremely rare and valuable book.  It is amazing that Robert Hall is not famous in Texas history.  This brave soldier and leader became a prominent and valuable figure in the early years of Texas.  He was a brave soldier and leader and many of Texas's leaders came to rely on Hall in tough situations.  He rescued women and children from the Comanches, fought bravely in the Mexican War and later the Civil War. He has a secure place in the pantheon of Texas heroes where he belongs.  Hopefully, in time he will become more famous among historians, students, and classrooms that teach Texas history.  This great biography of Robert Hall is highly recommended to anyone interested in U.S. and Texas history, Mexican War history, Indian War history, Confederate and Civil War history.  A great read of a truly great man and leader of Texas!

"Early Days In Texas: A Trip to Hell and Heaven" by Jim McIntire and edited by Robert K. DeArment (published in 1992, 184 pages) is a autobiography of this interesting Texan as he relates his life and adventures in the mid to late 1800's in Texas and other frontier states.The editor quickly warns the reader that Jim McIntire enjoyed telling "tall tales" of his life and experiences and to take his autobiography with "a grain of salt".  Jim McIntire was born in Ohio but as a youth traveled to Texas to experience the frontier and cowboy life he read about in 10 cent novels.  As a youth in Ohio, McIntire became a leader of a black "minstrel show" that travelled through Ohio and had some funny yet dangerous adventures.  After being bored with this, he traveled to Texas where he became a cattle driver, Indian fighter, Texas Ranger, saloon keeper, gambler, card dealer, an outlaw, and many more occupations.  His descriptions of fighting the Comanches and Kiowas is a thrilling adventure and gruesome.  Having no love for the Indians, Hispanics (he calls them greasers), and blacks (liberally using the "n" word), that are in Texas and he shows no mercy or understanding when they are breaking the law, according to McIntire.His stories of dealing with notorious Sam Bass, meeting Billy the Kid, Pat Garrett, and other famous western figures make a great read.  Eventually, McIntire would run afoul of the law and became a notorious outlaw himself, bragging about the men he had killed along the way.  His description of frontier Texas gives an excellent window into the frontier life of Texas small towns and ranches.Jim McIntire did a lot in his life, and it is amazing (if true) that he survived any of the encounters and circumstances that he was in.  As Larry D. Ball (Professor of History at Arkansas State University) says on the back cover, "The representation of this little volume constitutes a very worthwhile service to the readership in frontier studies.  While Jim McIntire is not always honest with his readers, he provides entree into the shadowy frontier underworld and the calloused and brutal nature of the Indian wars." The editor's annotations are very full and informative and give a truthful version of the circumstances that McIntire described.
