I have bought this both in bulk from Amazon and singly. It is a delicious, clean quinoa. I love that it's USDA certified organic. I cook it in chicken broth, and I like to keep a finished batch in the fridge. I love it mixed into salads or warm veggies, stirred into a quick soup... And experimenting with it in different ways. I've been known to eat spoonfuls of it as a quick pick-me-up snack. I've even mixed it with egg and seasoning and fried it in a patty. Any way I've tried it, it's been delicious and nutritious.My only complaint is that Amazon's price is too high. I can get 32 oz of it around the corner at my local grocery store for 17 bucks.  I will use Amazon for the red and multicolor varieties that I can't find locally.I have also tried other brands of quinoa, including the bargain "bulk" ones sold at our local Mediterranean markets. They were full of grit and pieces of twig, and rather bitter. This is a problem you'll never have with Bob's Red Mill. Any price differential is due to the quality of their products. They are always perfectly clean, and never bitter. In fact, I've never met a BRM product that I didn't love!
Great product. Pretty shapes. The biggest one is a BIG cookie!  I imagine that one as a Giant Swallowtail, which I saw in my garden a few times this past summer. Nice cutters.
Excellent file folders. Nice colors and alternating tabs. Good quality. Thanks I needed that!!
I too buy this calendar every year. It's my kitchen "Bible" and I couldn't live without it!
Wonderful "cat" cookie cutter!  The results are adorable, especially when paired with butterflies. Recommended!!!  Quality product.
Great cookie cutters!  Fun shapes, sturdy construction. Have used them a couple of times already, and the results are great. Buy them!!!

Used for the first time tonight, making a facial mask with the recipe provided online. I have to say, I'm not impressed. The product is very messy and hard to work with. When you finally manage to get some to stay on your face, you have to sit there for 20 minutes smelling low tide. The odor is nauseating. But I figured, "hey if it works really well I can overlook these things."Unfortunately, although my face felt refreshed, I don't think it did a better job than the avocado mask in a tube that I've bought at CVS. It didn't really tighten or clean my pores any better - and the avocado mask is less messy, more convenient to use, and doesn't smell like dead fish. And, I don't have to worry about the grainy stuff getting in my eyes because it stays put (I didn't even do my forehead or around my eyes).When rinsing off, the messy continues. At first I got some in my mouth and it grossed me out. After I finished rinsing, the bathroom, facecloth, and my skin all smelled like low tide.I am uncertain whether I will use it a second time, and I certainly won't buy it again.

A few weeks ago when I ordered this, it was only 99 cents. Now it's significantly more. At 99 cents, it was five stars. at 12 or 13 bucks, it's four stars. It's an ok case. I love the vertical flip style, and those are hard to find. The magnetic closure is a little bit weak
In a month's time, it caught nothing. Don't waste your money.  You will catch more by leaving a bowl of Apple cider vinegar out overnight.

This was my first experience eating hemp seeds and I didn't quite know what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised at how tasty they are!  I have added them to smoothies, my morning granola, and bowls of yogurt. Next I'll try them on chicken, although there is a warning that amino acids will be compromised at over 325 degrees.  Would even be good as an ice cream topping. The taste is similar to pine nuts, and I'm considering using them to make pesto. ;)
Not much to say about these except they are perfect for my job at hand: removing latched-on deer ticks.
Very nice mug. First one came with a defect but the company graciously sent me a new one and told me to keep the defective one for no charge. I'm using it in my office as a pencil cup.

It's just okay, overall. A friend who is a wholistic health practitioner recommended that I try a teaspoon of these tri-salts or baking soda in an 8 oz. glass of water to deal with my sometimes severe multiple chemical sensitivity reactions (I have especially bad reactions to certain scents).It worked pretty well, but quite honestly... The baking soda worked a lot better & faster, and is way more affordable. At eight bucks for this tiny bottle, this treatment could easily become expensive if you have a lot of very severe reactions like I do.Plus... It didn't give me instant relief from my symptoms. Baking soda does give me instant relief.So I guess what I'm saying is that I'll keep this bottle around for emergencies, in case I run out of baking soda... But I won't buy it again.Sorry, I wanted to love it but I just can't.

I know that others have had issues with this product (i.e., wires coming loose, screws letting go), so I waited a while before writing my review. I bought this at the end of May, and after almost three months of regular use, I am having no problems whatsoever.  I am careful how I handle it and care for it, though.  I wash my pizza stone with water only, use a plastic pot scraper to scrape off any burnt on cheese or toppings, and then allow the stone to air dry completely (overnight). Once it's clean and dry, I use this tool to buff it out in a circular motion, treating the entire surface of the pizza stone to a rub-down. The result is that the stone buffs out to a nice shiny patina and has developed a nice "seasoned" appearance over the past three months.So, bottom line is that I like this product very much and would recommend it!  One thing I should add is that I do inspect it before using, just to make certain that the wires aren't coming loose. A friend of mine recently got a piece of such wire (from a grill brush) stuck in her throat, and it required  trip to the ER and emergency surgery to remove it!  So better safe than sorry.I don't think my pizza stone would look as nice as it does, without this brush!

I am extremely sensitive to scents, and even unscented DEET sprays set off my asthma. This one, however, is the only spray on the market that my lungs can tolerate. Even though it's not fragrance free, the scent is mild and non-irritating to me. And it seems to work well at repelling pests.

Mixed this with organic quinoa flour to invent my own gluten-free pizza crust. It was better than any recipe I'd come across. Added roasted garlic, s&p, oregano, and some roasted garlic-infused olive oil to make a yummy crispy crust that could easily double as a flatbread. You really can't beat Bob's Red Mill products. Yeah they are a little more expensive, but in this case you get what you pay for. Their entire product line is all top quality.

Arrived timely and in perfect condition, seems to be a quality product, and color is exactly the dark purple that is pictured here. Gifting to a group of kids raising money for a child with MPS, to use in their bake sale products. #SaveJack !

Couldn't possibly use this product. Its scent is very strong. The exact ingredients should have been listed. It has a strong patchouli scent and I would have never ordered it had I known that it contained patchouli. That's one thing that instantly sets off my asthma. If strong essential oil scents bother you, this isn't the product for you. I found the scent repulsive. Gave it away to a friend who didn't mind the scent.

I don't have a whole lot to add to the good reviews already written here, but I bought An Awesome Wave shortly after it came out and fell in love. I listened once, thought it was weird - listened twice and thought it was cool - then got hooked. It's been in my digital library on every device and I listen to it periodically ever since, while many other good albums have come and gone this one is enduring and fascinating. The new one had a lot to live up to and I have to say, if anything, it's expansive and builds on the first. There are some extremely simple, rolling and melancholy tracks, and upbeat and pounding tracks, and sort of epic tracks. One I absolutely love that doesn't seem to be mentioned much is "Hunger of the Pine". But, this one is definitely worth a listen, especially if you liked An Awesome Wave.

For the price and the Samsung name brand - and the premium tablet it's designed to work with - this is a big disappointment. I'll be clear about what I'm benchmarking, though. Not other "folio cases" and separate bluetooth keyboards, which are nearly identical in functionality but can be had for $70 less (than the Amazon price, $120 less than MSRP), but to other integrated keyboards, to wit, the Asus Transformer Pad series.In short, the Asus keyboard is just far, far superior in terms of integration. That tablet locks in to a keyboard base that really enhances its functionality, effectively turning it into an Android ultrabook. The hinge of the Asus Transformer allows it to close fully (like a laptop) and puts the tablet to sleep when it's closed. The keyboard contains a big battery that actually feeds the tablet, keeping it mostly- or fully-charged and draining the auxiliary battery in the keyboard first. Charging is also fully integrated; the same plug charges the keyboard or tablet separately, but when they're docked, you can only put the plug into the keyboard - and it charges BOTH units simultaneously. It is tightly integrated, probably using USB technology, and contains a track pad which provides you with a mouse cursor on the screen; you can also still tap if you prefer, but it works very well. Finally, the base contains a full-size USB port and SD card slot. Altogether, it is a well-thought-out instrument that extends the functionality of the tablet.The Samsung keyboard contains nothing but a keyboard. The tablet does not lock into place; it simply sits in the slot at top, at an angle (which is of course not adjustable), and so, it is very loose and wobbly and not useful on your lap or anywhere other than a table/desk - flat, stable surface. It is possible to close the tablet and clip it into place, but that's basically just laying one on top of the other and closing the spring-loaded clip on the outside edge. There is no hinge. The keyboard contains a rechargeable battery, of course, but it only runs the keyboard, and does not feed / integrate with the tablet or any other device. The devices can both be charged using the same charger, but must be charged sequentially; there is no power integration. It does not contain any of the other amenities - no track pad, no USB, no SD card slot or other media extension. It is, in effect, just an overpriced Bluetooth keyboard, nothing more. I also agree (although this is also not a feature of the Asus), that a backlight would be helpful and to a degree, expected in a premium product like this.The one place I can give the Samsung keyboard a clear edge over the Asus is typing quality. Key travel is smooth and substantial, so typing is comfortable and accurate. Nevertheless, I never had trouble typing with the Asus keyboard, it just didn't have quite as good key press feel.All of this is not to say it's a bad bluetooth keyboard; it is to say that with the nature of the device, the size / bulk it adds to the tablet, and what competitors have accomplished, even 2+ years ago, in terms of functionality extension / enhancement and integration with an android tablet, this really falls flat. It's a one-dimensional product, and not a very ambitious one. Coupled with the newest, most premium tablet in Samsung's consumer line, I'd expect a little more engineering, some 'gee whiz' features, something really special about it, really useful, not just a glorified bluetooth keyboard with a stand built in.

The title of my review says it all. I can offer a few reference points to draw some boundaries around what this thing is/does for folks who are looking for an audio companion that doesn't just blurt out a lot of noise, but actually makes very compelling, high quality sound.First is this thing relative to other bluetooth speakers. Although I can't say I've tested the other bigger brothers of this guy, SRS X7 and SRS X9, and similarly expensive, larger "portables", I have tested a long, long list of them, including UE Boom, Dre Beats, Philips, Jawbone Jambox, and a whole array of other smaller-brand speakers. I owned a Creative Soundblaster Roar, briefly, and returned it because the sound was just awful. The only real competition for this speaker is the Bose Soundlink III and Soundlink Mini. None of the others are worth considering. There's no bass, no soundstage, most of them have serious problems with phase, and of course, the real cover charge for considering a decent speaker is whether it produces bass. Good bass, bad bass, little bass, big bass, deep bass or shallow bass. Some produce SOMETHING down below 100hz worth listening to; most do not. And that leaves us with exactly three contenders we even need to discuss: Bose Soundlink III, Bose Soundlink Mini, and Sony SRS-X5.All three use passive radiators to move some air mass outside the brick and reach well below 100hz. None of them will project a bass chord, let's say, in the 20-40hz range, so forget that. They can make the noise, but you can barely hear it on any of these little speakers, whereas when you're sitting in front of a decent powered 10 or 12" sub, the same chord will fill your ears and world, and "press on you", that there's a nice big, rich note there. That's only particular tracks, in particular types of music, where there's something that low, that is a prominent component of the music. I happen to listen to a lot of that music (electronic, alt rock, sadcore, Bristol sound, Ibiza, and so on). Some that will beat any of these three and leave the low end just petering out and unfortunately underrepresented would come from Esthero, Massive Attack, Yeasayer, Glass Animals.That having been said, there is a pecking order between the three. And before I make such bold claims, please let me issue an author's apology: they are all VERY, VERY good, absolutely competent and frankly incredible products. Don't not buy any of these on my account alone. But, the way it shakes out is this:#3: Bose Soundlink III. The lowest "projected", audible notes may even be a bit deeper than the SRS-X5, but bass-heavy tracks lead to really regrettable distortion even at reasonable listening levels. The distortion from lowest bass made this one a pass for me.#2: Bose Soundlink Mini. This is an absolute engineering marvel. If you want to get people at a party to say "wow", buy this one. It's small, it's slick, the enclosure is hard metal, gorgeous, feels great to hold, heavy, and SMALL. I may yet buy one just because the tuning is a little warmer, and as other professional reviews have cited, has a more pronounced mid-bass around low instruments and vocal depth that gives this an instrumental quality that absolutely should not be discounted. The phase is very broad for such a tiny box, soundstage is modest but present and really shines with something like accoustic guitar. I recently read a review that says, very aptly, that this speaker's sound bears the least resemblance to its size of any other speaker out there. True, true. It is a phenomenal feat. The very, very slight edge to the Sony is as follows: The Soundlink Mini does not include a speakerphone (irrelevant, when considering pure sound quality), and the bass peters out perhaps a bit higher, in the 70-80hz range.#1: Sony SRS-X5. This thing is the best of the best. The battery lasts all day. The treble is crystal clear and truly, when you listen to something, a movie or music that "sparkles", will make your jaw drop. And the bass is actually very, very good. It probably tapers off quite a bit after about 50hz but at and above that general range, it really has a good level of depth and projection, of "voice". Again, it absolutely isn't comparable to a powered subwoofer, but when you sit it on a kitchen countertop or bookshelf and play something, the reaction you'll get is: wow. Woah. Wait, that's coming out of THAT thing?? It plays loud and it plays distortion-free.Even then, it's not perfect. The unit goes quite a bit louder in the midrange and treble than the small subwoofer and passive radiators can keep up with; it's very good in that, if you want it loud, it goes loud. Not gymnasium-prom-loud, but louder than you'd want it at a party in your back yard. At some point, the itty bitty drivers just can't move enough air mass to make an equivalent dent in the space-time continuum with big, boomy bass. That's OK by me; wrong tool for the job. I want this for nice listening volume inside and outside and as such, it does just spectacularly well.It has a speakerphone that actually works very well, no echo, and is absolutely usable inside and outside. Not the way you'd USUALLY take a call, but it's in there, and it works.Lastly, it has reasonable sound quality, including depth of bass, when it's sitting out on the driveway, or on the railing of the back porch. When you really want to emphasize the amount of bass that comes out of it, the rear passive radiators are best about a foot away from a solid vertical surface to "reflect" the bass back at the unsuspecting listener. But, as an audio companion to, for example, go out on the driveway while you work on the car, or do some carpentry, or what have you - it actually sounds pretty decent. Wide open, outside, no reflection, but it still manages to produce quality sound.Now, lastly, I'd like to touch upon comparing this to another Sony product, the bigger brother's bigger brother, the Sony RDHGTK37IP "Party Speaker". It is big, heavy, it has blinking LED lights, it's a 2-way 2-speaker device with two piezo tweeters and two 8" woofers in a sealed enclosure. It's big, it's neat-looking, and you'd think it's a beast with the bass just looking at pictures of it - kind of like a Ferrari looks fast sitting still. Well, I bought one. I thought it may have a kind of deep bass oomph comparable to a larger speaker system with the big drivers and ample amplifiers, where maybe I could sit it outside and enjoy home-theater type of audio while I'm working on a barbecue or turning wrenches. Oh, no. No, that didn't turn out to be true. It's a good device for loud listening, but... read my review for the rest. What is relevant here is that I did a side-by-side comparison between that monster, and the SRS-X5. The SRS-X5 won. It wins, comfortably. Inside and outside, this little brick produces deeper, more pronounced bass at low to moderate listening levels, more rich, full sound, better soundphase, better soundstage, and all-around, better sound quality. That is nothing short of miraculous engineering, and taken from Sony's own product line. Bigger is NOT better; unless you plan to fill a gymnasium with blaring-loud, thumping, blaring bass and dodgy treble and distorted midranges, you don't want a big thing like that, or like the Behringer Eurolive speakers. This little speaker wins, it simply wins.Those couple of things make this better than any competitor, even better than any other Sony. Someone may invent a better bluetooth speaker, and I certainly hope they do - we will all benefit - but right now, having listened to all of the best, listened to the rest, and even stood it up against something that should have blown it away, it wins. You simply don't need to buy anything else to be absolutely guaranteed an incredible listening experience in any space, any time, all day long.I'm an impartial consumer, not paid by Sony (or anyone else mentioned here), but after having written all of this, I feel like I should be! Anyway, I hope I've delivered a useful benchmark-based review. Target has these set up on a display, you can pair your phone and listen; Walmart, Best Buy and others may carry it. Sound quality is so subjective, I encourage you to go give a listen, but if you want to take the word of an amateur audiophile (who used to design and build speakers by hand!), and maybe wouldn't miss the price of the unit, you simply can't be disappointed by this SRS-X5, unless you'll be disappointed by ALL bluetooth speakers; this simply is the state of the art, as good as it gets in 2014 and heading in to 2015. Reputable professional reviews, fortunately, do agree with my conclusion.Happy listening!

I may be a bit of a dissenting opinion here. It most certainly does deliver on the volume; it is LOUD. It's comfortably loud enough for a big pool party, gymnasium, what have you. It delivers decent, clean bass. It is definitely able to connect to Bluetooth very quickly and painlessly. Now for a couple of things that aren't great about it:- There is a VERY neat iPod/iPhone dock on it, with a little arm that swings down to hold it in place on the dock. Neat except if you don't have an iCult device. It turns out that other things, such as Android, also have bluetooth, and owners who want to stream music over Bluetooth. Great, but pointless for the 70%+ of the global market share enjoyed by Android devices. Does that strike anyone else as a little odd? It would be good if this at least had some capacity to clip in other types of devices, if not actually mount them (e.g., via microUSB). To be fair though, it does specify in the listing that it's an iCult port, so that's not really a surprise you just find out about when you unpackage it.- The crossover frequency is a little high. It's a two-way speaker, and what this means is, when the woofers are really moving, you get some "muddy" midranges, vocals and instrumentals. Not as much of a problem at lower volume, but...- It really only has passable bass when it's very loud. I'm virtually certain it's a sealed enclosure, and it's very much the sound of a 6.5" or 8" sealed enclosure speaker; the bass is very tight, "punchy", but the low-end is just choked off because the woofers can't move enough air. This has two negative consequences for day to day listening: first, I have a Sony SRS-X5 bluetooth speaker. Sitting in the family room, at the same volume (i.e., not super-loud), the bass response is very distinctly in favor of the tiny SRS-X5. That itty bitty thing has lower bass response. Still not the same as a 12" ported, powered subwoofer, of course, but it has clearly, comfortably lower response. The second is that ANY discernible bass response is really only limited to very high power levels - volume. If you plan to listen to it as background music at a party on your deck, or at normal volumes for whatever reason inside or outside of the house (anything under, say, 35 or 40 volume level on the unit), the bass is just pathetic, inexcusable for this much power and woofers this big. Basically, it goes very loud, or you don't want to bother listening to it, get a little SRS-X5 or Soundlink Mini, and they'll have far superior bass range and projection.- There is not a wide phase; treble is crisp when standing directly in front of it but for whatever reason, they put little plastic louvers around it that look neat, but create a sort of "laser beam" of sound. Walk 45 degrees left or right and the treble is weakened and garbled; walk around to 90 degrees and it's a muddy mess of ruined sound.I'm not giving this a 1-star. For my purposes, it is a 1-star device, and I'm returning it, but for specific applications, I'm sure it's adequate, if not GOOD. To repeat, if you don't expect VERY low bass response, and you expect to use it primarily at very high volume levels, it's decent. I might still poke around at other ones that could deliver better low-end response, but when it's loud, it is punchy, even if not very deep. But, I just thought I would add these notes to help folks who might be expecting a different level of performance and/or who might be using it in some of the applications I mentioned above (which is just about all I would need it for) - it may not quite meet the need ideally.Cheers.

Amazon's price is very good for this MAF sensor, there is one other store that offers the same price (after NC sales tax) and free shipping. This is the sensor for the Mercedes M119 V8 motor as well as many others, I'm sure. It works like a charm, and corrected an intermittent stalling condition on my '99 S420. Great!Amazon did have some trouble stocking it, then shipping it. It took about a month to get it in stock. I ordered it on a Sunday and it took them until Thursday to ship it out. It appears that the order fulfillment process involved in delivering this part is a bit challenged.

Not crazy about this. The predominant fragrance is nutmeg. The flavor is also unusually weak. I used it on fish and pork loin so far, and found that this added almost nothing to the inherent flavor of the meat, and the grill / skillet, even though both of those are relatively delicate flavors - especially the cod. Not crazy about this one.Update 11/14/14: Revising down to 1 star. This stuff is just awful. I tried it on pork loin (grilled), nice fresh cod filets (smoked), but then tried to load it up on some stuffed chicken breast and put that in the smoker. It is just awful, just an awful flavor. It's something... but not something good. You can very easily pick up cheap allspice, or nutmeg, but this is simply not in the family of spices called "barbecue" - not in America, not Indian, not Indonesian, not anywhere. It's simply not barbecue spice. It smells like allspice, is nearly flavorless, but if you load up enough to taste it, the taste is kind of sour, just 'off'. I STRONGLY suggest avoiding this if you're looking for actual barbecue spice.I also just tried the McCormick Grill Masters Pork Dry Rub, which is REALLY good. Tastes even better than it smells. I can strongly recommend that. I'm trying others to try and find the best on Amazon (or elsewhere), but for now, out of the half-dozen or so I've tried in the last few months, the Grill Masters Pork Dry Rub is at or near the top, and this Badia is easily, clearly at the bottom - and well below anything else I've tried so far.

Our four year old Frozen-fiend received this as a gift from her gramma. She lives in dress up clothes and is very hard on them, so I wasn't expecting this to last forever, but after one romp in the dirt outside, and one wash, the beautiful glitter on the skirt shriveled up and pulled away from the skirt. We were so disappointed! We had already cut off the giant and itchy tag on the back, so I was unsure how to wash it. I turned it inside out and washed it in cold water on the gentle cycle. I attached a photo showing where it pulled away, I managed to rub off the worst looking parts, so it's only a partially striped skirt now. My little Anna is pretty bummed.

I'm quite in to my music, and I like trying and buying a range of well-regarded earbuds and headphones to make sure that whenever I listen, I'm getting the best possible quality sound. No need to waste my good years listening to sub-par sound, or missing depth and detail in my favorite music! All of which is to say, I have quite a few headphones and earbuds and I like listening quiet and loud, while exercising, mowing the lawn, working, cooking a nice meal, or at work. I like classical, jazz, alt-rock, acoustic "sadcore", and recently, mostly smooth electronic and EDM. Bonobo, Glass Animals, Martin Solveig, alt-J, that sort.I like full bass. Hearing the lowest bass merely mentioned in the range of sound isn't enough. It can't be blaring and distorted, but it can't be just a hint. Lots of cheap and mid-priced earbuds/headphones can make reasonably crisp highs, but the real trick is getting a full-bodied bass out of a little tiny driver.Now, down to the headphones. For reference, the most recent earbuds I've purchased and listened to extensively are Velodyne vPulse, Symphonized GLXY, Symphonized NRG, Xiaomi Piston, Panasonic RP-HJE450. Headphones are a separate category. I use my phone (Galaxy Note) and listen to the same tracks to compare apples to apples.I bought these Symphonized, as well as GLXY, on the basis of good reviews, reasonable price, and out of curiosity with the wood enclosures. Boy, did they ever hit a home run. I'm not sure if it has anything to do with using wood instead of plastic, but these things pump out deep, rich bass which at least to date, i haven't found any other earbud can match. Both GLXY and NRG are stellar. The primary difference is that the GLXY are sealed and NRG is ported, but both produce stunning bass. Furthermore, they fit comfortably and are well-balanced in the ear because the cords are attached to the enclosures closer to the ear, so they sit comfortably and do not fall out easily. This is easily a 5-star product. I'm sitting here listening to these, just amazed how deep the bass is, how warm and 'alive' the midranges are, and yet, crisp, clear, distortion-free treble. This is proper sound.It is incidental, but they also look great. The packaging is plastic and nothing to write home about, but the earbuds themselves are very classy looking. The NRG cord seems a little more solid than GLXY but both are tangle-free fabric cords which is just great for active wear.If you have similar expectations for the performance and fit of earbuds, the Panasonic RP-HJE450 and both Symphonized earbuds are simply fantastic and come highly recommended. Expect bass out of those comparable to pretty substantial studio over-ear headphones.

I'm quite in to my music, and I like trying and buying a range of well-regarded earbuds and headphones to make sure that whenever I listen, I'm getting the best possible quality sound. No need to waste my good years listening to sub-par sound, or missing depth and detail in my favorite music! All of which is to say, I have quite a few headphones and earbuds and I like listening quiet and loud, while exercising, mowing the lawn, working, cooking a nice meal, or at work. I like classical, jazz, alt-rock, acoustic "sadcore", and recently, mostly smooth electronic and EDM. Bonobo, Glass Animals, Martin Solveig, alt-J, that sort.I like full bass. Hearing the lowest bass merely mentioned in the range of sound isn't enough. It can't be blaring and distorted, but it can't be just a hint. Lots of cheap and mid-priced earbuds/headphones can make reasonably crisp highs, but the real trick is getting a full-bodied bass out of a little tiny driver.Now, down to the headphones. For reference, the most recent earbuds I've purchased and listened to extensively are Velodyne vPulse, Symphonized GLXY, Symphonized NRG, Xiaomi Piston, Panasonic RP-HJE450. Headphones are a separate category. I use my phone (Galaxy Note) and listen to the same tracks to compare apples to apples.I bought these Xiaomi solely on the basis of the strong positive reviews on Amazon, and they were cheap enough to try. The bass is deep but underpowered. It's there, it's tight, it sounds pretty decent, but doesn't project as well as the Panasonic or Symphonized. It gets quickly overwhelmed with high-mids / treble. This could be adjusted with an equalizer but for practical purposes, earbuds have to sound the way they should sound 100% of the time for 99% of their users right out of the box. That's why I just test them with 'default' settings - no headphone amplifier for earbuds, no equalizer tweaking.They are, however, still far better than the Velodyne vPulse, which I just flayed in another review. They also aren't as poorly (physically, form factor) balanced as the Velodyne headphones, but nevertheless, they are not tremendously ergonomic and still do not stay seated well enough to use them for any activity. Also worth maybe 1/10th of a star is the fact that the Xiaomi earbuds come in some REALLY nifty packaging. When you first unpack it, you definitely believe you're holding a high-quality product. The machined metal of the buds themselves, the microphone/control, and the 3.5mm plug, is VERY nice, quality material that appears to be very well made and feels very nice to handle. Would that it were they delivered on the sound quality.I can't give these my highest recommendation, but also can't say they're altogether bad. They are better than a great many (most) earbuds, including more than a few that are more than a few dollars more expensive than these. They are GOOD. Especially at this price point, they deliver very clear, distortion-free sound and acceptable bass. I don't think you're making a mistake buying a pair of these. However, if you have similar expectations for the performance and fit of earbuds, the Panasonic RP-HJE450 and both Symphonized earbuds are simply fantastic and come highly recommended. Expect bass out of those comparable to pretty substantial studio over-ear headphones.

Mae Ploy and Maesri make good curry pastes, especially red and green. There are two strikes against the Massaman curry here:First, this size of jar is available for around $5-$6 at your local East Asian market. I have to admit I was not able to locate Massaman in this size at two markets I visited, but they both had the 4oz tins.Second, the Massaman in particular is not very bold-flavored. We prepared a curry with all the goodies, chopped onion, chicken, potato, fresh lemongrass, fresh Thai basil, coconut milk and coconut powder, and kept adding spoonfuls of curry - never managed to get it to have a bold flavor. It's neither as sweet nor as spicy as a good Thai restaurant can make their Massaman. It IS good-tasting, but it is not comparable to a restaurant experience. With the rest of this container I'll be figuring out what else to add to it to make it sweeter and spicier, but part of the point of these curry pastes is that it's really a good approximation of a cooked-from-scratch curry, quickly. The more work I have to do to make it "pop", the less the curry paste is doing its job.

Maesri and Mae Ploy curries are good, especially red and green, but if you live in or near a decent-size city, note that these 4oz tins of curry should be available for $1.10 to $1.25 at any local East Asian market.

The powder itself is OK, not great. Fresh lemongrass is obviously better. The listing does not give you the size of the bag in grams or ounces and it features a larger bag prominently in the pictures. The product label also does not show the weight of the package contents.You have to note the shipping weight, 1.8oz, which includes packaging. This is a very small bag, about 1.5 inches wide and 4 inches tall and contains right around 1oz of lemongrass powder. That's really very expensive and the listing is careful not to be clear about that. It's OK spice anyway, but badly overpriced, so adjust your expectations accordingly.

This is just a fair warning for other folks who need this for your course, optional or not - you can buy the registration code when you register for the course on the McGraw Hill Connect website, $125. For months, sellers have been charging more than full retail cost of the online code. I paid $20 above the retail value because you can't see the page to access and purchase the code until your professor actually gives you the link to his/her course in the Connect website, but you typically want to get your books before the first day of class.So... mea culpa... a sucker born every minute. Just don't be like me! Make sure, if you're buying this code anywhere but the McGraw-Hill site itself, you pay less than $125!

Revising to 5 stars.I am fickle. I have tried so many excellent wired headphones, wireless headphones, and earbuds. And many that were not excellent. Assume the bluetooth speakerphone is useless, a feature that doesn't work. Proceed from there. My impossible benchmark is, which set of headphones can most closely replicate a decent 12" powered subwoofer? (at least 200W in a 15x15 room). Leave aside the nuances of 10 and 8 inch subs, tight and punchy, or the 15" blaring, loud, bleeding bass that shakes everything, including things you don't want to shake. BIG bass done well is a matter of preference and implementation between 12" and 10" drivers, depending on the cabinet, amp, and your listening style. Anyway, I listened to a movie that provides a truly unparalleled soundscape for examining bass performance "The Fifth Element". Available on Netflix and DVD. I listened on several very, very, very, very, very good headsets, and only one does the "7.1 system powered with a 12" sub" effect... this one. Bluedio R+. This thing is, to date, without any wired or wireless peer. It is capable of pronounced, articulate bass down to sub-bass levels as low as 20-30hz, while also projecting adequate mids and treble. The treble isn't as sparkling as a Bose or B&O, but the details you hear below 60Hz, just pounding out with no distortion, is astounding, and at least in my limited experience, absolutely unparalleled at any price, makes this product best in class, IN SEVERAL CLASSES. If you can have a phone or tablet with bluetooth and you care how the bass punches, I know of no other headphone, wired or wireless, that competes with this. You absolutely have to hear it to believe it. right now, I'm listening to pulses below 30Hz, rich and pronounced, and the thing plays all day.It wins. Hands down. I've spent thousands of dollars figuring this out so that you don't have to. Wow. My only regret is marking this down a notch because the speakerphone doesn't work well. Screw that. You can not get better sound out of any other pair of headphones. CAN NOT. Spend $1000, that's easy enough - they won't make better sound than this. Congratulations. When this pair wears out or has a meltdown, I'll drop another $100 for another pair an instant later. This is it. Amazing!++++++++++++++The sound is very good. As has been noted many times, the bass out of the box is boomy and blaring. I read those reviews and thought, ha-ha! Surely you jest. Too much bass? What is this? I never heard of such a thing. Well, it turns out to be right on the money. What seems to hurt the worst is that the equalizer curve is a little funky. You can hear bass notes all the way down to the bottom end of the audible range, 20-30hz or whatever your particular hearing abilities permit. That's awesome, and it's actually good bass - tight, precise, no fluttering sound as the drivers struggle against the air pressure. However, the equalizer curve peaks at a slightly higher range, making mid-bass around 100-150Hz really loud and blaring, while the very lowest note levels are weaker, and a lot of the lower mids are just drowned out by the cacophony of "upper bass" range.So they are like a boom box for your head; it's at once great and terrible. It also depends a great deal on what kind of music you're listening to, as to whether it even has bass that low or prominent at all. Other than electronic / rock music, I found that the mids and highs are incredibly accurate and clear. There is no perceptible distortion; I agree with other reviewers that this is near or at the quality of much more expensive headsets.The utility is great; I wear my cell phone on my belt and the headphones run over Bluetooth. It has been a boon. Working on yard work, lawn mowing, car repairs, all just got a lot less frustrating. I can have my music, no wires, and listen to good sound all day.The battery life is excellent and I've had the chance to use them essentially all day, for periods of considerable volume, maybe a dozen times, and never had any complaint about low battery. The reception range does seem to suffer a bit when the battery is lower but that may only mean 15 feet instead of 25 feet. I did notice that it got choppy when going past 20 feet from the phone, even in a clear line of sight, with a full charge. So this is definitely not something you'll usually want to put down your cell phone and walk away from. If anything, you could put down the computer/phone if you planned to move around within the same room, but that's about it. Moving around between rooms or outside, you need to keep the source on your person.Now, there is a reference to equalizer functions in some reviews, but no specific instructions here, nor are the specific key press sequences available in any instructions or reviews that I can find online. I fiddled with pressing every combination of buttons, press-and-hold, and never got anything other than the button's primary function. The Bluedio website is Chinese and the internationalization is awful, so don't expect to learn anything new about these in English. I was not able to locate the Equalizer program that is referenced elsewhere on their website. After about half an hour of clicking, I gave up.We need to turn down the EQ setting at 100-150Hz, just blend that in with the low-mids, and we have a really excellent pair of headphones (bar none - Bluetooth or not). However, doing so will almost certainly generate frustration and, as I have, giving up in despair. The one thing that would make this a 5-star product is better English in the English instructions, more thorough step-by-step user guide, or at least, better documentation on the website (again, better English, better internationalization). Such as it is, I like it a lot, it's listenable, but better at lower volumes, and when you listen at higher volumes or to more bass-rich music, you just have to sort of forgive the blurting volume that is not at the bottom end of the headphones' response range, which is, almost unprecedentedly low, straight down to the bottom end of the human audible range. The amp in these is ample to drive these to incredible deep, rich lows.----------------------Update: I have to remove another star because of the microphone performance. I have tried taking several calls now using two different phones. This headset produces a great deal of echo for the caller. Everything sounds great to me, and they can hear me, but it echoes the caller's voice so badly that it's unusable for conversation. Every time I've tried using it, the caller has gotten confused by the bad echo and I end up having to disconnect the headphones and just talk on the phone. I tried with another phone to verify that it wasn't just my phone (Galaxy Note). It isn't. So, that's one function that is not really usable as such.
Good belt, fits Mercedes M119 / W140. Decent price but not much less than Autozone / Advance Auto Parts prices. Still, it's a good belt. Good for a refresh of the s-belt.
Fits perfect for upper hose in M119 engine. Solid hose, perfect fit. Better price than Autozone or Advance Auto, to say nothing for OEM. Solid deal!
Quiet and smooth bearing. I can't speak to longevity but it's a good price for a good part. Good part of a refresh of S-belt, water pump and other stuff on the front of the block!

Fits perfectly in the M119 engine on a '99 W140. I think it'll fit any M119 application. Good sturdy hose, perfect fit, and cheaper than Autozone and Advance Auto Parts, to say nothing for OEM. Good part!

Perfect fitment for M119 V8 block. The bearing is quiet and it appears to circulate the water just fine. I cannot speak to its longevity, but I'll go ahead and write the review - it does indeed appear to be a valid aftermarket part. The pump vanes are hard plastic, as they are on the OEM part. Some folks like to look for metal vanes on an aftermarket part, especially on ones that can fail and come apart with age, but this is a very solidly made, squat one that does not indicate any reason to expect failure at any age; I also have never heard anyone on the forums speak of failure of these.Good part!

I'll be brief - it's a sickeningly sweet, cloying fragrance that smells of bubble gum and cotton candy. If you want to smell like that, OK, this is your fragrance. It definitely is not something you'd want to have to smell in an office or when stuck in a car. Swing and a miss.

It fit my '99 LS400, it's solidly remanufactured, the bearings are quiet. I can't speak to its longevity. I have had it a few weeks and it's far quieter than the original one, but it takes years to really know whether a bearing is good. So far, so good. It's a solid part and it fits its application.

There are two parts of a useful review: what does the fragrance itself do, and what else is it comparable to. A third part, by far the most common and always completely worthless, is, "do I like it?". Here's my soap box rant: saying "I love this!" or "My boyfriend/husband/wife/second cousin/alien examiner during an abduction really liked it!" is worthless. You may also love a soiled baby diaper top note with a dry down of tar and nuclear waste. To each his own, but that doesn't help the rest of the world understand whether it's a fragrance they'd like.Please note that you may completely disregard the reviews that say, in 10 words or less, "this is the best fragrance ever on the planet" and assign it 5 stars. This is called social media spamming. The companies all spend a few grand paying folks who have 100 different Amazon accounts with 100 different email addresses to give a barely-legible, semi-inchoate review to whatever the company's product is, to artificially inflate the early star rating. More often than not, these reviews don't even mention the name of the product itself, they say "the item" or "this is", totally non-specific. So, take heart, this review is real.To place my tastes, I'm lucky to have an embarrassingly large and broad-spectrum fragrance wardrobe, numbering in several hundreds, representing all the major groups of fragrances - florals, fougeres, aquas, attars, woods, citrus, greens. I enjoy a variety of them from a few synthetic-based designer frags to the Montales, L'Artisan Parfumeur, and Amouages. I enjoy what's good and err towards high-quality aoud blends, quality chypres, orientals and greens. I don't like cloying, syrupy sweet fragrances. I despise bone-dry, cheap, astringent synthetic "spice" and "wood" frags. I like florals but I despise powdery smells. I'm geared towards, simply put, high-quality blends, creative and interesting.Now for Karen Low Exchange. It's a sickeningly sweet, cloying, headache-inducing, synthetic vanilla hot mess. Hanae Mori is at least a little dryer vanilla, not synthetic amber heaped on top of vanilla heaped on top of synthetic vanilla. If you want a truly sublime vanilla experience, go find a tester of Montale White Aoud. This is a potion of the most sickeningly, syrupy sweet synthetic chemicals known to man. I see no redeeming qualities whatsoever. It does resemble Hanae Mori but that manages to have a blast of vanilla, albeit synthetic, that isn't as offensively sweet. Givenchy Pi is also cloying and almost nauseatingly sweet but you get this blend of natural vanilla blended with some really mild florals. It's a decent fragrance. Karen Low Exchange is among the worst 100%-sweet, overpowering, syrupy fragrances I've ever smelled. It smells like vaporized artificial maple syrup. Warm and sticky. If you're a human being, and you don't want to offend the people around you, you don't want this on you. You'll fare better with stale cigarette smoke in your clothes and a bout of halitosis.Avoid it like the plague. You don't want to spray this on you. It smells strong and it lasts for an hour or two... but if you had a particularly violent session eating a tall stack of pancakes with a full bottle of artificially flavored high-fructose corn syrup maple syrup, and happened to spatter all over yourself, you'd smell this way... but you'd desperately want to wash it off. This doesn't smell clean. This smells like you got something on you whilst cooking or cleaning that doesn't belong, and you haven't had a bath yet.

I just can't help but complain. This is an anthem of vapid, one-dimensional 1950s soda fountain pop drivel. Move over Drifters and Quotations, here's the next big band: Cults! Each track is stumbling out from the last, doused in a huge dose of echo, more echo, less echo, sometimes "megaphone" or "PA system" sound, but lots of low-fi echo, on every track... as if we're recording rock in the 1950s all over again! Elvis and Cults! Lots of cutesy-wootsey, syrupy sweet little girl vocals, echo, twinkly xylophone, doo-wop and teenybopper pop beats, more echo, more echo, more little girly vocals, and more echo. You seriously expect this to come blaring out of a brightly-colored juke box after The Fonz hits it with a closed fist. All the school girls put down their milkshakes and start doing the twist. Plaid skirts twirling everywhere.Oh well, it appears that others like this formula. I find it insipid, cheap, cartoonish, just a chariacature of musical turf that has already been crossed. 10,000 times. I guess you can give the samples a spin and see if it sounds like what you're looking for. It sounded interesting in samples but I listened through two, five times, then after a few months, I realized, I hate it - it's grating to the nerves. Vapid. It's a stunt, but there's nothing in this album actually worth hearing. First class "happy idiot" music.

There are two parts of a useful review: what does the fragrance itself do, and what else is it comparable to. A third part, by far the most common and always completely worthless, is, "do I like it?". Here's my soap box rant: saying "I love this!" or "My boyfriend/husband/wife/second cousin/alien examiner during an abduction really liked it!" is worthless. You may also love a soiled baby diaper top note with a dry down of tar and nuclear waste. To each his own, but that doesn't help the rest of the world understand whether it's a fragrance they'd like.Please note that you may completely disregard the reviews that say, in 10 words or less, "this is the best fragrance ever on the planet" and assign it 5 stars. This is called social media spamming. The companies all spend a few grand paying folks who have 100 different Amazon accounts with 100 different email addresses to give a barely-legible, semi-inchoate review to whatever the company's product is, to artificially inflate the early star rating. More often than not, these reviews don't even mention the name of the product itself, they say "the item" or "this is", totally non-specific. So, take heart, this review is real.To place my tastes, I'm lucky to have an embarrassingly large and broad-spectrum fragrance wardrobe, numbering in several hundreds, representing all the major groups of fragrances - florals, fougeres, aquas, attars, woods, citrus, greens. I enjoy a variety of them from a few synthetic-based designer frags to the Montales, L'Artisan Parfumeur, and Amouages. I enjoy what's good and err towards high-quality aoud blends, quality chypres, orientals and greens. I don't like cloying, syrupy sweet fragrances. I despise bone-dry, cheap, astringent synthetic "spice" and "wood" frags. I like florals but I despise powdery smells. I'm geared towards, simply put, high-quality blends, creative and interesting.Now for Glenn Perri Unpredictable Night: this is a good fragrance. It's fresh and sweet. Heavy on the synthetic amber and I'm really not sure what else - a bubblegum accord, maybe some musky tobacco leaf. But it also doesn't have much depth to speak of. On skin you won't smell it after an hour, fabric has hints, whiffs, of something after 3-4 hours. Longevity is poor. Sillage is good... for 30 minutes, an hour on fabric. After that, it's only if you catch a whiff of yourself, but it's not a part of your wardrobe any more. When it's fully dried down, you may as well be wearing no fragrance. It's synthetic ambergris and some synthetic floral... I'm struggling to identify it... maybe some synthetic lilac and a touch of cedar? Or is it just an anonymous chemical not really associated with any natural flower?I will wear it and it is inoffensive and enjoyable to the family and around the office, but unexceptional. The reason I gave it 3 stars is simply that it IS good, pleasant, inoffensive, and unexceptional, and secondly (and this almost earns it a 4th star), it is poured from the same vat as Dunhill Fresh. Now, to be fair, there are any number of other mixes that are very similar if not identical - I think Yacht Man Metal - and an Adidas scent, but I can't remember which one. A light-blue or lilac-colored one. Team Sport or Fresh Sport or Footballist, who knows. But I have and used a bottle of Dunhill Fresh (wrote a review as well) and this is absolutely, perfectly indistinguishable from that fragrance, at less than half the price. There are doubtless many others which are also poured from the same tank.There's the conundrum. This is a part of a race to the bottom. It's clearly better than any dollar store fragrance but it's clearly worse than any quality designer fragrance, and two orders of magnitude worse than any proper perfume house, all-natural, high-quality blend. It's a race to the bottom... and you're as likely as not to get an identical synthetic fragrance in a different bottle for $50 as this one for $15. You can't even compare the "Afrag Black" to the "Bfrag Black", or the "Cfrag Night" to the "Dfrag Night". They play musical chairs with Black, White, Metal, Night, Sport. They have all the same six or eight but in Karen Low it may be White, in Thallium it may be Black, in Glenn Perri it may be Metal, in Dunhill it's Gentleman's Odor, and in Adidas it is Team Orgy. They are all purely and simply identical. So, go to a department store, walk up to the fragrances, close your eyes and grab one. You have about a 20% chance that it's this fragrance in a different bottle.This one is so inexpensive and so absolutely OK, in a nice, heavy bottle with a decent spray, that it's hard to fault it. It's probably $18 worth of fragrance but it only costs $15. (Not kidding.) But it is anonymous and forgettable and for me, as a collector, I will not replace it. That is why it got 3 instead of 4 stars. In my system, I give 4 stars to any fragrance I like enough to replace once the bottle is empty - a permanent member of my wardrobe (assuming that they still make the frag when the bottle is empty). Five is a sort of top-25-of-all, king-of-the-hill fragrance that competes with any and every bottle up to $350 in value. There are many in the $50 to $100 range that clearly swings with the high-value, high-cost fragrances. This one is simply... OK. Not bad. Not offensive. Not cloying. Not exceptional. It's OK. It's most likely a Coty blend that's pennies per liquid ounce at cost.You can't go wrong if you want something that's rock-solid, unimpeachable, alright. If you want something special, attractive, or unique (unique as in, when you get in an elevator with 10 other people, there's a 99% chance that nobody else is wearing anything like it), this won't do. It's good. Not bad. Not great. A rock-solid, 100% perfect, good. Good with a capital "G". I expect to write nearly identical reviews for a variety of other Glenn Perri and Karen Low and other fragrances I'm trying out right now.Happy days! :)

I bought this to replace the Goodyear hose that was also supposed to fit the LS400. The Goodyear just bowed out in such a way that it contacts the nut holding on the power steering pump pulley.This one is wildly not for the LS400 of any model year. Mine is a '99 but this will not fit ANY LS400. It is not possible to see from the picture but there's about a 30-degree bend in the hose right where the insulating sleeve is, perpendicular to the view you have of the hose. The net effect is that the hose cuts about 1" into the path of travel of the mechanical cooling fan when installed. This will NOT FIT ANY LS400 (and may not fit any 1UZ-FE application with a mechanical cooling fan, which I believe is all of them), this inaccurate fitment is not subtle - the first time you start your car with this hose installed, it will shred the hose into rubber chunks right through the middle (if you're lucky), or just burn out the fan clutch in a deafening smoky plume (if you're not as lucky).Amazon's applications are dramatically wrong at least for the LS400 here. Please save yourself the time and frustration. My car has been laid up for a week waiting to try this... and will be for another half week until an OEM hose arrives. Please take my advice, I'm just writing this to save other shoppers the frustration!Happy motoring...

My application is a '99 Lexus LS400. The rubber seal leaks. I bought two of these. The first one that went on started leaking oil all over the place at highway speeds, blowing all over the control arms and so on, after about 500 miles of driving after the oil change. I put another (new) one on and started the car, and boom, the seal started leaking again. I put on a Fram extra guard filter and it's perfect. Do not recommend this for a LS400, or any vehicle with the 1UZ-FE.

I purchased this from Amazon. Just installed. After a few days of driving I found that the molded hose sort of 'bows' when the cooling system is under pressure, in such a way that the hose presses up against the bolt holding on the power steering vane pump drive pulley on. The net effect is that this bolt head started grinding a hole through the hose. I had to raise the car for another reason but it was very, very lucky that I noticed that before it blew out on the highway. The hose didn't touch the pulley when it was initially installed.So, caveat emptor: it does NOT fit a LS400 properly, at least, not a '98-'00, not sure if clearances are any different on earlier revisions. Also, it very well may fit other applications with the 1UZ-FE. Steer clear... there are other options. I've ordered another lower hose from Amazon, this one is a "Mackay". I'll update this review when I find if that fits better (the picture of the Gates hose shows a much sharper 90-degree molding at the lower end of the hose, precisely like OEM). You can also special order a Dayco from Advance or Autozone, although the picture of that one looks like it has kind of a 'wide arc' at the lower end, like this Goodyear.

I'm a recent Sleigh Bells convert/addict. The new album, Bitter Rivals, is more lyrical, slow, methodical, and perhaps ponderous. I have to admit that I liked the sort of menacing or foreboding heaviness of the percussion with Alexis's easy, lyrical vocals juxtaposed on the hard-hitting noise. Several tracks on both (Kids, Riot Rythm, Infinity Guitars / Comeback Kid) really nailed it. I was hopeful that the new album might take it up a notch - more energy, more soft vocals, more shouty guitar and heavy bass. It's actually a little more in the other direction - a little more melodic, but more subdued. It IS good and if you like the last two you will almost certainly like the new one. But if I were to recommend Sleigh Bells to someone, I certainly wouldn't start with this album.Also - Dear Amazon: the MP3 album costs more than a printed CD? WTF M8?

I'm a pretty enthusiastic collector of fragrances. I buy one for my wife now and then but she's not tremendously adventurous with fragrances and has ended up ignoring about a dozen I've given her in favor of one of the very first I bought her, a long time ago, D&G Light Blue. It's a pleasant but thoroughly unexceptional fragrance.Well, I recently got her Kenzo D'Ete and that sort of sparked something. I guess I'd done a poor job selecting. She likes that one. Kenzo, Issey Miyake and Success de Paris are some of my own favorites, bar none (including my various high-end bottles from Amouage, L'Artisan Parfumeur, Le Labo, Montale and so on). She liked the Kenzo Summer. So I picked up Kenzo Flower. She likes it a great deal... and I have to admit, I LOVE it. I think this fragrance is going to put a new spark in our marriage because a woman smelling like this... yum. Yum yum, scrumptious!Ok, aside from waxing poetic (and failing, miserably so in fact), the fragrance itself: I can't speak to top/mid/base note differences. But I can speak to the base note. It's a syrupy flower. Flower syrup. It's in the same vein as Kenzo Power for men... it's a kung-pow punch to your nose of impossibly pleasant flowery serum. It's sweet but not cloying, so when I say "flower syrup" I mean something more like a finely crafted attar. It has a clear, bright, 'watery' rose note very similar to Le Labo Rose 31, but there's iris, chrysanthemum. My wife thought it was powdery but she says that about every floral scent, and to my nose, it's not the least powdery. It has a perfectly reasonable balance of ambergris. So it's sweet, but not cloying. It's appropriate, and the sweetness is a background to this one-two knockout punch of delightful and just... ugh... sexy bouquet.OK, I'm sold. I think she likes it a great deal, and it's my new favorite for her! Our 11th anniversary is coming up and I may make a special request for this fragrance to be part of her wardrobe on our special night! :)As a husband smelling this on his wife, I'm giving it a 5-star rating, and if I could give it 6, I would. I speak for no one but myself, but for a household with many hundreds of fragrances in circulation, for a new one to have THIS distinctive and impressive impact really kind of stands for itself. Consider yourself... warned? Informed? Encouraged? Well whatever it is. Get yourself (or your spouse) one if romance is in the air. They've bottled it here. :)

The keyboard is a nice size (100% scale), sits at a slight tilt towards you, and has REALLY nice, solid keys with plenty of travel. It's actually a lot more comfortable to type on than most ultrabook keyboards and is as good as the chicklet/island keyboards in most full notebooks.I haven't used this one extensively because of the layout. I bought it along with a Perixx Bluetooth keyboard (see my the product and my review here http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005F7RO20/), which does have its own challenges, to replace an old Amazon Basics keyboard that would eat through a new set of batteries in a day. Because I haven't used this Targus keyboard extensively I do not know what its battery life is like. However, it lacks some good features of the Perixx keyboard (and others):1, there are no shortcut keys. On the Perixx there are shortcuts for switching applications, navigating to the home screen, and 'esc' matches the 'back' button in Android. The Targus just has standard 'esc', function keys, and no shortcuts. The net effect is that navigation requires you to use the mouse a lot more for Android devices that have the standard back / home / switch application soft keys, or for Samsung phones that have actual buttons on the device for back / home / switch application, requires you to tap on the device to perform basic navigation in the operating system.2, and this just kills me, the "Delete" button is where "Back Space" should be, right beside the "+ =" button. On ANY other standard English keyboard int he world, the key immediately to the right of the "+" and above the \| key, is a backspace. On this Targus keyboard, it's a full-size delete key. I have no idea how a mistake this big could have made it into an actual finished, market-ready product, but it's not a matter of preference - it's just plain wrong. The "backspace" key on this keyboard is a small button in the top-right that can't be reached without taking your fingers off the home key area.Between these two deficiencies, I turned off the keyboard after two days of trying to get used to it and put it on the shelf. As I mentioned, it's a full-size, solid, comfortable keyboard, which makes it a shame that such obvious shortcomings are built in to it. These are physical defects, design errors, not just firmware - so the product is, unfortunately, bad. Unless you're wanting to get accustomed to a different keyboard layout and deal with a lot more hands-off-the-keyboard navigation, you will simply want to move on and find another keyboard that is better matched to the Android OS and that has a standard English keyboard layout.

I bought this keyboard to use with a docked Samsung phone via Bluetooth. It replaced an old Amazon BT keyboard that drained two new AAA batteries in a day.This keyboard is attractive and comfortable to type on. It is compact but they letter/number keys are 100% size. The battery life is great; I have not yet drained it so I don't know its maximum life but it has gone for two weeks of all-day use without needing a charge. I also really like the Android shortcut keys; F1 toggles the "switch application" function on the Android device; hitting it again returns you to the desktop. There's also a "search" shortcut (F2), volume up, down and mute, play, fast forward and reverse. There's a button that connects the keyboard to a device once it's paired. All very handy.The downsides: it has a few reproducible firmware bugs that make it somewhat annoying to use with Android (not sure about iOS or any other OS).First, holding shift then hitting "space" or any other button keeps sending a command to the phone that sets the language to English (US)... again and again and again. That's not a problem except that the shift key is 'laggy', in that when you're capitalizing "I" or typing anything in all-caps, then release the shift key, the phone still thinks that the "shift" is pressed. The software does not indicate that the shift is released for about 1s after you actually release the key. That makes it very annoying, since you either get this "English (US)" setting and it ignores the space keystroke, or else you have to stop yourself after every capitalized letter to make sure the firmware recognizes that you released it. Shift + other letters (meaning, the phantom 'shift', after you've already released the shift key) are either ignored or bring up a special-characters dialog. All in all, the functionality of the shift key and the capitalization on this keyboard are very choppy, very buggy. You should not have to type slow and plodding to make the keyboard recognize keystrokes accurately.Secondly, there are two problems when the keyboard is sitting for a few moments. It seems like it's in a 'hibernation' or 'timeout' state after 1-2 minutes. After a later period, maybe 5 minutes, the BT radio in the keyboard turns off. You hit a key and it re-connects with the phone. So far so good. The problems occur when it's in this low-power state between 1 and 5 minutes (roughly - my times may be off).The first observation is between about 2 and 3 minutes of idle time. When you hit any letter or number, the keyboard repeats the keystroke 7 times. Exactly 7. So you hit "S" and you get 7 of them. If you hit 'i', you get seven 'i's. The next keystroke is recognized and registers properly without repetition, but the repeating-keystroke is another thing that slows you down immensely when you're chatting or browsing and not constantly on the keyboard. It happens so often that I've just left the extra letters in place, and folks I chat with recognize that it's just the keyboard being wonky when I send messages like, "WWWWWWWhere is the hammer?" or "IIIIIII am just about finished." (In the latter case, after the repeating "I", I have to wait for 1-2 seconds or you run into the 'phantom shift' problem described above, and the space bar keystroke will be ignored.)The second bug occurs perhaps between 3 and 5 minutes. In this case, the first keystroke depressed registers in the phone as a long-press on the soft keyboard, so a dialog opens up to show special character sets (foreign language) associated with the letter on the keyboard. When this occurs, you have to wait for the foreign character dialog to open and become available, then hit 'escape' to close it and continue typing. If you don't realize that the dialog has opened, while you type you inevitably end up selecting one of the foreign characters and that replaces the letter you actually wanted. Again, it requires you to either go back and correct it, or to pause for a few seconds to get back to normal typing mode.All of these things have to do with 'wake-up' when the keyboard is idle for a few minutes. Once it is awake and responsive, typing is comfortable and accurate. However, a normal, usable keyboard can't be this finnicky and sensitive to short timeout periods. Any time you have a keyboard sitting on your desk, table, in your lap, or whatever, this is perfectly normal, mainstream usage. All of these things would be corrected with an updated firmware and I'm hopeful, but perhaps not optimistic, that the company will release fixes for it. As it stands now, though, the keyboard has a great form factor and great battery life, but is very annoyingly buggy, which makes it difficult to use smoothly. I can no longer send it back to Amazon but I may just put this one on the shelf and plug a USB keyboard into the phone dock until I see a firmware release for this keyboard.

It's made of fairly heavy-gauge steel, pretty strong. Installation is no easier or harder than any other wall mount. We've had an old-ish 55" LCD (not an LED - so it's about 4" thick, even 5" at the base, and about 90lbs) hanging on this for almost 3 years, and so far, there have been no problems. I will add that we have some serious bass in the room, and that the kids stomp on the floor upstairs from this room all day every day (jumping off beds, chairs... dressers... what have you) so this is about as much abuse as you could imagine a wall mount experiencing, other than being placed on a boat or in a camper/RV. Solid buy.

Wow. I'm a big fan of Fujiyama Homme. I had not tried Private Number until another customer asked me to write a review and I realized I hadn't even opened the box yet! (I have a huge fragrance wardrobe... love collecting!) I also have Fujiyama Black Label and Sport. Both "OK". Now for Private Number.Wow.The spray starts light, happy, only BARELY sweet. As the vetiver, grass, iris top note dried away quickly I thought I smelled mid notes that were pointing directly at a "Polo Double Black" type of solution, which is GOOD. Mango, dark chocolate, ambergris, still a floral I can't pick out, but it never even got quite a sweet as Double Black and I never consider that one cloying, by any means. But it kept right on drying. What you end up with, is sublime. I'm having a hard time drawing an analogy with another fragrance. It might be closest to Creed Silver Mountain Water. It's a bright, but dry, pleasant formal fragrance. The basenote keeps vetiver, and maybe lilac. There could also be the most subtle hint of tobacco, but it would be very subtle if it's there at all. Nothing whatsoever like Tabarome, if you're familiar with that scent.Sillage is great, it's not overpowering but a very pleasant amount to share with someone standing immediately beside you. Intensity grows the closer you get. So you wouldn't need to dump it on. It is ever so slightly powdery, but I don't want that to be off-putting. I really do NOT like powdery fragrances but this isn't the typical "powdery", I just mean, the base note has a VERY dry floral / green aroma.I wish I'd known it was this good! For something at this price point to be that interesting and dynamic, it's just hard to go wrong. I could wear this both for formal and informal occasions, although, in my mind, the fragrance is more to share with, and enjoy, being close with someone... so... wear it when you want to take a walk in the park, have a nice dinner, go to a movie. Something to be shared and enjoyed intimately.It's an easy 5 stars. For the price, the value is incomparable. I'd need to do a side-by-side to figure out if I like it better than Fujiyama Homme or not, but they are both VERY good fragrances. In any case, enjoy!

My wife and I both own a bottle of this. This clearly errs for women but a man can pull it off. It is a good, simple, extremely clean scent that focuses on green tea, a clearly synthetic vetiver, perhaps a hint of lilac. It is light and fresh. Although it is errs on the side of a feminine fragrance, it is enough of a green/vetiver to be usable, and enjoyable, for men, in the right circumstance - in fact, in most circumstances when you'd wear any light, fresh vetiver or aqua. I wouldn't wear it to work or to a formal evening, but for a day out at the park with the kids, it is great. So I don't use it as an everyday scent, where it very well may be that for a woman (at least when it's warm outside)! It also obviously requires a man who has a wardrobe, and a personality, that can adjust to the mood of the event. Perhaps it goes without saying, but for a man who needs to smell like saddle leather and gun smoke all the time to maintain a persona or self-image, this won't be relevant! :)

I'm glad this has shown up on Amazon, as I wrote an in-depth review that was filtered out from numerous Chinese-wholesale websites because it isn't positive. Hope someone can benefit from all of this info!IntroductionI am not a professional tester, but a `real enthusiast' for Android tablet hardware. I have owned many tablets; my current benchmark comparisons are: Google Nexus 7 and 10, Acer Iconia A500 and A700, Asus Transformer Infinity TF700T, Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1. I like these non-US-market options to compare against current offerings in our market. I am currently evaluating against these benchmarks a Vido N90 FHD, Nextway NX9, and Cube U9GT5.Physical Form FactorThe N90 is fairly well-constructed with not much creaking. It is solid and feels good to hold. The buttons are convenient when at top-left (portrait) or top-right (landscape). The front camera is nested in the corner which creates an odd, offset angle for video chats. The ROM is programmed such that the tablet's natural orientation is upside-down, meaning that some programs that orient themselves to "default" and ignore auto-rotation leave you with the buttons at the bottom, right on top of your lap / desk. The the power charging, Micro-USB, headphone and Micro-SD slots are all along the same edge as the power button. If you hold the power button near the top, your headphones, USB and/or power cord would also stick out of the top. This could be good or bad depending on how and when you typically use these ports.ScreenThe screen is of course a 4th-Generation iPad doppelganger. The resolution is stellar; the screen is bright and crisp and offers minimal edge-lighting effect (barely visible on black screen). There are no dead pixels. The surface sits perfectly on the frame - perfectly smooth with no warping - and there are no Newton rings on the screen. It is high gloss, attracts smudges, and reflects everything. The brightness is ample but perhaps not QUITE comparable to the best panels out there. The colors very good but are not quite as extraordinarily saturated as a Samsung panel, and the display is clearly not as bright as the Asus Transformer Infinity's Super-IPS display. For viewing photos and reading books this "retina" display is simply stellar. The challenge comes with the hardware and OS; neither appears to be equipped to take advantage of, or even cope with, the resolution available for games or movies.SoundThe sound is very good. It produces good stereo sound that is comparable with the best of the list above. The only better sound may potentially be delivered by the Google Nexus 10, which sports extremely high quality front-firing stereo speakers. The placement of the speakers on the N90, however, are such that you would typically have your palms around the area when in landscape mode, (i.e., watching movies) which creates a sort of `reflection' off your palms and simulates the direct-firing sound quality of the Nexus 10 or Samsung Galaxy Note.Battery and ChargingOn opening the box and turning on the tablet, the battery was at 83%. My first goal was to get it charging up. I found that the tablet cannot charge from USB. The standard 2.5mm, 2A / 12V charger must be firmly seated in the port or charging will not commence. I left the tablet on, but idle, and charging overnight. The tablet had only charged from 83% to 92% after 10 hours. In the morning, I found that the tablet had deadlocked. I had to perform a hard shutdown (hold power button for 10+ seconds) then re-start. The re-start sequence appeared to hang and took over 3 minutes to bring up the Android desktop.It dropped from 92% back to 83% no more than 5 minutes of usage (primarily, just configuration and installation of apps). After about 20 hours of uptime including about 8 hours of light use, including a handful of benchmark tests, downloads and installs, web browsing, messaging, and a few minutes of streaming video from Netflix, it finally went down to 15% and warned me; after another half-hour of Kindle reading, it went slowly down to 13% and I plugged it in. I may have gotten another hour of kindle reading from the single charge.Recharging had it back to 100% within 2 hours which is obviously not correct (given that overnight charging with the same charger only reached 92%). I left it to charge overnight. I unplugged it around 7am and it indicated a 100% charge. Within half an hour it nose-dived back to 83% or so (same as before), but after a full day of intermittent Kindle, web browsing, downloading apps, multiple restarts, all with the screen at full brightness, the battery sits at 45%. It is now after 9pm. The enormous battery indicated by specifications (10,000mAh) bears out in real world application even if the OS doesn't appear to be fully in touch with the voltages of the battery cell.After several recharge/discharge cycles I have found that it would reach 100% charge, but drops very quickly to the low-80% range. There must be some defect or error matching the voltage of the battery with the OS's battery monitoring firmware.ConnectivityThe signal strength of the WiFi card is excellent with it consistently reaching 3-4 bars in areas where other devices only reach 1 or 2. This is essentially a useless observation because download speeds are absolutely abysmal. Downloading an 8MB program from Google Play took over 2 minutes. Overall, simply with anecdotal observations, the WiFi card has consistently high signal strength but simply cannot download anything from any network at an acceptable speed. It is, in fact, so slow that I would assume this is a hardware or firmware defect.CamerasThe cameras are very good. Although the rear camera isn't the highest quality it takes pretty good pictures in good light. The front camera delivers pretty good quality and frame rate. On the rear camera, focus indoors, even in relatively well-lit areas, is not very good. There is also no LED flash. Although the front camera is great for video chats, the rear camera is unexceptional and would not rival the high-end offerings.SoftwareThe tablet unfortunately is not certified by Google, and so, none of the games and few of the other apps I've purchased are available in Play Store. Only those apps without device filters are available. Google Play Movies & TV is not pre-loaded on the device and is not available for download from Play Store. Netflix App is available in Play Store, and Amazon Prime Instant Video can be played via a web browser. The streaming resolution is very poor even with excellent connections and the frames skip regularly. Part of the challenge may be the high-resolution panel; a well-known issue is that the Android OS and most apps are not programmed to cope very well with the super-high-resolution panels that have become available in recent months. However, it appears that the maximum supported resolution basically doubles the pixels - so each `pixel' in the movie is actually a 2x2 block of pixels on the screen. The pixellation effect is pronounced and ends up in a video quality that is worse, in fact, than the same movies playing on a 1280x screen.
