I can't wait to see what the author has in store for the readers in the third book of the series!The Promise, Promise Series is an amazing series of new adult romance stories that are full of drama, emotion, and romantic angst that keeps the reader captivated and wanting more!

The Other Wife is a compelling and emotional story that follows two women whose world is turned upside down when they find out that they have been betrayed by the same man, their husband!Author Kathleen Irene Paterka weaves an intriguing story told in the alternating point of view of Eleanor Anderson and Claire Anderson, as they deal with the loss of their husband Richard, and how they find out about each other and deal with their loss, betrayal, and the difficulties of moving forward with their lives after the trauma caused by the man that they both loved.I found myself captivated by this story, it took me on a roller coaster ride where I felt the full gamut of emotions. You just can't help but feel compassion and empathy for both women as their worlds are turned upside down by the traumatic betrayal and selfish actions of a man that they had put their love and trust in. This is a beautifully written story that would be any married woman's nightmare, I couldn't even imagine what I would do if I was in Eleanor or Claire's shoes.The author does a wonderful job of drawing the reader into the story from the beginning, she weaves a thoughtful storyline that easily draws the reader into the womens' lives. It will keep you engaged and turning the pages as both women go through the process of learning about each other, the selfish actions that Richard wrought upon their families, and the internal struggle of picking up the pieces of their lives and moving forward.The Other Wife is a powerful women's fiction story of loss, betrayal, compassion, forgiveness, and growth. It is a thought provoking and emotional tale that will stay with you long after the last word has been read.Disclaimer: I received a copy of the book from the author in exchange for my honest review.

Everything Burns is a riveting psychological thriller that will give the readers goosebumps, and keep them sitting on the edge of their seats.Author Vincent Zandri weaves a chilling tale that has enough drama, mystery, suspense, and terrifying thrills and chills that will easily captivate the reader's attention, and draw them into the troubled world of Reece Johnston.I couldn't help but get caught up in this complex, dark, multi-layered tale. I found myself trying to figure out what would happen next as Reece's story unfolded with a gripping amount of tension, emotion, and intriguing twists and turns.The author does a great job of describing Reece's complex history of personal demons and obsession with fire. The reader is taken on an intense roller coaster ride as the storyline gains momentum. This is a thought provoking, compelling, and very disturbing tale of pyromania that made my fear of fire that much more real ... because when you have fire ... everything burns!Everything Burns is a seriously scary good psychological thriller that is terrifying, chilling, and fascinating, it will keep the reader engaged and guessing until the surprising conclusion.

How can you be happy and properly officiate weddings when your nineteen year marriage goes on the skids? That's what marriage celebrant Viv has to deal with when she catches her husband Peter cheating with a twenty-two year office co-worker. As her world turns upside down, and after over ten years performing weddings and any other ceremony her clients request, Viv just can't do it anymore, so she decides to quit after she officiates at her last ten clients' wedding ceremonies ... and throw in a funeral for good measure. For Viv, trying to pick up the pieces of her life while performing her duties can't be that hard ... or could it?In her debut novel, Confetti Confidential: They Do, I Don't, author Susan Murphy weaves a thoroughly entertaining tale that has just the right amount of drama, comedy, and romance that easily draws the reader into Viv's story.From ten hilarious weddings, a funeral, a heartfelt bond of sisterhood, enough crazy mishaps and daily life trials and tribulations that will make you laugh, and a unexpected romantic triangle, the reader is taken on an exhilarating roller coaster ride as they follow Viv as she tries to get her life back in order. This enjoyable story kept me turning the pages and left me smiling at the end.The author had to have drawn from her personal experience as a celebrant to create this sassy story that allows the reader a little glimpse into the behind the scenes world of weddings. Confetti Confidential: They Do, I Don't is a refreshing story that is simply too good to not read!Disclaimer: I received a copy of the book from the author / publisher in exchange for my honest review.

When I first got Echo setup, I was having fun giving it commands such as what's the weather, play a radio station, and of course music from my library or Prime music.  My kids joined in, and had fun with asking math questions, Wikipedia questions, and add their favorite candies to the shopping list for me!  They also asks questions like: Alexa, when were you born, who is your mother, do you have any siblings, and even make statement that kids make among themselves like "Alexa, you suck".  Each time they laugh and happy at the response from the Echo.  I even then joined in with questions such as "Alexa, are you better than Siri?" They of course love to play their favorite music, which my wife hates.Then my wife came in, heard the music, and say "Alexa, Shut Up!"  Alexa, of course, complied.  That made her smile.  She hates voice technologies, so naturally she also tells Alexa "You are stupid."  The response made her laugh again.  Then we asks Alexa to play her favorite song, which wasn't in my library or Prime music. Echo played a portion, and gives opportunity to buy it for $1.25.  Of course my wife says yes as it's out of my wallet!After that, my wife uses everyday and overrides any music or radio stations the rest of the family puts on! And she begin to tell all her friends about the Echo and get at least 10 of her friends to sign up to buy one. Now this is someone who NEVER recommends tech to anyone. It's ironic how a voice product can be sold by handling negative remarks. Kudos to the Echo team.Now after using it for more than 6 months, Echo still the most popular item in our kitchen / family room where we ask for weather, play music or radio stations, and ask to answer questions (found on wikipedia).There has always been a concern about whether Amazon is listening to our conversations, but I did a test on network. Unless you say "Alexa", none of the conversation are transmitted... So that's good..for now...I highly recommend this gadget as it's very useful. I hope this technology can be brought into smartphones outside of Kindle, wearables, and into cars in the future.

I bought this to protect GeChic 1502i, which has the extra width. This cover, at first, seems 1 inch shorter in the longest side. But with its elastic material, it was able to fully cover the 1502i. I was also able to flatten the stand, and hook it to the long side and include it in the cover!Since the title also mention other 15.6 laptops, I gave them a try. Fitting a Macbook Pro 15 is easy with room to spare. For my Lenovo Thinkpad W530 and W540, which both have 9 cell battery that protrudes out, still manage to fit. Again this is due to the elastic property of the material.For those who are concerned about finding a cover for the 1502i, this is it!

I purchased this to switch a PS3, PS4, XBox One, XBox 360, and a mini PC (Intel NUC) to a 4K HDTV and another 720p native monitor capable of doing 1080i.  So it's a good test of signals. I'm happy to say the game consoles, especially the older ones like XBox 360 and PS3, did auto detect and adjust to HDTV at 1080i on both just fine.The 4K display from my mini PC is detected and shown. However, the minute I go to browser the screen starts to blank and reappear. Sometimes once a minute, sometimes continuously on/off for few minutes!!! this drives me crazy!  After research it appears the likely cause is support for HDCP pass-thru. This switch, from web descriptions, appears to not handle that.  So this means hooking up a PC to HDTV via this switch is not going make you happy.For 4K, only 30Hz will be supported since it's not HDMI 2.0In a nutshell, I do like all the cool features including ARC (can be turned off), Optical audio and analog audio thru 3.5mm socket. Switching from 4 inputs to 2 outputs, and share same inputs on both outputs are cool and seem to work good. However, if you don't have PC as a source, then it may not be compatible due to no HDCP pass-thru capability.

I bought a much more expensive 4 input x 2 output HDMI switch supporting 4K and ARC. That worked good with inputs from PS3, PS4, XBox and output to a 4K HDTV. However, I add a computer capable of outputing 4K to one of the HDMI input, and my 4K HDTV starts to flicker with browsers.  After further research, the problem seems to be no HDCP support or no pass-thru.I got this one because of the HDCP pass-thru, and boy does it work like a charm!  zero screen blanks with my mini-PC outputing 4K with Intel HD Graphics 5000 chip. I also connected a PS3, PS4, and XBox One to the input and they all switched beautifully with 1080p detection while 4K from the Intel NUC mini PC.  And in my case, no need to use the enclosed AC adapter as power provided by input sources are good enough!

I use this adapter for my Intel NUC that has only the mini HDMI female socket. I plug this into the mini computer, and full size HDMI on the other side to my 1080p TV monitor, as well as to my DVI-based monitor with DVI/HDMI adapter cascaded. No blank screens, no flashes, no scrambled images. Just clear and stable picture.  It works.I prefer adapter rather than a cable with two different ends. This allows me to re-use or swap regular sized HDMI cables of different length when I move the computer

The size of this projector is amazing, and great for travel or take around. Showing my computer screen from 10 feet away is pretty descent. Resolution is low but if I'm just showing videos, or PowerPoint slides with large fonts, then it's fine.  The brightness is good in darker rooms, but I can make out large fonts in bright room also.Battery is greatI do think any super portable project do need keystone to compensate for the angles. Without it, the screen, even from few feet away, look awkward. I would pay extra $100 for both horizontal and vertical keystone adjustments. Vertical is definitely more critical.

I cracked my original pot while putting down in sink with slight force.  The entire bottom shattered.This replacement version seems much sturdier, higher quality than my original. I didn't try repeating the procedure to break my original pot, but just by tapping the glass it felt much more like those "tempered glass".Very happy with my purchase to replace the orginal!

I switched to TiVO DVR (Roamio Pro) over Xfinity X1 (and AT&T U-verse prior) because TiVO Mini has lifetime (promo to end of 2014). This allows me to have flexibility of lots of TiVO minis for each room (not necessarily all used at same time) without paying a bundle every month.The performance for playback on recordings is quite good, unlike my previous systems that were laggy when fast forward or rewind.I also like the fact that I can some some of these receivers on MoCA, and others on ethernet.

After decades of using DVRs from Dish and AT&T U-verse, I finally plunged in to this DVR after switching to Comcast/Xfinity. I did use X1 for a day before switching.I choose the Roamio Pro because of the following:* I wanted maximum storage inside, and expanded add-on storage* I wanted multiple non-DVR receivers where I don't have to pay for them monthly (TiVO mini with lifetime)* 6 (dynamically assigned) tuners is needed in my household, especially we do record 4 shows simultaneously on certain nights* Descent UI, but I really like the "What's on Now?". Season pass recording across multiple channels is very useful also* TiVO app allowing to watch outside of house (supported by Xfinity). Works on ipad, android, but not last gen Kindle HD 8.9* RF remote - I missed this badly with AT&T U-verse that only use IR* Option to go to the Slide, with keyboard and backlit* Option to get stuff from PC (separate software)The only thing negative I find is the guide is missing details on sports. In particular football playbacks in Pac-12 network do not have the teams info so I have to record all and delete those I don't want. SEC network has team info however.So because I wanted my DVR to be more open, less costly (DVR + lots of receivers), this is the best choice for me at this time. With one month into using it, i'm happy with my decision.

This circle shaped pad is attractive on the desk and doesn't take as much real estate when no smart phone is placed on it. I use it in my office.Charging time is reasonable for my Samsung Note 3, but sometimes it takes couple of adjustments to ensure the phone is center to the circle pad and charging will be consistent. If not placed correctly, I'll hear beeps as the phone will be on and off charging.I also have a Moto 360, for which this is perfect to do daytime charging in my office.

I'm one of those that usually don't make lots of stuff from total scratch, especially baked goods. I recently decided to make my own breads, because I just love when bread is freshly baked, and my local bakeries cannot guarantee consistent time to bake the bread i wanted for me to pick up.The recipe book that comes with my bread machine (Zo), has measurements in volume and in weight. Following volume for the first few bread always resulted in issues with bread with consistency, and always seem to be "off".  With reviewers of bread machine suggest a scale and point to this one, I grabbed one to try.Boy did it make a difference! there is HUGE difference of measuring by volume versus weight, especially when it cans to heavier amount. For example, the recipe book that says 4 1/4 cups of flour also list 416 grams if measured by weight.  If I use the scale to measure 416g, I get only 3 1/2 cups of flour in a measuring cup! I think it's because the weight of the flour push down and make it denser with higher volumes. So, my original 4 1/4 flour would've come out to over 600 grams!PRO: Features I really like about this scale:1. big surface - big enough to fit bowl or big measuring cups2. Quick reset: I first had to put empty cup on the scale and remember its weight, then subtract it from the total weight. But then I found out I can hit the on/off button to "reset" to zero including the container! Then I can just measure the content.CON: things that inconvenienced me1. Timer too short. It shuts off many times before I dump content in a measuring cup on the scale!Anyway, great scale! Made me a better baker!

I was looking for something that can charge the rechargeable batteries, especially the C and D batteries. But I became super excited to find this can charge alkaline batteries too! All my life I've been told it's not possible to recharge the copper tops and the pink bunnies, and I do have couple of medium-sized boxes of these drained which I just don't have time to disposed them properly.I will only comment on recharging the alkaline batteries, as there was no need for me to buy the Ni-MH and Ni-CD the minute most of my dead alkaline batteries were charged and put back in service! This thing does work! I can honestly say, within 3 days of recharging 12 drained C and 8 D copper tops and put them back to use, this appliance paid for itself!Couple of notes on the recharging:1. If a battery still have some juice in it, the charger will light up green and say it's OK. So I drain them using devices such as spare flashlights and electric toys.2. The advertised performance (70-905), as vouched by reviewers, is similar to the fully charged rechargeable batteries. Good enough for most use.I'm happy with this purchase, as it's a sound investment and help reduce the disposal of batteries.

Wow, what a game. Movie-quality cinematic with compelling story that inspires a good controversial discussion. Graphics is top notch, the weapons are solid, and the character movement AI(especially the sidekick/partner) is one step closer to being more human-like.I have played through many action games, and the ones I liked the least always involve battling zombies. I don't know, just not a fan of them. But it's different for this game! It's difficult for me to articulate, but somehow I enjoyed battling the 4 stages of the infected. Maybe is I'm able to control the actions better.The game is linear, which is good as the focus is on playing through and feel part of the story. However there is plenty of freedom to roam and explore the surroundings.The ending sequence with Joel's course of action was unexpected (and therefore inspires a lot of debate).  *SPILER ALERT* However, because the main characters are intact, it's a foregone conclusion that a sequel will follow!This game ranks up there with UnCharted in playability, and in my opinion is unrivaled in playing through a movie-quality story. I highly recommend this game to any gamer (over 17) without reservations.

With Microsoft Surface, there are two choices for keyboards that double as cover. Anything else you'll need the Bluetooth keyboard separately.I'm a typist, and any productive typing means rhythm, and rhythm requires feedback. With regular full-size high quality keyboard I can type around 90 words per minute with more than 99% accuracy. I can get 80 wpm with this keyboard which is darn good. This keyboard in my opinion is one of the thinnest typist keyboard out there, and the only one for the Surface. The other side is a non-slip protective carpet-like feel. It doesn't weigh that much. Together with the Surface it feels like just carrying a half-inch thick notebook!This is the only keyboard that I would recommend for a typist.

I bought two of these for a dual shower tub, and they look pretty side by side!  What I like are the prices and does the job. They don't have crazy number of patterns that I spent half of the shower just trying to decide! The patterns here are simple and good to use.During assembly, I did use the thread tape as I normally do with all plumbing hookups. However the tape may not be necessary as each connector has rubber ring, which do seal any possible water leak.Overall a good looking, simple yet practical shower unit that is also cheaper than most. We are happy with our set!

I bought this to wrap my Thinkpad Helix whenever I do local travel to family events. It fit perfectly. Translation: very, very tight fit! It's like a person wear a very tight fit jeans kind of tight!So the downside? Can't fit power supply. There is one packet about two third of the height of the bag. Good enough to hold some flat accessories.For the price, it's not a bad investment even if you only need it occasionally.

I bought Helix (i7, 8GB, 256GB SSD) two months after I tried Surface Pro 128GB with type cover keyboard. While Surface Pro was very nice, Helix is at another level of features, flexibility, and..yes, the price too.Windows Performance Index (on native Windows 8):------------------------------------------------Processor: 7.2Memory/RAM: 7.5Graphics: 5.5Gaming graphics: 6.4Primary hard disk: 8.0Pros----* The tablet is thinner than Surface Pro, and about the SAME thickness as thinnest tablets with cover. I know it's not a fair comparison, but no one is expected to put a cover on the Helix tablet portion, since when not using it's covered/protected like a laptop. Overall it feels like a solid slate with slightly larger screen at 11.6"* Love the quick detach and re-attach of the tablet/screen. It's fun to show off to others, but the real appreciation comes when I am using it as an ultrabook on the desk or on my lap, and then snap it off in 1 second and proceed to lie on couch/bed to browse in tablet mode! It's just not web surfing, but working through spreadsheet, redlining a word document, and even video editing. Just can't beat that!* full size productive, spill free keyboard with a smooth feeling pad. I get about 85 words per minute, while I get 90 on the regular keyboards.* Trackpoint - this is a must for me. More productive than trackpad and I don't have to carry a separate mouse.* Once docked, it's a real ultrabook - so can actually work in my lap (hard to do with Surface Pro)* Flip for TV watching/demo mode. It feels real good to work on free hand sketches on the desk as well.* Pretty good battery life for an i7 with 8GB RAM at around 5 hours with tablet, and 9 full. This is my active use; advertised total time is 10 hours.* Solid casing with gorilla glass (strong, scratch resistant). I don't feel I need a protective cover like my tablets* Pen storage inside tablet (really paranoid with the Surface Pro for not having it)* Fast boot / resume with Windows 8Neutral-------Weight: tablet and keyboard dock under 2 pounds each. Combined is reasonable weight at 3.74. Tablets like iPad and Android-based with cover gets to be about the same weight or more compared to Helix slate bare (no cover needed)Cons----* No SD/MicroSD card slot(boo)* Buttons on tablet are flush with tablet edge. It actually made pressing the buttons a bit more challgenging. I either have to press harder or need a longer nail* Hot with running fan most of times, but this is controlled well with the free "TPFanControl" downloadable program* No backlit keyboard (I can dream)* About $300 - $500 higher than the equivalent i7 8GB ultrabook. But the extra money for that 1 second snap-off and then head-for-couch justify the extra $$$ for me!

As vibrating your hands is not enough, Sony decides it fun to knock our heads around! Playing shooter like Black Ops II was a head-pounding experience! Not only the background explosions vibrate my head, but so does some gun shots. Machine gun does a pretty good job at knocking my head semi-automatically!The headset can be in various modes, from game to specifics like shooting and racing, to movie. The differences are subtle to me, especially my head is being a "shock absorber"...All these are in wireless bluetooth mode with PS3. Wired with audio cable is not bad. The option to use audio input on the USB stick is clever, but the sound is ordinary stereo...and disappointing since my head doesn't get the "massaging" action.I have the first generation PS3 bluetooth wireless headset as well. Besides the head vibration sensation, the other major sound difference is this one can do 7.1 effect on blu-ray and streaming movies as well if I recall. The previous one can only do stereo for non-games sound effects.I haven't ran out of battery on this one, with my longest session being 3 hours. Of course, I think that's all my head can handle before needing some quiet times!Headset is classy looking, with good blend of chrome/steel in frame. The leather-wrapped ear cushion is stiffer in this model, so the whole headset feels snugged and firmly "gripping" my head without feeling tight.  Firm "gripping" also helps in kicking my head around!Anyhow, enough of me describing my simulated migraines (without pain). It's worth the experience..unless you are headache prone.

I have an elder who is in senior center and needs a phone. Normal mobile phones are too small, so I got a land base module (Verizon Wireless) and this phone to try.The dial buttons are big, and sound is loud, and most features are all well thought out for seniors. There is just one not very well thought out feature, and that's the one button dial. Having the one button dial is great and the reason why I wanted this phone, but the buttons are too small for most "older" seniors to see! As you can see in the picture, the number pad (1-9, * and #) are huge, butthe quick dial buttons above are small..like 1/3 in size! The whole point for seniors reaching the stage where they need such a big dial button, is also the age where they won't remember phone numbers and will rely on the one button dials. It's the memory buttons that need to be BIG! For my senior, the handset will be attached to his wheel chair, so the charging will not be near.Perhaps we need to classified seniors: those that are young seniors (65-75), to middle-aged seniors (75-85), and senior seniors (86+). The phone I was buying is for an 87 year old senior. He can see the big number pad on this phone, but cannot see the writing on the memory buttons nor the labels on the base, and he definitely can't remember phone numbers to manually dial. I ended up returning this phone and is continue my search.But for young seniors, I think this phone is very good choice.

If you love white and want smaller system then PS3 Slim model this is a great choice. The console white is glossy with ribbed middle but the controller is matte white. The materials are made to be lighter than other previous PS3 consoles, but the plastic also feels a bit cheap if you are used to the previous PS3s. But if you are new to PS3, you wouldn't know it. The top loading is good if you are setting the console on top of some table, instead of in one of the home theater shelves.I already have 2 PS3 slim consoles used with two different TV/entertainment centers. I decided I wanted to stay with another PS3 for a third room over other devices. This is because not only PS3 offers the best and upgradable blu-ray player, but also upgradable streaming apps (Netflix, Amazon Instant Video, etc), and bluetooth remote (I have a lot of problem with Infrared remotes in my setups).The bundle price is a good deal. The Playstation Plus membership is worth it in my opinion. For just $4 (and change) per month, you get to build up library of free games. Overtime, you library of free or discounted games can exceed hundreds of games. Well worth it  especially compared to other monthly recurring subscriptions. It's a bigger plus if you have a PS Vita, as the same membership gets quite a few great games also.

This little thing is great for cars with OBD II female connector under the steering wheel where the thigh goes under. It's low profile so it won't hit my leg, like other "taller" adapters or wired adapters.The bluetooth is an older protocol (hard code pin code) which is actually good for me. I have Android 2.2 double din radio/navigation installed in a BMW X5 (E53). Android 2.2's bluetooth does not support dynamic pin number that some bluetooth device requires (e.g., newer bluetooth keyboard).As for communication, connecting to bluetooth and establish OBD II connection both takes about 2-5 seconds simultaneously from Android app. It sends info to my app on both Android 2.2 and Android 4.2 devices just fine (using Torque).However, Torque is reporting some communication errors over bluetooth, but it's like 1% of times. That is acceptable to me, especially for an wireless mini adapter at this price range. It's almost a no-lose situation to take a risk.

These jars come with their own gaskets on the side, in case the buyer wish to make sure they are absolutely air tight. Even before installing the gaskets, closing the cap and fasten the latch takes strength. My 9 year old can barely do it, while my 7 year old cannot lock it. Adding the gasket and even I have to apply pressure to close and open. It's definitely air tight.The bottles are glass, so are breakable. They are good looking set. Not flashy but simple and elegant.

I'm usually very skeptical for electronics that works well at cheap price. This one is one of those rare exceptions. The USB devices plugged into this little hub worked well and very stable, despite it's not an active hub which requires external power. For a mere few bucks it deserved every bit of praise its got. If you need o more than 4 ports, this is a low risk purchase.

I purchased another brand a year earlier, and it fell apart when a little force tugged it accidentally. To avoid the same problem, I pulled this pretty hard and tried to disassemble by hand, and couldn't do it. So it's stronger.The signals transmitted through these are clear with no distortions. So I'm happy with my purchase of these angled plugs.

I bought the "Honey" cover. So I'll address the color first. It's NOT honey. Doesn't look like any honey I have ever seen, but the color is identical match to that of regular yellow mustard. Yes Mustard would not be prude for marketing, but honey color is flat out lie. They could've come up with some fancy yellow color name, like paint for cars these days.As for the cover itself, turning Kindle on automatically while opening, and automatically off/sleep while closing is just GENIUS. It's my favorite part of handling Kindle. Always in awe and never gets old! That itself is worth extra premium to comparable covers.The cover is a perfect fit - obviously since it's from Amazon. The cover flips outward to become a stand, and it's pretty sturdy and also doesn't slip on gloss polished wooden tables.The leather is hard leather. It's more like the material you find on a European car door panel (e.g., BMW), then the plush ones you find in a luxury Japanese car panel. So if your expectation of leather is the plush luxury type, then you'll be disappointed. I personally think it's meant to seriously protect, rather than let dig your fingers and palm into it.All in all a very functional case. It's auto switch on/off is AWESOME, but its NOT Honey!

I bought this extended length for a extra long treadmill that is 3ft wide and 7ft long. The width barely fits, and the length has extra few inches to give. My treadmill is over 300lbs, and this seems to handle the weigh and provide good cushion on my soft hardwood floor.The mat is easy to clean. I'm able to take a hand vacuum cleaner and suck things right up. For dusts generated by the treadmill overtime, it's easy to just wipe it off.My only gripe is the horizontal strength. During installation of the new treadmill, we (stupidly) attempted to pull the mat with treadmill on it in order to shift the machine couple of inches into position. That pull ripped a corner off the mat! So heads-up: don't pull the mat in order to move the machine!

My DC31 handheld vacuum usually just sits on some stand waiting to be used. The charger is always plugged in, and is unplugged explicitly each time I use it. I bought a DC44 that comes with its own wall mount. I loved it and decide to find one for my DC31.This mount has the all important power tip entrance, allowing the tip to snap in place so that when DC31 is returned to this dock, the power tip slides right into the DC31 without any drama, and charging starts!This mount practically is good for facing up, where the vacuum rests in it. It cannot be facing down like DC44's dock. It may work on the 3 or 9 clock position, but the screws must drill into the studs very well.All in all it's a good mount to have for DC31 since I want it mount on the wall. I just think it should be included with the vacuum as it's pricey enough!

This power pack/charger was included in my Motorola Razr Droid smart phone package. It is quite thin and lightweight, with the size similar to a typical smartphone. Because it's so thin, the built-in battery doesn't hold that much power. So it's not likely to do a full charge of a typical device. I was able to charge from 10% to 50% of my Razr Droid Maxx, which lasts extra 2 hours with GPS tracking turned on.There are a lot of power pack with much higher capacity, but they may not be comfortable to charge on-the-go. I was able to have this power pack charging my smart phone in my jean pocket, without feeling the heat or any extra weight! So for as long as I only need to extend my phone for 2-3 hours of use, this ultra lightweight / thin power pack is perfect.

I bought this large capacity drive mainly to transfer large files, usually greater than 2GB, but sometimes up to 35GB (1080p movie). The speed of 90MB/s read and 20MB/s write is accurate for USB 3.0 on Thinkpad W510/520. Actually I'm getting 30MB/s for write which is better than advertised speed.The USB stick has a blue light, which stays solid when plugged in and working. When performing I/O, it will flash. It is one of the longer one, and is not a retractable. So must take care when it's plugged in.All in all for the price it's a good deal. I have used it actively for several weeks now and it's pretty solid.

I bought this to play early versions on Windows, of the current/recent sequel titles on PS3 and XBox 360. These games just not the same using keyboard, or anything other than console-caliber controllers. This Xbox 360 wireless controller was a logical choice since it's the same controller for XBox, and of course both XBox and Windows are from Microsoft.The package comes with the controller that is identical to the one that comes with XBox, and a wireless receiver plugging into the USB port on the PC. It also comes with two AAA batteries and a CD to install driver.After driver installation, the receiver and the controller runs without hitch. The issue then is the games. Most games will not function like this, and will require third party software/driver, and both vendor-contributed and public-contributed configuration files. This is where it requires time on your side. For example, the original Mass Effect game for PC may have multiple user-contributed configuration files, some work better than others. More recent Mass Effect 2 have better support.So your mileage may vary depending on the game you wish to play.

My boys just go into Acceleracer series. They spent a lot of time on YouTube viewing fragments. I found this on Amazon. At under $13 for four videos, it seemed a good deal. Now a month later, I can confirm it's a good value. I prefer my kids to sit on sofa watching, instead on office chairs watching a small video screen with bad resolution and incomplete videos.

I replace the 16GB card that comes with my Roid Razr Maxx with this 32GB, and it works flawlessly for over a month now. I put 15GB of music on there, and several 720p DVD videos. Playback is smooth for both music and video.I didn't run performance benchmarks on this card, but having quite a few transflash cards, I find find this with the same or slightly better speed but yet at much higher capacity. So that's always a good indication.

70+ hours over 3 months period. That's what the game gave me as a summary report when I finished the game - once. I've only sporadically played games throughout my life. My recent playing has all been FPS or action games in straight campaign linear mode to get through-and-move on. ME2 is a role playing game that needs to build up a team and build royalty while excavate minerals. The game like this usually turn me off after few hours as I refuse to put so much time in it (Dead Island for example). But this game is highly addictive, and I keep coming back to play. It was worth the money for sure.The only thing I find repetitive (but still wanting to do) is mining all the planets for minerals. This at the end wasn't necessary for 3 out of the 4 elements. The mining probably took me a good 1/4 of the time. I give 4 (instead of 5) stars for fun because of this time waster. In Me3 they simplify this which is good.The other complaint is the reloading time after getting killed. It can take up to 30 seconds to restart a section each time, which is a real downer. I have a 7200RPM hard drive and it's a real drainer. I strongly suggest using one of the faster SSDs if you want to play at more difficult level to deal with the slow reloading time.This edition comes with most of the DLC content, so lots to explore. That's a huge value! I think there is only one DLC that is not part of this and can be downloaded separately.My only major complaint is loading time after getting killed. Typically can be 20-30 seconds. On some very challenging battles, the loading-before-restarting can really drag the gaming session on. (I have a 7200RPM HDD, and may need to try SSD)All in all, it was a GREAT game that really had an effect on my work productivity and cut into my sleep time!

I bought this for my 9 year old on his birthday. He loved building stuff using Lego (especially cars), so this was next step in understanding the internal workings.All in all it took 5 hours. He was good doing himself 2/3 of the instructions, but got stuck. I did have to help. Unless the builder reads instruction carefully, and also look at the pictures carefully, mistakes bound to happen (e.g., reverse one of the main engine blocks). The screws are nice alternative to glue, but the screw driver worn out at the end.One of the final steps involve distributor/spark plug adjustment, and the instruction doesn't work. The way to adjust is to move the crank shaft's pulley until the spark plug light goes on.The valuable part is learning the terms of various engine parts while building. For example, the builder will say and repeat the parts piston, rocker, camshaft, timing belt, water pump, fan, fan belt, pulley, distributor, spark plug, and my favorite - oil dip stick! Then of course at the end when the whole thing working.As for the quality, I can definitely believe the issues reviewers here have identified. The motor can work pretty hard and can easily burn out.  I'm glad ours worked so far. Cross my fingers...

I bought one last year (2011) for my HD camcorder, and bought another this year for general storage. It's quite reliable and it performs well on reads and write. Not the fastest on the market but its above average. For the price, they are worth it for what I need.

I frequently use my computer late at night. I do keep my lights on but the only reason is so that I can see the keyboard. I really wished I didn't have to, hence looking into an illuminated keyboard. There are some in $20 - $30 range, but this one is worth the price because:1. Slick design and attention to detail such as clear trim.2. Overall look clean and polished, feel like an $80 keyboard3. Illumination of keys are clean, bright but soft, and can dim slowly and elegantly4. Wireless (see below)5. Re-chargeableWireless feature allow me to unplug the USB adapter from my desktop and plug it into my HTPC and allow me to use computer on a big home theater screen.The laptop feel keyboard is easy to type. However, for a full size keyboard I would rather see it deeper, perhaps between the depth of regular keyboard and laptop.I have not tested the battery life of this yet as I don't expect to go several hours without charging.

My boys used to love this Strawberry Yogurt Burst in 2011, but lost interest for a while. Now the 6 year old wanted bad, saying "I want Bursty!" but its no where found in grocery stores. It's understandable that different flavors keep coming out and if a supermarket is to carry every flavor of Cheerios it would have to dedicate entire isle for all varieties of the brand!Luckily Amazon carries it and price is reasonable. 5 stars for both the cereal itself for the Yogurt Burst lovers and Amazon.

I bought this when it first came out, but returned it as it wouldn't provide me any additional functionality then what I had with iPad. It was very nice device nevertheless, just wasn't offer anymore than what I already have. But implementation of the lending library and Prime membership benefits ONLY for Kindle devices made this device more valuable (duh). The free Prime Instant Video is also nice to have and definitely added value. So I bought one again to take advantage as a Prime member.

My Kindergardener has hand that is too small for regular mouse, so I bought him a mini mouse.  But the mini mouse was too small and prone for him to slip on drag. This mouse is smaller than standard mouse size and easy to click and drag for my child. He loves the Transformer Bumblebee color and this is the perfect color!The CD-ROM included has a driver. You need to use this as Windows 7's HID driver is generic and does not allow assigning various extra buttons.

As background, I've been making Belgian waffles for my family for almost two years now, for average of 3 times a week. We tried many cheaper ones on the market, but settled on Waring Pro double waffle maker for the last 18 months. The cooking surface has worn so I decided to replace with a new one. This product caught my eye with its features and stellar (but few) reviews.First the waffle maker. The countdown timer is very nice, although not intelligent. It sets on 2 minutes when sufficient batter is on the iron, regardless of whether I finished pouring it or closed the lid. Overflowing channel is easily cleaned.  The separate control for crispness is cool. I especially loved the method of making it non-stick: simply add some water and steam it off instead of spray with oil.The actual waffles baked (4 squares) are crispy at the time cooking is done, and it remained crispy when cold. The reason is the ridges / walls separating the holes are super thin. There is no "meat!" The Belgian waffles I'm used to have 1/8" width between holes and therefore can become soggy if the filling is "eggy" or not properly exposed during heat dissipation. The waffles made with this machine are also thinner between the top and bottom side, so they are less "breaded" if you will.I personally not too fond of less-meaty waffles, and it turns out my family members are more vocal on this - boths kids and wife. They are used to "meatier" waffles like me. So my wish is Chef's Choice to make a waffle maker of this caliber, but for "meatier" waffles.

Throughout most of the 1930s, the Popeye cartoons represented Max and Dave Fleischer at the peak of their powers. It's easy to see why the spinach-eating sailor surpassed Mickey Mouse in popularity. When the Fleischers lost their studio in 1942, things were never the same. Paramount renamed the operation Famous Studios, but Max and Dave's creative spark was sorely missed. As a result, the final black-and-white Popeyes remain a mixed bag. Nevertheless, the three-volume DVD collection is a must for animation buffs — loaded with special features, commentary tracks and bonus shorts (including several Fleischer "Out of the Inkwell" gems from the 1920s).

Routine, unremarkable Western plays like a Universal made-for-TV movie. The primary assets of "Showdown" (1973) lie in the easygoing chemistry between Dean Martin and Rock Hudson as well as Ernest Laszlo's expert location cinematography.  However, not even the finest talent can salvage a tired script that adds nothing new to the genre. Dino and Rock's last Western . . . and George Seaton's directorial swan song.

You don't have to be a Laurel and Hardy devotee to enjoy this two-reel classic. "Big Business" (1929) transforms a simple tit-for-tat premise into comic brilliance. Stan and Ollie's escalating battle with the inimitable James Finlayson never fails to evoke hilarity. The best L&H silent and one of the finest shorts ever made.

Though William F. Buckley Jr. borders on self-parody, this 1967 "Firing Line" broadcast remains essential viewing for the political commentator's mostly serious conversation with the legendary Groucho Marx. "Is the World Funny?" gets understandably short shrift among the wide range of topics discussed by Groucho and "Willy." A fascinating time capsule that has plenty of resonance in today's troubled times. Except for an irritating glitch at the 22-minute mark (due to a flaw in the original videotape), the DVD-R quality is very good.

Overlong, wildly uneven Western satire with enough hilarity to compensate for the occasional misfires. "A Million Ways to Die in the West" (2014) does not approach the high laugh content of Mel Brooks' classic "Blazing Saddles," yet director-star Seth MacFarlane displays more affection for the genre. MacFarlane's amiable presence and a strong cast keep the sagebrush raucousness on track. Pared down from 135 to 116 minutes, the theatrical version could have easily lost another reel.

"Buyer beware" in the truest sense. Why the geniuses at Warner Home Video would release this "double feature" in FULL SCREEN borders on the inexplicable. Since both "Mad Max" titles are readily available in widescreen format, there's no need getting stuck with this poor-quality disc.

Undeservedly obscure, writer-director Anthony Simmons' "The Optimists" (1973) is a surprisingly effective drama that transcends the usual family fare. Peter Sellers delivers a career-high performance as an aging London street performer who befriends two poverty-stricken children. Slightly overlong but a worthy change of pace. Another gem from Sellers' so-called "lost decade" (1965-1974).

Mostly satisfying crime thriller with Burt Reynolds in solid form as a world-weary Las Vegas bodyguard. Despite its troubled production history and subsequent commercial failure, "Heat" (1987) survives as one of Reynolds' better screen vehicles. A tighter script would have helped, but the overall film holds up relatively well. If only Burt had tackled more character roles during his box-office heyday.

"One Down Two to Go" (1982) represents a cool poster in search of a movie. A high-powered cast gets taken down by poor scripting and co-star Fred Williamson's amateurish direction. When in New Jersey, all action heroes stay at the Holiday Inn. Deservedly forgotten, this grindhouse throwaway failed to revive the blaxploitation genre.

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer strike a pose in this dated melodrama from producer David O. Selznick. However, the real star of "The Garden of Allah" (1936) is W. Howard Greene's three-strip Technicolor photography, which cannot salvage an arid desert romance. A pity that Dietrich and Boyer never made another film together. Recommended only for devotees of early Technicolor.

Self-defeating budget cuts plague this ambitious follow-up to "Escape From the Planet of the Apes." Despite a provocative script, "Conquest of the Planet of the Apes" looks like a made-for-TV movie — never catching fire until the disturbing (and surprisingly violent) final half-hour. Roddy McDowall and Ricardo Montalban act circles around an otherwise forgettable cast. Once again, penny-pinching studio executives shortchange a potentially fine film.

Michael Caine made "a lot of crap" throughout his long career. The veteran actor included "Jaws: The Revenge" (1987) as part of that cinematic junk pile. Diminishing box-office returns were not enough to stop Universal from green-lighting this beached sequel. Nonsensical filmmaking of the lowest caliber, with the mechanical shark at its most ludicrous.

One of John Wayne's best Lone Star efforts. Directed by the reliable Harry Fraser, "Randy Rides Alone" (1934) is traditional "B Western" fare with an unusually dark atmosphere. More than 50 minutes of hard riding, gunplay and romance — climaxed by a spectacular explosion. Yakima Canutt's vigorous stunt work remains a standout. Readily available in the public domain, but avoid the Fox/Lorber version with its tacked-on contemporary score.

A breathtaking comedy-drama inspired by the Hatfield-McCoy feud, "Our Hospitality" (1923) was Buster Keaton's first feature-length masterpiece. Shot in the Lake Tahoe area, the film has a pictorial beauty and authenticity that would influence directors ranging from John Ford to Orson Welles. Buster's dangerous stunt work remains one of the great natural wonders. Along with a generous array of special features, the Kino "ultimate edition" retains Carl Davis' definitive orchestral score.

"The Masked Marvel" (1943) features some of Republic Pictures' finest stunt work and visual effects in this fast-paced wartime adventure. Unbilled stuntman Tom Steele plays the title role — definitely earning his salary throughout 12 action-packed chapters. A slam-bang serial with all the classic elements. Nostalgic fun for all and one.

Rated PG for the entire family, "Sheba, Baby" (1975) finds Pam Grier taking her ass-kicking heroics to Kentucky. Without her strong presence, this blaxploitation programmer would vanish from memory. The funky soundtrack (featuring vocals by Barbara Mason) generates more vitality than the tired plot. Stick with "Coffy" and "Foxy Brown."

Suffering from the studio-bound stiffness that plagued many early talkies, "Unaccustomed As We Are" (1929) provides an agreeable  vocal transition for Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. The Boys' effortless charm overrides a static two-reel sitcom — bolstered by the classic presence of Mae Busch, Thelma Todd and Edgar Kennedy. Rather flat without dialogue, the accompanying silent version is worth a look only for historic purposes.

Despite the surprisingly good cinematography and a better-than-average cast, "The Flesh Eaters" (1964) is deadly dull exploitation fodder. Plenty of expository dialogue, but few chills on the Long Island beach (where the film was shot). However, drive-in fanatics should see this cult oddity at least once.OVERALL RATING: *

Two different eras of Stoogery are represented in this DVD double feature. A pre-Code MGM hodgepodge, "Meet the Baron" (1933) includes some memorable comic relief from Moe, Larry and Curly before parting ways with Ted Healy and earning immortality in Columbia's two-reel factory. Released by United Artists, "Gold Raiders" (1951) finds Moe, Larry and Shemp co-starring with George O'Brien in a painfully routine "B" Western that runs only 55 minutes. Stoogeaholics will want to track down these rarities, but the films are distressingly mediocre.

Edited for home video due to music-licensing issues (thus excising the Tom Petty performance), this 1990 special provides a fun-filled overview of David Letterman's NBC era. Taped at the Universal Amphitheatre in Los Angeles,  the "Late Night 8th Anniversary" features Dave's signature routines, wild interviews and recurring characters — not to mention the Top 10 list and surprise guests . . . plus Paul Shaffer and the World's Most Dangerous Band. A pity that Letterman ended these annual prime-time specials a few years after his move to CBS.

MGM's ill-conceived historical drama was a critical and commercial disaster. "Parnell" (1937) represented career low points for Clark Gable and Myrna Loy — both hopelessly miscast. Decked out in ridiculous mutton-chop sideburns, Gable avoided further embarrassment by refusing to play the title role with an Irish accent. A solid supporting cast and Karl Freund's cinematography emerge unscathed.

Influential yet decidedly tame (and rather silly) biker flick. Marlon Brando's iconic presence, with a strong assist from Lee Marvin, makes "The Wild One" palatable B-movie fare. In his later years, Brando admitted that the Stanley Kramer production had not aged well. Mill Creek's Blu-ray release boasts an excellent full-frame transfer, but no extras.

A stylistic change of pace from director Tim Burton that lacks the spark of his best work. The twisted saga of pop artist Margaret Keane and her husband Walter obviously was a subject close to Burton's heart. However, unlike the inspired "Ed Wood," the filmmaker opts for a standard biopic approach that drags down the fine performances of Amy Adams and Christoph Waltz. "Big Eyes" (2014) has a bright color scheme, but no resonance — evaporating from memory the moment it's over.

"The Battle of San Pietro" (1945) is a compelling documentary that places viewers in the line of fire.  Directed and narrated by John Huston, the 32-minute film remains a groundbreaking study on the humanism of war.  Like the best documentaries, it is a deeply affecting work. An examination of the U.S. foot soldier in combat, "The Battle of San Pietro" was filmed in December 1943 during some of the worst fighting of World  War II. The matter-of-fact poignancy of Huston's narration adds a sobering, ironic undercurrent. During his career as a screenwriter and director, Huston excelled in his understanding of the human condition. Nowhere is this quality more evident than in the harrowing chronicle of San Pietro. Even today, much can be learned from Huston's intelligent exploration of the human spirit under fire. The film survives as a landmark documentary and a work of cinematic art.

A hard-living torch singer becomes a mail-order bride on a North Dakota wheat farm. Yeah, right. "The Purchase Price" must have looked silly in 1932. Try though they might, Barbara Stanwyck and director William A. Wellman cannot salvage a ludicrous script. Stanwyck never gave a bad performance, but George Brent and Lyle Talbot are miscast. Little pre-Code spark in this hokey Warner Bros. melodrama.

Steely Dan's "Aja" represents 40 minutes of jazz-rock brilliance. A natural hit in 1977, this beautifully crafted album has lost none of its timeless appeal. "Deacon Blues," in particular, is nothing short of sublime. The group's finest recording and a genuine masterpiece (a word I do not use lightly).

Cursory research, no index, ugly cover. "Bowie: The Biography" reads like an extended People Magazine article with little insight on its subject. Wendy Leigh's tabloid mentality overshadows Bowie's music and cultural influence. Track down Peter Doggett's perceptive critical study "The Man Who Sold the World" (2011) and avoid this gossipy tripe.

"Death Wish 3" is a slight improvement over its sleazy predecessor, with Charles Bronson and director Michael Winner going through the motions on the Golan-Globus conveyer belt. Poor Charlie looks a bit haggard amid the cartoonish mayhem, yet he would sign on for two more embarrassing sequels. At least the Blu-ray offers a widescreen version for Bronson fans and "Death Wish" loyalists.

Stan and Ollie are intrepid repo men in this lesser-known short. "Bacon Grabbers" remains an enjoyable two-reeler that gets extra  mileage from the presence of slow-burning Edgar Kennedy and a young Jean Harlow. Making the most out of already-familiar material, Laurel and Hardy deliver some truly hilarious moments. By the time "Bacon Grabbers" was released in October 1929, The Boys already had five talkies under their belt — thereby bidding a reluctant adieu to the art of silent comedy.

Anything goes in the luchador genre. The Man in the Silver Mask teams up with a painfully broad Mexican comedian for some bad cinema. "Santo Contra Capulina" (1968) offers little wrestling footage but plenty of groans. "Family friendly" in the worst sense.

Entertaining 1935 musical-comedy with W.C. Fields in splendid form. Co-star Bing Crosby demanded that Paramount re-edit "Mississippi" in his favor, but the Great Man steals the show. Plenty of classic Fieldsian routines and Der Bingle croons a few memorable tunes. Breezy direction by the reliable A. Edward Sutherland. 100 Proof Dialogue: "Never been frightened of liquor in all my life."

Dated generation-gap comedy was an improvement over the dismal vehicles that plagued Bob Hope's latter-day film career.  "How to Commit Marriage" (1969) generates occasional spark thanks to the only movie teaming of Hope and Jackie Gleason, along with the  presence of Jane Wyman, Leslie Nielsen and Tina Louise. Unfortunately, a weak script bogs down the sitcom-style hijinks. Hope and Gleason fans will get a few laughs out of this missed opportunity.

Katniss and Company take a stunning nosedive after "Catching Fire." Representing Hollywood at its cynical worst, "Mockingjay - Part 1" was made by greedy profiteers who show contempt for their audience by delivering an unbearably padded and dreary film. The saddest aspect remains the waste of an excellent cast — notably Philip Seymour Hoffman's penultimate screen performance. He deserved much better . . . so did "Hunger Games" loyalists. In the immortal words of Bobby Bowfinger, "Gotcha suckers!"

One of the iconic wrestler's best movie outings. "Santo vs. the Martian Invasion" (1966) resembles a Spanish-language version of "Plan 9 From Outer Space" with better production values and entertainment value. Everyone's favorite Man in the Silver Mask thrashes muscular aliens outside (and occasionally inside) the ring while saving the world from outrageous destruction. A worthy companion to the 1962 cult classic "Santo vs. the Vampire Women." Ridiculous widescreen fun with English subtitles.

Stanley Kubrick's strategic black comedy did not garner a single Academy Award among the four nominations it received. I kid you not. More than a half-century later, "Dr. Strangelove" (1964) belongs on any serious critic's Top 10 list. Collaborative filmmaking at its most sublime — a rare example of extraordinary talent at the peak of their creativity. Peter Sellers (in three remarkable roles), George C. Scott, Sterling Hayden, Peter Bull, Keenan Wynn and Slim Pickens make a one-of-a-kind ensemble. Kubrick's cinematic masterpiece — "2001: A Space Odyssey" doesn't come close. Congress should be forced to watch "Dr. Strangelove" on a yearly basis, with "Duck Soup" thrown in for good measure.

If you like some of your David Bowie sliced and diced for Top 40 consumption, "The Singles 1969 to 1993" should fill the bill quite nicely.  Rykodisc's out-of-print American release includes enough gems to offset some jarring edited versions — notably "Space Oddity," "DJ" and "Ashes to Ashes." The "special" non-radio edits of the "Let's Dance" hits are recommended solely for hardcore Bowie devotees. Fortunately, most of the essential tracks — "Changes," "Rebel Rebel," "Young Americans," "Fame," "Golden Years" and "Cat People (Putting Out Fire)" — remain gloriously unaltered.  Far from definitive, yet undeniably entertaining.

Paramount's second "Road" escapade finds Bob Hope elevated to second billing above Dorothy Lamour while solidifying his lighthearted rapport with Bing Crosby. Slighty overlong, "Road to Zanzibar" (1941) is a pleasant jungle romp — mixing sight gags, reflexive one-liners and rather forgettable songs. As a musical-comedy team, Hope and Crosby didn't hit their stride until the following year with the classic "Road to Morocco."

"Check and Double Check" (1930) was the first — and last — "Amos 'n' Andy" feature. The novelty value of seeing radio comedians Freeman Gosden and Charles Correll on the big screen made the film a box-office smash. However, the team was dissatisfied with RKO's poor visualization and rejected any cinematic encores. Melville Brown's static direction emphasized the clumsiness of Bert Kalmar and Harry Ruby's padded script. Political incorrectness and all, this creaky piece of celluloid holds some historic interest — notably a memorable appearance by Duke Ellington and His Cotton Club Orchestra (with off-camera vocals from Bing Crosby and The Rhythm Boys).

The big-budget bomb that helped bring down George Harrison's HandMade Films. A painfully miscast Sean Penn is stuck with his then-wife (and non-actor) Madonna in a romantic-comedy fiasco. Not surprisingly, the ex-Beatle makes a brief cameo and contributes a few songs that he re-recorded with better results on his 1987 "Cloud Nine" album.

Columbia squanders the second pairing of Boris Karloff and Peter Lorre on a low-budget "Arsenic and Old Lace" knockoff. Largely devoid of humor, "The Boogie Man Will Get You" (1942) wears out its welcome at the halfway mark. The claustrophobic wartime farce relies heavily on Karloff and Lorre (who have great rapport) to prop up weak material. In retrospect, the Masters of Menace needed a comedic assist from the Three Stooges.

This rice has proven itself to be some of the best I've ever made myself. I'm not exactly a chef by nature, but I give it a go once in a while. my jaw dropped over and over again. Such an amazing series - always entertaining and very very well done.

The good part about this camera is that it has very decent video quality which is better than most, more expensive cameras out there. The bad part is that the cameras is somewhat bulky and attaches with a suction cup. I live in California and suction cups don't work too well in our heat so this thing pops off ALL the time. Also, the camera is fairly bulky and noticeable from the outside which means that if you leave it attached, there a chance that someone may break into your car to get it. Instructions are pretty vague and I had to ask my husband to figure out how to work this thing. The charging port is at the top which may be a problem depending on the placement of the camera. Hubby had to run the cables in a different way than he wanted to originally just to accommodate for the charging ports location. Overall, it seems like a pretty decent camera, but like all the others out there, it has some flaws. I received this product as a sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I have a similar colander that I really like and I originally got this one to use as back up for my other one, but it turned out to be so awesome that it is now my primary one. I am a smoker and the reason I decided to try this supplement is because I started wheezing at night when I sleep. Overall, seems like a good product that I would recommend to take as a preventative measure. I received this product as a sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

Whoever came up with this concept is a genius! This dress took some time to arrive and when it did, it turned out to be very different from what I expected. First, let me just says that the material is very thick and even though this listing says it's rayon/cotton/spandex blend, it's not. The dress has no label with the materials listed and it feels very rough and synthetic and not pleasant at all. I'm not exactly a pro at telling apart different types of material, but this feels similar to 100% nylon or acrylic.Also, I suspect that the dress in the picture is a completely different product cause even though the product I received is similar in design, it looks nothing like what's in the picture. First, the dress in the picture doesn't look like it has a seam between the torso and the skirt. The skirt part is shorter and not as flowy and the torso part is very strange and doesn't really sit right. The dress in the picture has a pretty deep v shaped neckline that should reveal some cleavage and a long torso that should go down to the hip bone. The dress that I got has a very short torso part which ends at my lower ribs and that's where the skirt starts. The part where my boobs are supposed to be ends up between my boobs and my neck and the waist part of the dress goes over my boobs. The skirt is sectioned and has seams going down which is also not visible on the picture.At first I thought that it might be small on me, but it seems to be just right width wise. The only thing I could come up with is that maybe this dress is made for petite people. I am about 5'5, 185 pounds and a size 14 and I ordered a XXL. The only good thing about this dress is that it's pretty well sewn together and there are no loose threads. To be completely honest, I've seen similar dresses at the local discount store which were better made, out of better materials and for a better price.I received this product as a sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I've tried other similar products in the past and the one major problem I have with all of them is that they are severely uncomfortable and they either fall off or it's impossible to get them off. In most cases you will end up with something poking you or not fitting you right....These wraps are not the most comfortable that I've ever tried, but they're not too bad. I did have to put on high waisted leggings to keep this thing on, but it does stick to your body so if you sleep in it, you won't lose it as you toss and turn. They are pretty soft and stretchy and they do not poke or pinch you anywhere. I applied it to my stomach and was very pleased to see that the patch covered the problem area perfectly and from the first try without having to fiddle around with it. After about 5 minutes I could barely tell that I was wearing it at all.I slept in it for about 8 hours and it stayed on just fine. When it was time, it came off easily and I just rubbed the remaining gel into my skin. I did noticed that my skin felt a little softer and more moisturized and definitely more toned. I will have to use more of these to be able to tell if it has any kind of permanent slimming effect because for now it seems to be temporary. Overall, this seems like a good product and while it doesn't give you very drastic results, it does work. I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I got this product for my mom who uses her laptop a lot throughout the day and takes it to bed with her at night. Overall, this seems like a wonderful quality product and I definitely recommend it to anyone who uses their laptop for extended periods of time. 0:57 MinsI wanted to bring to everyones attention that these are not just for the shower curtain rod. I use them on my patio for my patio curtains. They work for curtain rods too. Typically when you are in Florida and you have a sun-room, lanai, patio or porch. Blinds are used for the huge windows and not curtains. The blinds that came with the house were name brand well made blinds that did not reach the bottom of the window and at night we had no privacy out there with the lights on. So I set out to find blinds that covered the whole window so we had privacy if we wanted it. As I began shopping I saw the prices and the number of windows I needed to cover was going to put me in the custom windows prices. I very quickly decided 2 grand for blinds on my patio was out of the question. So I had to figure something else out. I decided that normal size would work with anything that I am going to do with the windows just as long as I hung them down about a foot from the top of the sills. That way I still have privacy, but not the bid dollar cost of custom window treatments. Which brings me to my next point. I love the sunshine and thats why I have the patio. These tab top curtains not only were murder in trying to open and close them daily, But also took away half the sunshine in the room. I hated that. Knowing that they make my shower curtain almost disappear when I push it to one side of the rod I thought why not use these for my curtains? They solve both problems I had. I am able to push them almost non existent to bring in the sun and they roll on the rod so easy that I can open and close them with ease now. I am so happy with these Outop Heavy Duty Roller Curtain Hooks! I recommend them 100%!

I have a new sink that I need to install and needed under sink mounts to be sure I can support my sink with out damaging my counters. I got these as it says I wont need to cut in to my counter tops causing more work and a possibility cracking or damaging the existing counters. Both something I don't want to happen. These did not come with any instructions how ever I think I figured it out. The round parts have holes in them so you can epoxy them to the underside of the counter top. I can let them set about 12 hours and make sure they are completely set. The bracket simply sits on the wing nut when you install the sink. This way you can give your sink the support it needs, the wing nut allows for a perfect adjustment and a snug fit to your counter top and allows for any adjustments you need in the future. And when you are ready to change the sink out you can just take off the wing nuts letting the brackets loose then pull out the old sink to install the new one. I plan to install my sink soon but if anyone has any input or instruction to how these work I am willing to take suggestions. The mounts are very durable and will support any sink I'll ever need to throw at it. I picked this off of a list of things needing a review at a discounted rate or free and gave my unbiased honest opinion.
