That dimension of war is as important as what happened during the battle itself. Stuart Sanders tells the story in all its details of human interest.

This is the kind of critique that should have been written about President Obama years ago, because most of the other critiques have been juvenile name calling: "Obama's a (Communist, Marxist, Socialist, Illegal Alien with no birth certificate)." These sorts of critiques are counterproductive because they don't convince anybody who's not already convinced, and they often generate a backlash of sympathy.I should say up front that I do not agree with the book's implied thesis that Obama is a megalomaniac who uses Progressive / Liberal ideologies to promote himself. My impression is that he's a humble personality with the same sorts of values of faith, family, and country that most of the rest of us have. (I understand that most readers will have a contrary opinion.) I'm basing this review on the part of the book that interests me, and that is the question of whether or not Obama has wrapped himself in the Progressive ideology or whether he is a non-ideological leader (like perhaps a Bill Clinton) who may have some core beliefs, but in matters of public policy tends to dabble a little here, and a little there, depending on which way the shifting winds of public opinion blow.My first critique of the book doesn't have anything at all to do with its substance, but is about its style of dense sentences and long, multi-page paragraphs. It would have been easier to comprehend if it were written in a lighter style of short sentences and paragraphs. Even an intellectually-deep book like this one can be written in a reader friendly format.In terms of substance, author Charles Kesler's premise is that Obama's primary failing isn't that he's an extremist in the sense of being a Communist or Socialist, but merely that he's a "decent man"  who "believes in justice" and therefore thinks of himself as being a Progressive. Kesler doesn't explain, at least to my satisfaction, what a Progressive really is. He explains PART of the early Progressive agenda as it originated in the late 1800s, the part of the agenda that sought, successfully, to expand the scope of government in extending its regulatory authority over corporations, banks, and railroads engaged in interstate commerce.However, he doesn't describe the heart of Progressive ideology, which is the belief that government has the obligation to restore the balance between Labor and Capital.Progressives believe that Labor (employees) and Capital (employers) should work together in a virtuous circle whereby Labor creates Capital, Capital invests in businesses that employ Labor, the laborers of those businesses save and invest some of their wages, thereby creating more capital for business expansion, businesses use this capital to expand, more people are hired, more capital is created, and so on to infinity. When this virtuous circle occurs the economy becomes ever more prosperous for business owners and their employees. Labor and Capital prosper together.Progressives believe that because there are almost always more laborers available than there are opportunities to employ them that employers (Capital) enjoy an inherent advantage over employees (Labor). Employers hire and fire employees and thereby exercise a considerable power to control their livelihoods. Employees do not hire and fire employers and usually do not have much, if any, leverage to increase their wages and working conditions.Progressives believe that without any superior power to constrain them, employers will use their economic advantage to replace their current workers with lower cost labor, thereby creating a constant downward pressure on wages as employees are made to compete against each other to work for lower and lower wages. What employers don't understand is that after they beat down the wages of their workers they don't have any customers left who have money to buy the products their business produces. In the absence of any higher power Capital beats down Labor, then Capital goes bankrupt because Labor doesn't have money to purchase what it produces.PROGRESSIVES BELIEVE THAT WORKERS MUST HAVE WAGES SUFFICIENT TO PURCHASE THE GOODS AND SERVICES THAT THEIR LABOR PRODUCES.Progressives believe that government must be the higher power that restores the balance between Labor and Capital. They believe that government must:1. Enforce a minimum wage so that wages can not be beaten down indefinitely.2. Increase the demand for labor by mandating a 40-hour week with premium pay for overtime; eliminating child labor; and creating Social Security pensions so that older workers may retire from the work force and open up opportunities for younger ones.3. That in extreme circumstances, such as economic depressions, that government should become an "employer of last resort" to soak up the idle workers that business can't hire. The idea here is to maintain sufficient purchasing power to prevent the entire economy from failing.4. That government should regulate the activities of banks and large corporations to prevent them from colluding to cheat consumers. Banks that accept the public's money are a public trust and must be regulated by government to insure their solvency. Corporations must not be allowed to use their concentrations of capital to unfairly rig markets in their favor by forming anti-competitive trusts or price-fixing cartels, which they did all the time before the Progressives reined them in with the Sherman Antitrust Act and the Interstate Commerce Act.Free market purists don't believe that government should have a role in overseeing the employee/employer or producer/consumer relationship. Thus there IS a great philosophical divide between Obama's beliefs and the laissez-faire orientation of Conservative Republicans.To me, the most insightful part of the book is:====================Obama is neither an old-fashioned Progressive nor a radical postmodernist. Part of what makes him interesting is how he handles the conflicting strains of his own thought. As a decent man, he believes in justice, and identifies with the civil rights movement's insistence that Jim Crow was manifestly wrong and the cause of black equality manifestly right. As a self-described progressive, he believes in change...=====================Kesler is absolutely correct that Obama ISN'T a Progressive, at least not in the sense that Progressives define themselves. If Obama really WERE a Progressive, we'd be hearing about the Progressive ideal of restoring the balance between Labor and Capital. He would be talking about raising the minimum wage, passing laws to improve employment security and pensions, and imposing tariffs on jobs-destroying imports. Genuine Socialists like Cuba's Fidel Castro and Venezuela's Hugo Chavez regard Obama as just another "Classical Neoliberal" bent on promoting capitalism at the expense of labor.My opinion after reading the book is the same as it was before, that Obama is more a dabbler than a committed Progressive ideologue. I believe he made Healthcare Reform a priority NOT because he sees it as part of a unified Progressive Agenda, but because he believes that it has merits on its own in expanding access to affordable healthcare to people of modest means. He has entirely ignored the rest of the Progressive agenda of raising the minimum wage, passing laws to improve employment security, etc. If Obama does transform the country along Progressive lines, it will happen on a piecemeal basis rather than as part of any grand design on his part. But opinions differ on what his real intent may be, so read the book and come to your own conclusions!This book is thought provoking and must be read on a scholarly plane. If you're comfortable with reading in deep thinking mode and don't mind dense prose, then by all means delve into it and decide for yourself whether Kesler's points have merit.

I read this book from two perspectives. First, decades ago, I was given a copy of the Air Force War College's textbook on geography as a basis for global military strategy and therefore became familiar at an early age with some of the concepts this book explores. Secondly, my family is bi-national American/Colombian, with family and businesses in both countries, and therefore is attuned with author Robert Kaplan's future vision of the USA evolving to become the center of an Anglo-Hispanic "supra-state."Although this book is supposedly focused in on the influence of geography in making and breaking nations, it is actually what we used to call "Social Studies" --- a combined analysis of all the factors of geography, demographics, history, economics, and politics that go into constituting a nation state.PART III. AMERICA'S DESTINY is the 25% of the book that most interested me. The other 75% is just OK, because it is an agglomeration of themes that students of world history and current events will probably already be familiar with. I didn't care for the lack of focus among so many topics. The chapter on Mexico starts with a rambling history of the Roman Empire followed up by a digression into our wars in Iran and Afghanistan, the history of China, India, Venice and the 18th Century mutiny of Indian troops against British Colonialists. However, those who aren't already familiar with these topics of World History 101 and are looking for the widest possible introduction to the geography, demographics, history, economics, politics, and current events in all parts of the world may enjoy Kaplan's "stream of consciousness" approach.Kaplan can also be a bit pedantic ("history and geography tell us") and prone to over-comparing motivations of current nation states to what their forebears did thousands of years ago ("Ancient history, too, offers up examples that cast doubt on whether Afghanistan and Iraq, in and of themselves, have doomed us"). He also says that he is "aware that I am on dangerous ground in raising geography on a pedestal" but actually covers so much material of a political, demographic, and economic nature that geography seems to be secondary. He might just as well have titled the book THE REVENGE OF (GEOGRAPHY, ECONOMICS, DEMOGRAPHICS, POLITICS, ETC. ETC.).My interest perked up in PART III  AMERICA'S DESTINY. This is the part that Kaplan put his heart into, as he explains:==============As a visiting professor at the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis some years back, I taught a course about future challenges in national security.==============In fact the book becomes especially interesting because Kaplan expands on the topic of "future challenges in national security" to include the future composition of our country in the combination of ALL factors that make us the nation we are, including geography, demographics, politics, and economics.Kaplan starts out by pointing out how fantastically blessed by geography we Americans are. We have 6% of the world's land area, but perhaps 25% to 30% of its arable farmland. Our entire country, except for the Desert Southwest, is drained by the Mississippi/Ohio/Missouri, and the Great Lakes/St. Lawrence. Our East Coast ports were perfectly positioned at the head of navigable waters to facilitate settlement, commerce, and the extension of political sovereignty for hundreds of miles inland. We ARE the center of the world's trading routes, with our East Coast facing Europe, our West Coast facing Asia, and our Gulf Coast facing Latin America. Kaplan perhaps overplays the idea that the United States is a superpower PRIMARILY because of our geography (the ambitions of our people also had a lot to do with making us what we are) but he makes it clear that no country has been favored by geography as we are.He then makes the point that in regard to the vision of what the United States wants to become as a nation, we are coming back to our starting point. Our country is named "The United States of AMERICA" (not NORTH AMERICA) because it wasn't until around 1900 that the word "America" stopped being used as a synonym for "Western Hemisphere" and the words NORTH AMERICA and SOUTH AMERICA began to be used to distinguish the continents. As late as the 1870s some prominent Americans continued to believe that the United States was destined to become coextensive with the entire hemisphere.Something of the reverse has actually happened. Instead of Anglo Americans going forth to colonize Latin America and incorporating it into the United States, tens of millions of Latin Americans have been attracted by our free political system and vibrant economy to come live among us. Kaplan makes a point that I (an Anglo American) and my Latin American family talk about almost every day, that the elderly Anglo population is passing, and America is being repopulated by a younger, more Latin American generation.Kaplan  thinks, as I do, that we're on our way to becoming an even more powerful Anglo/Hispanic Superpower whose economic perimeter includes not only Canada but also Mexico, the Caribbean, Central America, and much or even all of South America. He thinks our population will be browner, but we'll still be Americans living under the same Constitution, and a rising prosperity in Latin America will boost our own prosperity (I see this happening in the microcosm of my own family).My takeaway from this book is that Mexico and Latin America REALLY are vital to our own well being. Before reading this book I leaned toward the view that America's free trade partnership shouldn't extend beyond Canada. Now I am wondering whether free trade with Mexico and most of the rest of Latin America may not after all be necessary for our security. These free trade agreements have put millions of Americans out of work, but they are accomplishing their purpose of helping to stabilize fragile countries like Colombia and Mexico. Eventually the trade agreements may serve their full purpose by boosting American exports, and therefore restoring employment, to the newly prosperous countries of Latin America.You'll  find this book a worthwhile read if:1. You're looking for an education in Global Social Studies 101 (i.e. a basic literacy in global geography, demographics, politics, military strategic theory past and present, and current events).  None of these subjects is covered deeply, but the reader will become away conversant in just about every factor that influences the world today.2. You're interested in the part of the book I was, which is to glimpse ahead into the USA's future.3. You want to acquire a more open-minded view of the cost/benefit analysis of U.S. free trade with Mexico and Latin America. It led me to wonder if perhaps the USA should include Mexico in its continental integration perimeter to the same degree as Canada (an objective that Mexico's former President asked for).

This is an excellent introduction to the life and times of Confederate General Joseph Johnston, one of the most controversial Confederate military men. It captures the complex personality of the general, being ferociously brave as a person (his uniform accumulated 30 bullet holes in one battle of the Seminole War, he was hit five times in Mexico, and seriously wounded at Seven Days) but very cautious as a military commander.It tells some of the poignant episodes of Johnston's life, such as his fistfight with Jefferson Davis while both were cadets at West Point (apparently this is why Davis detested him during the Civil War) and his death from pneumonia contracted as the pall bearer at William T. Sherman's funeral --- his mortal enemy from the Civil War who became one of his best friends after the war.The book also wraps a lot of early 19th Century American History around Johnston, including his involvement in the Seminole War, the Nullification Crisis, the Mexican War, Bleeding Kansas, John Brown's Raid, and of course the Civil War. It's a great short introduction to the people who interacted with Johnston like Andrew Jackson, Robert E. Lee, U.S. Grant, General Sherman, and Jefferson Davis.Because Johnston arguably saw more of the Civil War than anyone else, being in command at Manassas, Seven Days, Vicksburg, Atlanta, and the final campaign against Sherman in North Carolina, this is also an excellent introduction to the Civil War.The entire book can be read in about 30 minutes to an hour, so it may be too basic for the serious Civil War buff. But it is extremely easy to read and therefore an ideal resource for students who may be doing a term paper on General Johnston or the Civil War as a whole. The maps and photos are superb. The battle field maps are some of the best illustrated I've seen in any book. The pictures, mainly of people who interacted with Johnston, are clear and well-selected.The book doesn't go into any analysis of whether Johnston's ambiguous reputation was justified by his poor performance as a general, or whether he was simply the victim of bad luck (being in the wrong place at the wrong time) and the animosity of Confederate President Jefferson Davis who wouldn't give him a fair hearing. It's nevertheless a well-written basic biography of the life and times of General Joe Johnston. If the reader didn't know much about General Johnston before the book, he/she will definitely come away with familiarity of who he was as a person and how he fought as a military man, especially during some of the Civil War's epic battles.

As a librarian, I read scores of books each year, and I enjoy nothing more than recommending a good read to fellow book lovers.  ME BEFORE YOU was my favorite adult read a couple of years back, and I was thrilled to learn that Jojo Moyes had another Louisa and Will story in her heart.  Indeed, even though Will is gone, AFTER YOU is still, in a unique way, a continuation of their story.  In the Robert Anderson play I Never Sang for My Father, the narrator tells us that "death ends a life, but it does not end a relationship, which struggles on in the survivor's mind toward some resolution which it may never find."  AFTER YOU tells the story of Louisa Clark's painful struggle, loss, and her unresolved feelings for Will Traynor.  Luckily for Louisa, and for us readers, there is a group of people who truly care about Louisa as she navigates the heartbreak of trying to settle back into her "normal" life, 18 months after the death of the man she grew to love.The hole which Will leaves in Louisa's life is vast, empty, and so painful.  There are a number of new characters who slip into the space Will left in Louisa's heart; some are likeable, others take a while to warm up to.  There is one surprise newcomer who throws an interesting curveball into Louisa's emotionally comatose state, and gives her something to wake up for.  There is, thankfully, no easy cookie-cutter magical leading man to jump into the shoes which Louisa so wanted Will to fill, but there is something....something that takes Louisa on a journey which signals at least the potential for happiness, for meaning, for value in her life...and Louisa spends this book trying to find out what that may be.Louisa's journey helps her to find a place in her heart, and in her life, where Will still belongs...in a way she can live with, while still allowing her to look forward to truly living.  I'll not write any specifics here about any of the story or its characters.  I merely hope that I've convinced any readers of this review to read AFTER YOU.  It is a heartrending, personal, unflinchingly honest account of this special character's efforts to put a devastating loss behind her...and come out on the other side of it with her love remaining....love for the one she lost, love for those special people in her life, and love for the life she has the opportunity to reshape and go ahead living.  AFTER YOU is a different kind of magic than ME BEFORE YOU...but it is a beautiful story which reminded me once again of how worthy love is, even if we can't be certain that we won't lose it, because it is never wholly gone.

Note: Series reading order follows at end of review.WILDEST DREAMS is the story of Lin Su Simmons, the nurse-caretaker of Grace's mom, Winnie.  To best appreciate this story, I recommend that the series be read in order, especially in light of the developing plotlines of all the secondary characters.  Lin Su's charming son Charlie features prominently in this story, as he befriends new next-door neighbor Blake Smiley, an Ironman professional competitive athlete.  Blake's immediate attraction to Lin Su is supported by the fact that he is ready to settle down and find "the one," and is even happy to find his "one plus son," but he is impeded by a tremendous amount of baggage carried by Lin Su.  She's got serious insecurities regarding her ability to trust, to love then lose others, and huge roadblocks regarding her son's health and activities, her own history, and the conditions of her employment.  Lin Su rationalizes her fears and insecurities in order to allow her to isolate herself and her son...and she lies, to others and to herself, about her family history and her past with Charlie's father.  Although I sympathized with Lin Su, I did not like her nearly as much as I have appreciated all of Carr's other Thunder Point heroines, and this detracted from the story for me.Conversely, Blake is a terrific hero, and the best parts of the story for me were those dealing with Blake's character development as he works toward reaching his professional goals, closing old chapters of his romantic past, and gently and with great care, developing a relationship with Lin Su.Charlie's struggle to gain some independence was a high point in WILDEST DREAMS, and gave the story its most funny and touching moments.I have read the comments of a number of other reviewers who were discouraged by the length of time it took the H/h to get together and share even a first kiss.  I consider myself a patient reader if the payoff was worth it, so I accepted the author's pacing.  I must say, however, that the ending was a great letdown for me.  I've read all of Miss Carr's series, and she does end some books far more abruptly than others.  I enjoy a complete ending, or an epilogue, but I am more than willing to accept a cliffhanger as well.  This ending, however, was none of those things.  Unfortunately, after a rushed and somewhat difficult to believe final event at the very end of the story, we are given the most abrupt, two-sentence HEA which I can ever remember reading.  I literally checked and rechecked my Kindle, thinking my "next page" touchscreen location was faulty.  When I verified that I was at the final location number point of the book, I was truly shocked.  This is the first Robyn Carr book which I have been tempted to rate at less than a 4; the last scene of the book and the unfinished, awkward feeling to the ending are the cause.  The hero's charm, the interesting and educational value of the author's writing regarding Blake's athletic career, and the humor and pathos of Charlie's scenes allowed me to rate this story at 4 stars.  I'm hoping for a return to form and a stronger story as I await the next Thunder Point novel.Until then, if you have not read Miss Carr's (earlier) Virgin River series, then I recommend that you run, not walk, to get the first novel in the series, also titled Virgin River.  For me, it is Miss Carr's finest novel.  I still long for a visit back to that special place, and hope that one day Miss Carr will spend some with those wonderful characters again.THUNDER POINT SERIES READING ORDER (this series is best read in order):1. The Wanderer - retired Army pilot (Hank) Cooper & pilot Sara Dupre2. The Newcomer -- Deputy Sheriff Mac McCain & waitress Gina James3. The Hero -- coach Spencer Lawson & single mom Devon McAllister4. The Chance -- auto mechanic Eric Gentry & FBI agent Laine Carrington5. The Promise -- Dr. Scott Grant & PA Peyton Lacoumette6. The Homecoming -- Deputy Sheriff Seth Sileski & HS guidance counselor Iris McKinley7. One Wish -- HS teacher Troy Headly & florist Grace Dillon8. A New Hope -– Ginger Dysart (Ray Anne’s ‘niece”) & Matt Lacoumette9. Wildest Dreams -- triathelete Blake Smiley and Lin Su Simmons (Winnie’s caregiver)**I received a complimentary e-copy of A NEW HOPE from MIRA in exchange for my honest review.**

A beautiful, lyrical, romantic rendition of the classic story about the relationship which develops between Fitzwilliam Darcy and Elizabeth Bennett.  This version of the movie beautifully depicts the emotions and intensity of the novel.  Although it is far shorter than the famous BBC production starring Colin Firth, this film, with its gorgeous English countryside settings and lively cast, truly embodies the spirit of the story.  A valuable addition to the library (film and book) of any Pride and Prejudice fan.  The film's audio score is particularly beautiful; I have played it literally hundreds of times, and the music thrills me each time (particularly the hauntingly beautiful albeit short "Lizzie on Top of the World").

Reading STAY was a terrific surprise for me; full of action, suspense, and old-fashioned good-guys-vs.-bad-guys intensity.  I loved the first person perspective of David Sparrow, the stay-at-home dad with a skill set unlike your average next-door neighbor dad.  At times, the line between right and wrong is blurred as David does whatever it takes to assure the safety of his family and take down the heinous threat that will not go away.  We gain occasional perspective from the points of view of David's wife and the big bad mobster who sets all of the drama and homicide in motion...but the bulk of the book is in David's entertaining, thoughtful, skillful  point of view as he cleverly observes and identifies what should not be happening in his suburban family environment, and quickly steps up to the challenge of becoming the vigilante rather than the victim.  The story is enhanced by David's musings on his family, his relationship with his wife, and other glimpses into his heart, making him an especially likeable character who just happens to also rid the world of bad guys...what's not to love?  I stayed up until 5am to finish STAY in one sitting.  A highly entertaining kick-ass read!

SERIES READING ORDER appears at end of review.EARLY SPOILERS IN REVIEW (only in the setup of the story – not the climax or ending).This fourth Travis Family novel almost didn’t happen; the author indicated on her website that she had intended to leave the Travises as a trilogy of stories.  Thanks to Lisa Kleypas’ listening to her fans, she was persuaded to write this book to tell the story of the last single Travis sibling, Joe, who’d been seriously injured in a boating accident with brother Jack when we last left the Travises at the end of Smooth-Talking Stranger.Six years have passed since the last book was written, and as Brown-Eyed Girl begins, years have also passed.  Joe has healed from his accident, the Travis family patriarch Churchill has passed away, and Joe’s brothers and sister have married and begun their families, all of them becoming parents.  We are treated to glimpses of Gage and Liberty, Jack and Ella, and a very touching scene with Hardy, as he anxiously awaits news of Haven and their first baby, when pregnancy and delivery complications threaten the lives of the ones he loves most.Against this backdrop, Joe meets wedding planner Avery Crosslin, who mistakes him for an employee, rather than a relative of the man whose wedding she has been hired to plan.  Sparks fly, and there is major chemistry between Avery, who believes that there is a happily-ever-after for everyone but herself, and Joe, who has been burned by love before and is now sure and steady regarding whom he wants and his ability to commit.  Their courtship is full of twists and turns: undeniable attraction, Avery’s attempts to deny the significance of her feelings for Joe and her fear of rejection, leading to her pretense that she can keep their relationship to a light affair, the involvement of her close friends (her employees) who provide many comical and serious moments, and through it all, Joe’s steady, reassuring presence in her life, as he waits for Avery to realize, as he already knows, that they belong together.I was thrilled to see Joe finally get his own story, and the conclusion of Brown-Eyed Girl is Lisa Kleypas at her best, weaving a touching, satisfying, mature romance between a strong yet vulnerable heroine, and a sexy, charming alpha male hero who knows exactly who he is and what he wants.  Avery’s friends offer terrific potential for yet another sequel….and there is one love-hate relationship among her staff which this reader would love to read more about!  Here’s hoping that Miss Kleypas agrees!If I had one wish granted here, it would be to have the ability to hear Joe’s point-of-view directly.  All of the Travis family novels are written from the perspective of the female protagonists.  While I greatly admire Miss Kleypas’ ability to depict strong, independent, worthy females, I also long to hear the voices of the male protagonists she writes.  The Travis men are among my favorites in all romance genres, and my only ungranted wish in this marvelous series is that we’ve never been able to hear what the men are thinking, only what their women hear or observe.  Since it’s been years since we’ve had a Travis story, and Avery is completely new to the family, I felt a sense of loss in not being able to hear and experience more from inside the Travis inner circle.  It’s a tribute to Miss Kleypas that she’s created characters that her readers have missed so much!SERIES READING ORDER:1. Sugar Daddy – Liberty & Gage2. Blue-Eyed Devil – Haven & Hardy3. Smooth Talking Stranger – Ella & Jack4. Brown-Eyed Girl – Avery & Joe**I was granted a complimentary copy of this title from St. Martin’s Griffin in exchange for my honest review.**  The hardcover copy which I purchased should be arriving today!

This DVD made for an enjoyable night with the family in front of the television.  Although the kids became a bit confused towards the end, the heartwarming conclusion (between father and daughter) pleased everyone.  We found the film entertaining, if a bit convoluted, and we enjoyed the performances very much.

UP is my family's favorite animated film.  It is a heartrending, beautiful story of second chances, the value of family and friendship, and the meaning behind the very best parts of our lives and the people in them.  We laughed, we cried, and in the end, we were reminded to appreciate the value of every day spent with the ones we love.  Whether or not we accomplish our bucket lists, UP reminds us that if our buckets are full of love, nothing else that we have missed really matters.

Stepbrother Mine begins with Dana, a dedicated college student with aspirations for grad school, being basically cut off by her mother and desperate for financial support.  She decides to follow her best friend's advice and put herself up for "contract" on a website for rich men looking to purchase a no-strings-attached sexual experience with a virgin.  Dana expects to get $50,000 out of this enterprise, but she's shocked to learn that her contract has been bought by none other than her stepbrother, a man whom she had an unforgettable teenage crush on and who, ten years her senior, disappeared from her life without a word after having become her best friend, protector, and confidante.  We are introduced to stepbrother Mason in a rather awkward experience with one of his many subs; he has become bored with all of them, he tells us, even though he has a bevy of submissive beauties in his life on a regular basis, all of whom know and seem unconcerned that he sleeps with the others routinely.  Mason, when surprising Dana at an arranged weekend tryst (after buying her contract), immediately falls back into the role of the honorable and heroic older stepbrother.  He is unable to resist Dana's efforts to cajole him into a sexual relationship, but he tells her that he wants to take things slowly.I liked these characters quite a lot, and look forward to seeing how Dana and Mason's relationship progresses.  I was not impressed with Mason's behavior during his first appearance, and found his descriptions of his social and sex life to be unappealing.  The alternating points of view are a big plus, allowing us to hear both Dana and Mason's perspectives.  Part one is a solid start to an interesting three-part serial novel, and I'm convinced by Ms. Carew of the chemistry that her characters have together, and the emotions that run deep between them.  The 66-page length had me anxious to read part two to see if Mason and Dana can find enough common ground to build a relationship (hopefully without the sub club!).**I was granted a complimentary copy of STEPBROTHER MINE by St. Martin's Griffin in exchange for my honest review.**

Please note:  SPOILER FOLLOWS.An Accidental Mother broke my heart.  Without any self-pity or over-dramatizing, the author tells her true story of parenting a child who grew to love her as his mother...and then losing him along with the man she loved when he moved on in his life without her.  Kindred's pain is very clear, and the only loss she focuses her energy on reversing is her relationship with her son; she wastes no time on the man who left her.  We are left with what most people who are abandoned by the one they love are left with...merely the hope that her future will reunite her with her child.  As I write this review, I still have a lump in my throat.  I found myself profoundly moved by this little book, and profoundly hoping that Kindred will be able to find Michael when he is older, and give him the journal she is writing for him along with all of the treasures she is accumulating for him while she waits for him to grow up enough so that she is permitted by law to reach out to him directly.

With nearly 7,000 reviews on Amazon for WONDER, there is no need for me to recount the story here.  Suffice it to say that this book is indeed a wonder, and it will tug at the hearts, touch the souls, and mark the minds of all who read it.  This is a book parents should urge their children to read, either after or while they read it with their children.

This is our family's seventh pair of Speedo goggles.  We have multiple swimmers in the family, and we've used a number of brands of goggles.  We've found that Speedos are reliably well-fitting, high quality, and long lasting.  This model, the air seal tri swim, is as reliable as the other Speedo models we have purchased.  Lens color is comfortable for underwater visibility, and the head strap adjusts easily and fits comfortably.  In all, a very good product.

I purchased the Audible audiobook version of this title and listened to it in order (a must-do for this series); SEE READING ORDER at end of review.I must say that author Pamela Palmer has truly hit her stride in this third book in her Feral Warriors series.  I enjoyed the first two entries and reviewed them considering my opinions of both positive and negative aspects of the stories and the writing, but in PASSION UNTAMED I was pretty much blown away by the strength of character, story, and expression.  This story was so exciting, so rewarding at certain times and utterly heartbreaking at others, that I found myself completely swept away.  Palmer's character development skills here far outweigh what she displayed in her first two titles in the series; Paenther (a black panther Feral Warrior shifter) and Skye (a Mage witch who is also an Enchantress, able to "call" any animal with a special empathic connection) are her most rounded and sympathetic characters to date, and both of their backstories leave the reader heartbroken and utterly invested in these characters.  I was desperate for Paenther and Skye to find their HEA, but Palmer took her time getting them to first acknowledge the goodness in each other and then start to understand each other, and that was anticipation at its best!  The alternating points of view from each of their perspectives gave us a fabulous glimpse into the mind of Paenther, who had been tortured and permanently scarred by a Mage witch in his past, and who truly hated Skye for encapturing him.  Watching Paenther's feelings change from hate to grudging respect, admiration, and finally love, was a beautiful thing!  Concurrently, Palmer develops the story of the lost daemon blade, the efforts of the dark magic practitioners to raise their evil deity, and the whereabouts of Viper.  Viper's story is heartbreaking, and Palmer handles it in a sophisticated, thoughtful way, while leaving Viper's future still to be written, and the reader wanting more, more, more!The audiobook was once again narrated by the fabulous Rob Shapiro.  His ability to change his voice to differentiate characters is superseded only by his uncanny ability to breathe precisely the perfect amount of emotion into every character...never over the top, but always reaching an emotional apex.  Unlike my reading of almost all other books, I actually prefer the audiobooks to the print titles in this series, all thanks to the excellence of this narrator.All of the elements of this story seem to be racheted up a couple of notches from the prior books in the series, and the writing is so much more rewarding.  I cannot wait to begin the fourth book; Paenther's story has made me decide to download the next audiobook immediately, and I can only hope that Jag's story will be as thrilling, passionate, and touching as Paenther's.  Long live the Feral Warrrios!SERIES READING ORDER:1. Desire Untamed - Lion + Kara2. Obsession Untamed - Tighe + Delaney3. Passion Untamed - Paenther + Skye3.5 Hearts Untamed (a novella originally printed in the Bitten by Cupid anthology) - Zee + Julianne - this novella is unrelated to the Feral Warriors plotline but introduces characters who reappear4. Rapture Untamed - Jag + Olivia5. Hunger Untamed - Kougar + Ariana6. Ecstasy Untamed - Hawke + Faith7. A Love Untamed - Fox + Melisande8. Wulfe Untamed - Wulfe + Natalie

Happily, I was able to purchase this Best Manufacturers whisk (also called a whip) in an Amazon holiday lightning deal, so I was able to save about fifty percent of the current price.  Without a doubt, this whisk is an excellent product.  It is well-constructed and sturdy, yet flexible enough not to get bent during robust use.  Its chief additional benefit, for my purposes, is its shape.  The length and flat presentation of the wires is perfect for reaching the bottoms of my pans, and the position of the wires allows for perfect blending when I whisk gravies and sauces.  I purchased the full stainless-steel version, and all of the cooks in my household love it.  I recommend close inspection of the various models within the product information; click on each picture and you will see the various construction materials (wood, metal) and colors.  Each model is a different price; the prices are accessed by clicking on each picture of the different whisk models.  Happy cooking!

Although music is a staple in my daily life, this is the first CD which I've posted a review for; I was compelled by all of the press, both positive and negative, about Taylor.  I have to say that I am completely impressed by her ability to deal so positively and productively with all of the negativity that comes her way.  Taylor also makes an impact in the way she is grateful and humble in her public appreciation of the many blessings which her success and fame have given to her.  The "Shake It Off" track has become a shield of mental armor for my children, and is something even my colleagues refer to when looking for inspiration to repel the negativity of others.  Taylor became a superstar long before this album; no matter what she writes and sings, it's all her....country, pop, whatever...and she is, in my opinion, a worthy role model for my children and all young people today.  I don't learn many lessons from celebrities; in fact, I feel that there are many lessons about what not to do in the publicized behaviors of many celebs, but Taylor is a complete exception in that regard.  I hope she keeps shaking it off for a long, long time.

I was a bit surprised to see the range of reviews for this product; while it's clear some buyers have received faulty sets, luckily, we received a very good quality product.  No leakage; no appearance of drying out, although it's only been a couple of weeks of use.  We've got more than one amateur artist and one serious adult artist in the family, and this set has pleased all.  The variety of tip widths is excellent for their drawing applications.  I was on the fence about ordering due to price, so it was a nice surprise to find the Sakura set offered as part of the holiday lightning deal specials.  We ordered two of this set and were quite pleased with both.  Hopefully there is now consistent attention being paid to quality control and shelf life of this product.

This acquisition represents our second family member who has purchased this phone case.  We're extremely satisfied with the silicon materials in combination with the hard case protection.  The colors and design are a plus.  The case fits very well, and the price was better than we were able to find in retail stores and in the discount kiosks at the mall. The first case we'd purchased, identical to this one except in color, has held up quite well, and we anticipate exactly the same from this one.  A satisfying purchase on all levels!

SEE NOTE AT END OF REVIEW REGARDING BUNDLE PACKAGING!HUNGER'S MATE PART ONE begins a four-part serial which continues the saga of the Shadow Shifters, which began in the Damaged Hearts serial and continued in the Shifter's Claim serial.  A. C. Arthur begins this new story with a glossary which is helpful especially to those who may not have read the two previous serials.  The setting is our current-day world with the addition of the supernatural shape-shifters, species of man-cats who exist unbeknownst to nearly all humans and who have a fully-developed hierarchy of their own government/protective elite.  Each shifter protagonist in these erotic romance stories finds his mate, whether she be shifter or human, against a plot wrought with danger, intrigue, and passion.In part one, shifter Lead Guard Ezra Preston has come to Perryville due to the possibility that the government may have learned of the existence of the shifter race.  He will perform a dangerous assignment at Comastaz Labs in order to ferret out a suspected government-backed plot to exploit shifter DNA.  Ezra is confident and as cool as a cucumber in anxiety-provoking moments at the labs; he is completely unprepared, however, for Jewel Jenner, an administrator at the resort he's residing in who stirs feelings within him that throw him completely off balance and bring to the surface painful memories from his past.  Ezra's past is just a dark memory, whereas Jewel's may cost her her life and more likely, her freedom.Arthur weaves an interesting tale; she's skilled at backstory, helping the reader to understand and sympathize with her main characters.  Another plus is the alternating points of view; we get to hear the story from both Jewel and Ezra's perspectives.  It is also gratifying to be reunited with characters from Arthur's other serials.  The story does suffer a bit due to its descriptive style.  In scenes centering on the emotional struggles within her characters, flashbacks, and interpersonal conflicts, the writing is at its strongest, particularly in the verbal battles waged between Ezra and Jewel; though they are brief chats, they are witty and charming.  The mechanics of the physical scenes, however, are less elegant; the descriptions of the physicality between Ezra and Jewel is not romantic or sensual, nor do their sexual encounters deliver the expected impact (perhaps due to many clichéd word choices during these moments), unlike the easy flow of other scenes.  The conflict at the police station seems staged, awkward, and a bit confusing.  In all, there is some choppiness in the descriptive narrative which led me to read through more quickly than I usually like to, slowing to absorb the more compelling scenes such as the flashbacks and emotional revelations.  Arthur does pack a lot of action, physical and emotional, into these brief 95 pages, but that also may contribute to the choppy quality due to the minimal page count.  It is challenging to set up the frame of the entire serial and still tell a story in a short first episode; considering this and the fact that Ezra and Jewel are promising characters whom I am interested in following, I am rating part one of this serial at four stars.  Due to the world-building and shifter vocabulary, and the return of Bas and Priya, readers would benefit from first reading the Shifter's Claim serial, though it is not a must-do.NOTE: THERE IS NO "PART 5" AS LISTED ON AMAZON; IT'S A BUNDLE OF THE ENTIRE SERIAL:The covers of the four-part e-serial each state that Hunger's Mate is "a novel in four parts."  Amazon's listing for Hunger's Mate Part 5 is actually the bundle pack of the original four-part serial in one title, either e-book or 352-page print paperback release. At this time, It does not state in the product information that there is any new material added to the bundle package title.  It is confusing to see this title listed as "Part 5."  The author's website clearly indicates that this Hunger's Mate title is simply the bundle of all previous four parts (not a new fifth part); the full print and e-book release will be available on the same date which the last (fourth) part of the e-serial is available---February 3, 2015.

One summer day, young Hippo's dad brings her to the library, and she is swept away into the wonderful world of books and the  imagination.  Hippo is amazed as she remarks, "Words are waiting to be read--new ideas to fill my head," and she embarks on an adventure of the mind, imagining herself to be a character in many of the books she sees.  Fliess' whimsical words and Laughead's bright illustrations put a smile on my face as I watched Hippo feel the book love!  Mock-ups of covers of a number of familiar, beloved children's picture books appear throughout the story, although the titles of the books are changed (not sure how I feel about that, but it's another example of the whimsy of this story and does hold a certain childlike charm).BOOKS FOR ME! is a lovely story reminding us of how magical and meaningful it is to help a child find the love of books and begin what is, hopefully, a lifelong relationship with their public library.

I freely admit to the bias of loving every Megan Hart title I've read. A couple of them have broken my heart, and more than a couple have stayed with me in a vaguely uncomfortable way which I've come to expect from the best of Megan's books...she brings feelings and vulnerabilities to the surface of her characters which are so resonant they leave the reader exposed, moved, and feeling that something real, poignant, and almost tangible has happened in the pages of her books.Considering the above, it was no surprise to me that DON'T DENY ME, PART ONE was one of the most satisfying serial book entries I've read. The e-serial is a very popular book vehicle nowadays, but I've not started any series with a more satisfying and impactful first episode. True to her style, Hart's characters nearly jump off the page, immediately making the reader feel that they are flawed, searching, and very real. The protagonists in this story, Mick and Alice, were lovers within a tight group of old friends, each of whom clearly have an interesting story to tell. While giving us interesting and provocative snippets of the lives of this band of friends as they eat, drink and be merry (think "The Big Chill" a la Megan Hart), Hart focuses on the passionate but seemingly volatile relationship shared ten years ago by Mick and Alice, who are reunited at a special anniversary celebration of the group. The chemistry between them is as electric as it was during their affair, and the reader gets to wonder along with Mick and Alice if there is any way, after a painful parting, they can find their way back to each other.Hart's depth of characterization, her skill at developing her entire cast of characters, and her uncanny ability to hone right in on the deepest regions of the heart, especially the less "tidy" aspects of love and desire, set her apart from other erotic fiction authors. She writes with an edge that reminds us that in real life, there really aren't usually silver linings, and that happily ever after does not come without some cost. I get the sense of all of these elements in this first part of Mick and Alice's story, and the potential for the same in the stories of a few of the secondary characters in Don't Deny Me...and I can't wait to read more!All of this potential, set up masterfully in only 96 pages? Also, one plus which is not in many of Hart's earlier stories: dual perspectives written from both Mick and Alice's points of view; love it! I have never been quite so enthused about rushing to the next part of an e-serial book, but if you'll excuse me now, that's precisely what I am going to do next.*I was given a complimentary copy of this title from the publisher in exchange for my honest review.*

Carl Sagan was a professor at my alma mater, and was always rather larger than life, just like the stars themselves seem to be.  This book is an absolutely beautiful blend of science, imagination, and inspiration.  Sagan changed the face of the universe for all of us; he got on television, talked about the COSMOS, and made the universe accessible to everyone.  His perspective on science and the universe is one still referred to today in many classrooms.STAR STUFF has beautiful illustrations, a big fold-out, and a number of vertical pages which enhance the illustrative value of the book.  There is extensive back matter for more serious students of the cosmos, and many anecdotes about Carl that make him seem just like any other little child who looks up at the sky and wonders...what if?Sagan's vision led to the inclusion of our world's "friendly greeting" message in every Voyager space mission; he encouraged us to think about the universe beyond our "neighborhood of planets."  In a world full of so much tragic breakdown of communication and connection, Sagan's message reminds us that we are all a part of this wonderful universe.

This series should be read in order; see READING ORDER AT END OF REVIEW.OBSESSION UNTAMED is the follow-up to DESIRE UNTAMED in the Feral Warriors series.  In this second entry in the series, we share the story of Tighe, the Feral Tiger, and Delaney Randall, a no-nonsense female warrior in her own right--she's a hardened FBI agent whose tragic past (her mom was raped and murdered when she was young, then her father abandoned her) has made her passionate about stopping criminals and fighting injustice.Author Pamela Palmer follows much of the same formula here as she did in book one; a strong female protagonist shocked to learn of the existence of a race of much stronger immortals who have forced her into their world.  It is again a pleasure to have the points of view of both the hero and the heroine presented.  The story alternates and moves forward between protagonists' voices, and that rounds out the perspective and character development in a very satisfying way.  There are also points of view of other characters in scenes throughout the story, which furthers the subplot and sets the reader up for the next book in the series.  Tighe is a very sympathetic character, and we learn so much about his broken past (no spoilers here!) that I felt even more interested in him than in Lion (book one) due to the strength and sadness of his backstory.  The author is honing her character development skills, it seems, because Delaney was also developed more than Lion's mate was, and we are able to truly feel for her as she struggles between her feelings for Tighe and her awareness that he and his brother Ferals kill for a living, and operate on the other side of the law.I listened to the Audible audiobook and was once again extremely impressed by the talent of the narrator; I'm very glad to see that he is narrating all of the books in this series.  The narrator's ability to render emotion in his voice and to differentiate between characters with a multitude of voice variations is a real plus.On the "down" side, I will mention only a few points.  There are omissions of events or information which seem obvious solutions to some of the crises befalling our characters (Why on earth did Kara remain inside the house when walking to the goddess stone to share her radiance would have radically improved the battle and danger our heroes were in?  And what was up with Paenther?  These are the immortals who constantly discuss mage magic, spells, and enchantments...and he skipped happily right into the most obvious setup in the story.  I'd have liked a more legitimate trap here; at times it felt that the story was leading the characters along, rather than the characters creating the story).  Also, there is excessive repetition, as in book one, of the same sentiments as our characters vacillate in their feelings toward each other.  Literally dozens of times both Tighe and Delaney ask themselves exactly the same questions as they think to themselves, musing about whether to love each other or not, whether he should allow her to live or kill her, whether they can resist the intense sexual attraction they feel to each other, etc.  A good deal of dramatic tension is lost when a character debates with himself a dozen times over the issue of whether or not to kill his lover!Happily, however, these flaws are diminished by the passion and intensity of the story and of the strength of the characters.  I was invested in Tighe and Delaney, and couldn't wait for them to find their HEA.  Palmer leaves us with her trademark cliffhanger "hook" into the next story, but she resolves Tighe and Delaney's relationship in a very satisfying, feel-good way.  I'll be listening to the next in the series, PASSION UNTAMED, in the very near future.SERIES READING ORDER:1. Desire Untamed - Lion + Kara2. Obsession Untamed - Tighe + Delaney3. Passion Untamed - Paenther + Skye3.5 Hearts Untamed (a novella originally printed in the Bitten by Cupid anthology) - Zee + Julianne - this novella is unrelated to the Feral Warriors plotline but introduces characters who reappear4. Rapture Untamed - Jag + Olivia5. Hunger Untamed - Kougar + Ariana6. Ecstasy Untamed - Hawke + Faith7. A Love Untamed - Fox + Melisande8. Wulfe Untamed - Wulfe + Natalie

The Feral Warrior series should be read in order; please see READING ORDER AT END OF REVIEW.DESIRE UNTAMED was quite a nice surprise!  I listened to the Audible audiobook, and was very impressed with both the articulation and the voicing of the narrator.  In a series about the supernatural shape-shifting "Feral Warriors" and the women they mate while attempting to save their race (and the world) from a number of evil supernatural forces, it was a true pleasure to hear a male narrator.  The majority of the dialogue was spoken by males, and hearing a deep, almost hypnotic male voice was an unexpected thrill!  The narrator altered his voice quite successfully to differentiate his characters, even making a noble effort to voice the female protagonist; Kara sounded certainly gentler than the male voices, though no one could actually call this testosterone-laden narrator feminine-sounding...but it worked just fine for me!  He had a mesmerizing voice, and it added substantially to my enjoyment of the story.The story itself was a solid alpha male-meets-mate and saves the world fare, with a few interesting conundrums added to hold interest.  The villains were, quite honestly, easy to spot; that, in addition to excessive repetition in parts of the story (Should I stay with the ferals?  Should I go?  Do I love her?  Should I hate her?) were the only flaws in the story worth mentioning.  Those flaws were eradicated by the strength of the author's character development...these characters are hard not to love!Although the villains, as I said, were not hard to predict, the ending was highly entertaining nonetheless, and had some surprising elements in it--enough to make me decide to listen to the sequel immediately.  DESIRE UNTAMED is an interesting, provocative new paranormal erotic romance series which will appeal to readers of those genres on multiple levels.SERIES READING ORDER:1. Desire Untamed - Lion + Kara2. Obsession Untamed - Tighe + Delaney3. Passion Untamed - Paenther + Skye3.5 Hearts Untamed (a novella originally printed in the Bitten by Cupid anthology) - Zee + Julianne - this novella is unrelated to the Feral Warriors plotline but introduces characters who reappear4. Rapture Untamed - Jag + Olivia5. Hunger Untamed - Kougar + Ariana6. Ecstasy Untamed - Hawke + Faith7. A Love Untamed - Fox + Melisande8. Wulfe Untamed - Wulfe + Natalie

Quiet Dell is a fictional novel which relates a true crime--the grisly "Ladykiller" murders in the late 1930s by Harm Drench, the son of a Dutch immigrant family who lured lonely, middle-aged women by answering their lonely hearts newspaper ads, convincing them to turn their fortunes over to him, then murdering them.  One case led to the conviction of Drench, who under the alias (one of many) Corenlius O'Pearson, killed widow Asta Eicher of Park Ridge, Illinois, and her three young children.  The murder occurred in cold blood in an underground basement he'd built below a garage specifically, it appeared, for the purpose of bringing his victims.  The bodies of the Eicher family were found in  a nearby ditch on the murderer's property, along with the body of another lonely heart victim.This sensational story had been recounted to author Phillips by her mother, who had been raised in the Park Ridge area.  When she was six years old, she'd walked with her mother past the infamous sight after Drench's conviction, as the "murder garage" was literally being picked to pieces by people by people who'd visited looking to grab up souvenirs from the crime scene.  The story remained with Phillips all her life; she made mention of it in her first novel then later decided to devote a book to what she imagined might have been the events leading to the Eicher murders.Weaving actual court transcripts, newspaper accounts, and numerous real characters with a number of fictional characters, events, and dialogue, Phillips tells us the story of Asta Eicher's life, her choice to rebuff a  close family friend and suitor in favor of O'Pierson, and the events leading to, including, and following the murders, right through the trial and execution.There is no doubt that Phillips can write well, evoke poignant and effective images, and develop her characters.  For me, however, the story was absolutely overdone.  The fictional protagonist of the book, a reporter named Emily, takes turn with the specterized real-life heroine chosen by the author:  Annabelle, the youngest Eicher daughter.  Annabelle is nine years old through most of the telling, but she has the voice of a decades-older wordsmith--a writer--and never sounds like a child at all.  When she appears as a ghost, her musings are soap operaesque.  Herein lies a major flaw of the book--the absence of credible moderation.  It is at times soap opera, mystery, true crime, ghost story, romance novel, erotic fiction (which fails miserably), historical fiction...it does not know its limits.  Mash-up genre books can be very entertaining and effective, but if they are not ever reigned in and too many excesses are imagined and indulged in, the read seems to have a very sloppy, self-indulgent feel...and that is the case with quiet Dell.  Each fictional story element was pushed beyond credible levels and became impossible to believe, and with a true story as shocking and sensationalized as this one was, the added fictional excess was a fatal flaw.I was encouraged as a result of reading this book to look into the actual historical information surrounding this crime, and that was quite interesting (as well as disturbing, of course).  That research was the most rewarding experience I can associate with reading Quiet Dell.  I wish I'd read a different Phillips title first, because I'm not likely to seek out another of her books at this time; perhaps after my TBR stack shrinks.

I've written a good number of reviews for Amazon as well as for publishers and authors directly, and I can honestly say that no other romance series has impressed or affected me as deeply as Sylvia Day's CROSSFIRE SERIES.  With thousands of reviews already written for the four books and sets currently available in the series, I will address a few points here which are outside the usual synopsis/review format.Firstly, the characters in this series--all of them--are, in my opinion, among the most rounded, dimensional, reliable characters in romance.  Miss Day's character development skills are simply among the best in the business.  Secondary characters are as complex and dynamic as the main characters in many other series, and Gideon and Eva are so real that I actually imagine them moving, breathing, and looking at each other with the intensity of all they feel for each other as their images pop so easily into my mind, thanks to the strength of the characterization and writing.It is tremendously rewarding for me to spend time with the Crossfire characters.  After reading each book, I've also listened to all of the audiobooks, and the narrator is superb.  She differentiates the characters expertly with her voicing, and even manages to express Gideon's passion and intensity.  The fourth book in the series, CAPTIVATED BY YOU, provides Gideon's point of view for the first time in the series.  This was an ENORMOUS pleasure for me and will be appreciated by any true Gideon Cross fan.  Although Gideon's narrator does not have the deepest, most masculine tone of voice, he has the intensity which embodies Gideon, and he conveys all of the singular focus which Gideon has for Eva, making the reader believe that Eva truly is the reason that Gideon draws breath, and able to understand how he could take some of the actions he has on behalf of Eva in his desire to protect and care for her (no spoilers here!).I must admit to being somewhat surprised and disappointed by a number of reviews which criticize and even insult the story, characters, and writing of the later volumes in this series.  It is my hope that new readers will be open-minded about the direction in which Gideon and Eva have gone.  Yes, the situations which befall them are sometimes extreme; this is a story about two passionate people who collide into each other with all the force and pathos of their personalities, and their relationship itself is highly sexual, emotional, and extreme.  Gideon's never been able to tell the reader how he feels prior to book four...so when you hear his anguish, his fears, his vulnerability for the first time, is it fair to call him weak or pathetic?  I say no; Gideon is written as a fully dimensional character, and the responsible reader will accept the notion that any man who could admit to having the profound need and emotion which Gideon has for Eva will also be intensely vulnerable to the thought of losing her.  Getting inside Gideon's head was one of the most vicarious literary thrills I've ever had!  Please, please, Miss Day, give us more of Gideon's POV in the next book!Finally, I am utterly confounded by those who complain that the author "said this would be a trilogy," and have problems with additional books.  I say PLEASE keep giving us Crossfire stories!  Do we not want to spend as much time as possible with the significant people in our lives, those we've come to love?  Why not hope for the same time with our most compelling literary characters?  I IMPLORE Miss Day to keep writing this series.  Gideon and Eva are such "big" characters, living big lives; I believe that they have a lot more to share with us.  The cast of secondary characters is so strong that many of their stories also warrant telling.  I doubt that there could EVER be enough of Gideon and Eva to satisfy me.  When it comes to the passion, the pain, the romance, the struggle, and the mad love between Gideon and Eva, we can never get too much of a good thing.  I run a large virtual reading group of women who love erotic fiction, and the group grows monthly.  The Crossfire series is our number one rave read; in fact, it's been Gideon and Eva who've gained our group quite a few of its members!).  You keep writing them (pretty please?), Miss Day, and we'll keep reading them.  Promise!

The premise of this series was interesting; shape-shifting human-animal paranormals finding their mates and being hunted by antagonist human extremists who want to eradicate them--a successful formula employed by more than a few PRNL romance authors.  However, the characters in OMEGA MINE continually lose their focus and trains of thought and action.  Often they veer into filibustering monologues!  The level of description in these lengthy speeches by each voiced character, and within all of the general narrative, make this story heavy, convoluted, and burdened.  Often the reader has to hang onto the plot line and wait for paragraphs of unnecessary description and musing while the thoughts of the character are repeated in a variety of ways.  An example:  paragraphs about vomiting, with three or four synonyms of the verb repeated, the detailed contents of the vomit and what had been eaten by the vomiter earlier in the day, the shape of the mouth, where he held his hands while vomiting, and on... We are waiting to learn what is happening in a significant event, but we are interrupted by paragraphs describing nausea and vomiting.  At another point, (secondary character) Emory is right in the midst of considering violent action to learn Mary's whereabouts from a women he wants tortured , and he stops to expound for (audio) pages about the notion of how Mary would feel if she knew...the feeling should have been a sentence (two max), not dozens of them.  The story was burdened to the point that it became frustrating, and these poorly positioned "asides" continually reduced the dramatic tension of the narrative.  Perhaps in print (text), where the reader can skim less interesting or repetitive narrative, these issues would not have seemed so pronounced, but the story suffered nonetheless.Another issue is the contradictory behavior of characters; consider the protagonists.  If you've presented your protagonists as ethical, loving, and victimized, you can accept and even expect them to be warriors defending their freedoms, but it is not prudent at the end of the novel to introduce (their) behaviors such as:  torturing their enemies, then healing them intentionally in order to re-torture, or playing versions of "The Deadliest Game," in which our heroes express bloodlust over their plan to set their captives free, then terrify and hunt them, murder them in animalistic fashion, and feast on their blood.  I thought these were the good guys!Thus, an otherwise interesting story became a frustrating read/listen.  A good edit would serve this story well, and allow the plot and characters to have the opportunity to shine.  The main characters are interesting, sympathetic, and developed fairly well.  The romance is heavily sex-based, but the explanation of mate pairing just barely legitimizes the mindless sexuality between Diskant and Ava.  Finally, the narrator of the Audible version, which I purchased, had clear articulation and voicing, but she stressed multiple syllables and words in each sentence.  Although her intent was probably to add intensity, the overuse of stressed syllables (almost to the point of iambic pentameter in more than a few places) was an additional distraction and didn't allow for the emotional ebb and flow which makes more intense moments effective and dramatic.  A good story, but its execution did not live up to the story's potential.

CONSUMED is the story of Olivia James, a "good girl" who catches the eye and then the heart of Seth Marc, a disillusioned young amateur MMA fighter who is making a run for the professional circuit while navigating a seriously dysfunctional family/personal life of his own.  Seth has never desired a real love relationship; he has used and been used by women, and has been hardened by (and nearly becomes the enabler of) his alcoholic mother.  Olivia changes Seth's life in many ways, and he becomes a better man by being with her.  Along the way, many conflicts and crises arise, including family emergencies, illness, jealous and competitive characters who want to come between Seth and Olivia, and many of the basic challenges which occur in a new, tenuous love relationship.The story itself has many similarities in plot, theme, and character to quite a few other series on the market (one has only to search MMA Romance to find a list of many titles which bear similar plotlines and characters), but because MMA and other fighting bad boys are such a hot topic in romance literature right now, it doesn't really hurt that the story doesn't offer anything essentially new.  It's still a good story about themes many romance readers enjoy, and Olivia and Seth are likeable characters whom we'd like to see find a happy ending.Where the story does disappoint, however, is in its actual execution.  The mechanics of the storytelling are often cumbersome and clinical, with Olivia narrating long streams of consciousness-style thoughts, and lots of "telling" instead of "showing."  I absolutely love description and detail when it adds to the richness of story, or to character development, or to imagery which enhances the atmosphere (mood) and the reading experience.  Olivia's long speeches, however, reflect every thought she has in clinical detail, whether it's about the way her washrag is washing each armpit (repeated use of that word in the description of many showers they took, together and alone), or the way Seth's "tongue shoots out of his mouth," or how he runs his hand around which knee, which leg, with which portion of his palm or exactly which fingers touch where...so much mechanical detail in such repetition it cripples the story, causing the mood to diminish until there is the feel of reading a manual rather than a novel.  Also, there is an unsophisticated use of the characters to forward the plot.  Multiple conflicts ensue because Olivia appears completely unable to extricate herself from the touches, grabs, pinches, pats, and hip-holds of multiple men.  Rather than simply verbalizing her outrage at being manhandled, she simply stares wide-eyed and closed-mouthed at Seth, allowing him to have overused, profound physical reactions in order to develop tension and conflict.  Similarly unsophisticated devices are used in the behaviors of other characters such as Olivia's best friend and mother, bringing these characters very close to caricature (e.g., the careless, exaggerated, repetitive descriptions of Selena and Jackson's kissing procedures; just because we're aiming for a new adult audience does not mean this trope should be used until the reader is sick of it, because quite frankly, many of us are).  Other characters behave more dimensionally, however, such as Olivia's boss Mason, proving that this author has the potential to develop her characters.  The very brief epilogue, in Seth's point of view, was a nice touch; the novel would have benefitted from much more of his alternate POV.I listened to the Audible audiobook, which was adequately performed by the narrator.  Olivia's voice sounded age-appropriate, which is always a positive as it enables the story to be more believable.  Her male voices were also well done.  The narrator's skill was not, however, capable of overcoming the encumbrances which I described above.In all, the read was an enjoyable enough one for me, although a few times I rolled my literary eyes at the areas which needed polishing for this story to get closer to reaching its potential.  Had the story been tighter and more polished (better editing would go a long way), and had the characters been more dimensional and compelling, I'd have hurried to purchase parts two and three in the series.  For now, I'll be going on to the next read that's burning a hole in my bookshelf and, perhaps in future, I'll peek in on Olivia and Seth again to see how they fare in book two.

This lovely outfit was a gift for my daughter, who immediately put it on one of her American Girl dolls. It fit well and looked lovely. I'd purchased the outfit as part of Amazon's holiday lightning deals, and even so the price was not negligible. I was a bit surprised to see that the full price is about the same as an actual American girl outfit. If the other outfits we viewed were less expensive, I'd certainly purchase more of them, but at current pricing, this one will be the only one we purchase for the foreseeable future. If we're spending over $20 for an outfit for our American Girl dolls, we are more inclined to buy directly from American Girl.

The signature collection is a "step up" from the regular-sized Webkinz product. This adorable ocelot is cuddly, fuzzy, and larger than the standard Webkinz animals. My children feel that any Webkinz is a wonderful addition to their collections, and the online activities they can explore with this ocelot is no exception. The signature ocelot is all of the good things we expect from Webkinz--quality, cuteness, and comfort.

I've been a chamomile tea drinker for many years, and have sampled varieties of chamomile from a number of countries. Stash chamomile tea is one of the best chamomile brands I have tried.  It is smooth, pungent, and rich in flavor. I've gifted Stash to a number of others, and I've happily received it from others as well.  A delicious cup of tea!

These earrings are lovely.  They are delicate and dangle very attractively. The size of the earrings is adequate enough to stand out but is not overly large; quite nice. The anchors and their ropes carvings are well-detailed and of good artistic quality. Each earring is stamped 925 to indicate sterling silver. A pleasing purchase!

I'm using these bulbs throughout our house and could not be more pleased.First and foremost, the quality of light they generate is indistinguishable from traditional incandescent bulbs - trust me, my wife *hates* any kind of blue-tinged LED or industrial fluorescent light, and she loves the light from these bulbs.Secondly, I also use these bulbs in our outdoor (enclosed) fixtures, and they work perfectly, even with conventional dimmers - no buzzing, flickering, or other weirdness.While I remain skeptical about the claimed lifespans for LED bulbs, and feel they are overpriced as a product overall, these bulbs are reasonably priced for LED bulbs. Longevity remains to be seen, but so far we are impressed with these bulbs.

We used this tree stand this past Christmas, and it worked perfectly. Placement of the tree is simple, the foot-pedal locking mechanism worked as designed, and it even has a water level indicator to let you know when you need to refill the reservoir.One point to note is that the foot pedal has a release button, which will remove the tension on the levers holding the trunk in place, and it's pretty easy to push. If you have curious or mischievous children (or pets) they could easily release the tree and cause it to fall. The good news is that the manufacturer included a small hole in the mechanism, and if you put something through that hole it will prevent the release of the foot pedal.We bought a small padlock for this purpose. It seems silly to lock up one's Christmas tree stand, but we wanted to be better safe than sorry. I'd prefer if the manufacturer put some sort of child-proof and pet-resistant solution in place for this, but it's a quibble about what is otherwise a great solution.Bottom line is that we highly recommend this tree stand, and also highly recommend that you put something in the safety hole to prevent accidental release.

We searched long and hard to find this toothpaste. We were looking for something that was all-natural, fluoride free, and also foaming-agent-free. The last one was the kicker - there are many (many, Many, MANY) toothpaste manufacturers who proudly claim that they are "Sodium Lauryl Sulfate Free" or "SLS Free", but which still include variants of this industrial surfactant foaming agent.It's funny that people go to great lengths to eat healthfully, but then will brush with toothpaste that is, literally, toxic due to the fluoride and foaming agents. Leaving aside hysteria, the facts are that fluoride is a poison, and if one were to ingest the contents of a tube of standard fluoride+SLS toothpaste that would call for an emergency room visit and could potentially be life-threatening.Also, the size of a unit of toothpaste is limited by the manufacturers in order to prevent lawsuits over accidental ingestion (usually by children). Have you ever wondered why you can't buy a huge tub of toothpaste with a pump on top? That's why - the manufacturers don't want the liability of putting lethal doses of sweet tasting poison on your bathroom counter.Also, if you think you're *not* ingesting these agents because you don't swallow, take a look at an article on sublingual administration of medication, where you'll find that mucous membrane under the tongue leads directly to a profusion of capillaries, and substances in your mouth diffuse through them and pass directly into the bloodstream. They don't even pass through the normal digestive or filtering mechanisms of the body, they pass directly into the bloodstream.So, we have made the choice to forego the dental benefits of fluoride and the familiarity of foaming (via SLS) by using natural toothpaste. Yes, we might get a couple more cavities, but we consider that a fair trade when weighed against the daily ingestion of known toxic and poisonous chemicals.

Our guest bathroom has ceramic tile flooring that becomes treacherously slippery when wet. We've had some random throw rugs and shower mats in there, but they didn't really work, particularly because they blocked the door from opening. The door has a fairly low clearance, so any kind of rug or mat with any height jams up under the door.Also, the bathroom is designed with a long stretch that goes from the door, in front of the sink, then to the front of the toilet area which is also where you step out of the shower, so this long, thin sized rug fits almost perfectly (could have used it a foot longer, but not taking any stars away).We did a hard target search for rugs that were both good for wet areas and also very thin, and this one fits the bill perfectlly. It's less than 1/4" high so the door easily passes over it, the backing is rubber-y so it stays in place and doesn't slip, it provides good footing even when the feet or rug are wet, and it looks great.What more could we ask for (other than an additional foot of length)? Bottom line, this is a fantastic solution for our guest bathroom.

We have a showerhead/handheld combo in our stand-up shower, and the hose for the handheld portion was just too short.
