Not only does this stick do a great job at loosening up muscles but it does it while feeling great at the same time.  Its like getting a massage that is the perfect amount of pressure. I have also used this on my neck and it feels great there too. You can probably use it anywhere although you may need someone else to use it on  you for the touch to reach spots like the back.  If your someone who wants a little extra help with stretching and muscle relaxation this is a great tool to help do so. It really helps loosen up muscles and feels great at the same time.

I purchased 2 of these Dns Night Spints with the hopes they would help with my recovery from achilles tendonitis.  The first thing I will say is that these do not actually stretch out your achilles.  I tightened them as much as possible and it left my foot in a comfortable 90 degree angle, which is not enough of an angle to actually stretch the achilles, not even a little stretch. I felt nothing as far as a stretch.  Irregardless, I tried to wear these for one night and I made it about an hour into sleep before I had to take them off.  I was so uncomfortable and I wasnt going to let a product that didnt provide an effective enough stretch to make a difference disrupt my sleep.  I am someone who likes to find the cold spot in my sheets for my feet and these splints just were too hot and bulky for me.  Some may be willing to put up with the uncomfortableness but if you're looking for a splint where you can feel the stretch, these will not give you that. I ended up returning them both unfortunately.

This is a great product.  It makes a regular S5 feel more like an S5 active.  A bit bulkier around the edges, still slides into a pocket nicely.  Looks like the phone is well protected.  Room for the phone with a screen protector made of gorilla glass.  I'd buy this one over the others.  My first one shipped without the hard cover part, but they remedied that without complaint.

OK, so you have had your phone for a while and the micro USB connector just doesn't fit well anymore.  It get's disconnected due to vibration in the car, and you have to hold your tongue just right to charge your phone.  Why not use a wireless charger you say?Yes, this is wireless in regard to the idea that you don't have to plug a wire into the phone, but it has a wire to provide power from your power source to the charging pad.  This device IS more efficient than wireless chargers, as it relies on direct physical connection to your phone case rather than transmitting electricity using electromagnetic waves (which causes some energy loss in the form of heat).  BUT, you now have to line up your phone case directly on the pad to make those little pins line up.  That can be hard to do since you can't see them when the phone is on the pad.  In addition, vibration on the road (I have a gravel road) can make those connections fail.For my purposes, a Qi wireless charging pad is more utilitarian, and more forgiving in regards to placement of the phone on the pad.  In addition, I can use any phone back cover (I like to pick ones with style and flair) instead of a proprietary cover that has those electrical connections on it.

I bought these tires at Ford Quick Lane, they installed for 13.68 each.  Free road hazard, balance and rotation for life.  70,000 miles warranty tire was less than I had hoped for - but after several experiences feeling jipped when I took a 100,000 tire for a warranty exchange (they find all kinds of reasons to discount the warranty, (eg sidewall damage, road hazards, uneven tread wear, etc.)  I went with these.  I have to say, they exceeded my expectations.  This is a nice quite tire that handles water well, drives up my gravel road in mud and dirt conditions with no problem, and seems to retain reasonable traction in icy conditions.  Quick lane also offered a 70.00 rebate which they doubled for a total of 140 back- my out the door cost for 4 tires was 228 and change - Good price, great tire, and free road hazard warranty ( a $20 upcharge per tire normally ).  (*price before rebate was $368 including tax).  Please do shop around for your best price, but when you finish - BUY THIS TIRE.  It performs, and that's what really matters - your safety.I've run top of the line Michelin and Uniroyal tires on my Camry in the past and these ride just as good, and perform as well or better.  The Pirellis I tried were a poor performer on my car (less than half the advertised treadwear), and the goodyear tires were nice for the first 50% of tread wear then very poor in rain.  After all that, I'm just now buying my second set of Hankook tires, and I'll likely be putting them on all my cars in the future.  Oh, and yes, I got the full 70,000 miles out of my tires before I had to replace them - not due to loss of traction, but more a sense of propriety as lincoln's head was nearly visible on my ad hoc 'penny test'.

The graphics are cheaply printed the case fits loosely and the graphic image is not centered on the back nor does it extend to the sides of the phone holder. I ordered this September 6th and received it 30 days later. It wasn't just a single printing error either I ordered two of these and they are identically bad. If you look at the image on Amazon you can clearly see that the print is supposed to extend to the sides of the case it does not I am posting this from mobile I did take pictures but I cannot upload them at this time I will try to do so later.

I got this with expansion in mind.  Added two really nice cameras no problem.  Works great.  Instructions poorly translated from Chinese.  They upgraded dvr at no cost automatically because the one I ordered was an older model.  Has all the features you would expect.  HDMI out, VGA out, 8 camera in, audio in, and the software was easy to figure out without instruction.  Can see night video clearly to about 100 feet.  Might well buy another for my daughter!I bought a wired system because the picture all he was much better than wireless and I did not create any interference for my other wireless devices with this system . If you do decide to go wireless recognize that you will pay a premium for a clear picture and that even with a clear picture you might get interference with other wireless devices such as your handheld phone or legacy routers .
Great shirt, buy a size up

Small 2" wide not 2" tall.  Hard to read unless you are close and not moving on a bike.  Love what it says but poor print quality, material not durable, and faded inside a week.  You could make better at home.

I ordered a few of these and just got them shipping was slow. However they appear to be made of steel they stick to a magnet and they are durable. The Pens write well and work as a kubaton nicely. I have yet to check the glass break functionality but intuitively doubt that persons of a slider build would be able to exert enough force to break a vehicle window with this device. It would also make a serviceable stabbing implement for self defense. Of note the pen is wider in diameter than I would have expected. This is a stout nearly half inch thick pen body which surprised me, it was nearly twice as large as I expected. That said, I have found that is more comfortable to write with then my old standby stainless steel self defense pen and like it alot.

Wow can I just say wow. Vou Mac's version of the Fitbit costs 30 bucks 4:33 which I bought two of. I love this device, it works very well as a pedometer and the app which is free on Android syncs well with the device. I had fully charged it prior to use, and have used it 5 days now with half a battery charge remaining. I have never removed it and it has function well even though it is taken in numerous showers with me. If I had one thing to improve on the device it would be the inactivity monitor. Instead of notifying me when I have been inactive for half an hour, the in activity monitor seems to be more of a every 30 minute alert. It has gone off whether I was walking or not.

Although the coasters are pictured and in the description on which I purchased were included they did not come with the coaster holder on two separate orders. As such this is an item that is falsely advertised and well deserving of a negative review.

It's not much to expect the device to work as it is intended but I was disappointed in this respect by the porta x10 HCS HDMI + 3 RCA. It does display the image and audio on legacy television sets. And if you connect it to a crappy TV you probably won't notice how badly it distorts the video in doing so. Unfortunately I have a large high definition display that the kids shorted the HDMI ports on but which still has component audio input functionality. On this TV this device exhibits static horizontal bending that scrolls up the screen during any video output. If you're old enough to remember what your TV look like when your antenna wasn't tuned in that's the kind of picture you will get with this device.

This was a nice sized magnet that stuck very well to my steel mailbox. It is a nice way to let my fellow veterans know that they aren't alone and there are still people out here to support them. The magnet was well designed and the sticker seems to be quite durable.

Home hacking projects for geeks is a very dated review of x10 technology and Perl scripting language. The interfaces the author uses to connect two televisions won't work on most modern televisions without significant acrobatics. And every home automation technique that the author has  used can be accomplished with much less expense and modern technology with HDMI cameras to boot!

This book blatantly represents the liberal agenda about slavery in the South prior to the emancipation. Unfortunately it is poorly written with a disjointed style and lackluster character development. It's extremely sad that the characters are the entire book and we're so poorly developed.I had high hopes for this book prior to reading it.  The invention of wings is a clever play in words on the idea of achieving freedom. It follows the lives of a southern girl and a black slave girl contrasting their lives and their search for freedom. It does present some interesting insights into the lives and lifestyle of that period in time.If you aren't obligated to read this book for some college class then I strongly suggest you pass on it and pick up something far more interesting like Tolstoy's war and peace for Sun Tzu's the art of war.
I got these to help me move furniture on my nice hardwood floors and thought it would be a great thing so that I wouldn't have to lift so much unfortunately the wheels scuff your floors badly.
There's a fee of 4.99 so you can use this product . I have abhore when somebody tells you something it's free only to find there are hidden fees .

This works, was nice, but I have since found less expensive ones that work just as well.  I like that it holds any phone you put a metal strip on - and the strip is unobtrusive inside my S5 phone back cover.

The best mount I have found so far for my car.  Why go with a mount that fits just one brand of phone when you can buy one that works for all phones!  I put a metal strip on my 12" tablet and it holds it too - although I wouldn't trust it going at high speed over a speed bump.

MALFUNCTIONS ARE USUALLY USER ERRORS HERE.ALL grease guns suffer from ONE common problem:  AIR LOCK.When you put in a new grease cartridge they lock up.  How do you fix it?  You bleed that air!They have valves on top for this purpose but it can be cumbersome to do so.  With a manual grease gun I don't bother bleeding with the appropriate valve on top of the gun - I just unscrew the grease compartment slightly until some air can get thru.  On a 90PSI grease gun, however, I'd highly recommend you carry an allen wrench around and do it by hand when putting in a new cartridge.  Alternatively, a hand turnable nut could replace that air valve on top of the gun.To those of you who had cross thread problems, I highly recommend you check the assembly of any item you purchase online before you use it.  Personally, I disassemble them, check the threads, then loc-tite and reassemble.  In that manner I prolong the life of my tools.  Yes, I bought a cheap chinese version of a tool, but I still want it to work!

Negative reviews here apparently fail to take into consideration a very important factor:  XC  Before you buy any SD or microSD make sure it's compatible with your operating system.  XC doesn't work on my windows computer either, go figure!  Before you chuck yours in the trash consider formatting it to exFAT.  Microsoft says that will help.

This book is poorly written, but you didn't buy it for the grammar, did you?  You bought it for useful tips on using a DSLR camera and you are a beginner.  OK - so I only mark it down one star for the grammar - it's still readable.  I mark it down another star because of it's stellar lack of content.  This book was easy to read in under half an hour.  Finally, I subtract yet another star for the lack of any illustrations whatsoever.I mean, come on!  An author of a book on DSLR photography should have a DSLR camera, right?My idea of a DSLR book is written clearly and concisely, with ILLUSTRATIONS.When you mention aperature - show the aperature inside the camera.  Take a picture of how to adjust it.  THEN take three more pictures of the same item in the same light - one small aperature, one perfect, and one large aperature - so the reader can SEE the difference aperature settings make!

There is so much free content out there for Prime members, I rarely purchase a book - the other reviews and the description of this book hooked me though.Then I started reading it...This book was clearly written by a person who doesn't speak English, then translated to English.  The diction appears to be Japanese, but that is besides the point.  I bought a book that was supposed to be in English, not a primer on every grammatical and punctuation error known to man!I'm not the kind of guy who spell checks love notes, I appreciate them for their intent.  However, this book is so poorly written that it is practically unusable.  Here is a direct quote - picked at random from my highlights (*which were chosen due to the merit of their content, not the poor punctuation)"Using an aperature that is narrow it lets in less light but will provide deeper focus for you.  What type of aperature you use will be greatly decided upon the kind of lens you are using."Yes, you can grasp the meaning if you really try - but it's not hard to write that better:Aperature: the diameter of the opening used to allow light to contact the camera sensor.  A narrow aperature lets in less light.Mine's not perfect, but the author's is down right cryptic.  If I had a paper copy of this book I would burn it.
I tried to make alcohol gel with this and did not do well otherwise the product came as describedI think if you want to make alcohol gel you might find it more cost effective just to buy the gel.
Didn't do much for psoriasis, but the woodsy smell is appealing and the soap leaves you feeling clean.  Pls rate as helpful if you found the review useful at all.
Got these for my dog.  He sprained his front paw, and just one pill set him right as rain.

The magnet isn't strong and the mount really isn't adaptable at all.  I went with another for my phone for less that has a stronger magnet and works with any phone.  If the review helps you pls click that box.

This cane is sturdy in spite of being collapsible.  It's light, yet functional, and I find that the glow in the dark handle and tip are actually helpful at night.  In addition, the metal is solid enough I'm certain poking an assailant with it would injure him enough to deter him.  I have considered filling it with sand or epoxy as I don't break it apart much.  I think instead, a solid bit of rebar would do the trick nicely - the lightness doesn't matter to me that much, and it would present quite a surprise to someone thinking me a defenseless old man!  I've also considered a high powered LED flashlight inside the handle, which is hollow with a DRIVE labelled cap on it.  For 7 bucks, I can afford to play around with it a bit!

The product website shows this being used inside a home, this I do not recommend.  The propane odor is evident after just a few minutes, and the possibility of personal injury is high if you do so.With that lone caveat, I must say that I wholeheartedly recommend this product for your home.  It comes with a lengthy propane tube, regulator, nifty lid and carry handle.  It works very well.  I have found that it's lacking an piezoelectric ignitor is not an issue.  I put a dab of hand sanitizer on a rock, light that, then turn on the gas.It puts out a lovely yellow/orange flame, the rocks (unexpectedly) glow a brilliant orange and retain heat for quite some time.  For short periods you could use in inside - we did during a freeze in Georgia.  We had a large space with ample air flow though.  I used to use firewood in a firepit on the deck during evenings for gatherings.  Now I use this.  The amount of time and effort I save is AMAZING!!!On high, a full 20lb propane tank burns for about 12 hours.  On low make that closer to 20.  DO NOT BUY THE REFILL TANKS.  Take your tank to a hardware store and refill it.  The exchange tanks hold 12-15lbs propane, a hardware store will fill you up to 25lbs for much less money, and you get more propane for the bargain!  A refill tank only lasts about 8 hours.  We did several continuous burns and this was an obvious difference for us.  If you just used it intermittently, you might have let the exchange tank company rip you off and not noticed.

My wife loves wine.  I open the bottles.  We've been married over 20 years - I've opened a LOT of bottles.  At first glance this appears to be just a standard corkscrew type opener.  IT IS NOT.Standard openers get strained as you pull the cork - just above where the corkscrew goes into the cork, the corkscrew bends.  The actual metal corkscrew bends.  Either that or the hinge where the metal lever you place on the bottle top fails.  Every time.  One of these two parts fails in time.This corkscrew is different.The reason standard corkscrews fail is that when you fully insert a corkscrew into the cork (*as you must do with real corks to prevent breaking the cork in the bottle) you are exerting force on the handle at an angle so that your pull isn't straight up out of the bottle.This corkscrew resolves that issue.  It has a springloaded hinge midway on the lever that you place on the bottle.  Once you fully insert the corkscrew, you push the spring loaded portion onto the bottle top and pull the cork part of the way out.  Release the spring and pull the cork the rest of the way out in the conventional manner.  In many cases the cork is out enough already that I simply grasp it and remove it by hand.The shorter lever arm allows the corkscrew to pull the cork straight up out of the bottle with less total force than used in a conventional corkscrew.  You aren't wasting any effort in angular motion bending your tool!

My daughter loves this coat.The patch makes people ask her at times if she's in the Army - I think they are joking with her.  Otherwise she has found it to be warm, comfortable, and stylish.  It's her coat of choice.I examined the stitching and weight of the coat.  It appears to be well made and of sufficient fill weight to provide adequate insulation for mild to cool climates - this is not an extreme cold weather coat.  I'd recommend it for up to 30 minute exposure in weather to 32F.  Beyond that and you'll have some extra warming to do when they come in out of the cold.

Excellent compression socks that have held up to the abuse my 21 year old son puts them to.  He's very active, sometimes wears them without shoes, plays basketball, dances, and works hard.  He's also a bit style conscious and finds them attractive enough not to impede his 'flow'.

I love this company.  The compression socks work very well too.  My son complained because he didn't have anything green to match them.  It would be nice to have a choice in the color for your size - I suppose that will come as the company sees more sales in this product line.Why is my son wearing compression socks?Our 21 year old son has severe venous insufficiency.  These socks work as well as 20-30mmHg compression socks for mitigating that issue.  They are also very stylish, if you like the color!He relates that they do slide down a bit and he wishes they fit over his knee - but at 6'4" he's out of luck - I can't find any that tall.(*Plus thigh highs would likely slide down even more given how much the knee moves, either that or they would form a constrictive band at the thigh which would affect him adversely.)

I bought a few of these and they have more capacity than I got from my HP cartridges.  The pages look just as good too.  I haven't done photo printing with them, but lots and lots of regular printed sheets without any issues.Bought a few more of these and the first was D.O.A. did not work at all.  Really stinks because I had bottom in anticipation of running out of ink and have missed my return window. Make sure that when you buy these you try them right away so you have the ability to return one if it's bad.

You know, math can be fun.  It really can be.  Any teacher can communicate the principles you need to learn to do math well.  It takes a superb teacher to communicate that in a fun and memorable way.  This book was not written by a superb teacher.  It works for the stated purpose, but I'm going to keep looking for a better one.

One of four books I got my daughter.  I read selections from each and they appear to have similar content.  Each has good practice tests and strategies.  This one was a bit dry and read more like a textbook.  I prefer to enjoy myself reading - even when learning.  Check out my other purchases - only one prep book got 5 stars.

I got this, the Kaplan book, and a math specific book to prep for the ACT - this was my daughter's favorite.  She used all three from start to finish, but this book gave her some good strategies and was written well enough to hold her interest from start to finish.  She found the others dry and sterile.

This book works for it's stated purpose, but was a bit dry and sterile to read. When my daughter said that - I read some of it.  Compared to the other one I got her she was right.  This one was more like reading a textbook.
The lids don't fit securely.  The bowls are thin glass, probably not tempered.  You'd do better with saran wrap than using these lids.

I bought this mainly to show my pride in our country.  I got great value as well.  Although it only holds 2 cards - often that is enough when you are running around.  The fake leather material is durable and the item was well stitched.  I'm guessing that it's RFID protected as well because the credit cards I put right next to my phone still work.  (*I've had my phone demagnetize the strip on a credit card overnight when I place it on the phone before.)I've dropped my phone several times, on end, on face, etc.  The case has protected it just fine.  I would take the precaution of installing a piece of gorilla glass as well though - in case you drop it with the case open.  Mine fits in the case with the glass on the phone.I wish they would send me a Canadian flag version as well.  (*It's safer to travel as a Canadian - nobody hates Canada!)

I, too, must have gotten a bad lot.  The screws came out on just the left side in all 3 pair in under 2 months.  Up until that time I really enjoyed them and found them to be a great value.  Aside from the manufacture issue they have nice big lenses, are clear and optically correct at the stated magnification.  (*by empirical comparison with lab provided readers)  I even found them to be rather stylish.They were such a great value I might buy a bottle of loctite and an eyeglass screwdriver and see if I can repair the defective manufacture issue in advance on another set of 3.

YOU NEED TO KNOW THIS BEFORE YOU BUYThe chances you get an inaccurate unit are HIGH, and there is a lot of variation between units.  What percentage of a particular blood glucose meter made are accurate?  (See photo for the actual data from the referenced journal.)A Sep 2012 Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology article evaluated most of the common home monitors in preparation for trying to update the standard of measurement from 20% error to 15% error acceptable for these units.  (Right now your glucose could be 200 and you can get a reading of 240 as accurate.)  You are going to poke yourself and draw blood.  You want that reading to be accurate, right?  OK - so when you look at how many of the units tested (out of a large sample) were accurate to within 5% of the actual blood glucose level - the percent of machines that were accurate might be a useful bit of information before you buy?  Think of this as "If I buy this machine, what's my chance of getting one that is accurate?"  The Bayer Contour USB hit 34%.  That's your chance of getting a good glucose meter with this manufacturer and model.  (The best performers hit 90% of machines were accurate to within 5%).

(Right now your glucose could be 200 and you can get a reading of 240 as accurate.)  You are going to poke yourself and draw blood.  You want that reading to be accurate, right?  OK - so when you look at how many of the units tested (out of a large sample) were accurate to within 5% of the actual blood glucose level - the percent of machines that were accurate might be a useful bit of information before you buy?  Think of this as "If I buy this machine, what's my chance of getting one that is accurate?"  This unit hit 69%.  That's your chance of getting a good glucose meter with this manufacturer and model.  (The best performers hit 90% of machines were accurate to within 5%).

The difference between this unit and mine is the added features, if the pump is on the drum WATCH OUT!ALERT ALERT ALERT - BEFORE YOU BUY A SAMSUNG READ THIS - ALERT ALERT ALERTHi folks - I hate to be an alarmist, but I have information you NEED TO KNOW about Samsung and other washing machines of this general manufacture.  I bought the 50 version of this washer (WA50) and after 2 years it failed.  It wasn't anything we did, it was a KNOWN issue with the manufacture of the machine.  You see, when it's ready to drain there's a pump that pushes the water out the exhaust tube into your drain pipe.THAT PUMP can easily crack, break, and fail - causing the machine to dump all it's water onto the ground.Until that happened this was a perfect washing machine for our family, worked flawlessly, saved water and energy, we were happy.How can you know if you got a model with the crappy drain pump?  In general the crappy pump is attached to the tub itself, right on the drum.  You simply tilt your machine up and look.  Follow the water exhaust/discharge hose from the outside of your machine to a cylindrical device that's (hopefully) attached to a hose that goes to the drum.  If the pump is on the drum, you got a bad one!The Samsung repair guy came out to repair mine and told me all about this issue.  I asked what makes the decision whether you repair one out of warranty (I was at 2 years the machine has a 1 year warranty - because the pump isn't part of the DRIVE TRAIN 10 year warranty.)  His response: whether the customer complains enough.Yes, my machine got fixed - but the customer service gave me a serious run around (over 4 hours on the phone).  One of the managers even had the audacity to call me, and left me the wrong return phone number THREE TIMES!!!  (*or does Samsung market time shares?)Their stellar lack of customer service and desire not to stand by their defective merchandise has earned Samsung this negative review and my warning.  Be sure your pump is mounted to the machine frame at the base of the unit NOT THE DRUM.  It makes sense if you think about it.  The drum sees a lot of vibration, a plastic pump mounted to that vibrating behemoth is bound to fail.SAMSUNG customer service works for Samsung, not you.  Know what to look for in a bad unit - read this review.
