I asked what makes the decision whether you repair one out of warranty (I was at 2 years the machine has a 1 year warranty - because the pump isn't part of the DRIVE TRAIN 10 year warranty.)  His response: whether the customer complains enough.Yes, my machine got fixed - but the customer service gave me a serious run around (over 4 hours on the phone).  Hence this negative review and my warning, be sure your pump is mounted to the machine frame at the base of the unit NOT THE DRUM.  It makes sense if you think about it.  The drum sees a lot of vibration, a plastic pump mounted to that vibrating behemoth is bound to fail.

ALERT ALERT ALERT - BEFORE YOU BUY A SAMSUNG READ THIS - ALERT ALERT ALERTHi folks - I hate to be an alarmist, but I have information you NEED TO KNOW about Samsung and other washing machines of this general manufacture.  I bought the 50 version of this washer (WA50) and after 2 years it failed.  It wasn't anything we did, it was a KNOWN issue with the manufacture of the machine.  You see, when it's ready to drain there's a pump that pushes the water out the exhaust tube into your drain pipe.THAT PUMP can easily crack, break, and fail - causing the machine to dump all it's water onto the ground.How can you know if you got a model with the crappy drain pump?  In general the crappy pump is attached to the tub itself, right on the drum.  You simply tilt your machine up and look.  The Samsung repair guy came out to repair mine and told me all about this issue.  I asked what makes the decision whether you repair one out of warranty (I was at 2 years the machine has a 1 year warranty - because the pump isn't part of the DRIVE TRAIN 10 year warranty.)  His response: whether the customer complains enough.Yes, my machine got fixed - but the customer service gave me a serious run around (over 4 hours on the phone).  Hence this negative review and my warning, be sure your pump is mounted to the machine frame at the base of the unit NOT THE DRUM.  It makes sense if you think about it.  The drum sees a lot of vibration, a plastic pump mounted to that vibrating behemoth is bound to fail.
Doesn't fit 1995 Ford F-150 fuel lines

I published a review about these discs several days ago, but it is no longer available on Amazon.  For some reason they purged all reviews.  Fortunately for you, I have the time to post a new one.In addition, I've learned more about these discs that you NEED TO KNOW BEFORE BUYING:The BD-R discs are compatible with most existing BD-R drives.  HOWEVER THE CD-R and DVD-R are NOT!!!!!!!!!!Ritek(dot)com provides this information on their website for Mdisc.  Look in their FAQ section, the third item explains it.(*Good thing I bought the BD-R!)Now to the GOOD PART:  Assuming you can burn an Mdisc BD-R you save a TON of money using them - providing keeping your data is important to you.  Prior to the MDisc you had to reburn your BD-Rs and DVD-Rs every 6mos to 1 year to prevent data loss due to degradation.  Mdisc claims 1000 years durability - but even at 10% of that you save money and a TON of time.  At the current cost of $6 per disc, compared to .50/BD (quality stuff not mass-trash manufacture) over 100 years you pay $6 for an Mdisc, and as much as $100 for conventional BD-R media.  When you factor in the possiblity of spending $1000 for the full life of an Mdisc, and all the time you spend recopying all those BD-R 1-2 times a year....  Wow these become a no brainer.This year I backed up 2.5TB of pictures onto Mdisc and gave them to my wife, with a backup copy now in the safe deposit box.  I also put all our financials and all of our tax returns for the last 15 years onto another separate disc now in that safe deposit box.  I filled that disc out with our wills, medical information, and complete list of our assets.  I also created a trust for a local charity, with a brief video of my intent with the donation I made so that those who benefit hundreds of years from now can understand the mindset of this benefactor from their very ancient past.I baked one of these discs into our Christmas Lasagna - Quite a way to unveil my present to the family - an enduring history of our lives.  IT PLAYS!!!Imagine your reaction today if you were to find a 30 minute movie made 1000 years ago.  Perhaps Leif Ericson discovers "Vinland" (possibly L'Anse aux Meadows, Canada) reputedly becoming first European to reach North America!  Maybe you see the supernova witnessed by ancient Egyptians, or perhaps you get to see Cnut the Great (or Canute), King of Denmark, claims the English throne after the death of Edmund 'Ironside'.  No, I doubt my poor efforts will ever compare with these great moments in history - then again, perhaps they will.  BECAUSE THEY WILL SURVIVE.  I did preserve a nice video of the geminid meteor shower from this year as well as my disdain for our current president.  Who knows, maybe some kid in the future will be prompted to understand what a 'government' was as a result!Remember the episode of Star Trek when V..G.ER returns from the other side of the galaxy as a sentient artificial life form>?  These discs are supposed to last longer than that space trip took!  (2271-1977= only 294 years)

The keychain lights are dim, but a nice bonus gift - as is the box.  That said, the LED lights are worth it by themselves.  Last year I bought 14 of these on Amazon for about $5.50 each.  The deal I am looking at has them at $11 with bonus items.  In addition, I have tested these lights - which you will find rated at 300 or 500 lumens.  I ordered some of the 500 lumen models to test them and with an AA battery they put out the same brightness of light I got from my earlier purchase lights that were rated at 300 lumen.  The brightness in both the old and new flashlights increased with the 14500 battery.  As such, and in the absence of contradictory information, I would recommend purchasing some rechargable 14500 batteries and a charger to go with these flashlights.  They last longer and put out more light on these batteries.As an afterthought I disassembled the heads of the old and new lights - the LED appears to be the same size with comparable electronics controlling it.  I have yet to note any adverse effects from using the 14500 batteries in my older 300 lumen flashlights as well.Hope this information helps you to make your buying choice wisely!I did a little investigation on the various forms of CREE bulbs currently in these small flashlights.  Light output at a given voltage and amperage does improve as you move up to better 'bulbs' you can go right to the cree website and check my information if you wish.  Basically the newer the CREE technology the better it is - but those differences can be small compared to the cost of the upgrade.  These go in ascending order for brightness as follows:  1 MC-E  2 MT-G2  3 XB-D  4 XM-L  5 XM-L2  6 XP-C  7 XP-E  8 XP-E2  9 XP-G  10 XP-G2  11 XR-C  12 XR-E  13 XT-ENow, the LUMENS - or brightness the LED emits is also dependent on power supplied to it.  For example a CREE XM-L T6 bulb at 3000mA produces 975 Lumens max, whilst a more expensive CREE XM-L2 T6 produces 341Lumen at 700mA.  (*It can produce 1100 lumens at 3000mA power).Why did I go into all this detail?  BECAUSE YOUR BATTERY POWER SOURCE MATTERS.  If your battery can produce more mA for the LED, then you get more light.  (*Providing the circuit supporting the LED doesn't limit power going to it.)All that means is that my result using a Lithium battery, which supplies slightly higher voltage and amps in these little flashlights got me a LOT more light - even though they were only rated at 300 lumens, that rating was for a standard alkaline AA battery.  Pop a high power photography grade lithium into it and you have a device that's bright enough to cause eye damage!!!  One caveat to my fellow light hungry buyers, though.  Light comes at a cost - the brighter it burns, the shorter both the battery and LED life will be.(*at under 6 bucks each, I can afford to burn up 10 of these before I'd be able to afford a Streamlight with a bulb that can handle such power over decades without burning out - plus my flashlights are always new =)So, in order to get the best bang for the buck out of these flashlights - put the best battery you can afford to fit into it's casing into it.Hope that helps you to 'see the light' too!

I bought 14 of these in black with 3 mode switches quite some time ago and have had excellent luck with them.  Each produces at least 200lumens compared to US made LED flashlights, has a dim, bright, and flashing mode, and much to my surprise - the outer bezel slips outward to allow you to zoom your light for a farther 'throw'.I gave them all to local police and firefighters - then ordered a batch direct from China to save money.  (*Note, the price on Amazon has gone up $2 since my initial order.)  I wouldn't hesitate to mount any of these on the rail of a gun, put a long life AA battery in it as an emergency light in the car, or to give one to a loved one for times of need.  Be sure to use extra long life batteries.  I know a lot of people review these badly - it is my opinion that Amazon may be grouping reviews of differing lights with these.  I bought the ULTRAFIRE single AA battery powered 3 mode black flashlight from a company named Grace Marketing.  I hope that helps you guys out!  I'm about to buy another batch of 100 for this year's gifts!

I bought mine over a year ago and have just now thought to review it.Before I bought it I read the negative reviews - just a few tips on those:1) completely disregard any negative review based upon damaged goods that were likely due to packaging Amazon used.2) pay attention to reviews about how well it filters water, manufacture, and durability3) as with all items of foreign manufacture, closely inspect for any signs they may have used hazardous materials in making your item - foreign manufacturers do have different standards for shipping items to the US vs Europe.Now applying the above filters, my review:Even with the preponderance of negative reviews, I chose to buy this.  Free returns with Prime had my back if I got a dud.  My pitcher arrived in good condition without damage to the box or the pitcher within.  I was, however surprised enough that it had very little in the box to protect it to remember that surprise even now.  I can see how it was easily damaged for other reviewers.  Upon unboxing I rinsed my filter, and installed PUR water filters into it - they filter slower but at the time of my purchase filtered out smaller stuff. Normally, with other pitcher water filters I removed the top part at this point to see if I have any water leaking from where the filter attaches to the fill basin - I could not do this with the stainless pitcher, so I shined a flashlight thru the clear window and looked - no leak noted.How well does it filter water?  At least as well as any pur filter usually does - which was good enough for me at time of purchase - more on this later for those of you who want some real detail.A couple things to consider, since the plastic water fill basin doesn't come into contact with the filtered water unless you grossly over fill, I wasn't overly concerned about BPA contaminants at time of purchase.  I have since learned that this plastic is BPA free.  I have not been able to ascertain whether the clear view window is BPA free, however - and it does come into contact with the water.  I am, however, fairly confident that it is BPA free though - since bisphenol A is used to manufacture FLEXIBLE polycarbonate plastics and the window is rigid plastic.  (*Note here - if you are worried about BPA check out your canned foods - those plastic lined cans are a major cuplrit of contamination by BPA)  Furthermore, BPA leeches out rapidly when the plastic is heated, I tend to prefer to filter cold water.  BUT you should still be concerned about the pitcher contaminating your drinking water.  It's steel.  Stainless steel has iron, chromium, nickel and manganese - non food grade stainless can even have lead in it.  I still don't know if this pitcher is made of food grade stainless - if it were of US manufacture it would be.  I can tell you this, I sent a water sample from my well after running it thru this filter and before filtration - both tests produced identical results save the filtered water has fewer minerals.  (*I have a very good well and filter only as a precaution against contamination.)  In addition, we never heat the water in our stainless pitcher - it's got plastic in it after all!  All of the studies I have read that showed any significant release of metal into food were done at high temperatures.  There's a really good article on this I mention at the end if you are interested.So, after over a year, how do I like it?  I'd buy another - but I don't need to, since there's nothing wrong with it.  I change my filters often and use it every day with 2-3 refills per day.  We drop it 4-6 inches occasionally onto our granite counter tops and it still has no dents cracks or leaks.  The kids use it and if I were to voice any complaint it would be that they fail to fill it when they use it.  Fortunately, they are growing out of that bad habit!I hope this review helps you make an informed decision on your purchase, please rate it accordingly if such is the case.Now some detail if you need to know a bit more about filtering water.  You see, before you filter the water it may prove useful to know precisely what it is you want to filter out and whether your filter is capable of doing so!Although the EPA regulates 91 water contaminants, there are many that still find their way into the tap water we use every day.  Other contaminants commonly found in tap water include lead, copper, sulfate, nitrates, pesticides, herbicides, arsenic, industrial solvents and trihalomethanes, a chemical known to cause colon and bladder cancer in large concentrations. Contrary to popular belief, municipal water treatment facilities were not designed to take out contaminants such as synthetic organic chemicals and toxic heavy metals like lead.Well water sources are typically not regulated at all, making it the responsibility of the well owner to test and evaluate the safeness of their well water.  Well water sources are susceptible to contamination from septic tanks, farms, pesticides and herbicides used in the surrounding area and can also have high instances of iron, calcium and magnesium which cause hard water. Hard water and scaling can damage home appliances and plumbing, as well as leave stains and spots on clothing, dishes, and surfaces in your home.With this in mind, if you don't live in the middle of the woods or on a lonely mountaintop - you're getting some chemicals in your water that aren't good for you.  Most of us don't have to worry so much about bacterial contamination, but those pesticides, chlorine, lead, and other contaminants can be bothersome.  I implore you to evaluate your water source, then select a filter designed to reduce the contaminants you have in it.  Unfortunately, for those of you on city water - that chlorination will fry your water filters fast, so be prepared to replace them often (*recommended about 50gal normally, so every 25 gal or so?)  And bear in mind that none of the pitcher water filters currently filter out Mercury, Asbestos or Chloramines well - although the PUR filters with MAXION do reduce cyst contamination and pharmaceuticals and I'm sure the other manufacturers whose filters fit this pitcher will soon do so as well.  If you've read all this - you're probably going to want a reverse osmosis filter for your drinking water - see pic.Finally, if you want to learn about the potential of stainless steel to leech metals into your food look for the 2010 study by the Finnish Institute of Occupational Health, titled appropriately: Review on Toxicity of Stainless Steel.

I bought this printer for the sole purpose of printing on CDs - I wanted to get near photo quality to produce our Christmas mailing to family and friends, as well as with an eye to help my daughter promote her singing career. Overall I was very impressed with it's ability to perform this task. Considering the printer costs about as much as replacing the ink cartridges with max capacity ones, I could not have beaten it for this price point ($90). What follows are some tips and tricks to help you get yours up and running properly, as the quick start guide is a little lacking as well as a few issues you need to be aware of when using this printer to facilitate your understanding before you choose to purchase this product.UNBOXING: it fits tightly in the cardboard box, and you will be tempted to use a box cutter to help - DONT. They used odd places on the styrofoam around the printer to tape things like ink, the software CD, and the power cord to. Be safe and just get a helper to hold the box as you pull it out. Then carefully look at all of the surfaces on the styrofoam for all your ink cartridges (5) the CD, the manual and quick start guide, and the included power cable. NOTE: no USB printer cable is included, and one will dramatically speed your printer setup. It's possible to set up wifi only, but problematic. Just use an old cable or buy one for a couple of bucks (I literally found one for under $2). (See pic) This cable connects at the back of the printer on the side opposite the power cord. With it you can easily set yourself up to use the printer wireless with all of your other devices. Please note, it's fairly common for network devices to need tethering to a computer during initial setup - and usually easier for devices that can be done without tethering as well.REMOVE ALL THE TAPE: Most of the tape is fairly obvious - some on the front to hold the paper tray shut, some to hold the control panel, which tilts up and down to allow you to access the paper slots below. (More on this later) and a couple on the back to hold the thing secure back there. BUT DONT MISS THE ONES INSIDE! Yes, you have to lift the scanner bed cover and remove one, then you have to lift the scanner glass up - it hinges at the back and is easily lifted from the right side at the front. Inside on the right you will find two more pieces of tape and a bit more styrofoam and cardboard - presumably to keep the print heads from banging around during shipping.CABLES: Connect that USB printer cable to your printer and the computer following your computer manufacturer's recommended proceedure, then plug the power cable into the printer and finally into your surge protected power source of choice.RUN THE CD: It actually has some useful software on it, like a CD printer - into which you can import your own pictures and add text or background should you so desire, not to mention the absolutely essential printer monitoring software.LOAD PAPER: Flip the control panel up, tilt the paper tray cover panel down, push the lower cassette in and then slide the paper tray out. Wait, what? Time to explain a bit. This printer handles lots of kinds of materials, and you need to know where each one goes to prevent jams. You won't want to try to print a CD from the paper or envelope trays, CD's don't bend well. From top to bottom you have 1) a removable CD printing tray that slides into it's slot for printing when that has been selected (*it has some resistance to it when you use it - scared me thinking I was forcing it until I got used to this), 2) the paper path output tray for envelopes and regular paper, 3) the envelope input tray for odd sized paper (envelopes, 3x5 photos and such), and 4) the rather small paper tray that holds your 8.5x11 paper. The paper tray can be hard to get out, so slide the tray above it forward 1/2 inch or so, then slide it out. Be sure to replace both trays so that they completely overlap each other when you close the paper tray! When I saw that it only holds 40-50 sheets at best I was very glad I have a laser printer for bulk printing! Don't overload it - just put in 1/4 in or so of paper.BEFORE YOU PRINT: Double check the back of your printer and insure that the paper feed rollers are properly in place - mine had shifted a bit during shipping, but this was easily fixed by pushing the sliding spring loaded releases toward the middle, pulling it out and re-inserting the whole little assembly.USE THE SOFTWARE AND PRINT A TEST PAGE: Really, if you don't do this any future problems are completely your fault - this is where you check your printer to see if it's a lemon or not.From here you should be good to go. I've included photos of the things I've talked about here, as well as a picture showing at 4x magnification what the output looks like on Verbatim printable CD's. You don't see these printer lines with the unaided eye, and the round line at 1CM around the spindle side of the printable edge is on the CDs not due to the printer.NOW SOME THOUGHTS:1) In general inkjet printers cost a lot more per page than laser printers - if you do a lot of printing you need to consider the cost of your supplies more than the printer or the printer's expected lifespan. If you only print 100 pages a year at .15 per page, $15 a year isn't bad. If you print 10,000 though - WOW - you pay more for the supplies than you did for the printer - time to get a better printer! This printer is a bit of an ink hog, so I'll be using after market inks on the first refill. Epson rates the cost at 13.4 cents per page, but I noted that the inks have to clean about every 7 CD's when printing and about every 15th page printing - that burns a lot of ink. I'd put the cost at about .20 per page based upon this empirical observation.2) Like all inkjets if you look at the print closely you get some banding (horizontal lines) and dithering (graininess) but overall they look great to the unaided eye.3) Page speed is comparable to most other inkjets at 5ppm black, 70s for a 4x6 photo, 36s for a CD photo - but BEWARE - those cleanings often mean you have to power down the printer, and back on - with a LONG wait for the sucker to be ready again (forgot to time it, but it's about 5 min). In addition, CD's must be individually loaded and that takes more time than it does to actually print them.4) Some inkjet manufacturers sell their printers with tiny little trial ink cartridges this printer seems to have come with more than that. I've printed 40 CD's photo quality premium and have over half full showing on my cartridge status. That's pretty good!If this review has helped you in any way, please rate it as helpful - thanks!My initial review was denied because I mentioned a brand name quite a pain to add all those photos only to have Amazon deny the review because I mentioned the brand of CD-R I used.  I took a bunch of photos to help you guys with this but there's no option to add the photos in the 'Edit my review' dialogue so I can't add the promised photos, sorry!  I hope Amazon fixes this issue soon - photos would have helped you avoid some pitfalls with this printer.

These inkjet friendly CD-R have a minimal blank space around the spindle hole and a thin unprintable outside edge. This is the largest printable surface on a CD I've seen to date. Using a new printer, I am able to obtain matte finish photo quality CD's rather easily with them. They appear to burn well too, my computer has had no difficulty burning at up to 52x with no unusable CD's or 'coasters' produced. Why not a 5 rating? See my tips below:1) They come shrink wrapped, without a spindle. My shrink wrap broke in shipping and several were scratched as a result. When you order 100, they really should put a dowel or something in the hole to prevent this issue. You will also need a spare spindle or two on hand to store them when you get them.2) Before you buy, make sure your printer is capable of printing on CD-R's. These probably won't work well or safely in a lightscribe recorder and must have a straight paper path printer to print on them. (Go figure, but CD's don't bend well!) If you haven't used a printer capable of printing on CD's before, prepare to learn a new skill set. The epson printer I got requires you load the CD onto a thin plastic tray then slide it into the printer 'just right' in order to work. At this writing, I am unaware of a printer that can accept a stack of CD's and neatly print on them.3) With inkjet printing on these CD's be prepared to wait at least a day for the ink to dry. You wouldn't want gobs of ink flying around at high speeds inside your CD player because you were impatient, would you? I waited 2 hours and put one in a sleeve, guess what? It smudged. Patience!4) Other than normal inkjet odors, my rather sensitive nose detects no smell from these during printing. The discs do warm a bit during printing though. Most plastic used in CD's does give off rather toxic fumes upon heating, so don't print a ton in an enclosed space - if you must, get out and breathe some fresh air often.5) Finally a tip on content to print on your CD's: Most of the time when we take pictures we do so with a regular picture frame in mind. It helps us to visualize our end result. That would be an error when you want to print on a CD. When you take your photo remember that there is a fairly large hole in the center of your image, so offset it a bit to one side. Furthermore, the outer curve tends to cut off your subject unless you plan for a round field of view in your shot. I've found that slightly offset photos work pretty well, and I've given you some images so you can see the process required to print. If you zoom in close, you can see the droplets of ink that got on the unprintable surface of my cd because I had the printer set to zero margin for spindle rather than the slightly larger size required to account for the narrow unprintable surface. You can also see a faint ring about 1cm outside the printable edge closest to the spindle, and you can notice clearly the inkjet printer lines - but bear in mind this is at 4x zoom. To the unaided eye, the circle at about 1cm is visible only if you tilt the cd to reflect light off of it, and the printer lines are not visible. (Besides, this is a review of the CD's not the printer - so the circle that shows near the spindle is more of an issue than printer lines for this review.)Anyway, I hope this helps you get the excellent results you desire - if you found this helpful at all please give the review a thumbs up!PHOTOS TO FOLLOW LATER AMAZON DENIED FIRST REVIEW BECAUSE I NAMED THE PRINTER BRAND - SORRY.  Those photos take a long time to upload and will help you, but I'm not going to the time to do so again til they approve the review at Amazon.

This horn is definitely loud.  I wouldn't call the sound it makes a "bad boy" though - it's more of a "naughty child".  I bought this horn expecting to hear a deep BASS grumbling horn reminiscent of hearing that semi pull up behind you and lay on his horn, but what I got was a decidedly high pitched kazoo blown really hard by a mean kid!After some thought though, I should have expected the smaller sound.  This is a very small compressor after all.  Air VOLUME is required for a deep baritone sound, and small compressors just don't have that.  It's loud though - and that's what you really need from it.
I didn't need this relay after all, the horn I bought came with one, but this relay is great to have as a spare should you ever have a problem.  I did test it in my system and it worked fine.

The wires were long enough, two of them were EXACTLY the length needed (*no margin for error) and two needed to be cut.  Using this made installing a new air horn quite simple.  This simple relay wiring kit makes remotely controlling any number of car electrical systems a breeze (additional circuit to flash your headlights or to install a car starter come readily to mind.)  It doesn't come with the relay though - although most air horns you buy will.  Make sure your relay fits this plug size or you wasted your time.

cheap plastic horn construction throughout - doesn't come with wiring harness which is required for install on most cars, horns sound like Erkel's car - not an impressive air horn sound, more like an extended clown nose sound.Why do you need a wiring harness?The compressor pulls more juice than the circuit wired into most cars.  It needs a direct connection to power supply (either battery or alternator wire) to get that juice.Will the horn button on my steering wheel still work?yes, if you install the wiring harness.  It wires to the battery for power (+) with a red fused wire, to the horn (+) with a red non-fused wire, and uses two gray wires to attach to your vehicle's existing horn wiring.  There's also a black wire for ground to deal with.  The horns in this review DO come with a relay to plug into that harness.What is a relay?A relay is a switch.  Generally, relays are used to extend the range or power capacity of an existing circuit.  In this application, it allows a low amperage circuit (your existing horn wiring usually 10-15 amp) to control a higher amperage circuit (the new horn compressor and it's wiring harness).  When you send a signal to the relay by pressing your horn, that current travels on the grey wires on the WOLO wiring harness to the relay (which you plug in quite easily), the relay then switches on power to the red and black wired circuit (30 amp) to power the compressor, which blows the horns.Can I use this without the relay and wiring harness?  (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005I4DNP2/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_18)Yes, if you don't mind blowing fuses and maybe messing with your car's computer.  It will likely sound weak if it works at all.  Some trucks, however have 30 amp horn fuses and would be fine to use these horns basically as a plug and play device.  (*they sound almost comically weak though, so why would you do that to your truck?)After going to all the trouble to install this wiring harness, I ended up removing these horns and buying another - the wiring harness worked just fine for that horn, and the exchange took just about 5 minutes.

These blankets are thin, like the airline blankets you used to get before they cut back on services.  They are of a more modern fleece though, and less prone to knotting of the fleece.  Furthermore, they are HUGE compared to a massage table size.  There's plenty of blanket to drape over each side, and can easily cover >6ft clients from head to toe.

Hardcover with nice, sturdy color pages. Everything is in color in the book, and the pages are thick and smooth. Lots of pictures, both photos and illustrations. I like that it's a variety of both, as well as the fact that the images are laid out almost scrapbook style. Each image is accompanied by some kind of fact about the country, its people, food, wildlife, etc. Again, there is a variety, so not every country focuses on the same topics.I really love that the book is organized by continent. I intend to use this as a supplement to our geography curriculum (we homeschool) and I want to study each continent individually.The book is a good size, too. Not terribly thick, or crammed with far too much--200 pages with a different country for each page. The book lies open well on a flat surface (the pages don't try to flip toward the front or back).My only complaint is that the print is a bit small. Probably not a problem for kids--the reading level is well past that of an early reader, so no need for a huge font, and kids old enough for the reading level will be fine with print this size--but for us parents....

I gave this to my 15 yr old son to use with his PS4. He was really not crazy about this.The only real positive comment he made was that the layout of the buttons was very logical for the game itself. But they feel "loose" (his word) which makes them easier to push, but worries him  that they'll wear out quickly (something we noticed actually has been a problem for other reviewers).The controller has no joystick, and my son prefers to use a joystick. Of course, that's more personal preference.The controller is corded, and he's very used to wireless controllers so that really bugged him.His biggest complaint was that the right side of the controller is "stubby." It was uncomfortable in his hand, an awkward having the sides two different sizes.The overall consensus was that if this were inexpensive--like $15--it might be worth it for the button layout and/or if you prefer to play this game without the joystick. However, for the price, it's totally not worth it as the standard controller works well and is much more comfortable.

My husband absolutely loves this. He says it's the best work light he's ever owned. Sturdy and well-built. The light is extremely bright, all LEDs. I mean really, really bright! The battery is rechargeable and so far has lasted well.It's fairly narrow--easy to grip and fits in tighter spots. The "handle" part is about the diameter of a paper towel roll tube, and has a slightly rubberized surface. It has a hook built in on one end, and another one that clips on to the other end, so you can hang it from either end or use both and hang it horizontally. There is also a heavy duty magnet on the side.Definitely recommended. Even though we got this through Amazon Vine, my husband said he would happily pay the $40 price for another one.

The device is as easy to set up as any other wifi router. My husband followed the instruction book for logging in and setting up until he got access to the device's wifi signal, then downloaded the app and used that from that point on.The app works well (we used his iPhone) and offers a lot of cool features. You can turn on and off anything that is plugged into the device with the app.  There is a schedule function that allows you to set different on/off times for different days.The wifi signal boost part of it really does work, too. We were having issues with the TV in our living room losing signal while we stream movies, as the router is in a back bedroom. Since setting the device up and putting it in the kitchen (about 20 feet from the living room TV) we've had no streaming issues.

I'm giving these two stars only because they are pretty and the hems are sewn nice and even. Had they been shoddily made, they'd get knocked down to one star. As it is, I opened the package and thought, "Did I order curtains?" These are basically fabric sewn in a rectangle. Not terry cloth, not microfiber, not thick cotton with any hope of being absorbent. They wrinkled like crazy in the washer/dryer as well. I intend to iron them and let my daughter use them as bed sheets for her American Girl dolls.

The case so far has been really good. Fits my phone well, snaps together tight. The image isn't just painted on, and I have hopes that it'll actually hold up well. My only complaint is that the image doesn't have the contrast that is shown here. The light blue areas are nearly as dark as the black. It's pretty, but hard to see. That said, I still like it a lot and am happy with the quality.

This is the third ring in this collection that I've gotten, and I think it's my favorite. I love the shaped edges!They all come in a lovely box--black matte on the outside, royal blue on the inside, and definitely a great presentation if the ring is meant as a gift. The ring itself is well-made, nice and shiny at the polished parts, and the dark parts add depth. The details are definitely paid attention to. They all have kind of a lip along the inside of each edge, which is something I like because it keeps the ring from being completely flat against my skin, a good thing in humidity. The ring is strong and straight, comfortable, and true to size. Very happy!

OK, I can't fully give this a five-star rating, but I can't tell you why it didn't quite hit the mark without spoilers, and since this book is a *mystery* I consider it doubly wrong to include spoilers in a review.That said, I really enjoyed this novel. I stayed up far too late last night so I could finish it--I just had to know the ending before I went to bed.I thought Nova, for the most part, was a likable character. And the romance that developed flowed naturally in the story. The other relationships were kind of hit and miss for me. I know teen friendships and such can be full of drama so it was realistic, but at times I got a little annoyed by everyone hating everyone.I really liked that Nova had a good relationship with her mom. And her brother. It was nice seeing a family that, despite less than ideal circumstances, including an out-of-the-picture father, were basically happy and got along and supported each other. I particularly liked Nova's grandfather, too.Anyway, even though I thought the story had a few minor speed bumps, I'd definitely recommend it! (A recommendation reserved for older teens, though, due to some thematic elements and sexual situations/references.) The writing is solid, the characters realistic, and the voice true teen--and it's a genuine mystery, not just a romance with a mystery in the background.

This is pretty cool. Rolls out nice and smooth, and sticks well. The surface is smooth and easy to write on and erase. Haven't tried cutting it, because we like the size, but it's very thin and I can't imagine it wouldn't cut well.What I don't understand is whether or not this is designed to be moved at all. It seems that it's meant to be stuck and stay in one place, but the package doesn't say that explicitly, nor does it say it's meant to move around.We've already stuck it to the wall (drywall painted with satin paint), then moved it to a semi-gloss painted door. It fell off the painted wall, but stuck well to the door. Still on the door, the corner is easy to peel back, leaves no residue, but the back of the whiteboard sheet still feels sticky--so I imagine we could move it at least one more time. My guess is it entirely depends on the surface it's being stuck to, and the number of transfers would be limited. Either way, nice to know that if you do decide to remove it it's likely that it's not going to permanently damage the surface.Anyway, I think this is a clever product. An easy way to replace the surface of a whiteboard, or to give yourself some whiteboard space on odd surfaces without putting holes in the walls or doors or whatever.

Works great. Sturdy metal construction. Outlet covers are a nice feature. Plugs fit snugly. Outlets are turned sideways so plugs can more easily be put next to each other. LED on light is easy to see. Great for the garage. Three foot cord is long enough, but not too long.

Finished this a few weeks ago, and had a hard time gathering my thoughts on it for a review. I'm on the fence about Christian fiction in general--being a Christian and a writer myself who likes the faith elements very subtle, often to the point of completely buried in symbolism. I tend to shy from books where the Christianity is overt, usually feeling preached at while reading.This book was overt, but it was one of the more genuine Christian books I've read. The main character is a teen boy, who happens to have superpowers, and also happens to be a Christian. He attends church, and hangs out at youth group...and competes on a reality show against other kids with super powers.The story concept is unique. I mean, a reality show for super heroes, in which they're assigned tasks to perform on live TV. And each week, one is voted off. How cool is that?The characters are well fleshed out. I definitely connected with Robin (aka Failstate). He's a real teen, with real teen problems, with real teen friends, even amongst all the superhero stuff. His life is by no means perfect, and he not only deals with taking out villains, but also struggles with his relationship with his mom and brother.The writing is good, with a unique voice, and the pacing kept me turning pages. Plenty of action, without sacrificing a well thought-out plot. Definitely has me interesting in continuing the series.

This watch is big. That's a good thing in my case. I got this for my son, who is 15 and over 6 feet tall with long arms and big hands (think Great Dane in human form) and the watch looks great on him. Yes, we had to take some links out of the band. We've never bought a watch that hasn't needed that (other than watches with leather bands, of course) and between my husband and I that's quite a few watches over the years.The watch came packaged very nicely. An outer cardboard box--sturdy, yellow--and inside a huge yellow, hinged watch box. There was a cloth covering the watch, and all the polished steel surfaces had plastic either wrapped around them or stuck to them (that clingy plastic). Great care was taken to protect this watch during shipping, that's for sure.And it was worth it. The steel is shiny, the crystal perfect. Everything is smooth, well made, and really good looking. The face is definitely easy to read, with such big numbers, but it doesn't look clownish or anything--this is a really handsome watch. My son LOVED it.For the price, this is definitely a good deal. Obviously, I can't tell you how long it will last, but it does have a one-year warranty, and I can't imagine a watch this solid-feeling falling apart. Definitely recommend.

Got this watch last week, and so far I love it. I am tall with long arms, so women's watches often look too small on me. But I don't want to wear a men's watch--partly for style, and partly because they tend to be a smidge too big for me. This is just the right size! The band is nice and comfortable.I love the look of the watch. Very basic and classic. The face is easy to read, although the numbers are not as bright as they appear in the photo--the image makes it look like white numbers against pure black. But in person, the black isn't fully black and the letters are dark silver like the case, but reflect well in the light.Re: ticking issue is that other reviewers have complained about. I don't hear ticking at all from this watch. Maybe it's something that has been corrected because of the complaints? Either way, I had to put the watch inches from my ear to hear it tick, and even then it wasn't loud.

High-priced-hotel towels. That's what these make me think of. They are bright white, super thick, very soft. The edges are sewn really well. Quality. And not insanely expensive, since you get two good-sized bath towels, two hand towels, and two wash cloths for about $52.Because they are made partly with bamboo (rayon from bamboo is what they say, along with cotton) they have a very slight odor when they arrive. I may not have even really noticed it, but we have a pillow that's made from bamboo and its odor was quite strong (easily fixed by 20 mins in the dryer), so the scent of these towels was faint but familiar. Totally gone after the first wash, though.I didn't bother reading the washing instructions. I always wash towels in hot water and dry them on high heat, and these came out perfectly.Using them makes me feel like I'm at a spa or something. Very cozy and absorbent. Definitely recommend.

I did enjoy this book. I liked Aster as a main character, and the story world is unique. The concept of the Fold and the way they traveled through links seemed a bit like the tessering in A Wrinkle in Time. I thought making the setting on Earth somewhat futuristic and dystopian while having Aster move into a fantasy world was original. And his series of adventures would definitely appeal to this age group.On of the issues I had, though, was the jumpiness of the story--yes, I get that he is literally jumping from place to place, but the way the plot flowed, it felt like it wasn't really heading in a direction, at least until the end. Also, there was a lot of information dumped on Aster by other characters. The whole, "Wait you don't know that? Let me explain...." got a little tiring. Lastly, there was something too adult about the voice at times. Aster is an unusual child, not allowed to experience life the way other kids do because of his illness (which, btw--don't want to give spoilers, but the way the author handled this was very cool), but too often in the book it felt like the story was being told by an adult.I would definitely read the next book in the series, because the ending picked up for me, and I would hope there would be less explaining since so much has been set up already in this one. And again, I think this would appeal to the target audience, even with the occasional stiffness in the writing. There's just so much action, and adventure through different lands, and Aster is the kind of kid you want to root for.

I grabbed this thinking my daughter (she's 12) would like the color, and she does. I'm not crazy about it, but I will say it's prettier in person than it is in the picture. On my screen, this almost looks like a cream color with the slightest hint of yellow. In person, it is a light yellow with the slightest hint of minty green. Very summery.The polish is nice and shiny, but it goes on streaky and thin. It put three coats on my toenails and there are still some spots that aren't opaque. I know that's an issue with light colors in general, which is why I'm giving this three stars instead of two. (If it were a dark color doing this, it'd get knocked down a star.)My daughter used this on her fingernails and went with four coats. She said it stayed on pretty well. But it being so thick with multiple coats, she was basically able to peel it off when she got tired of it.It's not a color I would use again--partly because of the color itself, partly because it requires so many coats. But my daughter likes it, and it will definitely get used again by her.

Love this ring. The box it comes in is lovely--actually, it's a box inside a box--a very sturdy smooth matte black cardboard with a blue lining, and the part that holds the ring is a soft black fabric-covered foam cube. Definitely makes it a great presentation if giving this as a gift. The silver is nice and bright, and the dark, recessed part really makes the polished knot work stand out. The ring is very sturdy, too. The width measures 8mm.The inside of the ring has a small lip on either side. I think there may be a benefit to this, actually, as wide bands often trap moisture under them.It also keeps the ring strong while not making it thick and heavy.Lastly, I found it to be true to size.

Love this ring. The box it comes in is lovely--actually, it's a box inside a box--a very sturdy smooth matte black cardboard with a blue lining, and the part that holds the ring is a soft black fabric-covered foam cube. Definitely makes it a great presentation if giving this as a gift. The silver is nice and bright, and the dark, recessed part really makes the polished knot work stand out. The ring is very sturdy, too. The width measures 5mm.The inside of the ring has a lip on either side, which kind of makes it feel like you're wearing two very narrow rings, but it doesn't bother me as I've noticed it does some other reviewers. I think there may be a benefit to this, actually, as wide bands often trap moisture under them.It also keeps the ring strong while not making it thick and heavy.Lastly, I found it to be true to size.Loved this so much I got another in a different style.

I really enjoyed this little collection. A quick read that was just right for an afternoon between trying to decide what novel to read next :). The writing is tight--no words wasted--but there is plenty of vivid description and character development in these short stories. All in the horror genre in one way or another, they had atmosphere and a great writing voice. Just....if you like horror, and are in the mood for something short and well-crafted, this is definitely worth your time.And I have to say: I will never look at houseflies the same way again.

Well, I barely got to try this because my 15 yr old son devoured the container. He's not vegan, but he's not much of a meat eater--just doesn't like it that much. So, this has been a good way to get protein in him without resorting to whey-based protein powders--I like that this is vegan and made of actual *food*.The taste is pretty good. I was afraid my son wouldn't like it, that it wouldn't be sweet or chocolate\y enough, but it's plenty sweet and chocolaty without being overly so or artificial tasting.My son tried mixing this in milk, but switched to water because it didn't dissolve well in milk. When I finally tried it, I used rice milk and found I had to stir it quite a bit and it still was kinda gritty. But my son said it mixes well with water.Overall, it's been a very good product. No negative effects for my son--no allergic reactions, no digestive issues. And he drinks them voluntarily. (Actually, I discovered he was drinking them twice a day.) I would definitely recommend it as a healthier alternative to a lot of the protein powders out there, especially if you want to keep to natural ingredients without sacrificing taste.

This does fit the YA category it's put in, but it really is a book that crosses over into adult readership. The story starts with Fig at six years old and carries through until she's seventeen, but the focus is so unlike most YA books. This is very much literary, very much a character-focused story, deeply emotional, and presented in such a way that would appeal to many adult readers who don't generally read YA.Fig's mother is schizophrenic, and while she has ups and downs, the trend throughout the novel is down. As Fig, who is highly intelligent and has OCD, grows up she adopts different ways of coping with watching her mother deteriorate. She cannot turn to her father, as he is so focused on her mother and the farm they own. Her grandmother is somewhat harsh with her, although many of her acts show just how much she loves Fig. Her Uncle Billy is her rock in many ways, but for a long time she doesn't see that. She has no real friends, and she feels out of place just about everywhere. The only time she feels release from the pressures of her life and at ease with herself is when she is making herself bleed.No, this is not a story about cutting--although Fig does try cutting once in the book. I want to be clear on what she does do, because if you are like me you may appreciate the warning (which I did not get from the book description or reviews and wish I had). Fig's self-mutilation comes in the form of scab-picking, and the detail at which it is described was at times too much for me. The other negative for me was the last chapter. The very ending just didn't fit quite right for me.The writing, however, is beautiful and haunting. Fig is a deep character and the author submerges you in her mind. The other characters are fully-developed as well, and the setting rich and realistic. I definitely recommend the book for the writing, but be prepared for a rather intense experience and a book that reads like a memoir--it is Fig's life, not a plot to be played out.PS--if you like to read author acknowledgments before reading/finishing the story as I sometimes do--this time don't. There are spoilers.

I'm not someone who believes there is a magic pill for weight loss (or anything else, for that matter) but I am completely open to the idea that some key nutrient or chemical component may be missing from my diet that has my metabolism wonky. Or my appetite has gone amok because I'm in need of some key nutrient. So I decided to give this a try.Let me first say: I'm not overweight. I would like to lose maybe 10 lbs--any more and I'd be officially skinny. So I was not looking to this as some kind of miracle. I already eat healthy, and I am active and exercise moderately on a regular basis.All that said....this product did nothing. No appetite difference, no weight loss. If I'd experience *something* I'd have given it three stars I suppose, despite the price ($20 for a two-week supply). However, I didn't drop it to one star because I suffered no ill effects whatsoever from taking it.

I went into reading this with two biases: 1) I adore Maggie Stiefvater's writing and art, and 2) I abhor unicorns being made into narcissistic overgrown My Little Ponies with horns (something I've found in multiple books and cartoons). I feel like those things kinda cancel each other out, making my review unbiased :).So, the book starts out with Pip at school during career day, and one of the parents breeds unicorns and bring a few with them for the students to see. Pip can understand and talk to magical animals, and while trying very hard to get to know the unicorns, she inadvertently creates an Incident that prompts her parents to spend the summer with her aunt, who is a magical creature veterinarian. During Pip's time there, a situation arises with the presence of a pesky creature and Pip must figure out how to save the day using her ability--which no one else believes she actually has.My inner nine-year-old was squeeing with delight through this whole book (with the exception of the narcissistic overgrown MLP-like unicorns) because of the creatures and the fun adventures. I loved the pages with creature illustrations and descriptions that come out of Pip's favorite book, Jeffrey Higgleston's Guide to Magical Creatures. I loved how Pip added her own notes to the book, and those notes are included in some of the illustrations. (And yes, I was happy to notice Maggie Stievater's voice in the descriptions and notes on those pages as well.)The story itself--I'll admit I found the writing in the opening chapter to be just okay (which may have, admittedly, had something to do with the focus being so much on the unicorns). Pip came to life to me right away, but found myself skimming all the description of the chaos created during the school event.That said, the writing and story picked up for me immediately with the next chapter when Pip heads off to her aunt's. The other characters are well-formed, each with their own distinct personality. I liked that Pip and Callie didn't always get along, but still worked together. I liked that while a lot was done by Pip and her new friend Tomas alone, the adults were involved with much of it, and they showed mutual respect--the adults listening to the kids, and the kids listening to the adults. Of course the creatures were pretty original, and it was fun seeing Pip getting excited about learning new things about them.The ending was a little abrupt. I would have like a bit more of a denouement after everything gets solved. Just another page or so. Either way, I can see this becoming a series, with Pip adding and adding to the Guidebook and helping to solve more critter crimes. I would definitely recommend this for elementary age kids. I know I would have loved it at that age.

OK, better. The first book I loved. The second book, not so much. I still enjoyed reading it, and still liked Rory, but the whole book just felt like a bridge between books one and two. Now that I have read the third book, I clearly see the second book was a lot of set-up for the third book. I really wish the author had found a way to combine these two books.Anyway, this book has an actual story and actual resolution (that book two did not have), and the secondary characters are back in full-force (they were kinda lost in book two). It still wasn't as good as the first book, and the ending makes it clear there will be more in the series. I will likely keep reading because I like Rory and the whole ghost thing is really cool. And Sid and Sadie have me intrigued.

Cute, and the colors pictured are true to what they look like in real life. A pretty gray and a nice cream color. They're a little bigger than I expected--I didn't read the exact measurements and expected something about as big around as one of those foam coolies for holding canned drinks. They are about 4" across and about 4" tall. The knitting is well-done, nice and tight. The yarn is a polyester, so it is smooth and I would assume it'd be somewhat stain-resistant. They stand up well. I was worried they'd be too soft and somewhat floppy, but they're stiff enough yet have a soft look. The striped one stands straighter. The solid gray one has a divider inside it, which is handy, but seems to contribute to its slight crookedness.My daughter pointed out that they would make great travel containers for make-up brushes and such because they fold up. There is a loop inside the striped one. I had no idea what it was for, but my daughter said she'd use it for her favorite make-up brush. Maybe it's to secure a larger or longer one?Overall, I think they make nice little accessories.

I discovered Rick Yancey through his Monstrumologist series, which is, imho, one of the best YA fiction series and some of the best horror writing I've ever read. When I learned he'd written another series, naturally I wanted to try it. THIS SERIES CAME FIRST. So, as expected, it's not quite up to the level of the Monstrumologist.That said, I'm very much enjoying this so far. It's the kind of book you read just for fun. Fast-paced, a lot of action, a few over-the-top characters. Exactly the kind of book that would appeal to the target audience of a book with a teen boy protagonist who saves the world over and over.The first book really ought to be read before this one. It explains how Alfred gets involved with the organization he's fighting alongside in this one, as well as the whole Arthurian legend tie-in that his history is based on. However, this book only uses elements of that, and focuses on Alfred and company fighting demons who get released into the world (I won't say why because of spoilers). I will say, this gets a little darker than the first book--I see hints of Yancey's penchant for horror writing in this one.Again, this isn't amazing literature, but it's loads of fun and Alfred Kropp is a really likable character. I'll definitely be continuing the series.

I really don't understand the great reviews on this. I gave up nearly half-way through. I honestly tried to read it--I read a lot of MG and YA books, so it's not that I didn't know what to expect. I felt the language was stilted. I didn't see all this beautiful description all the reviewers mention. All I saw was a lot of arguing, and parents who needed to be smacked up-side the head. The mom needed to grow a spine and the step-dad needed to wake up and see what a problem his daughter was. I understand there is some reconciliation in the end, but I just couldn't get that far because I found the writing boring and the pacing far too slow, without real character development. I have a daughter who fits the age range for this book, but I would not want her reading it.

I debated about giving this a full five stars. I'm not sure it's 100% there, but close enough. There were small issues, like jumps in point of view that bothered me. But the fact is, I found the story intriguing from start to finish. Sometimes dual story lines are frustrating because you enjoy one but not the other. In this case, I kept going back and forth between which I liked better. Both were dark and deeply personal. The idea of a generations-long curse borne from a family of circus performers--very cool.The story of Simon is told in first person present, while Amos's story is told in third person past tense. I thought it was really effective and worked well to separate the voices of the two. I loved the detail of the circus life in Amos's story. And the way his story was told was perfectly paired with the reveal of information in Simon's story. The characters were all fully-fleshed and believable. No one too perfect, no one so flawed you couldn't empathize. I admit I had the ending figured out, at least most of it, but that did not leave me feeling unsatisfied. It progressed naturally.Anyway, I am not sure what else to say about this book. It was one that kept me thinking about it when I wasn't reading, that I felt the itch to pick back up. The writing is very good and the pacing and placement of clues was just right.Now...for the thing that absolutely bugs me: The cover. I normally don't mention book covers--you know the old saying--but this one just bites. It's so generic. It does nothing to reflect the depth and tone of the story inside. It looks like a cover for a YA novel, which this most definitely is not. The advanced reader copy I have has a MUCH better cover that's actually representative of the story and its genre. Dear Publisher, what were you thinking? Gah. I hate this cover. It does not deserve the book inside it.

The scent is nice, and not strong. I don't see that it lasts for 12 hours, though. (Not that I care about that--I don't need to smell *like* something, I just want to be clean and not smell bad.)It lathers well, isn't drying, but isn't particularly moisturizing either.The color is really pretty. A deep, pearly burgundy. Of course, you only see that for a few seconds until you lather up. And I'm not crazy about coating myself in artificial coloring. I'd really rather it not be so loaded with dye. (I was actually worried at first that it would stain my washcloths, but it didn't.)Overall, I didn't find it any better or any worse than most body washes out there.

So I really kind of love this vacuum. Let me start out by saying this: The online price is $139.99, and as I write this review, Amazon is selling it for $99.99. So, we're not talking top of the line, high-end vacuums here. Yes, it's not built like a tank. It's not meant to be!That said, this thing has really impressive suction. Makes the big, heavy Hoover I've been pushing around seem kinda pathetic. The only problem I have with that is it totally sucks up my throw rugs. Guess I'll have to just shake those out instead of vacuuming them.It's super lightweight. As in, when it arrived on my doorstep, I though, "This can't be the vacuum...." It weighs almost nothing, unlike most tanks. But that makes it SO easy to push and carry around. It really rolls smoothly across both my carpet and hard floors.Very easy to assemble. It comes in several pieces, all of which just snap together. No screws, no bolts. Again, not tank-like. Does this mean the body of the machine is not going to last for ages? Likely. But it's the price you pay for light-weight.You have to turn a dial to switch from floor to tools, but I think that actually is one reason the suction is so great. The big Hoover I have sends all the suction the same way--through the tubing used for the tools--and the more direct route in the Eureka makes way more sense. That said, the tools aren't all that snap-off, snap-on. You have to make sure the hose clips in right and doesn't tangle with the cord when you're putting it away. The tools themselves each have a place to store, but everything is so tight together on the small body, it can be a little annoying. But they work very well.The machine is bagless, and it's very easy to snap the container on and off to dump out the dirt, although it feels like it's not entirely secure when putting it back in place, imho. Again, we're back the light-weigh vs sturdy thing. So far, despite the way it feels, the container holds tight.The one thing my Hoover has over this is the retractable cord. Oh, I love retractable cords! But retractable means you have to pull the cord out bit-by-bit, and of course it makes the machine heavier and bulkier. This one has a tab at the top of where you wind the cord--it flips down and the cord drops off easily. The cord itself is nice and long.Overall, the minor inconveniences are totally made up for by the light weight, smooth rolling, and awesome suction. I can finally use a vacuum through my whole house--which is mostly hard floors except for the master bedroom and a large area rug in the living room--and not be sweating when I'm done. And I know the dirt is picked up because the machine is so powerful. Very happy so far!

My son loves this. It fits really well, you can get to all the buttons and jacks, and it's comfortable to hold. The only drawback he could think of is that it doesn't fit well in the stand, which he only uses while chatting. A minor inconvenience, according to him, especially because he can rest assured his special-edition Legend of Zelda controller is being protected through many hours of use. He's had this for months and is still really happy with it.

This is really a gorgeous dagger for the money! Nice and solid, heavy. The detail work is good--everything is straight, well put-together, etc. Slides out of the sheath with no problem, but the sheath is not at all loose. Really happy with this!

I've been using the Avery "Ivory Business Cards" (27883, which uses the same template number) and have been happy--until I tried these. The Avery "Ivory Two-Sided Printable Clean-Edge Business Cards" proved themselves in one printing. I printed a sheet of the other along with a sheet of these, and there is such a difference.First, I must say, as I've seen mentioned before--the ivory color IS different. This product is significantly lighter. I happen to like that, but if you've been using another Avery product and need the ivory colors to match, well....That said, because the color is lighter my images showed up clearer and truer in color.The images and words were crisper on these than the other business cards. Granted, this one is smooth and the other is slightly textured.Breaking the cards apart was SO easy compared to the other. The trade-off may be that these are a little thinner. But they are by no means too thin. Edges nice and smooth, too.The paper went through my Canon inkjet printer with no problem. I haven't tried printing double-sided yet but I see no reason there would be an issue. Everything lined up as it should and the paper is the same on both sides.

I suppose for the price this is a pretty good little item. It's fairly easy to use--my 14 yr old son figured it out in minutes. There are two modes: chime and alarm. In the chime mode, you cannot disarm the device, but in the alarm mode you can set a four digit code for arming/disarming. I like the disarming feature and do not understand why that would not be available in chime mode, as the only other way to turn the thing off is to take the batteries out, or switch to alarm mode, which still requires taking the battery cover off. If this could disarm in chime mode, I'd give it another star--sometimes you want to BE where the thing is pointed and don't want to listen to incessant dinging.A fifth star might be there if it had a volume control--at least two or three different settings. That, I could see requiring the battery cover to come off, so an intruder couldn't just walk up and turn the thing down. But again, I'd guess if an intruder were going to do that, they'd likely just smash the thing anyway, eh? Which, frankly, is what I was tempted to do the first time we testing this out--it is LOUD. Good for warning, not so good for testing :P. Make sure no one is sleeping and cover your ears, folks!

Great ingredients, our dog eats it happily, and we haven't seen any digestive issues since trying this food with her. The price is a bit high, but then again, if the ingredients list can be believed, you're getting what you pay for.

Background: I'm one of those girls who doesn't wear full makeup on a  regular basis. When I do, though, I wear Maybelline or Cover Girl liquid-powder makeup as a foundation, then regular powder on top. The rest of the time, I wear neither.I've been wanting to try some different brands, so when this came through on Amazon Vine, I jumped at it. So glad I did. It's very nice over the liquid-powder makeup, but what I really like is that it's great on its own. Yeah, I have to admit, I'm at that point where I need *something* on the days I normally wear no makeup at all. This has been perfect. Not heavy, but covers well. The color looks natural.The only thing I'm not crazy about is having to open a separate compartment to get the applicator pad. And the mirror is with that as well, so putting on the powder when you don't have a large mirror would be difficult as you'd have to keep going back and forth between compartments. Still, five stars because I like the product itself so much.

This is the second Anne Stokes calendar I've owned. This one is just as gorgeous as the first one, but I have two issues: the paper is thinner, and the weeks start with Monday instead of Sunday. Still, I love the images and the overall design. Lots of attention to detail, lovely fonts, nice open spaces for each day so there is room to write things down.

I really wanted to be blown away by this book, after reading such glowing reviews. And it did have some good moments. But for the most part, it read like a series of after-school specials. While I did connect to some of the characters, they too often felt one-dimensional, each of them going through the same pattern: pages of angst, followed by an a-ha moment, and then feeling suddenly that everything is going to be just fine, all amid a world where adults are complete mental cases. The tie-together is that everyone in the book either gives someone the finger, or is on the receiving end. While I don't find that particularly clever, it is an unusual idea, and unusual intrigues me, but too often the finger incident in each chapter felt contrived. The writing is overall actually pretty good, so I'd consider giving another book by this author a try, but I would not recommend this book to any of my fellow YA fiction fans.

Patrick Rothfuss says it best in his author's foreword and afterword, so since you can read samples of this book on Amazon, read that foreword. Make sure this book is for you. It may not be. If you are held by strict rules about what a story must be, you may find this book uncomfortable or boring.But for those who are willing to stretch, you may find yourself completely enthralled.This is not a "story." It's a week in the life of Auri. I have to say, what this book did was scratch a major itch for me. Yes, I've wondered for a long time what Auri is really like. What does she do all day in the Underthing? How does her tilted little mind work? This answered those questions, and did so in a way that made me totally love her.Yes, some readers would find it boring. But this not about excitement--it's about getting to know this character, seeing what makes her tick. There's not a lot more to be said, honestly. Either you will love this or you won't.

Another great short from Jeff Chapman. This has his signature fairy tale flavor, with a side of creepiness. A dark take on the Tooth Fairy, with a likable main character--Jimmy, who is at that age when he's struggling with whether or not to believe in the Tooth Fairy when he walks into the bathroom in the middle of the night and discovers...Unexpected moments and a satisfying ending make this a one-sitting read.

Once you open the book, it will grab you, hold you down and you'll watch those pages turn and turn and turn some more until you reach the last page. You'll sit for a moment to wonder if what you read is what your read and you'll fine yourself reading it again. You're about to learn the real meaning of dysfunction ---lies, deceit, betrayal, many family secrets, incest and more. This book is inspired by actual events in one family. As you read you find yourself being drawn in and becoming a part of the story. Keep tissue by -- you just may need it. I thank Nancy Weaver for sharing this story -- it makes understanding those who have gone through abuse and worse a bit better and not look at them as though it was their fault. I gave this book 5 stars but it really deserves many more. I highly recommend this book to everyone. I look for more from Nancy Weaver because she sure hit it out of the ballpark with this one
