I'm a Master Gardener volunteer at our town greenhouse where, as luck would have it, we've a dispenser these 'Hard Roll Paper Towels', from Kimberly Clark, fit, and, that is now being put to good use. And there's, of course, no limit to the uses of these paper towels, for cleaning and drying. I keep a roll out in my shed, by the garden, and one in the garage as well. Without a dispenser, though, we cut them across a metal edge. They aren't as thick as a regular household variety of paper towels but they're of an excellent quality for their purpose and we've been using them for craft work and cleanup with the kids as well. An indispensable product of good quality, with a multitude of uses.

I've tested these 'Pure Critical Task Wipers', from Kimberly Clark, for a variety of purposes, other than their specifically intended use for W4 critical.But I have found them to be exceptionally good at everything I've used them for, without leaving lint, and without streaking, while cleaning monitor, mirror, window glass and photographic lenses of which I've more than a few.After cleaning lenses and monitors I'll use them on lesser glass as well as for normal household cleaning. Due to their quality to remain wet I've found using one for cleaning and another for drying purposes works very well. In many instances the durability of these 'Polypropylene' wipers might make them a better choice than paper products.

Putting aside that this 'Big Boys' Jacket', from Dickies Children's Apparel, is made in China, like so much else on U.S. shelves, this is a nicely put together very light jacket, almost like a lining for a heavier jacket. Hems are sewn well with no loose threads, the cuffs are tight to ward off drafts and I like the front pockets rather than having them on the side as items within, such as gloves, are more secure. Not as comfortable for hands but then there really isn't much warmth to be had as it is quite thin. It's attractive in black, though, and Dickies is a well known brand. And it is machine washable. However, I don't know how well it'll wear for active boys.

I'm an avid reader of Harry Bingham's Fiona Griffiths series, addicted even, and can't get enough. I've read each of the books, had this installment on my Kindle and finally got around to it, although out of sequence which didn't matter, at all. Fiona is totally readable, even out of order (which she normally is while committed to solving the most ingenious crimes). Once you have a feel for her you expect the unusual.Harry Bingham does it again as this is a terrific story with a cast of mostly bad guys who don't hesitate to kill in their drive for ill gotten gains. The story begins with Fiona discovering a body which leads to another that intrigues Fiona who, of course, sees that there is more to it and leads the reader deeper and deeper still into a complex criminal structure. I loved it.

Frankly, I couldn't wait for my first glass of wine using the 'Coravin Model Two' and I'm truly impressed with the ease of using this Wine System. The included directions are easy enough to understand. However, if unsure of how it works and how to go about doing it there is an excellent video available on "youtube" (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kphRqanm74I). The simplicity of it surprises me it hadn't been thought of much earlier. I've enjoyed but a couple glasses using this system and I've put the bottle away for a bit as I enjoy different wines for different purposes. And that's the main reason for the Coravin; wine will last and last because the argon gas replaces what air would've filled the empty space in the wine bottle: air in the bottle will cause wine to deteriorate.There are caveats, though: the system won't work with artificial corks, or bottles without corks, and there is a reportedly remote possibility of bottle breakage for which a bottle covering sleeve is included for that possibility.And I, like many before me, wonder why Coravin employs a proprietary connection for gas the cartridge which is considerably more expensive to replace than readily available replacement cartridges. I hope Coravin corrects that, if for no other reason than for PR purposes. The system comes with the Coravin Model, two cartridges, a sleeve and needle clearer/cleaner.

I'm guilty of following the 'probiotics' health fad, having thought it 'might' be a good idea. Voila! I'm assuming aren't a necessity, for me, as I've noticed no beneficial and, equally, experienced no ill effects from using Viva Labs Advanced Probiotics.

Not at all happy with this '14 Piece SS Cutlery Set', from Sabatier. Out of the set the steak knives alone felt good to hold and cut with. The other knives feel cheap and weighted wrong: too light in the hollow handle, too heavy at the bolster. And the advertised product page image for this product shows a completely different set, with triple riveted handles and an attractive wooden block (unlike the simple black block received). I would return them as it seems I got baited and switched to an inferior set of knives as an internet search shows almost identical sets, from Sabatier, for considerably less than this.

It isn't easy to describe, in words, the quality of sound from these "B6's, from ELAC". The reproductive sounds from these speakers really do have to be experienced; they are so very good.  I've connected them to my "HEOS wireless pre-amp" from Denon, and although my music preferences are somewhat eclectic (blues, country, rock, classical) the sound from these speakers, across the frequency spectrum and at varied volume, is stunning.

This R240HY Full HD monitor from Acer is excellent. I'm using it in a dual monitor system for photography and find the colors stunning with crisp detail and no noticeable screen glare. In fact the screen is perfect, with no obvious light bleeding or dead pixels and the controls for adjustments are accessible at the bottom right of it's minimal frame, and they're easily understood.Set up was easy but the monitor came with a VGA cable and my Acer Predator PC needed DVI instead; Luckily, I had one on hand and as soon as connected the monitor was up and running. This model has no speakers and can't be wall or stand mounted, either. Nor can the screen be rotated.For my purposes, though, and at this price, it'd be near impossible to find another monitor it's equal.

I was a bit taken aback upon opening the package containing this 'Swiss Legend' watch as the photo in the ad suggests what I'd consider an average size watch. However this watch is enormous, in size, and somewhat heavy as well.Swiss Legend, along with Lucien Picard, Invicta, etc. are of the 'deep discount' type watches and not Swiss made, as the name implies. They've a so so reputation and probably put together in China. Not a bad choice for those who find the style, and price, appealing. But internet reviews suggest problems if any difficulties arise with the watch. Unfortunately it's much too big for my wrist.

We have the family over all the time and the grand kids think this 'Madd Gear Mini Drift Trike' is awesome. Those riding it are between 5 and 10 and it apparently does not have much of a learning curve as they caught on right away. Well, it took the 5 year old a couple rides but, he too, has it down pat, now.Putting this trike, from Madd Gear USA, together, took less than an hour and without any tools other than those provided. It's really well built, and sturdy. The directions with pictorials are easily understood and all parts came bagged. There's also a full page of safety instructions suggesting wearing helmets, elbow pads, etc. Just what the kids wear when bike riding. It's definitely a lot of fun.

I am most definitely a fan of Harry Bingham and his Fiona Griffiths crime dramas. I've just now finished the 4th installment, and, "This Thing of Darkness" is so very good a read that I, sometimes, find myself thinking Fiona just can't be a fictional character: Mr. Bingham has made her so seemingly alive.I don't think this the best story of the lot; perhaps there is too much happening and so much to tie together. But Fiona, with all her personal psychological difficulties and quirks makes it all so wonderful to read about.The author's finesse in weaving the intricacy that is Fiona; her problems, history and how she does or, often, doesn't cope, the crimes she solves, and, dare I say, commits. Along with the fiends, enemies and really bad people; all together they form  such readable narrative keeps me yearning for more.

Of course this 'Compact 2-in-1 Soup Bowl, from Joseph Joseph, could be a bit bigger or a bit smaller, but, for all practical purposes, you really can't get a better quality and more useful implement than this. As the name implies it's actually 2 containers in one so you can keep a liquid separate from a solid, i.e. soup and crackers. It provides a good seal that does not leak and, for me, it's utility is excellent: holding enough for a quick lunch or a healthy snack. It's BPA free and microwave safe (no need to have the collar on when heating) and provides a smaller package for the return trip home. I truly do like it a lot.

I'm a beekeeper and use 5gal. food grade plastic containers to store, and for bottling, honey as the warmth obtained from a wrap keeps the container contents in a condition that promotes flow.I've compared this "Powerblanket" on a 5 gal. container alongside another with a string wrap and I'm very pleased with the results of the 'Powerblanket' as it will keep the container contents warm and I like that once placed on the container it won't slip or move. A device to enable temperature adjustment would be nice as would a longer power cord. However, as is, it does suit my needs.

Update: 10/29, 2nd. photo. 3 seed pods have sprouted, basil & dill. The dill is taller and is leaning toward the center of the light where red & blue lights are brightest.I've only just now completed putting together the "AeroGarden", from AeroGrow, and it's an attractive setup. The included photo shows the result of that. I've added water with nutrient and installed the different seed pods with plastic covers. And it was quite easy as there are very good directions along with pictorial diagrams. The lights are on 16 to 18 hours daily, dependent on which option you choose, determined by the type of plants you have growing. At what time the lights come on is also an operator option and it's common to schedule them for your awake hours.The LED lights, about 96 in all, are very bright. There seem to be 9 blue and 24 red, the rest being white, and I can't say why there are so many white LED's as, to my understanding, white (or full spectrum) light isn't necessary for plant growth and just contributes to energy waste, and cost, as plants primarily absorb light from the blue and red regions of the light spectrum. If you've never grown plants, though, from seed, this arrangement will probably prove to be interesting.

This "Battery" for my Phantom2 appears to be an exact replacement for the original. Included literature indicated before using this an upgrade should be downloaded. Which I did and charging was quick and without incident. And the battery performs perfectly. Very happy with this transaction.

This Yeminite Spice Mix will enhance any soup. Recently, In my regular recipe for chicken soup, I added just a bit of this mix and it provided that extra something that transforms good to great. It is now a part of the recipe. However, be careful as just a little will go a long way. Can't wait taste the result when added to my stew.

The ubiquitous watch, ever popular for it's ability to keep the wearer on time, is a necessity. However, it's also important for design as well; it's fashionable and, often, makes a statement..This Invicta Men's rugged appearance can't belie it's style, it's inexpensive and looks good while on one's wrist. I've found this particular watch almost, but not quite, too heavy and, also, almost, but not quite, too big; it's just about right for my 5'9" 160lb frame, has all the function you might want and it tells the time, as well.It comes packaged attractively if destined for a gift, and, especially for the price, it's fun to wear.

This is a great case, from GoPro. It's exterior is semi-rigid which appeals to me as it'll give when packed alongside other items. The outside dimensions are 8.5" x 6", inside is slightly less, and the interior depth is about is 3" total, 2" on bottom 1" on top.The interior separators are 'velcro' adjustable, as are my other camera cases, and although it's overall size won't accommodate a dslr with lens this case isn't meant for that, anyway. The case, though, is spacious as my included photos are meant to show. The case itself doesn't provide much padding but the 'velcro' separators do. And what's really nice is the upper 3rd of the case which is mostly netted, and intended for smaller items, contains a zippered, removable pouch; within that is a zippered non-removable smaller pouch. I've a cut to size foam I place between top and bottom for further protection.

I purchased these locally and have had them for a couple months. The LED's produce a bright light and I'll, mostly, use it at the 2nd level.  Like others I've experienced a problem, recently, where the light would go out almost immediately after I turned it on, at either setting. I removed the back to see if there might be anything obvious, there wasn't. Put the back on again and the light works just as it should. Removing the back has a temporary 'reset' effect; temporary because the problem persists, and worsens.

This rating isn't a result of a Sony defect but with other issues. I'm unsure if the difficulties I encountered with the installation of this "Sony STRN1060" AV Receiver was compounded by a recent upgrade to Windows 10, an incompatibility issue with my recently purchased Acer Predator PC, or my not having the correct devices.I did the internet download but have had continuing problems with an intermittent Bluetooth connection to my PC and my iPhone 5s. And came to an understanding, too, that I had to hard wire my speakers which is something I wanted to avoid. But frustration was compounded by not having an operators manual and having to download the PDF. Just one problem after another that I'd prefer not having to deal with.

This watch came within a really lovely box, perhaps a holdover from when Lucien Piccard was a respected name in watches. However, the huge discounts on today's watch with that name suggests it is of a different quality. Nowhere on the packaging, or on the watch itself, is there an indication of where it's made, although Japan is prominently displayed regarding the quartz that is used, I'm wondering if the watch doesn't come from China.With the aforementioned in mind and as my work has me out in the wild, often on water, I do have a need for the utility of inexpensive watches such as Timex, which I love for it's service and price, and Seiko. And if really nice looking they can complement one's attire.

This 'Collapsible Water Bottle' made of silicone can replace just about all of the popular water containers, whether plastic or metal. It'll hold up to some abuse, won't crack upon impact as plastic may, is dishwasher safe, will fit nicely in cup holder and some bike cages, doesn't leak and, if you're serious about not contributing to waste, it's being collapsible makes it very easy to carry out instead of discarding it as you would plastic. I'm often out and about with camera and such in a backpack or messenger bag and this bottle takes up little room which makes it, for me, very convenient; couldn't imagine hanging it from the carabiner, though.However, it's flexibility takes a bit getting used to, when drinking, and, I've found it does, at least for a while, impart a distinct taste to the water; rinsing and repeated use diminishes that, though.

This American Standard Diverter is exactly as ordered. Very close in appearance to the original part it was intended to replace. And the American Standard Diverter I eventually used, a duplicate of this but not the 'slip on' type actually works better than the original (almost no drip when using the shower). Installation was all of 5-10 minutes, and I couldn't be happier.

I enjoy cooking, and sharing the results with family and friends. And although I've only had this 'Stanley Vacuum Crock" for a short while I've found it's just as advertised. For me, this "food jar" is unsurpassed for transporting soups or sauces, just about anything, without worry of spillage. And it'll keep food hot, or cold, for a reasonable length of time, too.This is really solidly built without being heavy and it's a very nice size, as well, able to contain more than 3 quarts (12 cups). Certainly big enough for any of my needs. The lid, when closed, creates a good seal to the body and has 4 latches so you know it's secure. There's also a hook conveniently placed at the bottom of the lid for keeping near while serving. And I've not experienced any difficulty closing or opening the lid, either. It truly does "work great".

I'm unhappy with this very short, only 169 pages, third book in the quartet of 'The Giver', by Lois Lowry. It's much smaller in size than the others, and is so out of place. Where the other installments promise spiritual uplifting this "Messenger" book teases sameness but not only doesn't deliver on the premise but diminishes it, considerably.The short story, small book, substantial differences between what had been the unassertive preternatural is now in-your-face magic, suggesting a change in what the original story was leading to. Has the author lost direction? I would skip this installment.

After a minor adjustment of the invisible safety light and having put it all together I plugged it in and  was totally amazed that everything worked, perfectly. Not to suggest I didn't encounter any difficulties, which I did, minor ones, though. And not due to this garage door opener, from Chamberlain. It was an entirely new installation for me and I had a bit of electrical work to do: My garage light was exactly where the opener was to be placed and, needing extra lighting for the back of the garage, I moved the light and mounted an outlet close to the opener.I installed it without help and can't imagine it being any easier to do. I have, however, a technical background. But I'm not one to get along solely with written instructions, either, so I relied a lot on the 'youtube' video which really is very informative.The door flow adjustment, from open to closed was intuitive and WiFi set-up went without a hitch, too. I've no complaint with the battery back-up, glad there is one, though, and it's nice that the wall mounted control includes a clock, thermometer, light adjustments and movement sensor options. But more than anything I'm truly impressed with the quiet of this belt drive, as is everyone I show it to.

This "Lightning to USB Charging Cable", from Belkin, is MFi Certified and I've been using it to charge my iPhone 5s. Haven't noticed any irregularities and there isn't anything I don't like about it.The cable is supple, an appreciable 4ft length, and I especially like the '90 degree' aspect as it lays rather flat when attached to the phone and represents much less of an encumbrance.

Update: 9/21/15....Again, about a dozen pulls to start. One of the breakers tripped and upon investigation I found the fixture I plugged in had a wiring problem. The generator started right up after resetting. 5 stars for certain.Update: 9/12/15.....Took 12 pulls to start & functioned perfectly for the 3 hours I needed it for lights in the shed and work equipment.We've a recently purchased i2000 Honda and aside from the camouflage exterior this PowerStroke inverter/generator, from Baja Outdoor Products, is remarkably similar in size, weight, noise level and start-up, with an additional 100 watt advertised capability.Included directions are well written and understandable. And after familiarizing myself with the machine, and it's parts placements, setting it up for 1st. time use was very easy: adding the provided 4 stroke engine oil with the also provided container and flexible hose was a no brainer. Gas input on the top is also easy to use. 2nd. pull and it's running nicely, push in the choke and this generator is running smooth. Had it running for a couple hours checking it's ability to run small tools, i.e. sawsall, and then the freezer. Generator speed increases and then recoups, running smoothly after freezer compressor kicks in; idles easy, too. LED's provide info and there's a reset. Stability isn't a problem when a level setting is provided.Directions indicate there's a dip stick, for checking oil level, but on this unit it's just the plug. However, I'm 'very' impressed with it's operation but can't attest, yet, to this generator's longevity.

I have used this 'Pick-up Tool', from Unger, for picking up refuse at days end, at summer camp, and similar tasks.However, and most importantly, I've used it while floating downstream in my kayak during our club's river clean-ups. This pick-up tool extends your reach by a few feet and is solidly built as it's helped retrieve bottles and cans, filled with river bed muck, and other sundry things without the least bit of difficulty. And it has great longevity, too as I've owned it for some years now.

Purchased locally, for less. The GC1W0000 Large Deluxe Plastic Mailbox, from Rubbermaid, Is up and looking nice.The item I received did not come with instructions but it was obvious, given a moment, that all the pieces just fit together, period.And once I understood the doors had to be added last the installation was complete. Placed atop a separately purchased 4x4post (about 6ft is required) and voila.

A connoisseur of wine, I'm not, however, I do enjoy the drink with dinner, and social gatherings. And almost anything that might contribute to it's taste is appreciated.I find these Stemless Aerating Wine Glasses, from Global Amici, to be of a nice size and not having stems makes it so much easier, albeit less graceful, to decant, or aerate, the wine adding to it's flavor. And I find It interesting some reviewers have described these glasses as heavy when, in fact, I find them a bit light in weight. So I'll suggest they may be of a reasonable weight and somewhat easier to swirl the wine in without making a mess of the practice. And considering the science behind the optic ridges cut into the glass and resultant increased enhancement attained with such little effort I rather like these glasses.

Update 8/26/15: Constant operation most nights since purchase and working perfectly.Purchased new locally, at a big box store, at a better price than offered here, and I'm happy with it's operation the few days I've had it in use. But, of course, I had to tote it home.However, that's not the whole story. This is the 2nd LG Electronics Portable Air Conditioning unit I've purchased from the same store. My initial purchase ended abruptly as the unit didn't produce any cold air. But upon unpacking this 2nd unit I noticed it was packaged better and suspect the 1st unit had been a repackaged defect. No telling who's at fault there, either the store or the 1st purchaser.Regardless, this 8000 BTU unit is working just fine cooling my 169 cu. ft. bedroom. It's attractive, of a small enough size, and unlike other air conditioners this unit comes with a long enough exhaust tube so there's no need to elevate it. I had no difficulty installing it and I've been happy with other LG appliances in the past, too. If I've cause I won't hesitate to revise this review, though.

Purchased locally this "Lifetime Extra Large Deck Box", saved me a bit with my veteran's discount. It was easily transported in the back of the Subaru, with seats folded, and although the box is a little bulky I had no problem situating it.Putting it together, without help, wasn't difficult either, using 4 small wrenches. I found the directions to be explicit and all small parts (screws, nuts & bolts) were secured within a blister pack. The box itself is made of a tough plastic with pneumatic assisted metal hinges that ensures easy and safe closing, and it's lockable, too. It's interior size fits my needs and it will keep contents dry from inclement weather, but not from flooding. It looks really nice at the side of the patio, too. My family, with children, have had this same box for some years now and it's performed perfectly, so I know longevity won't be an issue.

I found this "Swing-Arm Task" Lamp from V-Light very easy to assemble; there were limited parts: bulb, shade, clamp & housing. It came delivered in nondescript packaging that included easily understood directions for assembly, operation, and warnings regarding the bulb: it gets hot and it should be replaced with an equivalent bulb. And there's a guarantee also, along with toll free information in the event one experiences any difficulties.Obviously, not a high end lamp. However, it does suit a purpose and has utility. It's only drawback is the clamp which is used to install it to a work area. And that has a limited opening of about a 1.5 inches. It fit well attached to a work bench as seen in the included photo. And, for those interested, it is made in China.

9/12/15 Update: It's now my go to wrench set.7/21/15 Update: Have been using this for a variety of projects and find them very useful.Ratcheting wrenches are great at saving time as the grip on nut/bolt remains firm while using, and in the week I've had this "GearWrench 7-Piece Ratcheting" set I've  had a few chores where I've used both ratcheting and normal ends of the 5/16" wrench on my car, while changing the battery, the 1/2" wrench on the wheels of my dirt bike and the 5/8" wrench to tighten nuts on my Karavan trailer.Nothing I did was what I'd consider heavy duty. However, these ratcheting wrenches were able to break the lock down of bolts on the bike and tighten nuts and bolts securely without any misadventure. I've found they function just fine. But you might consider shopping around as I've seen them for less, elsewhere.

Update 9/12/15: Nope, no interest here, at all.My 6 year old granddaughter is an avid reader and I'll occasionally read with her. She will read to her younger brother, too, and there are some books they will read over and over. However, with "Upside-Down Magic" she just didn't show any interest. It may have been the topic, or that the text was beyond her range, or perhaps the timing as the school year has just completed and there's so much excitement planned. In any event we'll pick the book up at a later date and see what happens then.

Torn between giving this 3 or 4 stars as "Lightless", by C.A. Higgins is a good story. It's just that it took almost two thirds through before it really became interesting. Before that it seemed to promise it would get better. Why I stayed with it.Not so much science fiction as it is a mystery and a psychological thriller. The build-up is relentless, but unnecessarily verbose, about worlds run by a 'system' being fought by rebels. The entire story takes place within a single and special space ship, there are only a few people within the ship, and there is the ship itself. All characters are developed nicely, but somewhat sketchily, at first. However, over time, the plot develops and not until the last third of the book is everything revealed, almost grudgingly.I liked the story, with it's twists, turns and plots within plots, but, did I mention it was a bit long in the telling.

I've had some difficulty with 'Belkin' products in the past. However, a cable either works or it doesn't (not rocket science) and this  Lightning to USB, 4 ft and also the 6 inch Cable work just fine. I'm using it to charge my iphone 5s; Connected, and it's immediately recognized and charges just like any of my other cables. But I especially like the different lengths of this cable as it is so convenient for the car as it fits perfectly without extra length draped in the way and by the PC where extra length is a necessity.

As I get older my vision requires an aid for reading, and I read quite a bit. With the +2.0 glasses from 'Gamma Ray Readers' I'd gotten a bit of eye strain and opted for the +2.5, The +2.5, from the same company doesn't seem to provide considerably increased magnification, over the +2.0, but it's done the trick for me.These are metal rimmed glasses and stiff to open, without spring hinges, and didn't come with a cleaning cloth. Considering the price, though, they're a decent purchase.

I purchased the 'Skechers Men's Go Walk 3 Mesh Slip-on Shoe' locally at an outlet shoe store where I've had some luck finding shoes that actually fit my not terribly odd size 8.5 wide. And after trying the shoes on, standing, walking around, I was stunned by how comfortable they feel. And their light weight as well; the lightest shoes I've ever worn.Two days later I returned to the store to purchase a 2nd. pair 'cause they're better than slippers, in the house, too. It's been a while since I've been as pleased as I am, now, with these Skechers.

I can't claim this "Honda EU2000i" generator is the best as I haven't tried all of the rest. However, I am absolutely thrilled with it's quiet and 'easy' operation. And, I was able to purchase it locally for less, even after N.Y. taxes. More so, though, I received first hand instruction about operation, and oil & gas was included. Almost a necessity due to occasional power outages this portable generator, by Honda, is insurance and useful in so many ways.

I was excited about trying this 'ilumi Color Tunable LED' and downloaded the app without difficulty. The ilumi paired up easily & quickly with my iPhone and I was very much impressed with the LED colors and when synced with music, too.However, after shutting it down and attempting to duplicate the initial operation, the colors wouldn't work. Although the main 'white' light works  I couldn't get anything else. I deleted the original download and downloaded the app again: nothing, no reward. I was unable to duplicate the initial success.I'm assuming (hoping) it's the app that's the problem as I'd really like the 'ilumi' to work. Also, operating the 'ilumi' isn't intuitive; it's complicated and needs simple directions.

Not the first 'Blue Tooth' speaker I've used but, without question, the largest "Ultra-Portable" and the best performing one, as well.This TS006BA is from TSST and after removing from the box I plugged it into my PC, with the included USB cord, to ensure it was charged sufficiently. And it paired immediately, without issue, with my iPhone 5s. It's ultra intuitive (an on/off switch with L.E.D's. does it all).Sound is very good, considering size, and volume is adjustable from the audio source. I'm quite happy with this speaker in all respects.

Just what I wanted, a basic grill that uses charcoal rather than propane. It's much safer, fuel is readily available practically anywhere, no disconnecting, exchanging, reconnecting tanks, either. It required a minimum of effort to put together and once you understand how to adjust vents the grilling results are excellent. Basic is best, imho. And did I neglect to indicate that the price ain't bad either, especially if you shop around.

I enjoyed reading 'Blood for the Sun', by Errick Nunnally. It's definitely not run of the mill. Instead the story is novel, creating it's own lore and the author keeps the action moving by providing a rich assemblage of good and bad characters, mixed together with a bit of confusion.Those who inhabit this story of mystery and mayhem are well developed and interesting, especially Alexander, the protagonist, who is suffering an intermittent form of Alzheimer's. And the story progresses evenly, in an easily understandable and linear progression, building toward the climax.I've taken a star off aa the ending didn't quite do it for me. But then, that's me and, all things considered, I did enjoy reading this story.

My soon to be 7 year old granddaughter thinks this 'Twister Moves Hoop' is great. She was truly excited about using the counter which happens to work nicely, and she has no difficulty using the hoop.It took perhaps a minute to put it together as each section snaps easily into the next. And you can mix the two colors the sections come in. Forget about dismantling it, though, as the sections fit rather tight. I can't imagine why most kids wouldn't be thrilled with it.
The same bad story retold from a different POV. Blatant money grab. Do yourself a favor and skip this.

Aside from terrific acting and visuals, the main thing that makes Jurassic World superior to both of the previous Jurassic Park sequels is indisputably its ability to stand on its own two feet, while also hearkening back to the theme of man vs nature started in the original film.The original 1993 Jurassic Park was, in many ways, a futuristic retelling of the Mary Shelley's classic novel, Frankenstein. In both Spielberg's film and Shelley's novel, we see the march of human progress for good or ill, and the inevitable contest between science/man and nature/god, in which (spoiler alert) man loses. In both stories we see human's attempt to harness primal forces that they cannot hope to control, and in the end wind up paying the price.Picking up years after the events of Jurassic Park, Jurassic World in a sense tells the same story. Not in the overly-derivative way that the previous sequels did, with talking dream-raptors and cheesy Godzilla parodies, but with a fresh story that continues with the next logical step of the original theme, that is, human beings playing god. Only now, instead of bringing dinosaurs back into a world that isn't ready for them, they've used genetic modification to take it to the next level, creating super dinosaurs, but without taking the responsible precautions necessary to ensure safety.The film isn't perfect (I think the subplot about weaponizing dinosaurs has been cliche since Alien 2), as I believe the original Jurassic Park to have been, but all in all it's much more grounded and clever, as well as honest to Spielberg's original vision, than its two predecessors. The film is able to bring the original into the background via the musical score and some callbacks to the first set, without allowing itself to be overshadowed. For example, the scene in the control room with the old Jurassic Park shirt and the subsequent conversation was an excellent callback to the stunning use of practical effects in the first movie, without coming off as apologetic for the use of CGI in the new movie.All in all I think Jurassic World is an excellent way of (hopefully) closing the circle that started more than two decades ago now. The final shot of the film, the T-Rex roaring over the island while the classic song plays, is an excellent shot to end the park's fated saga on.
Bought this for my dad for Christmas and he loved it. great variety of different types of jerky and a bargain.

The thing that you have to understand about the Babadook to really understand the movie, is that the monster and many aspects of the story are mostly metaphorical. This is not your typical horror movie. What the Babadook represents is a psychological concept called the shadow self, or "shadow aspect."The shadow self is the darker parts of our personalities that many of us like to pretend doesn't exist. In the case of this movie it manifests in a mother's desire to kill her problem child. Ignoring the shadow self doesn't make it go away, as repeatedly said in the movie, "you can't get rid of the Babadook." The only way to deal with the shadow self is to face it, and acknowledge it's there, hence the end of the movie.This movie is terrifying in both its exploration of the darker aspects of the human psyche, and with how terrible it can be to lose a loved one and be stuck raising a difficult child.

The color scheme and design of this piece of beautiful, but it's not as it appears in the picture. This image shows only the front of the heart, where as the back is basically an open hole. Imagine of a whole, hollow heart was cut in half.

Great decal, has thus far stayed on through winter and several car washes. Only problem is that I ordered two and they came attached to the same sheet, so I had to cut them apart, which was tricky to do without screwing up the decal.

2001: A Space Odyssey is not only a landmark pillar of science fiction, but far and away the greatest film made by the late, great Stanley Kubrik, an artist of unimpeachable integrity. The closest thing I've ever seen to visual poetry.

By far the greatest performance by the late, great John Candy. Uncle Buck is a movie that transcends any one generation, I enjoy it just as much today as I did when I saw it as a child. Uncle Buck is a roller coaster ride of laughs, feels, and life lessons.

The Guardfather Spike is a pretty cool gadget, and in a pinch I suppose it could be used as a defensive tool, but there are a few things you should be aware of.First, this is a fun gimmick, but not something I'd stake my life on. If you feel the need to carry a defensive tool other than a firearm, I'd stick with a knife, pepper spray, or taser. That being said, if you are a collector, like myself, or want a cool ice pick to show off at parties, you could do worse.Second, and more important, the trigger mechanism is a little sensitive. It once deployed inside a drawer that I shut too hard. Since the spike deploys extremely hard and fast, it could be dangerous if you're carrying it in a pocket, especially a shirt pocket facing your throat . . . you know, where most people carry pens.All in all, I'm quite satisfied with my purchase. It's a very reasonable price for a very unique and fun item.

Nice keychain. It's flat and compact so it doesn't bulge in your pocket, and the coloring doesn't rub off like with some soft rubbers. Only issue is the sword. Mine started to tear after a few months in my pocket and then fell off.
The Nightmare is an excellent story by a talented and promising young author.

The book pictured here is not the first edition of George RR Martin's A Game of Thrones. The US first edition has a picture of the Iron Throne, and the UK version, which precedes the US by three weeks, has a picture of a knight in silver armor astride a horse in front of King's Landing.

Now a lot of people have made some pretty harsh criticisms about the originality (or lack thereof) in Christopher Paolini's Inheritance Cycle. In this review I would like to refute some of these unfounded and unfair accusations. The main one of course being, that the series is a rip off of Star Wars.The series is about an order of ancient warriors called Dragon Riders who hold allegiance to no nation and use their martial, magical, and telepathic powers in the service of peace and justice. Now at first you may think they sound like Jedi, but they're not. You see Jedi use lightsabers, where as dragon riders just sue multi-colored indestructible swords. Totally different.About a hundred years before the start of the series an evil sorcerer named Galbatorix, not Palpatine, destroyed the riders, and established an evil empire. He did this with the help of a group of evil dragon riders called the Forsworn, the first of which was named Darth Morzan.The first book opens from the perspective of a young, sandy haired farm boy named Eragon. He is absolutely not Luke Skywalker, even though he was raised by his aunt and uncle, who are murdered by servants of the Empire shortly after he finds a mysterious object that belongs to the Empire, prompting him to flea home on a quest for vengeance.Accompanying him on this quest is Bromi-Wan Kenobi, the grouchy yet wise olf former dragon rider who gives Eragon his father's sword and teaches him just enough of the ways of the forc- I mean the ways of magic to get by, before he gets killed in the second act.After Bromi-Wan's death Eragon and his friends travel into the heart of Empire and rescue a princess named Arya, NOT Leia, that Eragon was having visions of (see, it's a VISION, not a hologram). With the princes Arya in tow, our heroes head south, to join an ALLIANCE of REBELS, called the Varden and combat the Empire's evil forces.This bring us to the second installment, where things start to get really unique and original. After an initial battle where Eragon and his companions manage to thwart the Empire, our hero travels to the homeland of the elves to meet his second teacher, who is not Yoda. UnYoda turns out to be yet another surviving dragon rider, who teaches Eragon deeper secrets of magic and telepathy, turning him into a force to be reckoned with. Unfortunately Eragon has to leave because he finds out his friends are in trouble, but before he does he promises to return to complete his training. Eventually he does return just long enough for UnYoda to reveal a secret about his family, and then die shortly later.At the climax of the book we find out something truly shocking. The Empire has managed to hatch a second dragon, a RED one, and the rider, reveals himself to be Eragon's brother, which means that Darth Morzan was his father! You see it's really nothing like the end of The Empire Strikes Back at all...Well things don't look too good for the Varden, but eventually Eragon manages to fight his way to the Emperor himself and challenge him. Unfortunately Eragon is totally outclassed by his more powerful opponent, but just when things look their worst, Darth Murtagh turns against the Emperor and saves him.Now in all seriousness, while Christopher Paolini managed to write a decent story, he did rip off many of his central plot points and characters from Star Wars, Wheel of Time, Lord of the Rings, and many others. That being said, if you can look past this, the story itself isn't that bad. My biggest problem with it is the utter lack of originality, and not just with the blatant plagiarism. The story adheres to almost every cliche and fantasy trope in the book. For young reader's it's okay, for more serious readers who want actual intellectual stimulation, I would suggest Wheel of Time, A Song of Ice and Fire, Malazan Book of the Fallen, The First Law Trilogy, etc.

I just love the feel of this knife. It has some great weight to it, and looks like something out of a fantasy epic. The functionality is cpmplete crap of course, but what do you expect from a nine dollar knife made in Pakistan? If you want a genuine boot knife buy the Smith & Wesson version. Buy this if you want a fun little prop to screw around with.

This was one of those movies that made vampires awesome, before Twilight came along and ruined them. Anybody whose here knows that Interview with the Vampire is a great movie, the Blu Ray release of which is long overdue. It's one of those movies, along with Flight Club and Inglorious Basterds, that reminds you Brad Pitt is actually a damn good actor. We also get a particularly memorable performance from Tom Cruise before he reached that point in his career when he started phoning it in.Not much to say about this particular version until it's released, but the audio and video quality on my current BR edition is excellent. The special features we know of thus far include:- Lestat, Louis, and the Vampire Phenomenon: A conversation with author Anne Rice about her influence on the new wave of vampires as heroes and anti-heroes.- Director's Commentary with Neil Jordan- In the Shadow of the Vampire- Introduction by Anne Rice, Neil Jordan and Antonio Banderas- Theatrical TrailerI expect there will be more goodies with the official release, and I'll be updating my review when more information becomes available.

I love Hellsing, and if you've stuck with it until this release, then that means you probably love it too. It's been one hell of a wait, especially for dub fans who went years without updates after the US branch of Geneon went under, but finally the end is here. Part of me is excited for teh final US release, although another part of me is also saddened. Hellsing was such an excellent anime, and it's one of those rare cases where the english cast works every bit as hard as the original, led by the peerless Crispin Freeman. Everything though, both vice casts, the music, the animation, the writing, is flawless. Here's to you Hellsing, it's been one hell of a ride.

When True Blood began it was a compelling show with morally ambiguous characters and a plot that wasn't afraid to take risks. Each season seemed to get better and better, with deeper and more complex villains and stories.Sadly, that show is no longer around. The writers no longer seem to know what they want to with either the characters, or the general plot. Whenever they decide they want to force a new "twist" down our throat, they either kill of a random side character, or throw two random people together in an extremely forced romance, only to have them separate again by the beginning of the next season.Plus the show is generally trying too hard the past few seasons to be Buffy the Vampire Slayer. When I heard that they were planning on bringing the series back to its roots for the final season, I was at first hopeful, but quickly found myself disappointed. The interpersonal relationships have gone from artificial, to laughably absurd. Andy and Jessica have a buddy cop type adventure and all the sudden bygones are bygones, Sookeh and Beel are back, Jason and Jessica are bouncing off each other again, etc etc. I won't even get into the stupid ghost Tara story. And the big villain of the final season? Sarah Newlin and the Yakuza. Yes really.Thus far the final season of True Blood has been one disappointment after another, and I doubt that the last two episodes are going to save it. The three stars I gave it are for the three brilliant seasons that the show started with, everything after that you can either skip, or go on Netflix and watch the better version. It's called Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

What a fantastic season of Game of Thrones this was! So much happened. Every season has one really big episode that everything builds up to, but this one had several. The acting was top notch, maybe the best since the show started. At first I didn't think Game of Thrones would have a chance at this year's Emmys since they're competing against last year's Breaking Bad finale, but then I saw Tyrion's trial. WOW, the emotion, the betrayal, the hurt, is all palpable. The Mountain vs the Red Viper fight was amazing, and the ending just as shocking as it was in the book. Arya and the Hound absolutely stole the show this season by the way. If they made a separate show just about them wandering the countryside murdering people, I would watch that show. The battle for the Wall was every bit as epic as the Blackwater, and let's not forget Daenerys and her ever more difficult to control dragons.I also want to give a nod to Jack Gleeson. We all hated Joffery, which is kind of the point. The kid is a terrific actor to bring such a rotten little monster to life and make us all revile him so much. It was great to see the little turd get what he had coming, but in a way I think I'm actually going to miss him. He certainly brought something to the show in the form of a memorable villain.I simply cannot say enough good things about this season of Game of Thrones.Not much to say so far about the box set itself, but I LOVE the cover art). There are at least two deleted scenes thus far that we know of, and more of the typical extras. An interview with the man himself, George RR Martin, a look back at the effects that the Red Wedding had on the war in season 3, commentaries of course, a thirty minute documentary about the battle for the Wall, a look at some of the cast members and their character's deaths, and more history and lore from the books that the show skips over.I'll update this review with more information when it's released, and of course when I have the box set in hand.
